name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the debate on the question with request for an oral reply to the Commission on the status of insularity, on behalf of the Committee on Regional Development (O-000013/2016 - B8-0106/2016) (2015/3014(RSP)).

name: Iskra MIHAYLOVA
text: Author. – Dear Mr President, Honourable Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, colleagues, the island regions of the European Union have common and specific permanent characteristics and features that clearly distinguish them from continental territories. Article 174 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the EUROPEAN Union explicitly recognises that island regions as a whole are characterised by permanently unfavourable conditions. As outlined in the Sixth Report on Economic, Social and Territorial Cohesion, the impact of the crisis has seriously affected the development opportunities of many disadvantaged regions, including island regions.  The islands in the European Union are also peripheral regions located at the external borders of the Union. This makes them particularly vulnerable to the challenges that Europe currently faces, such as globalisation, demographic trends, climate change, energy supply, and in particular in southern regions, exposure to increasing migratory flows.  The connectivity of island regions with the continent is a major factor in the development of their full potential. Therefore, particular emphasis should be placed on transport links, intermodal transport and sustainable mobility, as well as on the development of digital capacity, which is vital to compensate for connectivity disadvantages.  Due to these and other factors, the EU should adopt specific measures to improve the social, economic and territorial cohesion of island regions. However, in the preparation of the 2014-2020 programming period, eu island regions received no specific funding, only the possibility of modulating co-financing rates for certain types of islands. In this context, on behalf of the Committee on Regional Development, I would like to ask the European Commission: Can the European Commission provide a clear definition of the type of permanent natural or demographic handicaps under Article 174 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the EUROPEAN Union that island regions at NUTS 2 and NUTS 3 are expected to face? What specific cohesion policy instruments and resources are available to address the adverse conditions arising from the island nature of these territories? What action will the Commission take in the future to comply with Article 174 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union with regard to the recognition of the permanent disadvantages faced by nuts 2 and NUTS 3 island regions as permanent obstacles that may affect the achievement of cohesion policy objectives?  Does the European Commission consider that other indicators other than GDP could be taken into account, which are not limited to measuring economic production and take into account the specificities of islands, such as the Regional Competitiveness Index, in order to better reflect the economic and social vulnerability caused by the permanent natural handicaps faced by these regions? I look forward to the Commission's response.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members of the European Parliament, Madam President Mihaylova, dear colleagues, I would like to begin by thanking the European Parliament's Committee on Regional Development for this oral question on support for islands, restricted regions within the European Structural and Investment Funds.  I would like to say from the outset that I am particularly concerned about this subject. Last year we had two meetings: the annual meeting in Guadeloupe and another meeting in Réunion, and in the last session in Strasbourg we had a meeting, together with my colleague, Commissioner Karmenu Vella, with all nine Members of the European Parliament coming from the outermost regions, precisely with the idea of seeing to what extent we can, at the beginning of the 2014-2020 programming period , to help these regions, which, as you said, in addition to being very far from Europe, have a number of specific problems.  As you know, our funds, European funds have a long-standing and successful tradition in supporting regions with specific geographical characteristics, including here also island regions that face various social, economic and environmental challenges and that require a specific approach on a case-by-case basis. These issues are, in my opinion, in the new regulation, the one concerning the 2014-2020 programming period, which calls on the Member States, where appropriate, to establish an integrated approach within the framework of the Partnership Agreements in order to address the specific needs of regions experiencing severe and sometimes permanent handicaps.  This is why a number of islands already benefit from a derogation in terms of the thematic concentration of investments from the European Regional Development Fund. Other islands have greater flexibility in taking into account their specific needs. In addition, the outermost regions that are all islands also benefit from a number of exceptions and specific conditions, thus seeking to make up for the serious and permanent constraints they face.  But, of course, as you pointed out, I also believe that we can do more. The Commission shall monitor the situation in the NUTS-2 and NUTS-3 regions. The Commission has created a number of synthetic indicators that take into account, for example, the regional competitiveness index or the human development index. Unfortunately, the data that we have and have at our disposal are not precise enough at the moment to reflect the specific characteristics of all island regions, but we continue to invest in data collection and forecasts, which will allow us to present a more detailed analysis of the situation in these regions in the next Cohesion Report.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today is an important day for me, because my initiative – thanks, of course, to the procedure laid down by Parliament and which provides for the Commission – comes to this House. This is a central issue. I would, however, like to turn to the Commissioner to give her some concrete examples and to make it clear better and more how, in some way, her reflection, although appreciable, is also a little distant from reality.  The islands do not have access to the market. The islands today find themselves with the handicap and disadvantage of speaking only one language, the language that the Union must decide whether the support given to them is called State aid and is legitimate. Low-cost companies run away from the islands, multinationals run away from the islands. This means a lack of territorial continuity, it means a lack of competition with regard to the price of energy. The islands cannot, through their small and medium-sized enterprises, achieve the process of internationalisation because they are strategically abandoned. I think it is essential to understand that, when we talk about freight and people transport, we have a monopoly of companies and when it comes to the tourist system, the tourist system cannot be supported because there is no deseasonalisation. All this is related to the fact that the islands do not have dedicated funding. Therefore, Commissioner, these regulations you mentioned are weak and are certainly to be reviewed, evaluated and strengthened. We have important strategic objectives to define for territories that are abandoned. I would therefore ask you to reconsider this position with regard to the strategic framework of future programming.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank my fellow Members for the work they have done on this resolution that we have promoted and I thank the Commissioner for being present at this debate and for the attention she is giving to the condition of the islands. I care in particular. I am a Member of Parliament from Sicily and we islanders are well aware of the condition we are living in. The islands are among the territories with the greatest weaknesses; structural and natural characteristics represent their extraordinary wealth but also their enormous weakness. Today we are asking the Commission strongly to define these weaknesses and to define the shortcomings that prevent and hinder the growth and economic development of our islands. It is a bitter reality: mobility on the islands is reduced, fuel costs more, producers have more difficulty exporting and tourists also find it difficult to get there. However, these disadvantages can become resources. We need dedicated programming that takes account of the specific characteristics of the islands. That is why it is essential for the Commission to set up an island window made up of experts to coordinate and evaluate policies for island regions. The islands have so much to offer: the sea becomes blue growth, natural resources renewable energies, agricultural products organic farming. We strongly call on the Commission to support the islands.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: on behalf of the ECR Club. " Mr. President, life on the island is not always easy. As a resident of the Croatian island of Korcula, I often feel it on my own skin. Traffic isolation and unavailability of various products and services, notable in the field of health and education, are just some of the challenges facing the island population. The lack of jobs due to the drastic decline in production capacity and the outflow of young people further contribute to the difficult image of the island. But the challenges facing the islands must not be a cause of desperation but an incentive to exploit all potentials. To achieve this, we need to attract investors and the workforce to the islands, and this is only possible through incentive tax policies, deregulation and infrastructure investments in cooperation with the private sector. I believe we all agree on this, so this way I ask you to support the amendments I have attached with my colleague Lewer on behalf of the ECR Group.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. Mr. President, respected Commissioners, islands are not just a statistical category. Islands are life, but unfortunately today mostly life in a one-way street, because you leave the island. And if the islands were not only the statistical category NUTS 2 or NUTS 3, I want to point out because of the many small islands, because of the small and medium-sized islands, where life is still far more difficult, but on large islands. Croatia is one of these countries that has a really exceptionally large number of inhabited small and medium-sized islands. And in this context, life on the islands is really extremely challenging, extremely difficult in all segments. I would like to point out, in the end, that if we lose the identity of our islands, we will lose the identity of many member states, and in the end we will lose the identity of Europe, which has largely emerged on many islands.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mrs Cređu, Article 174 remains an empty letter in the implementation of policies that strengthen cohesion in island regions and the Commission must do more for the islands of Europe and in particular for the Aegean islands.  Lesvos, one of the Greek islands in the Aegean, has a population of 85000. In 2015 it welcomed 500000 refugees. Residents of Lesvos, along with volunteer and well-known actress Susan Sarandon, have been nominated for a Nobel Peace Prize because these war refugees showed humanity and solidarity, covering Europe's deficits.  But you, too, must do more, as the Commission, because these islands are places of considerable tourist interest, with large infrastructure deficits for residents, with huge transport costs and are Europe's vanguard in tackling the refugee problem. Not just words, then, but works.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, thank you for being here to address this important issue, which is also important for my country. We agree with the majority of what is expressed in the motion for a resolution, such as the desirability of using other indicators in addition to GDP. Let's take an example, Sardinia. According to the European Union, it is in good health and has a GDP of 77%, so it is excluded from the funds for disadvantaged areas, but at the same time has very high unemployment. We can very well say that the Union will also be vigilant, but it seems to me that it is also suffering from strabrism. The time for words is over, we have to face reality and give solutions, the citizens call us to do so. One of the problems of the islands is transport and energy. Well, Sicily has a very low rate of absorption of funds, due to the administrative inability of regional governments, and a transport system that is not up to the standards of the governments of the developed countries. But all the governments, from Berlusconi to Renzi, we must say, are vague on a bridge over the Straits, which is useless, harmful and, what is more, in a seismic zone. Instead, we could start the transition to a third industrial revolution, which would achieve a model of development based on renewable sources, sustainable transport, the Internet of Things. Finally, how can what is written in the motion for a resolution on energy and employment be reconciled with the foolish choices made by various national and local governments on oil, with the drilling rigs in the Strait of Sicily, the ridiculous royalties and the various concessions made to ENI?

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, one account is what you value, one count is reality. Sardinia and Sicily have youth unemployment of more than 50%, young people are fleeing. Sardinia and Sicily are treated as colonies, first by the Italian State and now by Brussels. Concrete examples show that not only are they not being helped but they are being damaged. European fisheries regulations are a total disaster as they have put thousands of workers in port. European agricultural regulations are demented because they have benefited from the import of products from the other side of the Mediterranean, closing thousands of farms and leaving hundreds and hundreds of fields and territories uncultivated. We are ridiculous on transport. This is about the environment and pollution, but in Sicily 80% of the rail network is single track and half of the trains travel by diesel! While you want to leave other people on foot, there is the Region of Sicily which has half the trains that travel by diesel. As far as Sardinia is concerned, we are not even talking about the rail network and there is even a lack of a motorway. And then the Commission sends infringements by driving away carriers and aircraft and allowing a monopoly on maritime routes. I mean, the less you do the better. I ask you, on behalf of the islanders of Italy and Europe, to let go, to let the islands manage themselves and develop their work and their territory, unless the Commission believes that the islands should base their future and wealth on the reception of immigrants. If that's the case, you'il have to go over our bodies first.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: – Mr President, first of all, I would like to say that this Resolution on the special situation of the islands is very welcome and to congratulate Salvatore Cicu and all the rapporteurs who have collaborated in this Resolution.  I come from Mallorca, one of the Balearic Islands belonging to Spain, and we have long fought – since the Treaty of Amsterdam – for recognition in the Treaties of Insularity – not only of insularity, but also of double and triple insularity, as is the case of Menorca or Formentera itself.  Insularity generates costs in agriculture and transport, difficulties in connectivity, difficulties in health, in education, and therefore has to be compensated. This is the case, as the Treaty acknowledges in Article 174 and also when it speaks to economic, social and territorial cohesion, but it is true that then, when we go to the budget, there are difficulties.  Here I welcome the Commission's proposal, and also the proposal for the Resolution itself, to create an Agenda for the islands of the European Union and a White Paper for the development of these islands, as well as an 'islands desk'. It is very important to help to be able to have the same competitiveness in all strategic sectors and to be able to have the same opportunities as the rest of the mainland.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: S&D). Mr President, in a Europe where respect for diversity is a basic principle, it is not enough simply to know areas with permanent peculiarities and disadvantages. The problems of island regions are many and must be prevented from being isolated. Targeted initiatives are needed to overcome the chronic problems they face and in many cases lead to problems of access to basic goods, such as water, as well as the deprivation of basic services such as healthcare. We have the example of small islands in Greece.  We must also make the most of the comparative advantages of island regions, such as the exploitation of various forms of renewable energy sources. Failure to integrate these areas under a specific framework in the current 2014-2020 programming period will be a missed opportunity for sound and targeted investment.  Finally, I should note that the definition of Eurostat should not be used since the one-sided approach that exists using a single criterion, whether an island region is an island state or not, does not give weight to other important issues, such as the population and distance of the island region from continental Europe.

name: Nikolaos CHOUNTIS
text: GUE/NGL). Commissioner, speaking today of insularity, that is to say the need for multifaceted support for The European islands, this, at least for my own country, that is to say the Greek islands, is not the case. It has been abolished in practice. It has been abolished, firstly, because the Greek islands are also paying for the consequences of memorial policies, austerity policies. Special tax regimes applied to other European islands, such as reduced VAT, have been abolished in order to deal with the specificities that we know the Greek islands have. Airports have sold out to private and foreign interests, so it is doubtful whether there will be a reduction in transport costs, which you know is crucial when it comes to transport to the islands. Finally, they suffer the consequences of the multifaceted refugee crisis, particularly the Aegean islands and the non-existent European political solidarity.  I would therefore appreciate this opportunity, Commissioner, if you would give me an answer to a question I have asked you four months ago about what specific measures you are taking in the context of cohesion policy, in the context of insularity, for the Greek islands that currently exist and accept the greatest refugee burden both in terms of managing people and registering refugees and tackling this problem.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you to my fellow Members who have wanted this debate in this House and thank you to the Commissioner for being here to answer our questions. I'd like to ask you a question. Today the islands live a marginal condition that is not only physical, but also economic and social. So far, the European Commission has intervened and proposed actions for the outermost regions without taking into account that there are many more islands within the European Union and that they live in this whole marginal condition. I ask you what the European Union intends to do to promote territorial integration, to promote continuity, to ensure that there is a real agenda to overcome the conditions of insularity, which is economic marginality, which is backwardness, which is not a condition of development. To get here I take three planes simply because I come from an island that is certainly less served than many others and I am certainly luckier than many others who have to pay for the ticket out of their own pocket. How does the European Union intend to overcome this marginality? What does the Commission intend to do to promote integration and to reduce transport costs and to ensure that our goods can reach the markets in the same way as the others?

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Let us now turn to catch-the-eye. There are many requests for action. During the debate I was flexible given the importance of the subject and the sensitivity of the issue of islands for many Members. If you all want to speak, however, it is absolutely essential that the catch-the-eye speakers speak for only one minute, otherwise I will then have to cut the number of speeches. Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: – Mr. President, I applaud the Commissioner and thank my colleague Salvatore Čić for this initiative. As an MP coming from the land of a thousand islands, I must express my fear for the survival of the island, due to the increasingly present trend of depopulation of the island. We need to develop better policies at European Union level, but also at national level, aimed at strengthening economic projects on the islands.  What we currently have the opportunity to see is that only higher co-financing rates fund cohesion policy-funded projects, and we need a lot more than that. Why shouldn't state aid be more flexible when it comes to economic projects on the islands? Why can't we finance at higher rates, regardless of which NUTS 2 region the islands are in, economic projects, projects entrepreneurs who will create jobs, otherwise we will just look at the islands, and no one will live on them.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: – Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, there are many problems faced by the inhabitants of the island, from the fact that the islands are on average lagging behind a fifth of G.D.P. for the mainland, through depopulation, poor connectivity and availability of healthcare to high cost of living, access to education, etc. But G.D.P. is not a criterion of the island's condition because it does not cover other parameters that make life on the island more complex and difficult.  However, each island is a unique, natural, cultural and economic entity. We can discuss different definitions, but I don't think we have done enough for the European islands to fulfil the obligations referred to in Article 174 TSI. Lisbon Treaty. In the Institutions of the European Union, policies towards islands have never come to life in the full sense.  I come from Croatia, a country with over 1,200 islands, and I join calls on the Commission to do an analysis of the cost of living on the islands and to adjust financial support and programmes. We need a strategic programme and a special EU agenda for the islands to at least partially compensate them for everything missed and help them reach their full potential.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, Article 174 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union recognises that island regions as a whole face permanent disadvantages that deserve special attention. These disadvantages are related to their demographic situation, but also to their physical position. As a result, the islands face problems of competitiveness and social cohesion.  In Greece the islands proved particularly vulnerable to the economic crisis. But instead of being supported, the Troika abolished the special tax regime of the Aegean islands and increased VAT from 13% to 23%. The Troika also launched the sell-off in Fraport of the most important island regional airports. In addition, the Aegean islands are now affected by the huge refugee flows as more than 600000 refugees were first accommodated on the Aegean islands in 2015.  However, the arrival of this huge number of refugees and the lack of infrastructure create social problems and have affected the tourist image of the islands. Measures are therefore needed, in particular, for the Aegean islands and the abolition of VAT from 23%, or a reduction to at least 13%.

name: António MARINHO E PINTO
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I am from a country that has two autonomous regions in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean. One of them, the Autonomous Region of the Azores, consists of nine islands, which creates a new problem, that of dual insularity, that of the displacement of populations between these islands. This region has thousands of emigrants, mainly in the United States and Canada. Some of these emigrants take less time from the United States and Canada to the main island of the Azores than then to circulate between them. In addition, both autonomous regions have great difficulties, given the high transport costs, to access the continent. Last year, I invited two schools from the Autonomous Region of the Azores, and of one of them, some children had to take four planes to get to Brussels.  I ask the Commission to take measures to support the inhabitants of these two regions, because there will be no real Europe, real European construction, without cohesion, without these people being able to move in their country and in the European Union itself.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: – Mr President, today the people of Europe suffer the consequences of austerity policies, support for the financial sector and large economic groups, and it is in this context that island regions are penalised more because they are those at a disadvantage in the context of the complete liberalisation of the economy.  In Portugal, we have two archipelagos, the Azores and Madeira, which suffer doubly from the insularity and effects of the troika and its adjustment programme in recent years. In the Azores and Madeira, populations have sought to overcome adversities, continuing to produce and trying to survive in this liberalized world.  However, as we have had the opportunity to check directly through a visit by this Parliament's Committee on Agriculture, it is not possible to continue to pretend that we will solve the problem by creating a European year of the islands or believing that tourism will solve all the problems. In the name of territorial cohesion, specific policies are needed to support productive activities, in particular at transport level, so that island populations can have the same opportunities as other peoples in Europe.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE). Mr President, first of all I must thank my dear colleague, Salvatore Cicu, and congratulate him, as well as the other colleagues who have really touched on the issue of our islands. Europe is also our islands. Above all, they are our islands. Imagine a European Union and a Europe without the islands! But I believe that this is the time when words must end and actions must begin. The islands are isolated and everyone recognises that I think in particular that the islands need to come out of isolation. We have concrete proposals. A corresponding package must be made, such as the Delors package and the Juncker package specifically for the islands in order to be supported. We're talking about isolation. The European Union could support our initiative to create a free Wi-Fi network for all islands. Support for communication and transport on the islands could be strengthened. They could incentivise the islands to cope with basic social goods. These islands, which represent the European Union deservedly, could become real islands that they can offer and also take from this European Union. I believe they are entitled to it, Mr President.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I am taking part with great interest in this debate on island regions in my capacity as an MEP born and resident in an island region, the Canary Islands, seeing the Europe 2020–2030 Strategy as a huge opportunity to boost this compensation to insularity in extremely sensitive areas. The first, of course, is employment: these are regions affected by unbearable unemployment rates. The qualification and training of local labour needs to be strengthened in order to access jobs that can boost this economy, but also, above all, the GDP criterion must be changed as the only exclusive and exclusionary criterion for measuring the economic development of these regions, in order to consider social, demographic and ecological sustainability. In short, a boost must be made to this synergy and to the solidarity of the European Union as a whole for the integration of island policies into European policies as a whole.

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I have followed the debate with great attention. I am not from an island region. However, there are many problems that have been described here, including in mainland Europe. I believe, of course, that difficulties in bureaucracy or in administrative management are having a greater and more detrimental effect on people on the islands than in other areas of Europe. In this respect, this is also an appeal to the islands to face up to their responsibilities. The refugee crisis at the moment shows how important the importance of functioning infrastructure on Europe's islands. That is why we should use the opportunity that now exists with the crisis to ensure that the administrative processes and infrastructures that help the people there to deal with the problems even better. I believe that there is also solidarity between the centre of the European Union and the islands.

name: Renato SORU
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the initiative of the REGI Committee is important, allowing us to bring this debate before the Commissioner this morning. In a few seconds, I would like to leave you this message, Commissioner: remember that the third report on the state of cohesion, which has already been mentioned this morning, reminds us that the recent crisis has hit the islands hardest and that it is more difficult for the islands to overcome a development delay and finally catch the growth that will allow the project of cohesion of the European economy to be fully implemented.  I would like to remind you of one point: today it is important to be on the net. Insularity is exceeded if you are on the net. Take some special initiatives immediately so that each island is networked in digital networks, every island is networked in energy networks – and there is no longer an island like Sardinia that is disconnected from the gas network – every island is on the grid as regards transport conditions and every island is fully guaranteed the right to mobility. Commissioner, few things but done now.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the debate we have heard shows, Commissioner, one thing: on the one hand, the islands are characterised by similarity, because all the islands have greater problems than the continent and the other areas of our Union, but, on the other hand, there are actually major differences between islands and islands, in the size, distance and problems they face. I would ask you, having heard all the problems, if you decide to make the White Paper, to take account of these differences and therefore to consider the large islands, the small islands, the islands that have problems of insularity with each other because they constitute an archipelago, as well as the outermost regions which, when they have island characteristics, clearly have even greater problems. So that is my appeal and I hope that it will be taken up.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Commissioner, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, although I do not live in an island country, as Mr Schwab said, I understand very well the problem that the islands have, as the countries in the eastern part of the European Union do. After all, the internal market of the European Union must reach cohesion policies that bring living standards to a near level, and I believe, Commissioner, that what you have said here – and, first of all, thank you for taking part in the debate – that you are thinking of some indices, for example the human development index, because any cohesion policy must aim to increase the quality of life , are welcome indicators and I suggest you take into account cohesion policies also in eastern countries, where we also have similar problems to those in the islands. I think it is well stressed here – I congratulate the REGI Commission – the importance of local and regional administrations in the public-private partnership that they must make for the development and implementation of cohesion funds.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: There was no shortage of stresses and also strong interventions. It is now up to the Commission to respond to Parliament's requests.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members of the European Parliament, dear colleagues, thank you very much for your contributions. I wanted to assure you from the beginning about my constant concern about the specific problems facing the islands, the outermost regions.  As I was saying, last year I attended the annual meeting in Guadeloupe. This year, the annual meeting of the outermost regions will take place in Madeira. Last month – two weeks ago, in fact – in Strasbourg, I met with a number of you who are Members of the European Parliament representing outermost regions, and I wanted to join me and the Commissioner for Climate Change, Mr Karmenu Vella, because I know that a number of you have specific problems with fisheries policies, maritime policies and so on.  As I was telling you from the outset, these outermost regions and, in general, the islands belong to Member States, and from this point of view, I was pleased that, even in December, the European Court of Justice issued a communiqué and obliged the Member States to take into account the outermost regions in the operational programmes and the specificities of these outermost regions. We confess to you that we have a permanent dialogue with the Member States, in order to pay particular attention to the outermost regions, the islands and those with a particular situation.  As I said at the beginning, the financial and political framework for the European Structural and Investment Funds for the period 2014-2020 is an important step to better meet the specific needs of island regions. I want to assure you that I have also recommended that the governors of these islands, the governors of the outermost regions, have a more active, more proactive role, because it is not enough for us, from the European Commission, to go once a year to an island. As you said, there is no way to know the reality, unless there is a mutual dialogue, constant in bringing to our attention the problems we face. From this point of view, you can count on me, on the Commission. As far as Greece is concerned, you know very well, last year I was here before you, calling for extraordinary measures for an extraordinary situation. We have managed to change the regulations and we have 100% co-financing – so, in fact, it can no longer be called co-financing. Basically, from this point of view, I think that, from our point of view, we have done everything we can for Greece. I share what was said here. More than 880,000 people came to Greece in 2015 alone. It is a huge burden and I assure you that the Commission is working very closely with the Greek authorities to support Greece on this huge challenge.  But I would like to tell you that it's all about administrative capacity. You mentioned the island of Lesbos. I met with the Governor there, explained to her to what extent she could use European funds. Unfortunately, Greece is one of the countries that does not want to use European funds for this migration problem, although there is a possibility that, with a small part of the amount, it will make mobile hospitals, kindergartens and so on. Italy is the only country that has called for the change of operational programmes and already the European Commission has transferred EUR 220 million to Italy, precisely for this purpose.  In any case, I know the problems that Greece has and I want to assure you that, in general, in relation to the islands, we are doing everything we can to meet the specific needs.  Many Member States, unfortunately, do not want these regions to be treated separately. Greece, for example, in the Accession Treaty wishes to be regarded as a single country and in the operational programmes and in the Partnership Agreement makes no particularity with regard to the special conditions of the islands, as, for example, France specifies in the Partnership Agreement that there are outermost regions such as Réunion, French Guiana, Guadeloupe and so on.m,d., which require special policies. So, as I was saying, this is a shared responsibility and, especially with regard to the implementation of European funds, I believe that this is 100% the responsibility of the Member States. As mentioned above, we have a number of specific instruments and derogations that are in place. The challenge for all of us in the period ahead is to improve regional policy in order to best meet the needs of all regions and future challenges. I want to assure you of my availability. We have requested and may be able to organise a meeting on this subject in Brussels this year. We must ensure, as you said, that island regions not only meet the challenges they currently face, but also that, on the basis of their European peculiarities, they contribute better to achieve the objectives of the European Union. I want to assure you that we are working closely with the outermost regions, with the islands. As I was saying, I also visited several islands in Italy, Sicily. We want European funds to be used as best as possible in order to have a positive impact in these economies, particularly in the fight against unemployment and, of course, the use of energy resources.  There is a big problem that you have also raised here in relation to transport connections. I understand very well. Someone said here they'd switch four planes. This is where we work together. It is the sovereignty of the Member States, as I was saying. For example, France contributes money from the budget to help citizens of these outermost regions have a lower cost. Other countries, such as Spain, for example, are calling on the European Commission to subsidise ticket costs for these citizens, which is not in our capacity-building power.  So I think we need to talk more about the specific problems of the islands, I am absolutely convinced that this is a major problem, I am absolutely convinced that we need derogations. That is why, as I said earlier, I have a permanent discussion with both Commissioner Vestager, with regard to State aid, and with Mr Vella, because I am aware that, as we have a very strict policy on fisheries, we need derogations for these islands, which are facing major problems.  So, from this point of view, I believe that the 2014-2020 programming period, which you have adopted as a co-legislator, brings an important step but, on the other hand, there is still much to be done and I am at your disposal to gather together the best ideas and discuss how to proceed.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I have received one motion for a resolution pursuant to Rule 128(5) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate on this subject, which is so topical, is closed. The vote will take place today at 12.00 p.m. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – Whereas EU funding could boost the standard of living on islands, the latter could not just rely on EU funding. Member States need to support sustainable projects and work to come up with tangible and innovative ideas and projects to improve connectivity to tackle the insularity challenge. Islands by their very own nature were characterised by a number of challenges, mainly insularity. In a global world it is difficult to speak of insularity but due to bad policies adopted by certain Member States, a number of islands were facing insularity challenges more than ever before, mostly because of connectivity issues. At times services by which islands are connected to mainland are deteriorating in terms of standard or frequency. This is evident in Malta and Italy. One could look at insularity as a resource and a characteristic that could attract to islands new economic sector case in point sustainable and high-quality tourism. Member States need to heavily invest in a sustainable manner in islands and the Commission has to identify innovative instruments to improve connectivity and tackle insularity and at the same time seek ways and means how to further implement the Treaty to make more EU funding available for islands.

name: Alyn SMITH
text: in writing. – Scotland’s islands are some of our bonniest spots, but they face some of the toughest conditions in the country too, and not just thanks to the weather. There is much to be welcomed in this Resolution, most particularly the call for an increase in digital connectivity for islands, better maritime access routes and better education opportunities. Steps like these will help to reduce disparities between islands and the mainland, and maintain the population in areas where it is at risk. As this Resolution illustrates so well, one size does not always fit all, and this is especially the case with Europe’s islands: even just in Scotland our islands face many different challenges and are extremely diverse places, let alone if you start to consider the differences with Greek, Italian or Danish islands. This is why it is so vital that European laws reflect this diversity and make appropriate allowances for it. I hope this Resolution demonstrates to the European Commission that they must act on some of these very sensible suggestions in order to better help our island communities face the future and the challenges it will no doubt bring.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the debate on the question with request for an oral reply to the Commission on the role of local and regional authorities in the European Structural and Investment Funds (EIS Funds), on behalf of the Committee on Regional Development (O-000012/2016 - B8-0105/2016) (2015/3013(RSP)).

name: Iskra MIHAYLOVA
text: Author. – Dear Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, colleagues, the framework legislation in the field of regional policy requires Member States to create the necessary conditions for consultation with local and regional levels of government in the preparation and implementation of partnership contracts and specific operational programmes.  Regional and local authorities of self-government are closest to citizens and better understand local problems and specificities. They have the advantage in formulating policies and initiatives aimed at improving citizens' lives in the areas of job creation, innovation, health, environment, energy, transport – we can continue this list for a long time. On the other hand, regional and local authorities, as a result of their limited resources, need more significant budget support and co-financing of projects than at national level.  In implementing cohesion policy, the level of consultation of regional and local authorities varies considerably between Member States, with some Member States still not taking the partnership principle enshrined in European legislation seriously enough. In general, regional and local authorities in federal Member States have a greater opportunity to shape national policies because of the powers at their disposal – powers that have an impact at pararegional and local level.  It is important to stress that improving administrative capacity at local and regional level is a key factor in better strategic planning and implementation of operational programmes, as well as for the more efficient implementation of structural and cohesion funds. It is important to note that cities are drivers for economic growth and employment, centres for the development of art, culture and creativity, a platform for innovation and emerging enterprises. Smart cities and smart specialisation strategies are innovative practices translated into specific European Union policies or initiatives. Furthermore, the 2015 Riga Declaration will lead to the Amsterdam Pact. The Pact aims at increasing the participation of European cities in proposing, drawing up and implementing specific initiatives and programmes within the framework of urban development.  Last but not least, the role of regional and local authorities is also important in developing cross-border links and initiatives, part of European territorial cooperation.  In this context, I would like to ask the European Commission, in the face of Commissioner Crezzo, to answer the following questions as defined by the European Parliament's Committee on Regional Policy: What specific support will the European Commission give to regional and local authorities with a view to strengthening their impact role, as well as for the management and concrete implementation of the ESI Funds for the period 2014-2020 , taking into account their respective responsibilities and the specificities of individual Member States in order to create economic growth and sustainable jobs?  And question two: Will the Commission hold a public consultation followed by a possible initiative to strengthen the role of regional and local authorities?  In addition to these issues, I would like to stress that they are of utmost importance to the Committee in the European Parliament, as the involvement of regional and local authorities is at the heart of the successful implementation of cohesion policy, i.e. at the heart of achieving the competitiveness, growth and job creation objective. The role of local and regional authorities is also at the heart of the future post-2020 cohesion policy planning.  I look forward to the Commission's responses and the debate.

name: n/a
text: Member of the Commission. Madam President Mihaylova, honourable Members of the European Parliament, I would first of all like to thank you for this oral question from the European Parliament's Committee on Regional Development, which brings to the fore the role of local and regional authorities in the context of the European Structural and Investment Funds. You know very well that, from our point of view, we work every day with these local authorities, sub-national authorities that play a key role in the implementation of programmes financed by our funds, because they bring the European Union and European policies closer to people, while helping to implement projects financed by European funds much more effectively on the ground. From our point of view, from the European Commission, we rely heavily on the role of local authorities, on the role of managing authorities. We believe that they know best what is needed in a region, what can be done and what cannot be done. Regional policy has this fundamental feature because it adapts to the needs of each region. As you know, with your support, with the support of the European Parliament, we have managed to persuade the Member States to involve local and regional authorities in the decision-making process, both at the pre-legislative stage and throughout the entire programming period. I am grateful to the European Parliament for the fact that the new regulations bring, as an ex-ante conditionality, the principle of partnership, the principle of bringing to the table both non-governmental organisations and local authorities, because Europe is diverse: We have countries where this principle of partnership has been a tradition for decades, but we also have other countries where this principle is not fully integrated. I would therefore like to assure you that local authorities have been closely involved, both in negotiating partnership agreements and operational programmes, and in implementing projects at local and regional level. The European Commission is already conducting a study on the implementation of this partnership principle... (interrupted sound) in 2014-2020 and I assure you that the study will be made public in the coming months. For example, with regard to the integrated urban actions, to which you referred, Madam President Mihaylova, and which are very important, EUR 15 billion has been allocated to cities in the period 2014-2020 so that they can meet their specific development needs. It is the first time in the history of the European Union that the Commission has practically given money directly to cities. I think it is a reliable decision about the ability of these cities to decide on their needs and to spend the money on their citizens. The same is true of local development actions under the responsibility of the community, where both the public and private sector and civil society are at the forefront of implementing local development strategies. On the one hand, we are working closely with the Dutch Presidency of the Council to ensure that the European Union's Urban Agenda becomes a reality, so that cities really have a say. An example would be when it comes to the European Union's support in reducing urban poverty or the social inclusion of migrants. You referred, Madam President, to the Riga Declaration. The Amsterdam Declaration follows. As I was saying, the Dutch Presidency places particular emphasis on the Urban Agenda and is due to hold a meeting in Amsterdam in March with all the mayors of the European capitals and then, in June, we hope to have this Amsterdam Declaration. This is the first time that all Member States have agreed that an Urban Agenda is needed. You know that, until now, some Member States have invoked the principle of subsidiarity, refusing a specific European framework with regard to the Urban Agenda. We, too, in the Commission, and I am personally thinking of organising a meeting with a number of mayors – primarily mayors of the capitals most affected by the refugee issue – because, regardless of national refugee policy, some mayors are forced to take emergency measures in relation to the challenges they face. I believe that we need to help these cities, which are most affected, on the refugee issue. On the other hand, we support the administrative capacity of local and regional authorities so that they can really exploit the potential of European funds, and here I think you agree with me that European funds are not always everything. Money isn't always everything. We need, first of all, administrative capacity, the capacity to develop successful projects, because we are not developing projects in Brussels. He's not sitting in our power. We can't decide. It is therefore a decisive year in this respect, a year when beneficiaries and local authorities must develop viable projects that truly meet the needs of citizens. As you know, the Structural and Investment Funds have a dedicated thematic objective, effective public administration, aimed at strengthening institutional capacity, with a budget of over five billion for the period 2014-2020. I am confident that these measures will clearly increase the impact of our funds on economic growth, and I hope that they will also lead to the creation of new jobs Thank you and I look forward to your comments.

name: Lambert van NISTELROOIJ
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Commissioner Creţu, I thank you for your response already, your positive attitude and commitment. Still, I have three dots. 1. The Committee of the Regions has looked again at how things have gone in recent times. They note that there is a trend towards renationalisation in many Member States.  2. The principle of partnership in Article 5 of our Regulation has not been fulfilled in all Member States. Regions and cities are not seen there as equal, democratically elected partners, but as one of the stakeholders. 3. The Committee of the Regions explicitly speaks of centralisation, which is contrary to the code of conduct we agreed in the Council. That is why I can tell you, on behalf of the PPE Group, that subsidiarity is essential for us and we are sticking to it. The question I have now is: you say there will be a study. We are talking about a public consultation. We shall start with Article 16(3) in the report of which I may be rapporteur on behalf of this Parliament. We want to explore this issue. I ask you: can you meet Parliament in this matter to have a public discussion about this?

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I believe that this debate and this resolution are appropriate, and I thank you, Commissioner, for once again affirming the role that regional and local authorities, particularly those in cities, must play in the management of cohesion policy. We know that cohesion policy is today the European Union's main investment instrument and remains the main instrument even with the Presence of the Juncker Plan. In the next programming period, which we will be discussing in a very short time, we believe that it absolutely must remain so. We have some concerns about this because, if the overall budget does not increase, it is quite clear that the increase in demand risks reducing resources in the sectors where these resources are most important. We believe that all regions should remain involved, including those of so-called competitiveness, and we believe that the full involvement of regions and local authorities must continue to be essential from the earliest stages of programming. We have always been in favour of coordination and coherence between the different sources of European investment, but we believe that cohesion policy remains an extraordinary force for growth and development and progress, as it has been up to now. So please be the defender of this, in the role of local authorities, but above all in its existence.

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – The European Union has a sustainable development objective. This is one of the conditions for equalization of internal differences as well as real competition in the global market. As a result, more and more funds should go to the poorest regions.  Often, local governments find it difficult to spend the funds already allocated or wonder whether to apply for them at all. The barrier is not so much the own contribution as the need to add VAT. Therefore, in projects co-financed by European funds in the period 2014-2020, VAT should be the eligible cost of the project. The relevant Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council of 2013 should therefore be amended. In my region, in the Lublin region, local authorities have long called for such a solution, as well as increased flexibility in the use of funds earmarked, for example, for the conduct of research and development activities by companies, which would give impetus to deeper cooperation between business and science.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. – Mr. President, I want to first thank President Mihaylova and all my colleagues from other groups for accepting this initiative.  I have dedicated my entire political career to strengthening local and regional self-government units. Stronger cities, stronger municipalities, stronger regions have always meant a stronger quality of life for me. What I want to emphasize today is that I am 100% convinced that the principle of subsidiarity has no alternative. We really need to see the principle of subsidiarity to the end, as European practice is also known where the most normalised countries, such as Denmark, have by far the best standard, the best development. As far as the most centralized countries, such as my Croatia or like Greece, have major development problems, and there is something that is crucial alongside it. The key issue is absorption power. Today we have a common situation that supercentralized states do not have quality absorption power. That is why I am committed to the possible direct access of cities and regions to European funds, because we often have a political competition between a national government or some regional or local government. In this way, if we are going to have the possibility of direct access by local and regional authorities to European funds and various other sources of financing at the Level of Europe, I am sure that we will strengthen the quality and security of living in many cities and regions of the European Union.  Here I add the need for quality cross-border cooperation, financing cross-border cooperation, where we have excellent experience, for example IPA Adriatico is a fantastic good experience of good financing of cross-border cooperation and of course macro-regional cooperation. I conclude in my belief that it is through this issue that the Commission will be more sensitive to local and regional development.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mrs Cređu, there is indeed a need for greater involvement of local and regional authorities in the use of the Structural Funds. Greater decentralisation, less centralisation, less bureaucracy and a greater share of the Structural Funds and the relevant funds for local and regional authorities. But, above all, more assistance is needed as well as technical assistance from the Commission, in dialogue with national authorities, local and regional authorities. Because very small municipalities or regions do not have the know-how and administrative capacity to submit proposals, to file dossiers.  And of course more needs to be done in both money and technical assistance for those cities, islands, regions that are facing their permanent problems and the exacerbation of the refugee crisis. In Greece we have many such cases, not only on the islands, but also in the capital of the country, Athens. I therefore look forward to both the consultation and the Commission's proposals, because local and regional authorities must gain more weight in practice, both with technical assistance and with money.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – This is a very timely issue. Getting out of the economic crisis and ensuring long-term sustainable economic growth and the well-being of all Europeans will be extremely difficult if we do not exploit the potential that lies in our cities and regions. I agree that the European Union does not have the power to establish the internal structure of the Member States, but the Commission has developed open coordination mechanisms, and it is the error of good practice that in many cases becomes a factor that drives change. I would like to ask the Commission to promote the exchange of experience on good governance, with particular emphasis on the good involvement of local regional authorities in decision-making practices. I would also like to call on the Commission to develop a methodology to assess the effectiveness of the internal administrative structure of the Member States. It should focus on the quality of local and regional authorities being involved in the decision-making process at national level and the extent to which sufficient and own resources and powers local and regional authorities have to implement autonomous regional policies or tailor national regional policy decisions to specific internal needs. The proposal to secure partnership is very important because the true partnership between central, local, regional authorities, communities and social partners is still very lacking. It is more formal despite the fact that local governments and communities are closest to people and can most accurately identify basic needs and plan activities, especially in view of regional disparities that are only exacerbated by the effects of migration flows, globalisation and climate change.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, cohesion policy must, in order to be successful, be shared and based on a constant relationship between the various levels, from the European Union to the territories. Today, the way it is designed and, above all, implemented, it does not work and does not achieve the aim of reducing the gap between the different European regions. There is a huge problem of governance and administrative incapacity on the part of regional authorities. It would be too long to mention here all the waste and unnecessary work that has been done over the years, including in my country, causing serious socio-economic and image damage not only for the regions involved but also for the whole cohesion policy. In addition to the analysis of the last programming, which we must do, we must ask ourselves how to overcome the critical issues encountered. I am referring to the very low expenditure of the early years and the accelerated, sudden and incredible expenditure of recent months, with the use of bank projects so as not to lose the available resources. I am sorry to see that the late adoption of the operational programmes, which is the main cause of the critical issues, has also been repeated in this programming. We absolutely must reverse course and speed up the appointment of managing authorities, so that calls for tenders can be issued as soon as possible and projects can begin. But Europe also has its responsibilities. The links of cohesion policy with economic governance and the disunity of investment from the calculation of the deficit must be discussed again. From the beginning the 5 Star Movement insists on these points and on these issues and I note that other parties also finally share the thing. The Italian Government itself and Renzi himself seem to agree, but we fear they are cosmetic actions and mere electoral operations. Ladies and gentlemen, let us remember that it is not with budgetary constraints, it is not with austerity policy that a good cohesion policy is being implemented.

name: Olaf STUGER
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – In two months' time, we in the Netherlands will have a referendum on the agreement with Ukraine. It emerged last week that Mr Soros, a major American investor, had poured EUR 200 000 into the campaign coffers of the Yes camp. Investigations are now taking place, as more and more people with large financial interests put money into that yes camp. That is what this referendum has been rigged with. This shows that the Netherlands is underdeveloped and underdeveloped countries, you call them regions, the Netherlands region, let me say, can call on the regional development fund. Through you, Mr President, I would like to ask the Commissioner: save democracy and generously pour into the campaign coffers of the 'no' camp! [The speaker responds to two "blue card" questions pursuant to Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.]

name: Lambert van NISTELROOIJ
text: "blue card" question. It can be very short. I am very dismayed by Mr Stuger's comment that the Netherlands is an underdeveloped democratic area. How can he represent the Dutch citizens here and also abuse this agenda? Because it is about the role of the regions in regional policy. You're going to miss the mark. Can you respond to that?

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – Thank you for taking the question, Mr Stuger. I notice you speak about the referendum in the Netherlands and big business getting on the side of the ‘yes’ campaign. Do you think that the people in the Netherlands will actually take this referendum as a vote on the whole EU itself? Also, as you know, we have a referendum coming up in the UK. Would you have a message for the people of the UK as well?

name: Olaf STUGER
text: "blue card" answer. – At a time when large American investors - and I am talking to Mr Van Nistelrooy - are going to interfere in a referendum in the Netherlands without the Dutch government responding to it, you can talk about the fact that there is a democratic deficit in the Netherlands in relation to this referendum, and I am talking specifically about that. That is why it is good to call attention to this. In response to Mr Etheridge's question. Of course, the Dutch people see the referendum as an opportunity to express all the pent-up anger and frustration with the EU and all its failures in that referendum. I therefore hope for a good result, for an overwhelming 'no'. And I also hope that this may be a prelude to the referendum in which you will soon be able to take part in the United Kingdom.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI). Mr President, local and regional authorities in today's Europe are perhaps the key cell on which we should rebuild the states of Europe. These principles in countries such as Greece have been greatly weakened not so much because of a lack of competence, but mainly because of a lack of people. The population has shrunk dramatically resulting in the current bad situation. I therefore fully agree that we must strengthen the Region and, above all, its people. The farmers, the farmers, all those who choose to do business in the province. Our aim must be decentralisation, which will also improve the situation in large urban centres.  Unfortunately, the current Government in Greece has set itself the sights on exterminating among other social groups and farmers. Its policy renders what we are discussing here today meaningless, as there will be no farmers in a few years' time to support them. Finally, we must ensure that all the resources, european taxpayers' money, that will be made available should be made available with complete transparency and control away from any suspicion of corruption if we are to have tangible results.  I would like to send a message to Greece, in which there is now a nationwide, pan-Labour strike, against a mnemonic Government of the Left, which continues the memoranda and impoverisheds the lives of the Greeks.

name: Joachim ZELLER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her We know that local and regional authorities play an important role in achieving the objectives of the European Union, as set out in the EU 2020 strategy. Local and regional authorities bear a great deal of responsibility in addressing current challenges – such as now the integration, reception and accommodation of refugees and migrants. That is why the European Parliament's demand was and is that local and regional authorities should be involved even more strongly than before in the partnership agreements, operational programmes and projects under the European Structural Funds.  We must now state that this has not been fully achieved. For example, the 5% earmarked for urban projects is not allocated to cities in all countries. Our development is now a call and a wake-up call to the Commission, the Council and the Member States to take greater account of local and regional authorities in the implementation of the Structural Funds in regional policy. European policy and European cohesion can only be seen in this way, only on the ground, in the municipalities, among the citizens. (The speakers agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. I myself agree that local and regional authorities should be much more involved in the work of this fund and other funds. So there's a consensus. However, I would ask you how, in particular, it is possible to prevent certain funds from reaching the hands of politics and political parties, after which these authorities themselves are politically exposed?

name: Joachim ZELLER
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Policy also plays a role in local and regional authorities. However, we have laid down in the regulations how the funds made available within the framework of regional policy are used, and those regulations must also be adhered to by the political leaders. I am not aware that regional policy funds are likely to be misused for party politics. That would be a clear violation and would therefore have to be prosecuted and punished.

name: Louis-Joseph MANSCOUR
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am pleased to see that the debate today is about the key role of local and regional authorities in the development of our territories and, above all, on cities as a source of growth and employment, and therefore deals with urban policy. As you know, in 2015, 40% of the population of the European Union resided in cities. Having an effective urban policy is a necessity. Nevertheless, I would like to draw your attention to the concerns of certain regions of the Union which, since the financial crisis, have seen widening development gaps between urban and rural areas. This is even more true in the outermost regions, which, as you also know, have many handicaps.  Cohesion policy must therefore retain its original spirit of territorial solidarity, which is important not to be questioned. Complementarity between the different territories is a reality, and this requires a cross-cutting approach, guided by the principle of subsidiarity, both at European and at the level of each Member State.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: – Mr President, we understand that, from the European Union and on the basis of the Community project, we can establish common lines aimed, on the one hand, at citizen rescue, through job creation and, on the other hand, social transformation towards a more environmentally sustainable model.  We must therefore enhance any investment well aimed at meeting these two objectives, bearing in mind that it is indeed local authorities and civil society organizations that have the best capacity to assess where we should concentrate all efforts. We must therefore work on more participatory management and investment to maximize the impact of the Funds.  However, the combined use of the five European Structural and Investment Funds should not leave the door open to possible cuts or to take advantage of urban development to the detriment of rural ones, as these European Funds are now the main means of financing social projects for the development of certain regions at territorial, social or economic disadvantage.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: – Mr President, I know that you, Madam Commissioner, are a fair and reasonable person, so I am going to highlight a problem that we have, and there may be a way that you can help us and show your own personal fairness to my region. The first problem we have is that in my region of the West Midlands of the United Kingdom we are being forced into a combined authority, which is actually designed entirely around getting loans and funding from the EU. It is being done behind closed doors, it is being done in a dishonourable way, and the people have not had a chance to vote on it. This gives a bad reputation to the EU and to the whole idea of city regions and authorities. However, Madam Commissioner, there is an opportunity for you to show your personal honourable nature. There is an issue in the West Midlands where we need help from regional funding, and after all the UK does contribute far more to the EU than we ever get out. It would be wonderful if you could come and have a look at the region with me. In particular I would like to raise with you the issue of Dudley Hippodrome, which requires funding to get it back off the ground. It is a matter of culture, it is a matter of arts, and it would be very good for the local economy in an area that has suffered recently. So thank you for listening, Madam Commissioner. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Olaf STUGER
text: "blue card" question. Mr Etheridge, I know you as a Member who maintains very close contacts with his supporters and what I wonder, also in the context of what is happening in the Netherlands, is how is the atmosphere, if you come to your region, among the people who have lost their jobs there in recent years, who are in debt up to here and have to pay a lot of tax? What is the mood towards the EU and regional development? Do they even know the concept of regional development? Do they have anything to do with it? Do they see any of it?

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card answer. – The people from my area in the West Midlands do not understand the concept of regional development; they do not understand that it is all part of ‘cohesion’ and to make for easier European governance. What they do feel is that they want to be freer; they do feel, because they voted in large numbers for my party and always do, that the EU is not necessarily helpful to them. The hardships that have been suffered in my area, with unemployment and with wages being driven down by uncontrolled immigration, have caused the people of my area to feel very bitter towards the EU. They want change and they want to be free.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: Mr President, I have listened carefully to Corina Creu's comments and I am a little concerned, because we are at a turning point in the transfer of powers from the Member States, because in the long run what is being sought is for the regional authorities to replace the Member States. In fact, Corina Creu admitted this a little because she said that, when it comes to welcoming migrants, it is sometimes necessary to help cities against, in many cases, the opinion of the Member State. We are witnessing a real circumvention of sovereignty that is not acceptable. So my question is: what will be the political role of the Member States tomorrow when they are in deep divergence with a local authority?

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Let us now turn to catch-the-eye. There are a great many requests to speak. I do not think I can give everyone the opportunity to speak, because there are about fifteen requests. Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I would first like to congratulate Mr van Nistelrooy on the efforts of this resolution, which is long-awaited in our Committee on Regional Development, and Mrs Mihaylova for supporting such initiatives.  As you know, 80% of the European budget is managed by the Member States and a huge percentage of this money is spent in European municipalities through projects that are implemented on their territory. Often, however, a very large part of this money the municipalities have difficulty implementing them, turning it into projects. They say the only thing worse than not having money is having and not knowing what to do with it.  In order to avoid such a situation, I propose several things: First, support for municipalities "A to J", from the selection of projects through their submission, reporting and management, so that no mistakes are made; to create flexible funding. I know a lot of mayors in many countries who can't afford to run a project because they don't have money. We must encourage countries to establish compensatory mechanisms to do so.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would just like to make one comment to the Commissioner: on the one hand, we have a progressive strengthening of the role of local authorities – cities, regions and even macro-regions – with the urban agenda, but at the same time, with the reform of economic governance at European level, between the European Semester, budgetary constraints and reform programmes, a conditioning of the role of subsidiarity and cohesion policy. These are two trends which probably require additional reflection in order to understand also what the new role of cohesion policy is and, above all, what the role of local authorities is. I would like us to think carefully about this, so that in the coming months and years we will not be faced with two phenomena that do not converge but separate.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Madam Presidents, local and regional authorities are best versed in the problems faced by various environments. And that is why I think they need to play a greater role in managing structural and investment funds. However, I am afraid that in some Member States such bodies unfortunately do not have the necessary capacity, but also the experience to manage such programmes. Larger and more developed members who have been nurturing the principle of decentralisation for decades and strengthening the capacities of local and regional self-government units are in this sense with great advantage over smaller, newer and less developed members.  That is why I believe that the Commission should encourage Member States to decentralise and exchange best practices in the field of the organisation of local and regional self-government units with a view to making as many decisions as possible for the lives of citizens in the immediate vicinity of citizens in the foreseeable future.

name: Jozo RADOŠ
text: – Madam President, Madam Commissioner, I would first like to thank my colleagues from the Regional Development Committee for launching this very important topic. Every investment from each fund ends up in a local or regional environment and that is why their participation is important. Therefore, I agree and support the proposals of colleagues that local and regional self-government units have direct access to European funds or the setting of rules by which central authorities will be obliged to allow local and regional self-government units to participate in these funds on equal terms without party discrimination and without regional discrimination, which sometimes happens. I also call on the Commission to propose measures that will allow this mechanism to be monitored. With that, I am convinced that using European funds would be much better than it is now.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: – Madam President, what I would like to stress is that the fundamental principles of regional policy are partnership and multileash governance. However, they often do not apply in practice. We have the opportunity to see operational programmes adopted at national level in many Member States and not recognised by local and regional units.  That is why I propose that in the future, when we think about the development of cohesion policy, one of the rules we need to introduce is that really operational programmes are adopted regionally, that they be regional operational programmes and that this ownership of their implementation is at regional level.  What is very important is the inclusion of regional units in economic policies, this is often neglected. We are talking about the need to connect cohesion policy with the European Semester, but without the role of regional units, we cannot achieve this either.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is a fact that in cohesion policy the degree of consultation of regional and local authorities, from the stage of negotiations on legislation to the adoption of operational programmes, has increased little over time.
