Only a third of the Member States consulted in 2015 by the Council of European Municipalities and Regions set their own financial priorities in consultation with local authorities and regions. Municipalities and regions must be allowed to negotiate, within a stable legal framework, investments in priority areas essential for their development. It is essential that local and regional authorities are involved in the design, implementation and monitoring phases of programmes, for example by setting up joint task forces bringing together different levels of governance, socio-economic partners and civil society. The Commission must launch a public consultation as soon as possible on how to strengthen the role of regional and local authorities and then, on that basis, launch a formal initiative. The creation of a genuine partnership between Member States, regions and local authorities is essential to promote economic growth and the creation of sustainable jobs.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Colleagues, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. Local and regional authorities, which account for 70 percent of public investment, are undoubtedly a key player in the Structural Funds. Their role and commitment to shaping and implementing EU strategies is undoubtedly growing, but we must ensure that this takes the form of a genuine partnership, not just mechanical fulfilment by Member States of the obligations under the Regulations. I also see room to use their knowledge and experience in the European Fund for Strategic Investments, for example by involving them in the European Investment Advisory Hub. I believe that only genuine mutually trusting cooperation between local government, the Member States and the Commission will increase the effectiveness of cohesion policy and will translate into long-term benefits for the EU economy.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members of the European Parliament, thank you very much for your contributions. As far as I am concerned, you know very well, I believe that our main partners in terms of regional policy are represented by local and regional authorities, the presidents of the more than 280 regions. We have ongoing consultations. I believe that they are closest to people, they understand the local needs, policies and initiatives that can change people's lives in the area of job creation, innovation, health conditions, the environment, energy, transport. I know, on the other hand, that these regions have their own limits. Firstly, they need more than national authorities for budget support and co-financing of projects.  I also share your point of view: the role of cities is very important. I am grateful to the Dutch Presidency for attaching great importance to the urban agenda. More than 70% of Europe's population lives in cities in the European Union, be they capital or small and medium-sized cities. They are engines of growth and job creation.  I am also – and the whole European Commission is – grateful to the European Parliament for its support and contribution to the partnership principle, to which we are, of course, of major importance. I share Mr van Nistellrooij's view that a public debate is needed on how this principle of partnership and the principle of governance on various levels is applied.  Basically, next week I will be in the plenary of the Committee of the Regions, where we will discuss this subject, and I am sure that I will be very pleased to come before you and discuss this subject. I believe that an exchange of best practices is needed from this point of view. As I was saying, there are countries that have this culture, this tradition of developing projects together with civil society organisations, with academia. In other countries, local authorities basically consider that they are the only ones who can make decisions without consulting citizens and their representatives. So that is why we have paid close attention to ensuring that local and regional authorities are really involved in the negotiations of partnership agreements and operational programmes. You know very well that in the new programming period this principle represents an ex-ante conditionality.  I cannot answer all those who asked questions, but Mr Jakovčić asked a question that also came back to the speech of other colleagues. I would like to say that every country has the right to organise itself as it wishes. It is important that this organisation and the implementation of projects respond to the regulations and legality of the management of European funds. We have countries like Poland, for example, which is a centralised state, but which has performed very well in the area of European funds, but we also have, for example, the experience of France, which has now moved to a decentralised system and which works very well. Of course every country, as I said, has the right to organise itself as it wishes. In any case, we will continue to monitor how the partnership principle is implemented under Article 5 of the Common Provisions Regulation for European and Investment Funds.  On the issue of refugees, I would like to address your concerns. We are not forcing any state, no city, no region to use European funds. We have sent this letter to all ministers to let them know that we are willing to change operational programmes. We are aware that a year ago, when they were drafted, this refugee challenge did not exist. As I was saying, Italy is the only country that has called for the change of operational programmes and we have already directed EUR 220 million to mobile hospitals, kindergartens, social problems for the integration of migrants. Other countries, such as France, the Netherlands, Germany are already using European funds for the integration of migrants, but there is no link in our regulations between the allocation of European funds and the refugee issue.  I'd like to make one last point. I am quite amazed to see a UKIP representative talking about the need for European funds. I know you come from a less developed region, which has suffered a lot, where mines have been closed. I will be very pleased to join you and show the citizens of the United Kingdom to what extent cohesion policy has contributed to the retraining and creation of new jobs in such an affected region, and perhaps we will be able to contribute together to strengthening this idea of solidarity and the need for a united Europe. Thank you very much and, of course, are going to we are still discussing this issue.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: I have received one motion for a resolution tabled in accordance with Rule 128(5) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place shortly. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – EU cohesion policy is still the most important investment instrument covering all EU regions during the 2014-2020 programming period. At the same time, it is also an opportunity to start a process that is better bottom-up in order to ensure sustainable economic growth, support job creation, entrepreneurship and innovation at local and regional economic levels, as well as improve citizens' quality of life, build solidarity and strengthen the development of EU regions. The European Regional Development Fund Regulation provides that 5 % of the ERDF should be allocated to promoting integrated sustainable urban development actions, while bodies at urban, sub-regional and local level responsible for implementing sustainable urban strategies should be responsible for actions at least related to the choice of operations. I would therefore like to stress once again that strengthening the administrative capacity of local and regional authorities and reducing structural weaknesses are essential both during the programming and implementation phases of operational programmes, as well as in order to achieve a higher level of use of the ESI Funds. I therefore call on the Commission to ensure that local and regional authorities, their administrations and bodies are provided with capacity building support so that they can play their crucial role in cohesion policy, especially when implementation tasks are delegated to lower-level administrations, in particular urban administrations.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. – Local authorities are the main actors responsible for the implementation of cohesion policy. They are in direct contact with citizens and always meet their needs. However, in some Member States, excessive centralisation makes the local level less taken into account in the decision-making process. One step that precedes legislative initiatives is the process of public consultation of citizens. Unfortunately, there is little participation in these consultations by local actors in centralised states. Measures are therefore needed to increase the involvement of these authorities and to identify ways in which public consultations can become as attractive as possible.  Moreover, I am convinced that we can contribute to decision-making responsibility at these levels by encouraging participatory governance measures. We have at our disposal tools such as ITI and THE DLRC, which aim to implement local initiatives by increasing the involvement of actors and access to funding aimed at exploiting local development potential. Vertical partnerships between actors at different levels, as well as attracting private sector partners, guarantee the success of these initiatives.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. – The european structural and investment funds were designed to achieve sustainability and growth, which promote economic, social and cohesion development. As we know, economic and social preconditions are in place, which, among other things, contribute to and make these funds more accessible to the Member States. In addition to linking the European Structural and Investment Funds with the European Fund for Strategic Investments, the issue of multi-role play by local and regional authorities in managing the Funds is an important factor. In particular, small organisations or firms have in the past been subject to additional costs and time constriments due to excessive controls and a large number of bureaucratic rules. This amendment could therefore benefit from a more rational distribution of tools, as well as a streamlining accessibility and thus increasing users' motivation. If local and regional authorities are able to manage the funds in a more direct manner, the conditions can be formulated more smoothly and specifically in the specific territorial and other circumstances.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – EU cohesion policy is one of the best examples of multi-level governance. The involvement of regional and local authorities in decision-making is justified, as these authorities are the closest to citizens, are best aware of local development needs and their consultation strengthens the democratic dimension of the Union. The motion for a resolution encourages the exploitation of synergies between the EU Structural and Investment Funds and other EU programmes, in which local and regional authorities can play a useful role. At the same time, the motion draws attention to the fact that, although local and regional authorities were mostly consulted during the negotiations on partnership agreements and operational programmes, their involvement did not mean a full partnership. Furthermore, the level of consultation with the authorities varies from one Member State to another. I consider it important to strengthen the administrative and institutional capacity of local and regional authorities, as this will allow them to participate more effectively in shaping cohesion policy. At the same time, I believe that consultation with the authorities should not lead to an increase in the already heavy administrative burden on cohesion policy and a significant slowdown in decision-making.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. – ESIF represents the EU’s main investment policy tools with a total budget of €454 billion for 2014-2020. The ESIF budget for Romania will deliver a critical mass of investments for the following programmes: Rural Development Programme – €8,127,996,402; Aid for the Most Deprived Operational Programme €441,013,044; Human Capital Operational Programme €4,236,838,744; Administrative Capacity Operational Programme €553,191,489; European Maritime and Fisheries Fund Operational Programme €168,421,371; Large Infrastructure Operational Programme €9,418,524,484, €1,329,787,234; Regional Operational Programme €6,700,000,000; and the Technical Assistance Operational Programme €212,765,958. The allocated ESIF budget for my country totals €31,278,538,726 which represents approximately 13% of the total ESIF Budget. I support the calls in this report underlining the key role played by local and regional authorities in shaping and implementing EU’s strategies and in achieving cohesion policy objectives. The report reiterates that the European Code of Conduct and the reinforced partnership principle will set out legal involvement of local and regional authorities providing minimum requirements for their involvement in all phases of preparation and implementation of the operational programmes. The report concludes that these funds are essential for Europe’s as well as Romania’s ability to address medium and long-term development challenges.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. – Due to their closeness to citizens, local and regional authorities play a key role in shaping and implementing european union strategies. Through european union cohesion policy, local and regional authorities can create new jobs, stimulate entrepreneurial innovation and growth. Regional and local authorities need to make more efforts to achieve a higher utilisation rate for the European Structural and Investment Funds. As a result, it is essential to address the structural weaknesses of local and regional authorities in the operational programme design and implementation phase in order for these authorities to take a better position in cohesion policy. Cohesion Policy is a good example of multilevel governance with a bottom-up approach. In such an approach, local and regional authorities strike a balance in their dealing with the European Structural and Investment Funds between achieving greater economic, social and territorial connectivity and the impact of European Union policies at local and regional level. Local and regional authorities today face challenges such as globalisation, climate change, energy security and migration waves, and it should be taken into account that each region has its own specificities and specific needs.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. – Regional development cannot be achieved without the decisive involvement of local public authorities. The managers of European, urban or rural communities are best placed to decide priorities and programmes for local and regional development. Given the ongoing need to bring the decision closer to European citizens, I support the increasing role of local and regional authorities in shaping European investment policies. The call to the Commission is justifiable. Local authorities can play a decisive role in regional development, job creation and economic growth, only if we take into account the fact that non-federal states need procedures that bring local government closer to investment structures. The Commission must come up with concrete solutions to strengthen the local and regional role in the EU. Reduced resources at the level of some local governments remain the main impediment to the contracting and co-financing of massive development works, from transport and infrastructure to health or the environment. For example, how many of the projects that are under consideration or under way under the Investment Plan for Europe are initiated and managed by European local public authorities? Undoubtedly, too few.

name: Vladimir URUTCHEV
text: in writing. – Dear Colleagues, regional and local authorities are closest to citizens and best see local needs, policies and initiatives to improve citizens' lives – job creation, health, the environment, energy, transport, etc. and specific local policies.  In general, regional and local authorities must be able to participate in shaping pan-European and national policies that have an impact on regional and local levels. Unconditionally, there is a tendency to increase the level of consultation of regional and local authorities in cohesion policy, but this consultation is very different between Member States.  Cities are engines for economic growth and employment and an ideal platform for innovation and emerging businesses. Smart cities and smart specialisation strategies are two strands that can quickly become specific EU policies or initiatives. In this context, the EC should take an initiative to strengthen the role and impact of local and regional authorities on the management of the ESI Funds in order to serve European citizens in the most effective way.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on the human rights situation in Crimea, in particular of the Crimean Tatars (2016/2556(RSP)).

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: author. – Madam President, I think it is fitting and appropriate that this Parliament comes together in a joint resolution to highlight the human rights situation in the occupied Crimean territories. In particular, the Crimean Tatars have been persecuted from the very beginning of the Russian invasion. Their elected representatives have been prohibited from fulfilling their electoral duties pursuant to Ukrainian law. In fact, Russia has been carrying out repression against Crimean Tatars because there is a very widely expressed mistrust of this part of the population. We think that it is very important that Parliament expresses its solidarity. We are happy that we can share that together.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: Author. – Two years ago, a multinational group of MEMBERS of NATO's Parliamentary Assembly travelled to Kiev to hold talks on Ukraine's security in Verchów Council. It was composed of Federica Mogherini. Yanukovych was president at the time, the pacification of Maidan was supposed to happen in a few days, and the annexation of Crimea in a few weeks. At night, I would circle the Maidan, climb barricades, watch berkut faces, bend my forehead in places where snipers got the first victims, talk to ordinary people. I have no doubt that the will of these ordinary people has determined the changes in Ukraine, and it is leading the country towards change despite many difficulties. We owe them solidarity. I remind you of the policy of not appeasing the annexation of Crimea. Putin can conduct operational combinations to crush our solidarity. To undergo these operations would be a sign of great weakness on our part, and i therefore thank all my colleagues very much for taking up this subject. I ask you to adopt a resolution.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, human rights violations in Crimea have increased sharply since Russia's occupation and illegal annexation of the peninsula. Several international organisations have reported many violations against the Tatar community, the majority of which expressed objections to the Russian occupation and boycotted the referendum, the so-called referendum of 16 March. These abuses include abductions, enforced disappearances, violence, torture and extrajudicial executions, which the authorities have failed to investigate and prosecute. Those who refused to take Russian citizenship, for example, after annexation continue to suffer discrimination in all areas of political, social and economic life. The Ukrainian and Tatar media have been silenced and various journalists have therefore been forced to flee Crimea for fear of prosecution. We denounce this situation so that it ceases as soon as possible.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Author. – Madam President, I want to say that I am very pleased to finally discuss Crimea today. My political group has been trying for more than half a year to put the discussion on Crimea on the agenda of this assembly, and it must be said that we have had very serious opposition from the other political groups. The only group that supported us was the conservative one, until this month.  The reason is the ambiguous attitude towards Russia, in fact, and towards the occupation of the Crimean peninsula. We are at a time when a major political group in Parliament is asking us to go as an official delegation to Moscow. I think it is unacceptable to take such a step, until all our colleagues in Parliament who are blacklisted by the Kremlin are removed from this list, and also until Russia leaves Crimea. It seems to me that normalizing relations requires this step.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: Author. – Madam President, in Crimea we are seeing geopolitical interests once again stand before the lives of the population. We are concerned about the economic and social situation of the population, something that will not be resolved as long as the blockade remains. That is why we understand that it is necessary to lift it, so as not to bring the drama even more to the civilian population. And we are particularly concerned about the violation of human rights and the situation of the rights of the Tatar community and other ethnic minorities in this conflict. The rights of ethnic minorities and indigenous peoples must be respected in Crimea as well as anywhere in the world. Therefore, a United Nations-sponsored negotiation is necessary, as well as the necessary conditions for access by journalists, humanitarian aid and human rights organizations. It is urgent that they be able to act while this conflict is resolved.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: author. – Madam President, Russia’s president, Vladimir Putin, in a recent interview he gave to the German newspaper Bild said the following: ‘the nationalist group in the Ukrainian capital of Kyiv in February 2014 has hugely scared 2.5 million Russian people living in Crimea. So what did we do? We have not gone to war; we have not fired; not a single person was killed’. President Putin, you keep lying to the whole world. As the chief commander of your little, polite and green men, you bear a personal responsibility for those who have disappeared or been murdered since 2014 in Crimea. Let me read the following names of Crimean Tatars who lost their lives: Reshat Ametov, Timur Shaymardanov, Seran Zinedinov, Islam Dzheparov, Dzhevdet Islamov, Eskender Apsalyamov, Ruslan Ganiyev, Arlen Terekhov. The list is not complete. Let us not repeat the mistakes of the 20th century. Let us call things by their right names.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, our resolution supports the clear choice by Ukraine to pursue the European path and again draws the attention of the international community to the severe breaches of human rights in Crimea, which was illegally annexed by Russia. We strongly support the Crimean Tatars as an indigenous people who face discrimination and abuse because of their opposition to the occupying authorities. The European Union must continue its policy of non-recognition of the annexation and maintain the related sanctions against Russia. If the Russian authorities want to improve their relations with the European Union, they should withdraw from the Crimea and allow Ukraine to re—establish control over its territory. It is vital that international organisations, human rights NGOs and the media have unimpeded access to Crimea and that their presence is coordinated with the Ukrainian authorities. Therefore I welcomed the mission of the Special Representative of the Secretary-General on Human Rights of the Council of Europe. I also support the proposed ‘Geneva Plus’ format and believe that the question of Crimea’s return to Ukraine and efforts to stop the conflict in the East, specifically in the Donetsk and Luhansk oblasts, should not be decoupled. We know that the causes of these two problems are the same.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – I would like us to make it clear that all the important political forces in this Parliament are in favour of re-ingening the situation in Crimea, and the primary means of doing so is for putin and Putin-backed forces to stop the attacks on the Crimean people, including the Tatars. The way I see it, the ambitions here in this Parliament, which, by the way, reduce the weakening of Europe and the possibility of expressing our solidarity, are essentially doing Putin a favour. It is a gift to Putin every move here in the European Parliament, in the European Union, that disrupts our unity. So, for my part, I call on all forces to do so in favour of the sanctions imposed by the European Union against the Russians, and for no one to try to resolve them simply because there may be other reasons. Weakening European unity is the greatest sin we can commit.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Anyone who has ever visited Crimea in better times knows that this was a region with a vibrant tourism sector, a beautiful mosaic of different languages, cultures and traditions. I was there myself a few months before the annexation by Russia. A jewel on the Black Sea is now a peninsula of fear.  Since the illegal annexation, the methods of Putin's Russia have been used without scruples. We know what that means for the human rights situation. The attitude of the authorities comes down to :'think it', 'shut up' or 'go away'. Dissident voices are oppressed and persecuted. Journalists and pro-Ukrainian activists are outlawed and especially the Tatar community is targeted. Their media are being restricted, their mosques and cultural centres are being harassed and, worse, they are the target of kidnappings, murders and torture. Shame! History repeats itself for this proud people.  The Council of Europe delegation is not a day early. It will be crucial that all cooperation is required from Russia on the final conclusions of their report.

name: Kaja KALLAS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank – The reason why Russia is bullying or restricting the freedom of expression of the Crimean Tatars is because they are very critical of the authorities. When there was a referendum in Ukraine, they were most active in the streets protesting against the referendum. In the two years since Crimea has been annexed, the situation of the Crimean Tatars has deteriorated sharply. Their TV channel was closed, their schools could no longer learn Tatar, and the job is that if a person does not speak Russian and does not have that citizenship, they will not be able to work. It's only part of the list of how they're being bullied. Persecution actually violates not only human rights, but also jeopardising the preservation of cultural heritage. It is therefore Russia's duty to ensure that Crimean Tatars can live in a decent place in their historic homeland and preserve their cultural heritage.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: – Madam President, the right to education in Tartar and Ukrainian is systematically suppressed in Crimea. The number of Tartar schools and classes is decreasing. Freedom of speech is under threat. Some Tatar media have been forced to shut down. Cultural and symbolic elements of Tatar identity are restricted or suppressed. We should also condemn the exhosting and intimidation of Tatar political leaders. This also applies to Mustafa Jammeh, who has long pointed to the Russian Federation's efforts to occupy Crimea. Let me remind you that Mustafa was imprisoned in the USSR for three years in 1968 for criticizing the occupation of my country, Czechoslovakia. His prosecution by the Crimean occupation authorities for crimes under the Russian Penal Code cannot be accepted at a time when Crimea is still considered Ukrainian territory under international treaties. The Crimean Tatars need our support in times of non-freedom.

name: Kati PIRI
text: – Madam President, the two million people living in Crimea are facing unprecedented levels of human rights abuses. For the Tatar community in Crimea, like all who have categorically opposed the illegal occupation and annexation of Crimea, this means systematic persecution, intimidation, expulsion, abduction, violent attacks, torture, etc. with no legal redress. It also means that the local population has no access to the international bodies which all the people of Europe can turn to when their rights are being violated. We stand in solidarity with the Mejlis, the entire Crimean Tatar community and all Ukrainians who are in a vulnerable position for openly supporting the territorial integrity of Ukraine. I call on the Russian Federation and the de facto authorities in Crimea to grant unimpeded access for the independent experts of the UN, the Council of Europe, the OSCE and the High Commissioner for National Minorities.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: – Madam President, following Russia’s forceful and illegal annexation of Crimea in 2014, the peninsula’s Tatar population and Ukrainian minority have suffered a marked deterioration in civil and political liberties and other fundamental human rights. The Tatars’ very principled boycott of the imposed regime’s 2014 bogus referendum on Russian rule has exacerbated the historical enmity between Crimean Tatars and Moscow dating right back to Stalin’s brutal programme of Tatar deportation in the 1940s. Consequently, Tatar political leaders have been exiled, media outlets suppressed and Tatar public commemorations prohibited. Reports suggest that unlawful arrest and detention are becoming increasingly commonplace in the peninsula. The human rights situation in Crimea, therefore, remains extremely troubling. I unequivocally condemn Russia’s annexation of Crimea, which legally still belongs to Ukraine, and urge the de-facto authorities to respect the fundamental tenets of human rights in their dealings with the Tatars. The EU and the international community are watching very closely.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). Madam President, the European Union is produced and acting and has become the opinion of only certain countries and centres of power, especially Germany. If anything, we are hypocrites when we discuss the restrictions of religious activities in Crimea, at a time when Agia Sophia, although a temple of the Orthodox Christian faith, is forbidden to be used as a worship place for Christians by Turkey, which seeks to become a member of the Union.  You are talking about a violation of human rights by the occupying forces in Crimea. When was there an invasion and by whom in Crimea? The rapporteur did not tell us. At the same time, you turn a blind eye to the wretchedness of the Turkish occupying forces in Cyprus. I will describe it as a political perversion to want Turkey to supply you with jihadists, Islamic extremists, illegal immigrants and drugs from the Middle East, because otherwise it cannot be explained.  Turkey, which with its neo-Ottomanism and doctrine of strategic depth is interested in the minority of 12% of Tatars, whom it has been feeding and supplying for twenty years and leading you to the conflict with Russia. Avoid conflict with Russia. Find a common place of interest and try to normalise the situation in the wider region of Europe.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, I am pleased to be able to speak on this point and say one sentence, which has also been said by the previous speaker, Mr Szczecin. As a Czech, I am very proud that Tatar leader Mustafa Jamilyev protested against the occupation of Czechoslovakia in 1968, and I am glad that we are now notionally returning support to this nation, which was oppressed in the Soviet Union throughout the 20th century and is now being oppressed again by Russia. It is very good that a resolution is being drafted here today calling on Russia to refrain from oppressing the Tatars in order to respect their fundamental human rights. Sad facts have been told about how the Tatar media is being suppressed, how the Tatars are disappearing in Crimea. Only one number that has not yet fallen here – 20,000 Tatars left Crimea last year precisely because of this pressure and went to Ukraine. So the Tartars are leaving their homeland again, leaving Crimea. We cannot allow this, and we must put pressure on Russia and raise this issue permanently.

name: Marek JUREK
text: –It is good that today in Strasbourg you can hear the voice of the Crimean Tatars. This small nation, its situation is the most emphatic illustration of what are the consequences of the Russian annexation of Crimea. It is only a pity that we talk so little about what depends on us. Yesterday we had a debate before the next European Council. In the statement by the President of the European Commission, we have not actually heard at all about the annexation of Crimea, we have not heard at all about the situation in eastern Ukraine related to the expiry of the Minsk agreements, with the serious threat of a resumption of aggressive action by Russia, the pro-Russian forces. Finally, please, we have heard virtually nothing about the construction of Nord Stream 2. The construction of Nord Stream 2 turns sanctions against Russia into a farce. Let us react consistently. Let us show that action against international peace and security really provokes our response in what is up to us and let us be consistent.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: author. – Madam President, I ask for the opportunity to react to a personal attack, and I would like you to take note of this. In my remarks I welcomed the fact that six political groups came together for a joint resolution, and indeed this discussion shows that we are united. I regret, therefore, that Mr Preda has used his speaking time as a co-author to attack other colleagues, including me. He said that those who did not support EPP proposals earlier are showing an ambiguous attitude towards the Russian occupation of Crimea. I think this is untrue, insulting, unjust and splittist, and I strongly reject that accusation.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: This is based on Rule 164 so it is noted.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, almost two years have passed since the illegal annexation of Crimea and Sevastopol by the Russian Federation, which the European Union does not recognise and continues to condemn. In addition to being a grave violation of international law, the illegal annexation has had a serious negative impact on the human rights situation. The systematic curtailment of residents’ basic human rights and fundamental freedoms is an emblematic feature of the current situation on the peninsula. The imposition of Russian laws and citizenship has created a situation of legal uncertainty and discrimination. The Crimean Tatar community and Tatar residents supporting the territorial integrity of Ukraine are paying a particularly high price for the views they express. Public events in Simferopol to commemorate the 1944 deportation have not been allowed. Tatar media outlets have been closed and the Mejlis, a self-governing body of Crimean Tatars and its activists, has been prosecuted. The appearing cases of enforced disappearances, torture and killing of young Crimean Tatars have not been properly investigated so far. High Representative Mogherini discussed these cases when she met in person the representative of the Mejlis of the Crimean Tatar People in Ukraine in November 2015. Let me also stress the EU’s concern over the detention and sentencing of Oleg Sentsov and Alexander Kolchenko. Their case, which the EU has monitored, is in breach of international law and elementary standards of justice. The EU will remain vocal in demanding their immediate release and safe return to Ukraine. Finally, the EU has repeatedly called for full, free and unrestricted access for international human rights actors to the whole territory of Ukraine, including Crimea and Sevastopol. We welcome those missions which have taken place so far: the mission of the Council of Europe’s Commissioner for Human Rights, Nils Muižnieks, in autumn 2014; the unofficial mission of Turkish prominent persons in spring 2015; and the continued work of the non—governmental Crimean Field Mission on Human Rights. We also praise the efforts of the UN and OECD, autonomous institutions which have so far been denied access to the peninsula but document human rights abuses using a wide variety of sources. We very much hope that the most recent mission, dispatched by the Secretary—General of the Council of Europe last week and headed by Ambassador Gérard Stoudmann, will pave the way for an improved human rights situation in the Crimean peninsula.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: The debate is closed. The vote will be held at the end of the debates. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. – The Russian Federation has occupied the area of Crimea and Sevastopol against international law. Crimean Tatars along with Ukrainian soldiers have shown loyalty to Ukraine, thus protecting Ukraine's interests in the fight against Russian rebels and the Russian military. In doing so, the leaders of the Crimean Tatars - Mustafa Dzemilov and Refat Chubarov - are not allowed to enter the crimea area.  Crimean Tatars, Ukrainian journalists and activists, as well as Crimean residents who have expressed their public disagreement with the local authorities, are subject to all forms of torture and violence, kidnapping, eabusiness and murder. All those who have in any way opposed local authorities, including religious communities banned from gathering, do not have the option of extending the validity of identity documents.  The European Parliament condemns such a policy of human rights violations, discrimination against the population, prohibition and non-recognition of the right to extension of identity documents (passports), primarily to the Crimean Tatars by the Russian Federation, as ethnic minority groups are in these areas.  The EU is urging the Russian Federation to release prisoners including Oleg Sentov and Olexandro Kolchenko as well as other activists arrested in crimea. The EU also calls on Russia to investigate all forms of violence against prisoners in crimea and those deported to Russia.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: in writing. – I welcome the decision of the Council of Europe to send a delegation to assess the human rights situation on the Crimean Peninsula, especially because for over a year now no other international organisation was allowed in there. Following annexation, the changes carried out by the new authorities dramatically restricted a vast range of human rights of residents, particularly those who were opposed to the annexation, the Tatar minority but also Ukrainians. I would especially point out the suppression of the Mejlis – the self-governing body of Crimean Tatars – as well as the intimidation, expulsion or incarceration of prominent leaders of the Tatar community. I therefore strongly support the continuation of sanctions against Russia as long as the illegal occupation of Crimea and the blatant human rights violations continue.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. – The Russian Federation unlawfully annexed Crimea and Sevastopol and thus violated international law, including the UN Charter, the Helsinki Final Act, the Budapest Memorandum of 1994 and the 1997 Treaty of Friendship, Cooperation and Partnership between the Russian Federation and Ukraine.  During the illegal annexation of Crimea to the Russian Federation in March 2014, Ukrainians, including Crimean Tatars, and the Ukrainian army have shown great courage and loyalty to Ukraine and peacefully opposed the aggressive act of annexation. Targeted rights violations against the Tatar community have been reported, which in the majority opposed Russian annexation and boycotted the so-called referendum on 16 March 2014, in particular by implementing unspecified and overly broadly defined Russian legislation against extremists with the aim of intimidating or stipping opponents.  I therefore condemn all human rights violations against the population of Crimea, in particular crimean Tatars who do not accept the imposed rule of the so-called local authorities, in particular on the pretext of combating extremism and terrorism.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Russia is a permanent member of the UN Security Council and a member of the G8, which brings together the world's richest industrialised countries. The country has ratified a number of international human rights treaties, including the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, the Convention on the Rights of the Child, the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination. However, the current situation on the Crimean peninsula is far from stable. According to the findings of the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, violations of the rights of Crimean Tatars are becoming increasingly serious. Tatars become victims of violence, the so-called self-defense of Crimea with complete passivity on the part of the local militia – m.in cases of brutal beatings of Tatars are becoming more frequent. It is becoming common place for local authorities to violate the fundamental indigenous rights of the inhabitants of the diaspora in order to intimidate its members. In addition, the Federal Security Service of the Russian Federation is conducting a mass search of the homes of members of the Tatar diaspora on suspicion of possessing weapons and explosives. Members of the Tatar diaspora are also forced to accept Russian citizenship under threat of expropriation. The situation of the Tatar diaspora is further exacerbated by the fact that utilities such as water and electricity are supplied by Ukrainians, which may change in the event of annexation. So the Tatars became hostages to the Ukrainian-Russian conflict. One of the many solutions to the situation is the establishment of a forum composed of representatives of the Visegrad Group countries and the Baltic States, who are close to the issue of human rights violations in Crimea for geopolitical reasons.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on Bahrain: the case of Mohammed Ramadan (2016/2557(RSP)).

name: Alyn SMITH
text: author. – Madam President, there has been genuinely good cooperation across the House in the production of this really very solid resolution and, bluntly, I would hope so too. If we cannot unite on something like opposition to the death penalty, I do not think there is much hope for us. There are those in Bahrain who do feel that we focus too much upon the Kingdom; we criticise too much the lack of progress in Bahrain that we have seen in parts, and since there are other abuses in the region, why not focus upon them? Firstly, we do focus on other abuses in the neighbouring countries in the wider region, and secondly, in many ways it is a compliment, because there is a feeling within this House that there is scope for a dialogue with Bahrain that is actually going somewhere. There is actually a process towards reform that we can assist, and there are useful discussions to be had. It is important that we recognise the progress that Bahrain has made in a reform programme. There has been institutional reform; we have seen steps towards an independent judiciary; we have seen the establishment of ombudsmen; we have seen the establishment of the Prisoners’ Rights Commission and the special investigations unit; and there have been a number of declarations which have been really very positive. But that progress has stalled, and we need to see that progress continue. We can assist in that process by being vocal in our criticism but also constructive in our willingness to help. We must be vocal about our criticism of the sentencing to death of Mr Ramadan along with nine other individuals presently on death row within the Kingdom, and I hope we will be unanimous in our condemnation of those sentences. I would also, in a very solid resolution, pick out in particular paragraph 3: ‘Stresses the obligation to ensure that human rights defenders are protected and allowed to conduct their work without hindrance, intimidation or harassment’. Internal dialogue within Bahrain is vital for underpinning progress. We can assist with that process, and I hope we will unite around this resolution today.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is impossible to deny the failure of the Member States and the European Union on the Bahrain issue. What has been done in practice and what will be the next steps towards the release of imprisoned, tortured and ill-treated activists? To date, there has been a wonderful proxy activity between states, to which we ask for friendship and with which we always try to have wonderful relationships. For our part, we have in no way succeeded in protecting and protecting human rights activists and defenders.  Today, other facts highlight the abuses that continue in the country, such as the restriction of the right to expression and the right to peaceful protest. The case of Mohammed Ramadan, Husain Ali Moosa and Nabeel Rajab, who were arbitrarily arrested and tortured only for exercising their rights, is clear proof of this. In the light of these facts, it is appropriate for the European Union and the Member States to work a strategy, especially on the major foreign players operating in Bahrain, to exert economic and diplomatic pressure in order to secure the release of illegally imprisoned activists and prisoners.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in the dramatic clash that is inflaming the Gulf area and in which two regional powers such as Iran and Saudi Arabia, committed to imposing their hegemony, are pitted against each other, Bahrain is taking part, with repeated violations of human rights in the face of political dissidence. Mohammed Ramadan, whom we are dealing with today, is just another activist in the crosshairs for having had the courage to denounce government policies in total contradiction to human rights.  By the way, another case we have recently dealt with is that of the activist Nabeel Rajab, who is still banned from leaving the country despite his release. The situation is made all the more alarming by the numerous reported cases of police use of the practice of torture. All this is part of a widespread logic that tends to reduce the space for civil society and to intensify state control over the media. We therefore express our deep concern and would ask the Bahraini authorities to respond positively to our requests.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Author. – Madam President, I would like to say first of all that this resolution is a great compromise and is a compromise of all parties. In the end, the European People's Party supported it, but I must start by saying that we had a number of reservations about this text and that we were not entirely united in how the text was created. And this text also shows you another thing about how to verify your information. Some groups tried to put information in the text that turned out to be false and that could not be verified from neutral sources. I would like to appeal, first of all, with this resolution to the Government of Bahrain, to examine the case of Muhammad Ramadan, together with other cases where human rights violations are suspected, and I also want to applaud some of the progress bahrain has made in the death penalty in recent years.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: author. – Madam President, there are clearly legitimate concerns surrounding the arrest and trial of Mohammed Ramadan, and my group calls on the Bahraini authorities – and His Majesty in particular – to carry out a full investigation into the allegations of torture, suspending any convictions, particularly the death penalty, until this process has taken place, and to review the sentences where appropriate, following the conclusions that have been made. Nevertheless, the proposed joint text today, in our view, is far too strong in its general condemnation of this fragile island state, which is making huge efforts to improve its governance and human rights situation, for us to support it and to sign it. It fails to recognise the security risks that Bahrain faces, including external interference by neighbouring Iran. My country, the United Kingdom, has a tradition of strong ties with the Kingdom of Bahrain, dating right back to the foundation of the modern state – when it was its initial protector – to today, when construction is commencing on a Royal Navy base, as agreed between United Kingdom and Bahrain in 2014, which serves to remind us of the close security ties we have and the important role that Bahrain and its tolerant , multi-confessional state plays in the region’s security.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: Author. Madam President, on the occasion of the Spring of Peace in 2011, almost half of Bahrain's population took to the streets. They were mostly Shiites, an oppressed majority, but their demands were democratic and social. They did not find an echo, and Saudi Arabia intervened to restore order. NGOs estimate that there are 3,000 political prisoners. The country has the second largest prison population in the Arab States. The entire population is restricted in its freedoms. The fight against terrorism is also being exploited here. The country seemed to be on the road to abolishing the death penalty, but ten convictions have just been handed down. The loss of nationality is also instrumentalized, more than 208 in a few months. If the Bahraini authorities are truly ready to embark on the path of reform, it is time that they implement the 26 recommendations of the independent commission of inquiry and put an end to the practice of torture and the convictions obtained on that basis. Progress is being judged on the facts and, at the moment, the least that can be said is that in Bahrain, we are not going in the right direction.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: author. – Madam President, this week many of the people here – just like I did – heard from the authorities in Bahrain. Those authorities would like to focus on energy, security and other issues of mutual concern, and I too would prefer not to have to ask the Bahraini authorities again to stop torture, to stop repressing minority opinions, to stop revoking people’s citizenships, and now – the worst punishment of all – to stop the death penalty. Mohammed Ramadan is one of 10 people on death row in Bahrain, but he is the first to have exhausted all legal appeal mechanisms. We urgently call on the Bahraini authorities to reinstall the moratorium on the death penalty. More broadly, the best way – and in fact the only way – to develop fruitful and deep cooperation between Bahrain and the European Union is for them to unequivocally respect the rights of all people in Bahrain, to grant the Special Representative of the UN access to the country and full access to detainees at facilities, and to make sure that it respects the rights of people.

name: Ramona Nicole MĂNESCU
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, I am categorically against the death penalty and the use of torture and I believe that nothing can justify the use of these measures by any government. I hope that the Bahraini Government will also reconsider these measures, and I believe that I can do so, because they have shown very good involvement and a very positive trajectory in this regard.  However, I believe that no matter how many resolutions we make in the European Parliament against small Gulf states, as long as we continue to use a double standard in our dialogue and in our relationship with third countries, we will fail to be truly defenders of human rights. A recent report by Amnesty International shows us an Iran that leads the top of the states that use the death penalty and very frequent executions, a frequency of about two to three executions per day.  Madam President, I believe that when we stop expressing ourselves selectively about these human rights abuses, we will really be able to support people where they need it, including in Iran.

name: Ana GOMES
text: On behalf of the S&D Group– Madam President, five years after the first pro-democracy demonstrations in Bahrain, reports of intense political repression continue to come to us, including arbitrary arrests, torture, violence against demonstrators and political opponents and other human rights violations, such as court sentences against activists such as Nabil Rajab, who were sentenced last month to six months in prison for a tweet.  The use of the anti-terrorism law to silence activists and political opponents is a common practice of repressive regimes, but we are particularly concerned about such a law that was used to sentence Mohamed Ramadan to the death penalty who was allegedly tortured.  It is urgent to reintroduce the moratorium on the death penalty as a first step towards its abolition in Bahrain, and we have already called for royal forgiveness to commute the sentence of Mohamed Ramadan. I hope that the Member States and the High Representative will also make themselves heard in this request. It is urgent that the UN Special Rapporteur on Torture be able to visit Bahrain and be given unrestricted access to all detainees and all places of detention.  Finally, I take this opportunity to leave my solidarity with all the bahraini activists who are wrongfully imprisoned, including those I know, such as Ibrahim Sharif, Abduladi al Khawaja, Mohamed Al-Mokhtar and Sheikh Ali Salman.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, tá áthas orm labhairt ar an ábhar tábhachtach seo, ach cosúil le Feisirí eile, ba mhaith liom ar dtús a rá go bhfuil a lán dul chun cinn déanta ag Bairéin, agus tá comhoibriú maith idir an tAontas agus Bairéin maidir le trádáil agus a lán áiteanna eile.  Ach ní hé sin le rá nach ceart dúinn féachaint ar na rudaí atá mícheart agus go háirithe go bhfuil rudaí imithe ar gcúl maidir leis an bpionós báis ó 2011. Níl sé sin ceart agus téann sé i gcoinne coinbhinsiúin idirnáisiúnta. Dá bhrí sin caithfimid brú a chur orthu deireadh a chur leis sin, go háirithe mar a bhaineann le Mohammed Ramadan agus an tslí gur éirigh leo teacht ar an gcinneadh sin: triail mhífhéaráilte agus foréigean á fhulaingt aige.  Ach ag deireadh ba chóir dúinn grúpa oibre a bhunú idir an tAontas agus Bairéin chun caint ar na rudaí seo agus chun cearta daonna a chur chun cinn.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, I would like to express my heartfelt solidarity with Mohammed Ramadan and with his family and loved ones. It is the responsibility of all conscientious citizens in this world to stand up against arbitrary arrest, brutal torture and the death penalty, no matter where they take place. I also wish to use this opportunity to speak about the unfounded arrest and ill treatment of children in Bahrain: 237 cases of children detained by Bahraini authorities were reported in 2015 alone. Many are subject to ill treatment and beatings and made to confess to crimes they did not commit. The cases most recently reported are those of: Sayyid Ali Abbas Mohammed, the brothers Jassem and Hassan Mohammed Hassan, Fadhel Mohammed Hassan, Sayyid Fadhel Saeed Shams and Sayyid Mohammed Hashem – all teenagers who have been arrested in recent months who must be returned safe and sound to their families. In 2013 this Parliament issued a resolution calling on Bahrain to apply the Convention on the Rights of the Child, to which it is a party. I would like to reissue that call here: the Bahraini authorities must release Mohammed Ramadan and all child prisoners.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: – Madam President, we are currently witnessing a debate in many countries on how to strike the desired balance between freedom and security. Even if Bahrain is going in the right direction, we cannot overlook the case of Muhammad Ramadan and other people sentenced to death. At this point, the execution of the death penalty in his case can only be prevented by the pardon of the Head of State. I therefore join the appeal to the Bahraini authorities to reinstate the moratorium on the death penalty as a step that will lead to the abolition of the death penalty in the future in order to continue reforms of judicial and police regulations in the spirit of respect for human rights.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the regression of Bahrain towards the practice of the death penalty is a cause for concern. Fundamental rights to a fair trial are denied in that country and many people are tortured during detention and interrogation. It is appalling that these practices are carried out systematically and on a large scale, despite the many promises of reform. On December 29, 2014, a Bahraini criminal court sentenced Mohammed Ramadan and Husain Ali Moosa to death for their alleged involvement in a bomb attack in February 2014. Both defendants claim to have been subjected by the authorities to torture in order to induce them to confess to the crime. Economic and diplomatic pressure must be brought to bear on the Government of Bahrain for a moratorium on the death penalty, geared towards the abolition of this practice, and investigations must be launched into reports of torture by those condemned to death. Finally, the death penalty for Mohammed Ramadan and Husain Ali Moosa and all those sentenced to death must be commuted.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, let me first stress that since the events of 2011 the EU has been closely monitoring the situation in Bahrain. The EU has been consistently engaging with local authorities at all levels, maintaining constant contacts with a wide range of Bahraini stakeholders and activists. Bahrain is an important partner in the Gulf region and has an important role to play in ensuring the stability of the Gulf region, which can best be achieved by strengthening the existing framework for the protection of human rights and individual freedoms. The EU will therefore continue to maintain an active dialogue with the country and its government and support Bahrain’s stability and development. We consider that this objective can be best achieved through a process of inclusive national reconciliation, leading to gradual political and socio-economic reforms based on dialogue and tolerance. Like many in Europe, we have been concerned by the death penalty sentence imposed on Mr Mohammed Ramadan and Mr Husain Ali Moosa for their alleged involvement in the February 2014 bomb explosion which killed a police officer, a sentence upheld by the Bahraini Court of Cassation on 16 November 2015. The EU is unreservedly opposed to the use of capital punishment under all circumstances, and its universal abolition will continue to remain a cornerstone of the EU’s foreign policy. Allegations regarding their possible mistreatment in detention, as well as the basis for their conditions, should also be fully investigated. The EU, both in Brussels and through its delegation in Riyadh, accredited to Bahrain, will continue to liaise with the Bahraini authorities to advocate the protection and promotion of human rights and fundamental freedoms, as per Bahrain’s international commitments, the recommendations set out by the Bahraini Independent Commission of Inquiry and the recommendations made during Bahrain’s universal periodic review process. The EU will continue to call on the Bahraini Government to act proportionately in all cases to protect the rights of individuals indicted as a result of criminal charges, as was done during the second visit of the EU Special Representative for Human Rights, Stavros Lambrinidis, in May 2015. On this occasion, the EU conveyed again its preoccupation as to the imposition of the death penalty, recalling its principled opposition to this inhumane and degrading punishment. The EU, in close coordination with the EU Member States represented in Manama, has been closely following developments related to these individual cases and to the overall human rights situation in the Kingdom of Bahrain. The European Union has expressed formally on many occasions that violence is not justified in any circumstances. The EU has also constantly called for transparent and due process and for the proper investigation of all alleged cases of ill-treatment and of torture. Bahraini human rights institutions should effectively tackle these matters in a transparent way, while the robust recommendations stemming from the National Human Rights Institution should be implemented in the interest of all the citizens. In this regard, the many steps taken by the Bahraini authorities to implement the recommendations of the Bahraini Independent Commission of Inquiry are positive and have the potential to improve the human rights situation in the country, but more is needed. The Ministry of the Interior’s ombudsman, the Prisoners and Detainees Rights Commission and the National Institution for Human Rights have an important and pro-active role to play by fulfilling their mandate in full independence and transparency. Let me once again assure you that we will continue to remain seized with the case of Mr Mohammed Ramadan and Mr Husain Ali Moosa, and to voice the EU’s concern through appropriate channels.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: The debate is closed. The vote will be held at the end of the debates. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. – I did not support the urgency resolution concerning the human rights situation in Bahrain and the case of Mohamed Ramadan. Although it is important that the European Parliament attaches a high priority to the human rights situation in every country with whom it develops cooperation, I nevertheless consider Bahrain a country which, in the difficult overall situation of the Middle East and Persian Gulf, represents a good example of how a small country with a complicated ethnic and religious background can preserve its stability and maintain a constructive role in regional and international relations. It calls for a sensitive political approach, with no less importance of human rights and human dignity, but has to be put in the context of the overall situation in the wider region and of the standards of democracy and respect for human rights in this region. I consider that the European Parliament and European institutions have enough capability to observe and influence the political process of democratisation in Bahrain without portraying the country as a specific case of violation of human rights. We should stand for the respect of the rule of law and human rights in Bahrain and at the same time support its stability.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on the case of the missing book publishers in Hong Kong (2016/2558(RSP)).

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: Author. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The case of the five Hong Kong booksellers is a matter of great concern, especially since this case, in which people first disappear and then reappear in China under mysterious circumstances, is not confined to these five booksellers. It also concerns, for example, a former columnist for the Southern metropolis Daily newspaper, Li Xing, or the son of two Chinese human rights lawyers. I believe that we in the European Parliament should make it very clear that this apparently pericipable practice of forced return or kidnapping to China is completely unacceptable. I would like to point out that two of these five booksellers enjoy the citizens' rights of European Member States. That is why we, as European citizens, are also concerned. The Chinese authorities are deceiving themselves about what they are doing. There is an ancient Chinese proverb, that is, the stone they have raised will fall on their own feet. That seems to me to be the case here too. What is being practiced undermines respect for the rule of law in Hong Kong, undermines the commitment to the motto "one country, two systems," undermines China's respectability. We should point out to China that it is thus opposed to international rules.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the facts say that there are fewer and fewer openly speaking people in China, even fewer than they publish. The 2016 chinese publishing season opens with yet another controversy related to censorship and freedom of opinion. Corrente Poderosa publishes books that the Beijing regime considers prohibited and that are therefore outlawed on the continent, but are available instead in the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region. The texts have been put on the index because they attack the Government of the People's Republic. 2015 celebrated the 40th anniversary of diplomatic relations between the European Union and China. The strategic partnership is of fundamental importance for relations between the European Union and China. I believe, however, that it is only appropriate for the European Union to deepen these economic and trade links if there are visible and tangible improvements in the human rights situation. The Union must strive to strengthen democracy, the rule of law, the independence of the judiciary, transparency and freedom of expression. We must avoid being indifferent, especially after these events.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in the last four months, the tracks of the five Hong Kong publishers have been lost. Two of them, Gui Minhai and Lee Bo, are European citizens of Swedish and British nationality respectively. It is feared that the five publishers have been seized by the authorities of the People's Republic of China for political reasons. In fact, these disappearances are most likely linked to the publication of literary works critical of the Beijing government. Furthermore, the fact that Lee Bo has been taken from Hong Kong territory is not only a clear violation of human rights, but also an alarming intemperance on the part of the authorities and, above all, the lack of respect for the autonomist principle of political and legislative division between China and Hong Kong, known as 'one country and two systems'. There is therefore an extreme concern about the fate of European citizens and other personalities involved, and it is necessary, given the specific gravity and strong censorship of freedom of expression in China, for the European Union to raise this issue very clearly with the Chinese authorities.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: I apologise, but we are not taking blue cards because we are a bit tied to the time.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: author. – Madam President, last January thousands protested in Hong Kong to voice their concern about the disappearance of five independent local publishers and booksellers who are said to have been taken to mainland China against their own will, and we certainly share the grave concern of many thousands of Hong Kong citizens about their whereabouts and wellbeing. Hong Kong has internal autonomy, a framework of the system ‘one country, two systems’, which provides for free speech and citizens’ liberties. So we would like to remind the Hong Kong authorities that the independence of book editors, journalists and bloggers must be safeguarded, and we call for an immediate end to human rights violations and political intimidation.

name: Bas BELDER
text: Author. – In preparing for this debate, I came across a wry joke in a famous Hong Kong newspaper, the South China Morning Post, and the next one: the quickest way to cross the border with the People's Republic of China from Hong Kong is to open a bookshop or a publishing house. I would add that even without valid travel documents, this is possible. See the abrupt disappearance late last year of publisher Lee Bo. And yes, if Beijing's arm reaches so far and so deep in Hong Kong, the creators of politically unwanted jokes towards the Xi regime will be more and more wary. It remains to be seen whether the new owner of the South China Morning Post will tolerate critical, independent journalists.  Madam President, the EU must not let China get away with flagrant violations of the 'one country, two systems' principle because of competing economic interests of the Member States. After all, our divisions towards China give Beijing a free hand in a policy of divide and trade.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: Author. – Madam President, human rights are inalienable and indivisible. This means that respect for human rights must be analyzed by paying attention to all rights, not to one another and not to one another, depending on the interest we want to defend. Unfortunately, the Urgent Resolutions of this House increasingly fall into the mistake of responding only to the political interest of the grand coalition.  Hong Kong is an autonomous territory with special status within China. Its particularities are different from those of China and so are its allies. We must denounce the growing deterioration of freedom of expression in Hong Kong, as the disappearance of the five libreries shows. But we also have an obligation to remember that in Hong Kong homosexuals suffer every day from legal barriers that heterosexuals do not suffer. This is gender discrimination and is a violation of human rights. There are also more than three hundred and twenty thousand immigrant women who practice as domestic workers in a situation of semi-slavery, in the absence of rules that guarantee their rights, and this is also a flagrant violation of human rights. Let's stop cynicism when we talk about human rights and defend them all at once.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Madam President, five journalists and booklets from Mighty Current, known for publishing works critical of the Chinese regime, have mysteriously disappeared in the last months of Hong Kong, in conditions that appear to be coming out of an Agatha Christie book.  When Hong Kong returned to Chinese rule, it adopted the "one country, two systems" model, and this formula allowed the conservation of unknown freedoms of expression in the rest of China. However, with the seizure of Mr. Xi Jinping in 2012, repression and persecution of publishers and booklets in the territory intensified. The conditions of the disappearance of these five publishers seem to cross an intolerable border: China's security agencies operating in the former British colony on the sidelines and in absentia from hong kong's legitimate authority.  The European Union must firmly support Hong Kong's civil society, which has so courageously fought for the defence of its freedoms and cultural identity and clearly demonstrate to the Chinese regime that these values are not subjugated to the logics of the World Trade Organisation or to the statutes of a market economy.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for China is in trouble: economic growth is at its slowest in twenty-five years, taiwan's election was won by a Democratic candidate and announced the end of China's influence on the island, and in Hong Kong, under mysterious circumstances, book publishers are beginning to disappear. The disappearances of the booksellers are abducted because their publications were critical of the authorities in Beijing. The case of their disappearance appalled seven million Hong Kong, in January thousands of residents took to the streets under the slogan "No to political kidnappings". The future of Hong Kong freedom is at stake. There have been concerns about whether Beijing intends to maintain hong kong's autonomous status, which enjoys freedoms in accordance with the accepted principle: one country, two systems.  The European Parliament, in its resolution, expresses serious concern about the situation, but calls on the mainland authorities of China and Hong Kong to clarify this matter as soon as possible.

name: Jo LEINEN
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her In accordance with the "one country, two systems" principle and Article 27 of the Basic Act, Beijing has promised the people of Hong Kong freedom of expression and communication. That is why the information that has recently been attacked is irritating journalists who have written critical reports or comments. The mysterious disappearance of the five booksellers has raised global concerns about whether the guarantees from Beijing still apply to Hong Kong or whether they no longer apply. Publishing books is not prohibited in Hong Kong. That is why the booksellers have not planned or done anything illegal. We therefore call on the governments in Hong Kong and Beijing to provide information on the whereabouts of these booksellers and, unless they have done anything criminally relevant, to release them immediately. We also call on the Commission and the European External Action Service to shed light on the situation and to work for the release of the booksellers.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Madam President, the disappearance of five employees of the same publishing house, thought to be critical of China, sings horror in Hong Kong. Bookstores take political works off the shelves. Publishers owners of shops selling books banned on the continent feel threatened. The five missing worked for a company known for its books reluctant to the Chinese government. Publisher Li Bo's case invokes particular concern. He disappeared from his home in Hong Kong, contrary to the other four. Three employees disappeared while in southern China, thailand's fourth.  The practice of kidnapping and forced removals to China is unacceptable. We have a duty to provide an open space to hear different opinions. China tramples on the introduced principle of one country - two systems and this kind of behavior tramples on freedom of speech and the dignity of people which is unacceptable.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, last month five well-known Hong Kong publishers disappeared. They were known for their criticism of the Beijing government for behind the scenes of Chinese rule and for various scandals. It is therefore a given that Hong Kong public opinion is now convinced that Beijing's leadership is responsible for the disappearance of these five well-known publishers. That is why we also have several protests by Hong Kong residents against the Government of China, calling for the release of the missing, but also for the consolidation of the right to freedom of expression of speech.  The European Union must therefore oppose the violation of human rights taking place in Hong Kong, and defend the freedom of speech and expression of publishing houses, journalists and citizens. Finally, all the Member States of the Union should require a thorough examination of the specific disappearance of the five publishers.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, I would like to join the debate taking place here and support the motion for a resolution as put forward by the rapporteurs. I think there are two lines to this story. The first one was clearly mentioned here, i.e. the fate of the five booksellers who mysteriously disappeared, and we, including the Commission representatives, should press China to explain whether it has so-called "fingers crossed" in this disappearance and what happened to these people. That's one story. But the other, which I think is just as serious, is how communication between China and Hong Kong takes place, and whether or not the principle – one country, two systems – is preserved. And this particular story of five people shows that the two-regime system is not being maintained, and that China is trying to steer hong kong's rights. We should support Hong Kong students, hong kong's opposition in the fight for further democratization in Hong Kong, in the fight for a better right to vote. It's our duty.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in China today, not only five booksellers, five publishers, have disappeared completely, but the much-vaunted, but completely violated, 'one country, two systems' principle has completely disappeared. There is no longer any need to hide, ladies and gentlemen. Regime censorship now works hard against the critical activity and free expression of anyone who is in any way disputing the government's actions. These citizens have paid the price and many others will follow. I ask you, at last, to start using double standards, depending on the situation. We cannot think that China's geopolitical and economic weight will affect our attitude. We must therefore immediately demand the release of these people who have been arrested and made to disappear, even worse irregularly, and perhaps confessions with torture will also be extorted from them, and ask China to respect the international agreements it has signed. No more two-faced Europe. We must for once be truly consistent with what we should be defending.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I am also of the opinion that the disappearance of two booksellers, who are, moreover, even European citizens, is unfortunately only one of a series of human rights violations in China, namely Hong Kong. And let's remember what China promised when it took Hong Kong into its administration after Britain. It must be said that hong kong citizens have become accustomed to the level of rights, and instead of what China has promised, there is a fundamental violation of human rights, pressure to change the state order. Human rights violations are long-standing, systematic, we have seen this in the protests of these people. I want to support the proposed resolution and really call on China to respect what it committed to when it took Hong Kong from The United Kingdom.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: – Madam President, in Hong Kong today we are witnessing violations of the Constitution. Indeed, the arrests and abductions of booksellers who sell or self-publish permitted literature, and their subsequent torture for confession to drunk driving, speaks eloquently of the true nature of a Chinese regime that does not even respect its own laws and deviates from the principle – one country, two systems. We have experienced similar practices in various forms in many European countries recently, so some of us feel complicated in standing up for similarly discriminated against everywhere today. I am therefore unequivocally in favour of what is said in the motion for a resolution, in particular point 9, that relations between the European Union and China must exist in an effective open dialogue on human rights. Just a resolution is not enough.

name: Corina CREȚU
