text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members of the European Parliament, continuing lack of precise information about the well-being of five Hong Kong residents associated with the publishing house Mighty Current is extremely worrying. Two of them are EU citizens: Gui Minhai is a Swedish national and Lee Bo is a British national. Gui Minhai was reported missing in Thailand in mid-October. As the Hong Kong chief executive has stated, it would be a violation of the basic law if mainland law enforcement agencies have indeed been operating in Hong Kong. This would be inconsistent with the ‘one country, two systems’ principle. Respect for freedom of expression underpins all free societies. The relevant authorities in China, Hong Kong and Thailand should investigate and clarify the circumstances of the disappearances in conformity with the rule of law. A statement by the spokesperson of High Representative Mogherini on the disappearance of individuals associated with the Mighty Current publishing house in Hong Kong was released on 7 January. We are in contact with the Hong Kong authorities and are working closely with the UK, Sweden and the head of the EU mission in Hong Kong on this matter. We have also requested further clarifications from the Chinese authorities in Beijing. At the moment there has been no clear, reliable answer from the Chinese authorities to the request for information from the Hong Kong Government and Sweden and the UK on this issue. We will continue to call upon the Chinese authorities to clarify the status of all persons associated with the Mighty Current Hong Kong publishing house and to grant consular access to EU citizens concerned.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: The debate is closed. The vote will be held at the end of the debates. (The sitting was suspended for a few moments)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item is voting time. (For results and other details of the vote: see Minutes.)

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: – Mr President, regarding paragraph 7 of the oral amendment, it is just a technical correction of part of the sentence which was agreed during the negotiations; it simply sticks with the text that was agreed among all the Groups in the negotiations.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: – Mr President, for the next amendment by the EPP, we reached a compromise just before the voting started, so I would like to thank the shadow rapporteur for the EPP for accepting to withdraw their amendment, Amendment 8, and agreeing to just take out of the original paragraph the passage that reads, ‘and calls for the drafting of further legislation and statutes in line with that ruling’. So that would be my compromise with the EPP, and I would like to ask all of the shadows to also agree on that. We did not have time to talk to you because it was just done at the last minute, and I would like to ask you to accept that.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: – Mr President, on behalf of the EPP Group I would say that I agree to Ms Lunacek’s suggestion. (Mixed reactions)

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Mr President, the negotiators of the various political groups have agreed to ask that this vote be postponed to the next mini-school. Thank you for accepting it.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: – Mr President, I chaired the negotiations on this resolution, which is on the plenary agenda at the request of my Group. In discussion between the S&D Group and the EPP Group, we will jointly be supporting a postponement. It is just for two weeks. There is a humanitarian catastrophe in Yemen. We want this Parliament to resolve its position, but there is a very important delegation of the Foreign Affairs Committee this weekend, and we believe our influence to implement what we believe in will be maximised by delaying this vote. There are some that are trying to suggest that the postponement is part of a plot to undermine a strong Parliament position. I am delighted that we have that position, and I am in fact very grateful that the EPP has signed up to the joint text, which I know they were unable to commit to at the meeting. They have now done so. So there are no plots, but this is the best way to influence what we believe in.

name: Alyn SMITH
text: – Mr President, I have much respect for the rapporteurs, but we do not agree to this postponement. The situation in Yemen is grave. We have been working on this resolution for a long time. There is a majority in this House to take a strong and progressive position on an urgent conflict where people are dying on a daily basis. There is no good reason why we should delay this. The resolution is good to go now. We have a majority in this House for a strong and progressive position. There is no good reason to delay it. I hope we vote on it today.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: We now come to the explanations of vote. I must inform you that we have received many requests for oral explanations of vote. If we do not get through, I have to tell you now that we can only continue the sitting until 2.45 p.m. at the latest, so that the services can prepare for the resumption of the sitting at 3 p.m. The remaining explanations of vote may then be submitted in writing, if necessary. Mr Arnott has raised a point of order.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Mr President, is this place supposed to be a student union debating society or is it a parliament? I am speaking about a couple of matters. We have had that oral agreement with the EPP and ALDE Groups where the text of the report is changed at the very last minute, so the rest of us do not actually have a clue exactly what the text is that we are voting on. But more seriously, on the humanitarian situation in Yemen, when we see two political groups, with a carve-up between the EPP and the S&D, deciding that something is going to be delayed for a couple of weeks. They do not give us a proper explanation. They just force it through by weight of vote. Seriously, this is not what democracy is all about, and it is high time that we learned what it is in this place.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mr Arnott, I would like to thank Mr Arnott for his work We are not a student club, we are a democracy. That is why we voted beforehand, and the majority of the House voted in favour of adjournment. That was the one case you raised. The second case is that your group had the opportunity to rise. I asked whether there was anything to be said against Mrs Lunacek's oral amendment, and no one stood up at all. I asked if there were any objections. No one has risen, not even you. You could have done that earlier. That request was therefore put to the vote, as requested orally. This is entirely in line with the rules of this House.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Mr President, the problem was that it was not clear what it was we were supposed to be voting on or not voting on. I did not know whether I objected to it or not. We did not know what it was.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Yes, Mr Arnott! It is usually the case that there is a person responsible in a political group for every operation in this House. If I were the person in charge and I was not sure what it was about, I would have given my group the signal to rise up for safety. That did not happen, however, and that is why the motion was put to the vote. And that was absolutely right.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Serbia's negotiations and rapprochement with the EU are only to be welcomed. There are many of us who hope that new chapters in negotiations will be opened so that both Serbia and other Balkan countries will soon become members. The problem is, you're wavering. There is still an idea that Serbia can have two mothers, both the EU and Russia, because while Serbia is reaching towards the EU, it has not followed the EU's foreign policy towards Russia.  It has allowed Russia to dominate Serbia's energy market and has thus been exposed to future pressures. It is preparing a joint military exercise with Russia and supports the statements aimed at dividing Bosnia and Herzegovina. It therefore feels important to add to the report an encouragement to Serbia to continue on the path of rapprochement with the EU.  That is where Serbia's future lies. It also feels important to encourage the Commission to help Serbia to detach itself from Russia. Serbia may be the EU's bridge to Russia, but then you must first be part of the EU. I would like to add this to my vote, which is why I choose to vote for both Serbia, and it is in the interests of the European Union and Serbia to make this possible.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, Ukraine has had more than its portion of human suffering. In a new history of that vast country, Serhii Plokhii makes the argument that, between 1932 when Stalin began the famine and 1944 when the last of the Nazi troops left, it was the most dangerous place in the world to be a human being. Even by the standards of that troubled and turbulent country, the Crimean Tatars have suffered particularly. I had meetings with a number of their leaders when I was last in Ukraine, and they told me the same things that are detailed in this report – the human rights abuses, the restrictions on free speech, free assembly, free religion and all the rest of it. How much this House can intervene in a distant land is a separate question, but at least let us be clear whose side we are on, where our sympathy lies. I hope that some of the colleagues in this Chamber who have been making excuses for the Putinite aggression will look at who it is that they are lining up with.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mr Hannan, I would like to thank Mr Hannan for his I was not quite sure whether you were talking about the progress report on Serbia. You have also spoken on other items. In the future, I will stop it.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I supported the report on Serbia. It is in the interest of the European Union, it is in the interest of the Czech Republic, which I represent here, that Serbia become a member of the European Union. On the other hand, they must meet clear economic, political, judicial, etc. conditions. This report describes not only Serbia's progress, but also its shortcomings, and I think that is important. These shortcomings need to be particularly pointed out and serbia should be told what it must therefore improve. Personally, as a person who has dealt with judicial reform in the Czech Republic, I am particularly interested in those passages that describe that Serbia is still far from the rule of law, that the independence of the judiciary in Serbia needs to be strengthened, that the institutional elements of the independence of the judiciary and the public prosecutor's office should be guaranteed. And another problem is the political orientation on Russia. It is not possible to want to be a member of the European Union and thus have close military and other ties to Russia. This must also be said to Serbia.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: - Mr President! Recent years have not been easy at all in EU-Serbia relations. Balancing the path of the future with historical memory - civil wars and NATO bombing factors, normalization of relations with Kosovo, other neighbors, the need for choice between the European Union and Russia in general (although it should not be at all) - all now play a fundamental role in life in present-day Serbia and will continue to play for years to come and even ten years. However, Serbia is initiating and currently actively implementing a number of reforms in order to move closer to the European Union in economic, political, social and legislative terms. At present, it has a rather important role to play in the European migrant crisis, given the current challenges, and so on, and while a number of challenges remain to be resolved by the country's accession to the European Union, I cannot imagine Europe, the Western Balkans or the Balkans without Serbia.

name: Peter JAHR
text: - Mister President! I also voted in favor of the Serbia progress report because I think it is balanced. It is good that we talk to each other at all, that we have made progress in the interests of the people. This report has a lot of light, and that shouldn't be put under a bushel. We have better cooperation, we talk about basic democratic values, we want to increase people's standard of living with the economic perspective. We also have shade, of course. But you can also put it this way, the deficits can also give courage to continue negotiating with each other in order to keep talking. And I keep saying it: you don't have to start with the prospect of membership right away. One should start with conversations. One should start by emphasizing common values. One should start by also emphasizing the shared responsibility for this Europe, and in that sense, I believe, it is not the last progress report. I am also looking forward to further cooperation with Serbia and can once again thank the rapporteur for the good work.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: - Mr Chairman! Undoubtedly, 2015 was a turning point in terms of relations between the European Union and Serbia. Finally, after almost three years, accession talks with this country began. However, the positive decision to open negotiation chapters is not so much due to Belgrade's significant progress in internal reforms - it is rather due to Serbia's constructive policy towards neighboring countries, especially Kosovo, and the appropriate attitude of the local government during the immigration crisis. I supported this report also because it cannot be denied that Belgrade's decisions have saved us from an even greater humanitarian catastrophe. However - as the report shows very clearly - the country is still experiencing enormous problems in adapting to EU requirements in the area of ​​justice and home affairs. Negotiations on these chapters are yet to start, but it can be assumed that they will not be easy. Another problem, somewhat overlooked, is the difficult economic situation in the country. Many migrants who came to Germany, Sweden or Norway have Serbian citizenship. This shows that poverty in this country can trigger migration waves to the EU. It is therefore necessary to focus on improving the economic situation in Serbia.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing.- The report addresses the Serbian situation in a coherent and realistic manner.The text highlights the main problems, which concern: the independence of the judiciary, discrimination against weak groups (linguistic minorities, LGBTI, etc.), persistent corruption and the unacceptable persecution of non-aligned journalists.The journey begun is still yielding results but much still needs to be done.However, I have decided to abstain from the vote because there are clear geopolitical ambiguities of international level within the text.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against. However, we recognise the importance of information sharing for British policing and are supportive of such measures, with appropriate safeguards, on a bilateral basis.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against. However, we recognise the importance of information sharing for British policing and are supportive of such measures, with appropriate safeguards, on a bilateral basis.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: written.- We have abstained from voting on the Resolution because, although we are in favor of the peoples deciding on their own future, also on their membership of the European Union, we understand that the EU only seeks to expand its market and its geopolitical presence,in addition to bringing a privatization and free market agenda to the region.Furthermore, the Resolution recognizes Kosovo as a State, something with which we do not agree, and for this we have abstained.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – I abstained on this resolution, which contained both positive and negative elements. This resolution of the European Parliament is a follow-up to the Commission’s Progress Report on the Serbian EU integration agenda. It welcomes the progress in the accession negotiations, but emphasises that many problems remain. There are positive elements urging progressive reforms in Serbia on human rights issues (such as protection of minorities), regional cooperation with neighbouring countries (on missing persons, war crimes prosecution, normalisation of relations with Kosovo), the rule of law and on the civil society sector. The points in the resolution that I object to related to promoting the EU’s right-wing agenda on economic governance, structural reforms, labour market reform and privatisation, as well as calling for Serbia to align its foreign and security policy with the EU’s. While there were many aspects of the resolution that I welcome – particularly the progress on normalisation of relations with Kosovo – there were too many problematic aspects for me to fully support this resolution.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: in writing.- Serbia is a country reduced by seven million inhabitants, following the dismantling of Yugoslavia in the 1990s. Whether in Bosnia, Kosovo or Montenegro, the Serbs find themselves victims of a new map of theEurope.However, the only prospect, by default, of this regional power is European integration through which it hopes to regain its rank.Pursuing the objective of integrating the Union by 2020, the country is the subject of special monitoring by the European Commission.This focuses on economic criteria considered the alpha and omega of the country's future.However, we note that the integration of Croatia into the Union two and a half years ago is a disaster for its economy.The question of Kosovo, whose independence Serbia will have to recognize in order to join the Union, is an insurmountable blockage that the report eludes.This is why I opposed this text.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I do not believe in Serbian accession to the European Union.  This progress report works towards that goal; therefore, I had no choice but to vote against the resolution.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report.Serbia still has some work to do in the fight against corruption and respect for media freedom, but we must keep in mind that any rapprochement with the Union will lead to more stability and prosperity throughout theregion.I would also like to point out that I am opposed to any enlargement of the Union.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this proposal for 2015.Serbia 's progress reports.It welcomes the start of negotiations on Serbia's accession to the EU and theprogress has been made towards the normalization of relations between Serbia and Kosovo.I support the calls for Belgrade and Pristina to implement the agreements reached as soon as possible, the implementation of which is one of the conditions for Serbia's membership of the EU.Serbia needs to further implement systemic reforms, ensure that the work of judges and prosecutors, as well as the media, is not influenced by politicians, and strengthen the fight against corruption and organized crime.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against. However, we recognise the importance of information sharing for British policing and are supportive of such measures, with appropriate safeguards, on a bilateral basis.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: in writing.- I voted against this report, which seems to me to be a digest of arrogance against Serbia that the Eurocrats intend to place under their supervision.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing. - In its joint resolution, Parliament underlines Serbia's continued commitment to the integration process. While highlighting the economic reforms undertaken, Parliament calls on Serbia to harmonize its foreign and security policy with that of the Union, including with regard to Russia, and notes that political interference remains high as regards judiciary power. It also calls for an increased fight against the significant presence of corruption and organized crime. He recalls the need to strengthen parliamentary oversight of the executive and stresses the importance of civil society action. Finally, in the area of ​​human rights, the resolution welcomes the fact that Serbia has an adequate institutional and legal framework to protect fundamental rights and fundamental freedoms, but notes, however, the persistence of shortcomings in the implementation. , especially with regard to discrimination and violence against LGBTI people.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: written. - I voted in favor of this report, which recognizes Serbia's progress in different areas, especially in the economy and regional cooperation, while demanding greater progress in other aspects such as the environment or freedom of the press. Serbia must be a preferential partner for the EU. Its geopolitical importance and the majority desire of its population to be part of the Union demand it. Their integration would also mean a strengthening of the stability of the region. For these reasons, it is necessary to cooperate on all issues involved in the accession process so that Serbia is finally a full member of the EU. Despite my rejection of the unilateral declaration of independence of Kosovo in 2008, I consider it positive that this report praises the good spirit of the Serbian Government in its relations with the Kosovar authorities in order to have a good neighborhood, as with other countries from the former Yugoslavia as Bosnia and Herzegovina.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. - In 2013, the European Council decided to open accession negotiations with Serbia. The report on the progress made by the Balkan country in the stages of its approach to the EU, presented in 2015, represents an important moment of reflection to understand what the difficulties and successes of the path undertaken have been. Serbia has undoubtedly made important efforts by launching an ambitious plan of systemic and socio-economic reforms aimed at strengthening the entire structure of the country. The report, which I supported with my vote, underlines in particular the importance of progress in the area of ​​normalization of relations with Kosovo and underlines more generally the continued commitment of the Balkan country in the process of European integration. Strengthening the rule of law and democratic mechanisms, the protection of human rights and respect for minorities must continue to be a priority alongside the Serbian commitment to the creation of fundamental energy and transport infrastructures.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: written.- We abstain in this vote, understanding that the paragraph of this Resolution concerning Kosovo: 1) contravenes international law since, although the International Court of Justice concluded that Kosovo's unilateral declaration of independence did not violate international law or Resolution 1244of the United Nations Security Council, and that the process of nationalization of Kosovo is irreversible, the ruling does not imply that the former province has a well-founded right to be recognized by third parties;2) not only does it not contribute anything to the necessary political resolution of the conflict, but it also interferes in relations between Russia and Serbia and hinders the proper approach to actions leading to a real and lasting stabilization of the area.Furthermore, we reject the nature and orientation of the economic measures implicit and explicit in the proposed Resolution.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: written.- I want to thank the rapporteur for his work on the 2015 progress report on Serbia.He also welcomed the opening of negotiations in the chapters on "Financial control" and on "Normalization of relations between Serbia and Kosovo."It is a big step.In addition, a mention is made of the rigorous application of legislation and policies as an indicator of the integration process and progress regarding the business environment, the reduction of the budget deficit and the labor market, including labor legislation and policy.of employment.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing. - I voted against this resolution, which wishes to continue the process of Serbia's accession to the European Union. Of course, Serbia has historically, culturally and politically an important place within Europe and I remain convinced that it must be an important voice in the concert of free and sovereign nations. However, this monitoring report once again reveals the arrogance of the European Union which seeks to operate a real blackmail, in particular by interfering in the internal affairs of this nation. It is thus scandalous that the Union tries to impose on Serbia a certain model of family policy, or even, that it dares to dictate to this one its conduct in matters of foreign affairs, indicating to it who are the "good ones. countries "with which it is entitled to have relations, and the" bad ones "to which it should turn its back - in this specific case, of course, Russia. With such reports, the Union is once again trying to use the Balkan countries as pawns in a game of chess which it would play against Russia, but in the name of Atlanticist interests. A contemptuous text which fills all the friends of Serbia with shame.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing.- The text being voted on is not very balanced and acceptable.Support for LGBTI and strengthening Roma integration are not what I would call primary requirements for assessing Serbia's progress in its accession process, so I did not intend to support the resolution with my vote.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: written.- I have abstained.I believe that Serbia's integration process, and possible future EU membership, should be decided by the people of Serbia.Integration requires many economic, social and political changes that affect the whole of society.In the end, the best form of a popular decision is a referendum.That's why I abstain.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: written. - This report makes a detailed analysis of the progress of the negotiations for accession to the EU of Serbia. The opening of the chapters on financial control and the process to normalize relations with Kosovo are noteworthy. Furthermore, the report highlights Serbia's commitment to the European integration process. Although progress has been significant, this document highlights that Serbia has a lot of work to do, on the one hand it lacks a greater commitment from Serbia to press freedom, it is also worsening the conditions of freedom of expression and on the other hand, the absence of a real effort to fight corruption, since there is a lack of transparency in the financing of political parties and electoral campaigns. Finally, the report also invites Serbia to make further efforts to improve the situation of the Roma and to ensure the consistent application throughout the country of the legislation on the protection of minorities. That is why I have voted in favor of this report.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution because it assessed Parliament's 2015 progress report on Serbia.Parliament welcomed the fact that in 2015negotiations were launched at the Intergovernmental Conference in Brussels and that a negotiating chapter on financial control and a chapter on the normalization of relations between Serbia and Kosovo were opened.Parliament also welcomed Serbia's continued commitment to the European integration process and noted Serbia's commitment to an ambitious reform agenda.Parliament therefore continues to call on Serbia to resolutely and unhinderedly undertake systemic and socio-economic reforms, with a special focus on youth.Parliament also emphasized the need to step up the fight against organized crime and to build on the experience of final convictions.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing. - In its 2015 Country Report on Serbia, the European Parliament adopted a balanced, realistic, objective document. Serbia has taken important steps in the past year, resulting in the opening of the first negotiating chapters. The report highlights the progress made so far in regional cooperation and in tackling the migrant and refugee crisis, but also points to shortcomings, in particular in the areas of freedom of expression and the media, the rule of law and the fight against corruption and organized crime. In Serbia, many promising laws and action plans have been drafted in the last year, the implementation of which is key not only to the opening of negotiation chapters, but also to the rule of law at the European level for Serbian citizens as soon as possible. This is especially important for national minority communities, including the Hungarian community in Vojvodina. This report seeks to provide further encouragement and guidance to the Serbian government in this regard.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: in writing. - I am very pleased to support the European Parliament's report on Serbia, because I am very pleased with its progress and the country's desire to join European integration. As a member of the delegation for monitoring Serbia's progress in parliament, I visited Serbia three times last year, and also met several times in Brussels and Strasbourg with its governmental and non-governmental representatives. I am pleased with the opening of the first two negotiating chapters at the end of last year, which are a sign that the negotiating teams can start working and continue on the path to democratizing society and improving the situation in these areas. Of course, Serbia still faces many challenges, many have to eradicate old practices of the former political system, pay more attention to the prosecution of corruption and organized crime, strengthen dialogue with civil society, pluralize the media and ensure greater independence, etc ... But I believe only stable , a democratic and economically prosperous Serbia can ensure the political stability of the entire Western Balkans. That is why the European Union must help them to the best of its ability, including through more pre-accession funds, and enable them to modernize their infrastructure and create new jobs. I myself will be happy to help on this path, as the city of Serbia, as well as all the countries of the Western Balkans, is sooner or later in the European Union.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this document because I believe that the progress made by Serbia, especially in the normalization of relations with Kosovo, represent important steps towards the accession of the Balkan country to the European Union.The prospect of the accession of the Balkan countries to the European Union is one of the main factors of stability in the region and, therefore, must be supported by both European and national authorities.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: in writing. - Under the pretext that the negotiations on the accession of Serbia are in progress, the European Union allows itself to draw up recommendations concerning Serbian domestic policy. In other words, this motion for a resolution aims to list the main political orientations to the Serbian authorities in return for progress in the negotiations with a view to its accession. It includes the normalization of relations with Kosovo, the adoption of an Atlanticist foreign policy that is less oriented towards Russia, the implementation of structural economic reforms in favor of investors, the reception of illegal migrants and inclusion. social protection of the Roma as well as the fight against discrimination against so-called vulnerable people. This motion for a resolution reflects the will of the European Union to interfere permanently in the national affairs of both Member States and third countries. Not only are we opposed to Serbia's accession to the Union, but above all we are outraged by the nature of the recommendations made to the Serbian government. The Serbian people are sovereign and in no way have to satisfy the whims of the European Commission. I therefore voted against this motion for a resolution.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: signed up. - Serbia is the 33rd state to participate in the European Union's civil protection mechanism, being one of the countries aspiring to become a member of the EU. Serbia has made significant progress on the European integration process, making considerable efforts to align with the principles and values ​​of the Union. Serbia has therefore taken outstanding action towards the normalization of relations with Kosovo, which has resulted in the first agreement on the principles applicable to the normalization of relations. It has also made consistent efforts to develop the business environment, reduce the budget deficit and develop the labor market, including in terms of labor law and employment policy. Moreover, it elaborated the plan for the reconstruction, improvement and modernization of some sections of the railway network. I welcome the progress made by Serbia and the reforms initiated in key areas such as public administration, infrastructure, the economy, which is why I spoke in favor of this report. I continue to encourage these steps towards European integration and support Serbia's efforts to align with the Union's foreign and security policy.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing.- I voted against this resolution because it welcomes Serbia's constructive approach to tackling the migration crisis;notes however that a constructive approach with neighboring countries needs to be promoted.It is noted that Serbia is an essential and collaborative EU partner in the Balkans and that it is therefore imperative that the Union provide resources and appropriate financial support.It notes with satisfaction the substantial efforts made by Serbia to ensure, with EU and international support, reception and humanitarian aid for third-country nationals and calls on it to rapidly increase its reception capacities.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of Serbia's 2015 Progress Report, which demonstrates continued commitment to the European integration process and which has launched an ambitious reform agenda. I believe that in-depth negotiations of the chapters dealing with the "Judiciary and Fundamental Rights" and "Justice, Freedom and Security" are essential to address these reforms. Serbia needs to improve planning, coordination and monitoring of the implementation of new rules and policies. I also call on the Serbian authorities to encourage an increase in investment throughout Serbia and to reduce the economic and social disparities between its regions, ensuring the protection of foreign investments and resolving long-standing disputes. While recognizing the progress made in restructuring public enterprises, I think that more needs to be done and that more transparency is needed in the privatization process. Finally, I note that corruption and organized crime are still present in the region, which represent an important obstacle to the democratic, social and economic development of Serbia. A database of investigations and indictments of corruption, including high-level corruption, needs to be established.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against. However, we recognise the importance of information sharing for British policing and are supportive of such measures, with appropriate safeguards, on a bilateral basis.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the progress made by Serbia so far which has brought it closer to European integration and the ambitious reform agenda set by its government. There is still a lot of work to be done and Serbia should continue on its path of modernisation and further development and I therefore voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. - The report presented by my colleague McAllister cites many important issues and touches on absolutely acceptable issues, such as the condition of the judicial system, aggravated by backward causes and subjected to political pressure; corruption, which is an absolutely persistent plague; discrimination against vulnerable groups such as LGBTI and linguistic minorities; the necessary participation of civil society and the opposition in the political process and also in integration; the existence of a still too militaristic rhetoric. Although I appreciated the realistic approach of the relationship, I cannot overlook the issue of relations with Russia: the request made to Serbia to move away from Moscow, inviting Belgrade to align its foreign policy with that of the Union, when not even among the States members today there is no homogeneity of external action, it led me to abstain on the final vote. Moscow remains and will have to go back to being an essential interlocutor for the Union. I don't understand why people insist on seeing obstacles and not relaunching a serious and frank political dialogue.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing.- We support the report and welcome the progress that Serbia has made on its path to European integration, as well as its efforts to comply with the Copenhagen criteria and the conditions of the Stabilization and Association Process.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing.- I decided to vote in favor of the measure because I am convinced that Europe must applaud Serbia's continued commitment to the European integration process.The progress made on the constructive approach to addressing the migration crisis, on economic reforms and on the business environment make Serbia worthy of EU support to carry out further reforms and to encourage institutions tomake greater efforts to progressively align its foreign and security policy with that of the EU.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing.- The Balkans, in the recent history of our continent, have always been a very problematic area.Still, either because of the aftermath of fifty years of dictatorship, or because of the war that has tormented some of the countries, there are problems that affect our security.In this context, the European Union does well to stimulate reform processes that allow countries to have free and functioning institutions on which to base a society that develops and quickly reaches the level of neighboring countries.And if opening accession negotiations is the counterpart, they are welcome.Of course: those who are not ready to enter must remain at the door, but those who commit themselves and improve their situation, especially judicial and democratic, it is right to sit at the table with us.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against. However, we recognise the importance of information sharing for British policing and are supportive of such measures, with appropriate safeguards, on a bilateral basis.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing.- The progress made by Serbia in many areas of internal and foreign policy is indicative of the will to become part of the Union.Examples are the reform of the judiciary, the fight against corruption and freedom of expression and of the press, although there are still limitations on the full implementation of the reforms necessary to be in line with EU policies.I have decided to cast my favorable vote for Serbia to continue the accession path it has undertaken by implementing European values in its national legislation and to continue working to improve cooperation in the region, in particular with Kosovo.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ As an aspiring Member State, Serbia needs to ensure that it meets democratic standards including the rule of law, democracy, human rights, respect for minorities and good neighbourly relations. Accession can only take place once these criteria are completely fulfilled, and the EU cannot afford to take on new Member States that are not fully committed to these principles. The motion for resolution encourages political leaders in Serbia to strengthen their endeavours in attaining such standards. I have thus voted in favour.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. - The report analyzes the Serbian situation with coherence and a realistic approach, denouncing the shortcomings alongside the improvements recorded, especially as regards: the judicial system, still exposed to political pressure and burdened with backward cases; the corruption; discrimination against the weaker categories; the need for greater participation of civil society and Oppositions in decision-making processes; deficiencies in respect for freedom of expression and in the media; the need to give judicial proceedings for war crimes, so as to guarantee truth and compensation to the families of the victims. On the other hand, less shareable aspects are: the importance recognized to business for the purposes of the normalization of the neighborhood in the Balkans and the facilitation of privatization which could undermine the importance given to labor policies. The relationship tends to be positive and the horizon of the accession of Serbia and the other Balkan countries remains desirable, but the request made to the country to move away from Russia in order to avoid new maneuvers to marginalize Moscow which remains and will have to return to being an essential interlocutor for the Union, can only lead me to vote abstention.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: written.- We have abstained from voting on the Resolution because, although we are in favor of the peoples deciding on their own future, also on their membership of the European Union, we understand that the EU only seeks to expand its market and its geopolitical presence,in addition to bringing a privatization and free market agenda to the region.Furthermore, the Resolution recognizes Kosovo as a State, something with which we do not agree, and for this we have abstained.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing. - The procedure report takes the progress made by Serbia in an overall positive light. Public administration reform is underway, but the administration has yet to be depoliticized. The same is true of the judicial system. Corruption continues to spread, but efforts to combat it have yet to produce tangible results. As regards the economic criteria, Serbia has made progress in developing a functioning market economy. Unemployment has dropped below 20%. However, the private sector is still underdeveloped. The report called on Serbia to align its foreign and security policy with EU policy, including policy towards Russia. On the issue of democracy, the report calls for more stakeholder consultation on parliamentary procedures, for improved parliamentary scrutiny of the legislature and for the depoliticization of public administration. The report also stressed that Vojvodina's autonomy should not be weakened and that the situation of the minority, in particular the Roma minority, should be improved. I support Serbia's efforts to integrate with the EU - with that in mind, I voted ZA.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report, which welcomes the launch of negotiations with Serbia and focuses on the developments made in the accession process of Serbia to the EU last year. It must be noted that, while progress has been achieved last year in Serbia’s reform agenda as well as in the normalisation of relations with Kosovo, many pertinent issues remain unresolved. The deterioration of freedom of expression and media freedom, corruption and the lack of transparency in the funding of political parties and election campaigns remain key issues, but the protection of minorities also requires immediate attention. With the upcoming early elections it is crucial that Serbia further progresses with its EU agenda.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report by Mr McAllister, which is a useful assessment of ongoing reforms in Serbia, including in important areas such as the rule of law, democracy, human rights, respect for minorities and regional cooperation. It rightly recognises that Serbia has embarked on an ambitious reform agenda. We in Britain support the ongoing efforts to ensure that EU applicant countries fulfil the criteria for EU membership and very much welcome all efforts to secure peace and stability in the Western Balkans. So, for these reasons, I am happy to support this report.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: in writing.- In this motion for a resolution, MEPs recall that enlargement remains an essential policy of the Union and the Union's attachment to the countries of the Balkans.MEPs welcome the progress made in normalizing relations between Serbia and Kosovo, and note that relations would be facilitated if all EU Member States recognized Kosovo.The European Parliament encourages Serbia to maintain a positive dynamic and to step up legislative reforms in the protection of vulnerable groups (eg the Roma), the independence of democratic institutions and the judiciary.Supporting these goals, I voted in favor of this resolution.

name: Rachida DATI
text: in writing.- The 2015 follow-up report on Serbia highlights the progress made by Serbia in the framework of the negotiations for accession to the European Union.I voted in favor of this text which encourages Serbia in particular to pursue ambitious economic reforms, but also to adopt a constructive approach to the management of the migration crisis.While it is good that the candidate countries initiate the necessary reforms in order to come closer to European criteria, I would remind you that it is essential for the European Union to take a lasting pause in its enlargement policy.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing.- Serbia has made considerable progress in the accession negotiations with the European Union over the past year and made important steps forward in normalizing relations with Pristina.Despite these results, the Serbian authorities still have to work hard on the fight against corruption and in guaranteeing judges, prosecutors and the media freedom and independence from political influence.I have decided to vote in favor of this resolution to invite Serbia to continue the path of reforms it has undertaken in the judiciary, in the fight against corruption and organized crime.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: in writing. - The progress made in 2015 in the normalization of relations between Serbia and Kosovo is to be welcomed. Now Belgrade and Pristina must move forward in the full and timely execution of the agreements reached. Serbia must therefore continue its reforms, ensuring that the work of judges and prosecutors, as well as the media, is carried out in complete independence, free from political interference, and to intensify its efforts to fight against corruption and organized crime. Indeed, according to the 2015 progress report, two years after the launch of accession negotiations with the European Union, Serbia is still not ready to assume its Member State obligations in most areas. . It should also be remembered that the European Commission made a wise commitment in 2014 to take a break from enlargement to consolidate what has been achieved between the 28. This is why, in line with the commitments made during the European campaign, the French delegation of the ALDE group chose to abstain on the final vote.

name: Andor DELI
text: in writing. - With David McAllister's 2015 country report, the European Parliament has adopted a balanced, realistic, objective document. Serbia has taken important steps in the past year, resulting in the opening of the first negotiating chapters. The report highlights the progress made so far in regional cooperation and in tackling the migrant crisis, but also points to shortcomings, particularly in the areas of the rule of law, freedom of expression and the media, corruption and organized crime. In the last year, many promising laws and action plans have been drafted in Serbia, the implementation of which is key, and not only because of the opening of negotiation chapters, but also for the citizens of Serbia to be given the rule of law at European level as soon as possible. This is especially important for national minority communities, including the Hungarian community in Vojvodina. This report seeks to provide further encouragement and guidance to the Serbian government in this regard.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: in writing.- As a member of the EU-Balkans Friendships, I take note of the factual elements contained in this resolution concerning the process of Serbia's accession to the European Union, and in particular the state of play of preparatory measures.I welcome a number of positive developments, in particular the efforts undertaken to normalize relations with Kosovo and the constructive approach of the Serbian authorities to the migration crisis.I remind you that I am very attentive to aspects relating to democratic gains and the rule of law - respect for press freedom, respect for minorities, the fight against corruption, depoliticization and professionalization of the administration.are central points.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing.- As is often the case with the Balkans, the proposed texts show a notorious lack of respect for the sovereignty, internal affairs and institutions of Serbia.It is regrettable that this approach hinders any responsible action on these subjects.Being attached to the principle of national sovereignty, I voted against this text.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: In written form. - The European Commission's annual report rightly states that the legal and institutional framework for guaranteeing the fundamental rights of minorities has been put in place, but unfortunately the legislation remains on paper and does not apply. I am in constant contact with the Bulgarian community in Serbia, which complains of strong discrimination by local authorities - Bulgarian schools are not funded, there are no educational materials in Bulgarian, the freedom of association is limited. In general, people live in fear of calling themselves Bulgarians. I supported the European Parliament's resolution on Serbia's 2015 progress report, because in it the European Parliament called on the Serbian government to ensure consistency in the implementation of the legal framework for the protection of minorities throughout the country. Serbia still has a long way to go to ensure that every ethnic minority can use their language freely, have access to education, participate in local government, and have media and worship services in the minority language. I strongly hope that in the process of Serbia's integration with the European Union, the situation of the Bulgarian community will improve.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: in writing.- It is proposed to vote against Serbia's progress report as: a) it imposes on Serbia a change of attitude towards Russia, b) it demands from Serbia equal efforts with Kosovo to normalize the situation, c) it depends on the progress of the accession negotiations on the normalization ofrelations with Kosovo and (d) impose on Serbia the absorption of a large wave of illegal immigrants, exacerbating the already aggravated situation in the Balkans.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: in writing. - With David McAllister's 2015 country report, the European Parliament has adopted a balanced, realistic, objective document. Serbia has taken important steps in the past year, resulting in the opening of the first negotiating chapters. The report highlights the progress made so far in regional cooperation and in tackling the migrant crisis, but also points to shortcomings, particularly in the areas of freedom of expression and the media, the rule of law, corruption and organized crime. In the last year, many promising laws and action plans have been drafted in Serbia, the implementation of which is key, and not only because of the opening of negotiation chapters, but also for the citizens of Serbia to be given the rule of law at European level as soon as possible. This is especially important for national minority communities, including the Hungarian community in Vojvodina. This report seeks to provide further encouragement and guidance to the Serbian government in this regard.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing.- The European Council decided to start accession negotiations with Serbia, which has been making progress towards European integration, including important measures in favor of normalizing relations with Kosovo.Serbia has also embarked on an ambitious reform program and must continue decisively and directly systemic and socio-economic reforms, paying particular attention to young people when implementing their reforms.The progress made by Serbia in the business environment, in reducing the budget deficit and in the labor market, in particular in terms of labor law and employment policy, is worth mentioning as well as the progress made in economic reforms, which have improved the country's budgetary situation.I voted in favor of the report.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: in writing.- I voted against this deliberation because it stigmatizes the Serbian people and claims to dictate their codes of democratic expression.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - This report comes as part of Serbia's accession process to the European Union. The rapporteur addresses the application of the impositions that the EU imposes on Serbia in areas such as the democratic rule of law, human rights, respect and protection of minorities, regional cooperation and good neighborly relations, energy, environment and transport. A set of measures that serve as conditions for Serbia's accession to the EU are listed: reforms in the judicial system, recognition by Serbia of the existence of Kosovo, labor reforms, privatizations, restructuring of the public sector, protection of private investment, reform budget, impositions in the scope of the functioning of the institutions, among others. The great powers of NATO and the EU want to compel the Serbian people to accept the violation of their territorial integrity and sovereignty with the acceptance of Kosovo as a state. Serbia's accession to the EU adds to other ongoing processes that demonstrate how the sowing of ethnic divisions, aggression and support for the destruction of Yugoslavia had the purpose of economically dominating the resulting countries, their natural resources , exploit their workers and destroy the peoples' immense social achievements. We voted against.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained because I reject the neoliberal economic reforms that are promoted.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing - I welcome the opening and opening of the first chapters of the integration process at the end of last year and expect no problems in opening Chapters 23 and 24 during the negotiations on this year's enlargement, as Serbia is an important and important partner for the European Union in the Western Balkans..However, it must be emphasized that the country still has a long and difficult way to go and a lot of work to do.Issues such as media freedom, deteriorating conditions for freedom of expression, lack of transparency in the financing of political parties and election campaigns, and insufficient action and regulations to protect national minorities must not be forgotten.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing.- I am voting against Serbia's progress report as: a) it imposes on Serbia a change of attitude towards Russia, b) it demands from Serbia equal efforts with Kosovo to normalize the situation, c) it depends on the progress of the accession negotiations on the normalization of relations withKosovo and d) impose on Serbia the absorption of a large wave of illegal immigrants, exacerbating the already aggravated situation in the Balkans.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I believe we need to be aware that a lot of work lies ahead for Serbia:  improvements are very much needed with regards to rights, freedoms and the security of minorities, the freedom of the media , the lack of transparency in funding of political parties, the equal representation of men and women.  I believe that, in our talks with Serbia, we must keep our European priorities and values clear in our minds:  the goal of achieving stability in the region is important but we cannot forfeit our support and defence of the exercise of democratic liberties in the Balkans.  I expect the Serbian government to refrain from anti EU rhetoric and to stop manipulating public opinion through pressure, censure and the government's massive propaganda machine. I support this process but at the same time I believe that we must take a clear political position.  It is about time for us to show that no State that wishes to join the EU can avoid putting fundamental democratic values into place and can show no interest in the values that Europe represents.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing. - With David McAllister's 2015 country report, the European Parliament has adopted a balanced, realistic, objective document. Serbia has taken important steps in the past year, resulting in the opening of the first negotiating chapters. The report highlights the progress made so far in regional cooperation and in tackling the migrant crisis, but also points to shortcomings, particularly in the areas of freedom of expression and the media, the rule of law, corruption and organized crime. In Serbia, many promising laws and action plans have been drafted in the last year, the implementation of which is key, and not only because of the opening of negotiation chapters, but also for the citizens of Serbia to receive the rule of law at European level as soon as possible. This is especially important for national minority communities, including the Hungarian community in Vojvodina. This report seeks to provide further encouragement and guidance to the Serbian government in this regard.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: written.- I voted in favor of the report after noting the progress made by the Commission on the progress made by the country towards European integration, evaluating its efforts to meet the Copenhagen criteria and the conditions for the stabilization and association process.However, Serbia must decisively address the systemic and socio-economic reforms that it so desperately needs and continue with the reforms necessary for alignment with EU standards.From the EU institutions, we must continue to support the efforts of Serbia and provide them with support for the achievement of greater well-being for all Serbian citizens.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing.- I would like to vote in favor of the resolution on the progress of the accession negotiations between the EU and Serbia.I too agree with the passages in the adopted text which underline the progress made.I would like to comment, in particular as a member of the JURI commission, on the situation of the judiciary, which has been the subject of reforms that it will be crucial to continue to implement in order to ensure that Serbia complies with the principles of the rule of law and good functioning.of justice, with particular reference to judicial training.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the resolution of the European Parliament, presented following statements by the European Council and the Commission under Rule 123 (2) of the Rules of Procedure, on the 2015 Progress Report on Serbia. In fact, I consider the efforts made to stabilize the country and the commitment to proceed along the path of European integration and normalization of relations with Kosovo to be worthy of appreciation. At this point on the path towards Serbia's full participation in European processes, it is necessary to help the country strengthen economic governance, the rule of law and the state administrative system. A demonstration of will to pursue this path is certainly supported by the progress made in the entrepreneurial field, in the labor market and in employment support policies that are beginning to bear fruit. However, several aspects of the country's political and social life remain which are still worrying, such as the lack of progress on media freedom of expression and lack of respect for human and minority rights. I therefore share the invitation addressed to the Serbian authorities to implement concrete measures to address these critical issues and promote the full implementation of European values.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: written.- I voted in favor of the 2015 progress report on Serbia, which reflects the situation in the country in a very differentiated way and shows realistic prospects for membership.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: written.- In Serbia, significant progress has already been made in many different areas.However, existing problems such as corruption and organized crime still need to be addressed effectively.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this resolution which calls on Serbia to pursue its systematic reforms, ensure that the work of judges and prosecutors, as well as that of the media, is free from political influence, and step up its efforts to fight corruption and organised crime. It furthermore is important to acknowledge that Serbia has taken important steps in the normalisation of relations with Kosovo, which is vital for safeguarding peace and stability in the region. The EU can play an important role in encouraging both countries to continue on this path.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: written.- We abstain in this vote, understanding that the paragraph of this Resolution concerning Kosovo: 1) contravenes international law since, although the International Court of Justice concluded that Kosovo's unilateral declaration of independence did not violate international law or Resolution 1244of the United Nations Security Council, and that the process of nationalization of Kosovo is irreversible, the ruling does not imply that the former province has a well-founded right to be recognized by third parties;2) not only does it not contribute anything to the necessary political resolution of the conflict, but it also interferes in relations between Russia and Serbia and hinders the proper approach to actions leading to a real and lasting stabilization of the area.Furthermore, we reject the nature and orientation of the economic measures implicit and explicit in the proposed Resolution.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution, as it welcomes the opening of the EU accession negotiations and calls on Serbia to pursue its systematic reforms, ensure that the work of judges and prosecutors, as well as that of the media, is free from political influence and step up its efforts to fight corruption and organised crime.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour on the progress repost on Serbia 2015. Serbia has made positive progress in various areas. Serbia is moderately prepared in the area of public administration reform. Good progress has been achieved with the adoption of a comprehensive action plan. Serbia needs to remain committed and implement its reform targets. However, the country should still put efforts to prevent corruption.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE / NGL), in writing.- We support Serbia's accession process, however, we disagree with the Union's stance expressed in the report and interfering in the conduct of Serbia's foreign policy.We also disagree with the attempt to impose economic models that have been proven to have had such a negative impact on the peoples of Europe.Respecting the will of the Serbian government and people for a closer relationship with the EU, we believe that the appropriate stance is that of abstention.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution regarding the Commission’s 2015 report on accession negotiations with Serbia and its progress towards European integration. The progress report on Serbia focuses on the rule of law, democracy, human rights, respect for minorities, regional cooperation and energy, the environment and transport. While Serbia has made a lot of ambitious reforms and opened chapters on financial control and normalisation of relations between Serbia and Kosovo, which in particular is an important condition for Serbia’s accession to the EU, there are areas which must still be improved. Although steps have been taken to form an independent judiciary, political interference remains high. The issue of corruption and organised crime also remains worrying. Progress has been made with a whistleblower protection law but corruption, including at the highest levels, must be pursued and an action plan for an anti-corruption strategy fully implemented. Hopefully these issues will be addressed in the submitted action plan for a Chapter on Judiciary and fundamental rights. Finally, regarding freedom of expression and the media, no progress has been made on this democratic cornerstone. Continuous political pressure undermines media independence, with journalists threatened and intimidated. This is a crucial outstanding issue and must be rectified for Serbia to progress.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: written. - On the basis of this resolution, the European Parliament issues an opinion on the Commission report, in which the Commission set out Serbia's progress towards European integration. The resolution welcomes Serbia's progress so far, including improving the business environment and reducing the budget deficit. At the same time, she notes that corruption and organized crime are widespread in the region, which also stands in the way of the democratic, social and economic development of Serbia. In general, it is a good and balanced opinion that I have taken note of as such. However, I cannot identify with the fact that in the face of current problems, new accession chapters are being opened and further accession negotiations are being conducted. The EU leaders have known only one answer for a long time: ever more and ever larger Europe. In the situation when the structural deficiencies of the eurozone continue to deepen and Great Britain is considering leaving the EU, it is extremely dishonest on our part to give Serbia the prospect of accession. The EU must first be able to solve its problems, i. H. must first reform itself so that an EU enlargement can come into question. From this point of view I could not support the abovementioned parliamentary resolution and abstained from the vote.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this resolution because I welcome the steps taken towards Serbia’s ascension to the EU. I urge the Serbian political leaders to continue with the reforms needed in order to reach EU standards. Serbia has also made significant progress regarding economic reforms – partly due to the Commission’s support. I hope Serbia will remain strong on its current path.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written. - I voted for the report on Serbia for 2015, considering that I consider the process of European integration of Serbia extremely important for the citizens of Serbia, but also for preserving stability in the area of ​​Southeast Europe. I welcome the opening of negotiations and Chapters 32 (financial supervision) and 35 (other issues - item I: the process of normalizing relations with Kosovo) at the Intergovernmental Conference in Brussels on 14 December 2015 and Serbia's continued commitment to the European integration process; Serbia's progress in terms of the business environment, reducing the budget deficit and the labor market; progress of economic reforms; constructive approach to the migrant crisis; progress made in the area of ​​justice; better cooperation between government and civil society; adoption of a comprehensive action plan for public administration reform; Serbia's commitment to drawing up a special action plan for national minorities, which will enable further progress; Serbia's engagement in building good neighborly relations with Kosovo; continuing cooperation with neighboring countries, improving bilateral relations and resolving disputes peacefully. On the other hand, there is a problem with the opening of negotiation chapters 23 and 24, then poor progress in improving the situation regarding freedom of speech and media, corruption and organized crime are still widespread. There is a problem of adopting the acquis in the field of transport and energy infrastructure, implementation of waste legislation, creating a legal framework for participation in the EGTC.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: in writing.- Serbia is a country reduced by seven million inhabitants, following the dismantling of Yugoslavia in the 1990s. Whether in Bosnia, Kosovo or Montenegro, the Serbs find themselves victims of a new map of theEurope.However, the only prospect, by default, of this regional power is European integration through which it hopes to regain its rank.Pursuing the objective of integrating the Union by 2020, the country is the subject of special monitoring by the European Commission.This focuses on economic criteria considered the alpha and omega of the country's future.However, we note that the integration of Croatia into the Union two and a half years ago is a disaster for its economy.The question of Kosovo, whose independence Serbia will have to recognize in order to join the Union, is an insurmountable blockage that the report eludes.I therefore voted against this text.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – I voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report with my fellow UKIP employees.  UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such I voted against. However, we recognise the importance of information sharing for British policing and are supportive of such measures, with appropriate safeguards, on a bilateral basis.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing.- This resolution concerning Serbia welcomes the progress made by the country in the perspective of its accession to the European Union.If the text underlines the important measures taken by Belgrade to normalize its relations with Kosovo, it nevertheless regrets the joint military exercises carried out with Russia and calls on Serbia to align its foreign policy with that of Brussels.I therefore voted in favor of this resolution.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written.- I am voting in favor of this report.He strikes a good balance between the country's structural problems and the progress that has already been made.Serbia is more than ever a strategically important EU partner in the Balkans and should receive the best possible support from all member states for rapid EU accession.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution, as it welcomes the opening of the EU accession negotiations and calls on Serbia to pursue its systematic reforms, ensure that the work of judges and prosecutors, as well as that of the media, is free from political influence and step up its efforts to fight corruption and organised crime.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: written. - On the basis of this resolution, the European Parliament is submitting an opinion on the Commission report in which the Commission set out Serbia's progress towards European integration. The resolution welcomes the progress made by Serbia so far. These include improving the business environment and reducing the budget deficit. At the same time, the resolution notes that corruption and organized crime are widespread in the region, which also stands in the way of the democratic, social and economic development of Serbia. In general, it is a good and balanced statement that I have taken note of as such. However, I cannot identify with the fact that in view of the current major challenges in the EU, new accession chapters are to be opened and further accession negotiations are to be conducted. The EU has to reform itself and solve its structural problems in the process, before EU enlargement can come into question. For this reason, I was unable to support the abovementioned parliamentary resolution and I abstained from the vote.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: in writing. - The 2015 Progress Report on Serbia welcomes Serbia's continued commitment to the European integration process and has made significant progress in this direction. The document emphasizes that serious and sustainable progress is inconceivable without the rule of law. He notes that the cultural diversity of Vojvodina contributes to Serbia’s identity. It also calls on the Serbian authorities to ensure consistent implementation of legislation on the protection of minorities throughout the country, including in the areas of education, language use, public administration representation and access to media and church services in minority languages. Given that Serbia is at the forefront of Hungarian national, neighborhood and security policy, and in defense of the interests of the Hungarians in Vojvodina, I voted in favor of the report.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ The 2015 report on Serbia concluded that Serbia has made some political and economic progress (public administration, economic governance). The GUE/NGL group welcomes the progress and the positive developments in the country. However, since we cannot accept the recognition of Kosovo and the neoliberal economic reforms, I voted abstention.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: In written form. - I support the report because it is an indisputable fact that Serbia has embarked on the path of reforms and European integration. We must congratulate the country on the opening of negotiations on accession chapters 32 (Financial Control) and 35 (Normalization of relations with Kosovo). Serbia's desire to work in this direction is a clear sign of the presence of political will for change and development. Last year, Serbia also emerged as an important partner of the European Union in the Balkans on the issue of the migration crisis. The government has made great efforts to provide asylum and protection to many third-country nationals on its territory. Of course, despite the progress made, Serbia needs to make further efforts to address issues in leading political spectrums, such as the protection of minorities, the rule of law, the fight against corruption and discrimination, and violence against LGBTI people. I believe that the European Union can provide significant technical assistance to the country to meet these challenges. I find it extremely important for the Serbian government to bring the country's foreign policy fully in line with that of the European Union. An effort in this direction will legitimize Serbia's desire to be part of the European family. And what greater reward for the European Union than the membership of all the countries of the Western Balkans in our structures?

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - The European Council, on 28 June 2013, decided to open accession negotiations with Serbia. The latter, like any country aspiring to become a member of the EU, must be judged on its ability to meet, implement and comply with European legislation. The 2015 Progress Report from Serbia shows that significant progress has been made towards European integration. We have been able to attest that progress has been made with regard to the business environment, the reduction of the budget deficit and the labor market, including labor law and employment policy. I also consider that Serbia's commitment to the normalization process of relations with Kosovo is satisfactory. A noteworthy aspect is the elaboration of an adequate legal and institutional framework for the protection of human rights and fundamental freedoms, although progress is still needed as regards the fight against organized crime, the independence of the judiciary and the media. Ultimately, recognizing Serbia's commitment, I decided to vote in favor of the motion for a resolution.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: in writing.- I voted against the resolution on the progress report of Serbia, this text being a digest of arrogance of the European Union towards Serbia.The text, like most of the amendments tabled by traditional political groups elsewhere, shows interference in the internal and external affairs of a sovereign state.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: in writing.- I voted against this report because the Union interferes in the internal affairs of Serbia with unbearable arrogance.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: written. - On the basis of this resolution, the European Parliament issues an opinion on the Commission report in which the Commission set out Serbia's progress towards European integration. The resolution welcomes Serbia's progress so far, including improving the business environment and reducing the budget deficit. At the same time, she notes that corruption and organized crime are widespread in the region, which also stands in the way of the democratic, social and economic development of Serbia. In general, it is a good and balanced opinion that I have taken note of as such. However, I cannot identify with the fact that in the face of current problems, new accession chapters are being opened and further accession negotiations are being conducted. For a long time, EU leaders have only known one answer: ever more and ever larger Europe. In the situation when the structural deficiencies of the eurozone continue to deepen and Great Britain is considering leaving the EU, it is extremely dishonest on our part to give Serbia the prospect of accession. The EU must first be able to solve its problems, i. H. must first reform itself so that an EU enlargement can come into question. From this point of view I could not support the abovementioned parliamentary resolution and abstained from the vote.

name: Petr MACH
text: in writing.- The EU is in trouble and not ready for enlargement.I do not agree that we should impose European policy on Serbia and interfere in its foreign policy affairs (military exercise with Russia) or that we will praise the organization of a gay pride march.I voted against.
