name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written.- The Commission's report emphasizes the importance of Serbia's progress in joining the EU, especially in resolving the refugee crisis.Serbia has taken some steps towards opening the first chapters for EU accession, but the situation is still unsatisfactory, especially with regard to the exercise of all guaranteed rights of national minorities, especially Croats, the return of cultural goods and the discovery of missing persons from the Homeland War.Furthermore, judicial reforms and the intensified fight against corruption and organized crime, as well as strengthening freedom of movement and media independence, are needed.The report places special emphasis on the need for constructive agreements and talks with Kosovo.I supported the Commission's report because in the process of joining the EU, Serbia must implement reforms that will democratize society and contribute to the normalization of relations with Croatia and other EU member states.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing - Serbia, as an independent country, is one of the youngest countries in Europe.It was established in 2006 after the secession of Montenegro.Serbia is aspiring to join the EU, formal negotiations began in 2014. Serbia's position was complicated by the situation associated with the declaration of the former province of Kosovo as an independent state, which Serbia did not recognize.However, relations are gradually being normalized; in 2015, bilateral agreements between these entities were finalized.Serbia, as a candidate country of the European Union, must meet all the set conditions for European integration, for which we will provide the necessary assistance from the Union.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing.- I abstained during the vote on the Motion for a Resolution on the 2015 report on Serbia, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the European Parliament on 3/2/2016 and because this Motion for a Resolution is not complete.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: signed up. - I voted in favor of Parliament's resolution on the 2015 report on Serbia. Since last year, Serbia has taken concrete steps to complete much of the acquis communautaire. The Commission has set out a clear set of requirements for Serbia on the need to strengthen economic governance, the rule of law and public administration capacity. Serbia has shown that it can be a socio-economic engine in the Western Balkans: it has reduced the budget deficit, improved employment policy and the investment climate. Negotiations on the judiciary, fundamental rights, justice, freedom and security remain to be prepared. Serbia needs to take further steps to implement the legal framework for the protection of minorities, especially in the fields of education, religion and culture. It is important to clarify the legal status of the National Councils of Minorities. All minorities must be represented in the Serbian Parliament in order to increase the effective involvement of minority representatives in the decision-making process. Serbia must give national minorities access to public administration and representative bodies at local, regional and national level, respect and strongly promote their non-discriminatory treatment. I hope that the Romanian minority will enjoy in the near future this process of Serbia's legal alignment with European standards.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing.- I voted against this report.The European Union, puffed up with arrogance, gives itself the right to monitor the situation in Serbia and allows itself to judge it.As is always the case in its reports, the Union interferes in Serbian affairs by giving "advice".It even goes so far as to undermine the culture of the country by allowing itself to impose on Serbia ideas about family and sexuality that concern only the Serbian people!We oppose this text.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this resolution, which ‘Stresses the importance of the work of civil society organisations in a democratic society; notes that cooperation between the government and civil society organisations has improved; encourages the Serbian authorities to take additional measures to ensure a transparent dialogue between civil society and state institutions, and to increase the effective involvement of representatives of civil society and of national minorities in the decision-making process; calls on the authorities to guarantee adequate financial support for the efficient functioning of civil society organisations; calls for timely and transparent communication to citizens, organisations and the general public on the developments of the accession negotiation process and to facilitate their broad participation in this process’.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: written.- I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution on Serbia, in which we welcome the opening of the first negotiating chapters within the EU accession process.Now, Belgrade needs to continue with reforms to ensure the independence of judges and prosecutors and the media and to intensify the battle against corruption and criminal networks.

name: Georg MAYER
text: written.- Kosovo is and will remain a province in the heart of Serbia.The Serb majority only became a minority through targeted infiltration.If we continue to recognize the now predominant Muslim majority in Kosovo - which came about in addition to infiltration, displacement and military conquest - as a legitimate reason for independence, then we will soon have to accept many other regions in the middle of Europe as independent.Because soon Muslims will be in the majority in many parts of Europe.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the EP resolution assessing Serbia's progress towards EU membership in 2015.The resolution discusses the situation of democratic reforms, the rule of law, human rights in Serbia, as well as the country's environmental, transport, energy and regional cooperation policies, and identifies the main directions of reforms that should be implemented in order to achieve EU integration.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: in writing. - The resolution welcomes the opening of the chapters of accession negotiations and the "ambitious" economic program that Serbia had to put in place to show a white footing. "Golden rule", privatization of public enterprises and limitation of public aid: everywhere the same neoliberal policies with the same disastrous effects for the people. Serbia is a centerpiece of Merkel's economic annexation of Europe, in particular via the "Berlin process" which should ensure a corridor of transport infrastructure to deepen European social dumping. The good student apprentice is not at the end of his troubles, especially when the EU will ask him in addition to recognize the independence of Kosovo (against the very position of the UN). Since the war, the EU has taken over from NATO to judge the country's "performance" in terms of good respect for its line in foreign affairs. Understand: end all relations with Russia and develop cooperation with NATO. In short, after the butchering, unconditional surrender. For these reasons, I vote Against

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: in writing.- Serbia is a small country of seven million inhabitants, following the conflicts in the years 1990. Wherever they are citizens now, the Serbs find themselves victims of a new map of Europe.However, the only prospect, by default, of this regional power is European integration through which it hopes to regain a rank worthy of itself.The country is the subject of special monitoring by the European Commission as it pursues the objective of integrating the Union by 2020. This focuses on economic criteria considered as the alpha andthe omega of the country's future.However, I note that when Croatia joined the Union, two and a half years ago, it was a disaster for its economy.Finally, the question of Kosovo, whose independence Serbia will have to recognize in order to join the Union, is an insurmountable blockage that the report eludes.I therefore voted against this text.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the resolution on the 2015 Serbia report.The EU must continue to promote its appeasement policy with regard to relations between Serbia and Kosovo.It is important for Serbia to continue its reform program and to remain an important EU partner in the Balkans.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because it is important to meaningfully analyse the happenings in Serbia and to start the European Integration process. This resolution also notes the positive steps Serbia has taken with the drafting of a dedicated Action Plan for National Minorities.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: written. - In 2003, the European Council issued the prospect of the accession of the countries of the Western Balkans. Ten years later, the same European Council effectively opened the negotiations for Serbia's accession. In the annual progress report, Parliament takes stock of the progress made by the candidate country. It is important to note that Serbia has already started preparing action plans for the reforms to be implemented in the areas of justice, the judiciary and security. It is therefore appropriate to open the relevant chapters in 2016, but at the same time to insist on respecting fundamental freedoms such as freedom of the press. The budget deficit has been reduced and progress has been made in the organization of the labor market, although important efforts still need to be made to improve the investment and business environment in Serbia. Waste processing in Serbia remains a tricky issue and it is therefore recommended that Serbia remediates the thousands of illegal landfills and makes effective a sustainable waste policy. Serbia's entry also depends on relations with Kosovo. It is hopeful that important steps have been taken to normalize those relationships.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing - Serbia has a turbulent history that has greatly influenced the country's development.As Serbia has set itself the goal of joining the European Union, not only the government but also the population, each generation must make an effort to meet the set criteria as a state.This path is not easy, as every country that has gone through the period leading up to EU accession knows.Recently, however, Serbia has made great strides towards European integration in a number of areas.I particularly appreciate the progress made in the area of business, including through appropriate legislation.Improving the business environment could reduce regional disparities, which are a reality in Serbia.Economic reforms will continue to be important for Serbia in the future, but further steps await it, especially in the area of the rule of law and democracy.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I welcomed the 2015 Progress Report on Serbia and the opening of first chapters end of last year and support the opening of Chapters 23 and 24 in the EU enlargement negotiations with this important player in the Western Balkans this year. Therefore, I voted in favour of this Report. However, it should also be underlined that a lot of work lies ahead.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing. - Serbia has applied for membership of the European Union and the European Council of 28 June 2013 decided to open accession negotiations with Serbia. On 10 November 2015, the Commission published its 2015 Report on Serbia, which reported on Serbia's progress in European integration and assessed the country's efforts to meet the Copenhagen criteria and the conditionality of the Stabilization and Association Process. The draft resolution of the Committee on Foreign Affairs proposes that Parliament welcome the opening of negotiations, the preparations made by Serbia for the effective start of accession negotiations, and the progress made by Serbia in various areas. He also suggested that Parliament draw attention to further efforts in the areas of the rule of law, democracy, human rights, respect for and protection of minorities, regional cooperation and good neighborly relations, and energy, the environment and transport. I supported the motion.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. - Serbia, as well as all countries that aspire to join the EU, should be assessed on their own merits as regards compliance, application and respect for the same set of criteria and that these countries' dedication to necessary reforms and quality these determine the timetable for membership. It is worth noting the Serbian Government's continued commitment to the process of European integration, at the beginning of an ambitious program of progressive reforms, covering the business environment, the reduction of the budget deficit and the labor market. I highlight the adoption of important measures by Serbia in favor of normalizing relations with Kosovo, which led to the first agreement on the principles governing the normalization of relations in 2013 and which, in 2015, four important agreements were reached. I think it is important for Serbia to improve its judicial system, to make it independent and impartial; reinforce the fight against corruption and organized crime and extend the protection of human rights and fundamental freedoms to the most vulnerable groups, namely with regard to non-discrimination of persons with disabilities, people with HIV / AIDS and LGBTI people.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: in writing.- This report relates to the 2015 follow-up on Serbia.However, this is an alignment of attacks on its sovereignty through overt interference.This report is therefore a compendium of Community arrogance towards Serbia.So I decided to vote against this text.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing.- I abstained from the vote on this monitoring report concerning Serbia.Indeed, although I am in favor of the references therein to the progress made by Serbia in many areas and in particular in that of the normalization of its relations with Kosovo, this text contains provisions likely to maintainsterile escalation of sanctions between the European Union and Russia, which I regularly fight in the European Parliament.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: in writing.- Within the framework of the integration process of Serbia, I would like to salute the reform efforts of the Serbian government and to recall the basic principles which are ours.I therefore voted in favor of the resolution, which describes the current situation and encourages Serbia on its path to European Union membership.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ In 2015 the report on Serbia notes its efforts to comply with the Copenhagen criteria and the conditionality of the Stabilisation and Association Process towards European integration. I have voted for this motion for a resolution that welcomes the opening of negotiations on financial control at the Intergovernmental Conference that took place in Brussels on the 14th of December 2015. This new report highlights Serbia’s progress and areas that need improving on the rule of law, democracy, human rights, respect for and protection of minorities, regional cooperation and good neighbourly relations, energy, the environment and transport.

name: Dan NICA
text: signed up. - I voted in favor of the 2015 progress report on Serbia. Serbia, as a contracting party to the Energy Community, should remain active in the Energy Community institutions and continue to implement the acquis in order to build sustainable and secure energy systems. The authorities should start implementing the objectives set out in the energy development strategy, as there is no significant investment in the renewable energy sector. We encourage Serbia to develop competition in the natural gas market and to take measures to improve alignment with the acquis in the fields of renewable energy and energy efficiency. The Commission should play a greater role in supporting the Serbian government in reducing the country's dependence on energy imports and diversifying Serbia's gas supply. We draw attention to the IPA II package 2015 which includes a program of EUR 155 million to contribute to the financing of major regional infrastructure projects in the energy and transport sectors of the Western Balkans. We also encourage Serbia to align with the EU's average climate change commitments and the Paris Agreement at COP 21.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: written.- I voted against this report because it essentially reduces Serbia's autonomy in favor of increased influence from Brussels.Serbia should retain the right to an independent foreign policy and - beyond a minimum - be able to decide for itself whether and, if so, to what extent it wants to stand up for the rights of certain minorities in its own country.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: in writing. - It is to be welcomed that Serbia has finally embarked on an ambitious reform agenda. This is the first step that the country is moving towards the EU and is ready to meet all the requirements of the European integration process. It should be noted that Serbia must meet requirements that are not only economic but also political. In particular, the country needs to pursue systematic and socio-economic reforms with determination and without hesitation. Economic governance, the rule of law and the capacity of the public administration need to be strengthened, as well as regional cooperation and good neighborly relations. In addition, there is a need to improve investment conditions throughout Serbia and to reduce economic and social disparities between their regions. Greater attention needs to be paid to the implementation of the rule of law, the strengthening of trust in the judiciary and the direct strengthening of cooperation between Serbian and Kosovo law enforcement and liaison offices in Belgrade and Pristina.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against. However, we recognise the importance of information sharing for British policing and are supportive of such measures, with appropriate safeguards, on a bilateral basis.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing.- On 28 June 2013 the European Council decided to start accession negotiations with Serbia, a country that aspires to become a member of the EU.Two years later, the Commission reported on the excellent progress made by the country towards European integration, I would therefore have voted positively, declaring admiration and support for this country.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – Serbia has made substantial progress on its path towards the European Union. As a neighbouring country to Bulgaria, the two countries are closely related and cross-border cooperation could be facilitated if Serbia enters the EU. I welcome Serbian reform efforts and I vote in favour of the report.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: in writing. ‒ I congratulate Serbia for its real progress towards the EU, especially for the recently opened chapters. The opening of EU accession negotiations means that Serbia has successfully put itslef into reform mode. Happy that in EU spirit, Serbia keeps a supportive attitude towards the reconciliation process with Kosovo. I won't compete with those who enumerate problems in Serbia, but join those who are committed to the opening of chapters 23&24.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - I believe that the successful continuation of Serbia's accession negotiations with the European Union is of crucial importance not only for the wider European community, but also for the entire region. These negotiations will significantly contribute to the stabilization processes within Southeast Europe and provide an encouraging example to neighboring candidate countries. However, Serbia must respect the acquis communautaire. Ensuring the rights of national minorities, and in particular their right to education and media programs in their mother tongue, is extremely important, so Serbia must take concrete steps in this direction and respect the rights of Croats in Serbia. Furthermore, of special interest to Croatia are the issues of jurisdiction over war crimes committed during the Homeland War, as well as the problem of missing persons and the return of cultural goods and property. Serbia has made no progress in this regard. Successfully resolving these issues would be a clear indication that Serbia is ready for integration with the European Union and for deeper cooperation with neighboring countries. I supported the progress report on Serbia for 2015, because it points to important problems that Serbia still has to solve on its way to the EU, but also in relations with neighboring countries.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: in writing.- This report full of arrogance is written under the influence of prejudices hostile towards Serbia.He is not objective and constantly calls for extreme interference in the affairs of this country.The consistency of the European Union in carrying out stupid and catastrophic policies in the Balkans cannot be denied.I therefore vote against this text.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. - With a view to joining the European Union, Serbia is making a great deal of progress to meet EU requirements. In particular, the country has taken important steps forward in the process of normalizing relations with Kosovo, a negotiating condition for EU membership. Having recognized Serbia's progress towards EU membership, I voted in favor of this resolution because it is necessary to continue to support the country by indicating the sectors in which to operate. This path involves carrying out reforms that free the judiciary from political interference, as well as a greater commitment to the fight against corruption, abuse of power and organized crime. Furthermore, the country must engage in a virtuous dialogue with civil society, the importance of which is reiterated by the Commission's invitation to the Serbian government to conduct regular public consultations that ensure full transparency in negotiations with the EU. There is still some concern about the involvement of parliament in legislative consultations, as the use of the urgent procedure for the adoption of laws is a widely used practice which, however, does not allow the full exercise of democracy. Serbia therefore still needs to fulfill many aspects and it is important that the Union favors the government in this process.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written. - I thank my colleague McAllister for a constructive report on the state of affairs and the progress that Serbia has made in the past year. An improved legislative framework to be followed by effective implementation, participation in peacekeeping missions, progress on the Euro-integration path are just some of them. At the same time, this report covers much of the content of last year's report, which means that Serbia still has a lot of work to do. Endangered freedom of the media, insufficiently effective fight against corruption, progress in the rule of law, participation of the opposition in democratic processes, respect for human and minority rights, harmonization with EU foreign policy are part of the "to-do" list that Serbia must join without delay. The opening of negotiations with Serbia marks the beginning of "positive pressure" to seriously transform a large number of sectors in the neighboring country. As highlighted in the report, a constructive contribution to relations with neighbors and resolving remaining bilateral issues such as border demarcation, missing persons, succession, minority rights in Vojvodina and war crimes law is extremely important in this process. By solving problems from the past, we open the space for discussion and cooperation on issues, I hope of a common, European future.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. - This motion for a resolution weaves a wide range of considerations into the process of Serbia's integration into the EU. Well beyond the evaluation of the process, it points to a wide range of constraints towards accession, which confirm the extent of interference and loss of sovereignty imposed on countries and peoples in the process of joining the EU. We highlight reforms in the judicial and political system, recognition by Serbia of the existence of Kosovo, labor reforms, privatizations, restructuring of the public sector, protection of private investment, budget reform, impositions in the context of the functioning of institutions, cooperation with the Criminal Court International for Former Yugoslavia. Successive enlargements have allowed large economic and financial groups to expand the Community's internal market, allowing new economies to dominate, creating new opportunities for the exploitation of a qualified and low-cost labor force. It is unacceptable the manorial stance with which the recitals and conditions required to satisfy the precepts regarding the integration of the country are exposed, taking away from the peoples the legitimate right to decide their future, where they belong, the free and sovereign choice of EU membership. , but also economic and social development strategies. For these reasons, we voted against.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing.- The opening of the first negotiating chapters in Serbia's accession process to the European Union were welcomed by the European Parliament.Serbia has taken important steps towards the normalization of relations with Kosovo and has been able to face the migratory crisis with great capacity.I hope that Serbia will continue its systematic reforms, so that the work of judges and prosecutors, as well as that of the media, can be free from political influence and aimed at stepping up efforts to fight corruption and organized crime.I voted in favor of this resolution.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing.- I voted for the 2015 monitoring report on Serbia.As its name suggests, this report sums up the difficulties and inherent needs for progress necessary for Serbia to come closer to European standards of stability.This while underlining the positive aspects of the country in order to support it in its policy.It is a balanced report.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against. However, we recognise the importance of information sharing for British policing and are supportive of such measures, with appropriate safeguards, on a bilateral basis.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. - (PT) I voted in favor of this report as the Serbian Government's continued commitment to the process of European integration is recognized. Therefore, I agree that Serbia should continue to make a decisive and direct contribution to systemic and socio-economic reforms, continuing the preparatory work aimed at the effective start of accession negotiations. I welcome this report in which essential considerations are made for the evolution of this process, namely with regard to the rule of law, democracy, human rights, respect and protection for minorities, regional cooperation, good neighborly relations, energy, environment and transport . I therefore voted in favor of this report because I believe that it contains essential recommendations for Serbia's European integration process, more specifically with regard to the rigorous application of the legislation and policies necessary for alignment with EU standards.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: written. - This report makes a detailed analysis of the progress of the negotiations for the accession to the EU of Serbia. The opening of the chapters on financial control and the process to normalize relations with Kosovo are noteworthy. Furthermore, the report highlights Serbia's commitment to the European integration process. Although progress has been significant, this document highlights that Serbia has a lot of work to do: on the one hand, there is a lack of greater commitment from Serbia to press freedom, and conditions for freedom of the press are worsening expression, and on the other hand there is a lack of a real effort to fight corruption, since there is a lack of transparency in the financing of political parties and electoral campaigns. Finally, the report also invites Serbia to make further efforts to improve the situation of the Roma and to ensure the consistent application throughout the country of the legislation on the protection of minorities. That is why I have voted in favor of this report.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing.- I abstained on this resolution relating to Serbia, which was adopted by 498 votes in favor, 66 against and 70 abstentions and the text of which welcomes the opening of negotiations for accession to the European Union.On the other hand, I have supported the country's efforts to continue its systematic reforms, to ensure that the work of judges and prosecutors, as well as of the media, is free from political interference, and to intensifyits efforts to fight corruption and organized crime.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution because it is very important to monitor Serbia's progress in implementing reforms.No less important is to identify Serbia's achievements and to assess possible challenges from the outside.The report also calls for a stronger focus on clean energy in Serbia.At the same time, the Commission is called upon to support the Serbian government's efforts to reduce the country's dependence on imported energy by diversifying Serbia's gas supplies.These steps are important not only for Serbia, but also for the European Union in the context of both security and climate change.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. - The EU has been reaffirming that the European Union's priorities are related to growth and jobs, together with investment in peace, democracy, prosperity, security and stability across the continent, with enlargement being a process that takes on a secondary character in this legislature. However, Serbia's accession negotiations with the EU began in June 2013, with progress being assessed by the country towards its European integration, in particular, taking into account the conformity of its reforms with the rule of law. In view of Serbia's significant and important progress, it can be said that the negotiations are moving in a positive direction. The respect and protection of human rights deserve to be highlighted, namely, their attitude towards the migrants' crisis, the full respect shown for the protection of the most vulnerable groups, as well as the effective application of European legislation and the efforts made by this country in the concerning their position in regional cooperation and in establishing good neighborly relations. Therefore, I am pleased to note that Serbia has adopted measures that are allowing it to move closer to the EU, so I voted in favor of this report.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this monitoring report on Serbia for the year 2015. Every year, Parliament adopts a report on the candidate states for membership of the Union, including Serbia, a candidate countrysince 2010. It should be noted that Serbia has a positive dynamic and is engaged in many reforms.I supported this text because it nevertheless recalls that Serbia must intensify its legislative reforms and ensure their effective implementation, in particular as regards the independence of the judiciary, the fight against corruption and organized crime, orstill freedom of speech and media.Finally, this text asks Serbia to continue to normalize its relations with Kosovo and to commit to strengthening its good neighborly relations, and progressive alignment with the CFSP.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing.- The European Union must encourage those countries, such as Serbia, which are making considerable efforts in the right direction and recognize the results achieved.Moreover, let us not forget the key role of the Balkan area, which is once again the gateway between East and West, a crossroads for thousands of migrants who cross it to try to reach Europe.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: written.- We abstain in this vote, understanding that the paragraph of this Resolution concerning Kosovo: 1) contravenes international law since, although the International Court of Justice concluded that Kosovo's unilateral declaration of independence did not violate international law or Resolution 1244of the United Nations Security Council, and that the process of nationalization of Kosovo is irreversible, the ruling does not imply that the former province has a well-founded right to be recognized by third parties;2) not only does it not contribute anything to the necessary political resolution of the conflict, but it also interferes in relations between Russia and Serbia and hinders the proper approach to actions leading to a real and lasting stabilization of the area.Furthermore, we reject the nature and orientation of the economic measures implicit and explicit in the proposed Resolution.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: in writing.- I welcome the fact that Serbia has prepared for a real start to accession negotiations with the conclusion of the screening process and the preparation and presentation of the comprehensive action plan for Chapters 23 (Justice and Fundamental Rights) and 24 (Justice, Freedom and Security).

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: written. - I voted against the Resolution on the 2015 Report on Serbia, although it contains positive aspects such as recognition of the important steps taken by this country towards the normalization of relations with Kosovo or the importance of respect and protection of minorities that inhabit Serbian territory. However, the Resolution is mainly aimed at encouraging the process of integration of Serbia into the EU, with all that this entails and that is included in the Resolution itself: the demand for structural economic reforms (knowing that this euphemism implies the cut of the social and labor rights of the popular classes), the restructuring of public companies (privatizations), the correction of budgetary imbalances (cuts in public spending), the protection of foreign investments (protect large transnational corporations), etc. These are measures and demands that I consider very negative for the popular classes of any country.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: in writing. - Serbia is an important partner in the region for the EU, which is why it is important to establish and develop the situation in the context of accession negotiations, as well as current cooperation on issues such as the migration crisis. Serbia has made important progress in recent times, further contributing to the deepening of the positive dimension of relations with the Union. It is necessary to continue to fulfill the criteria of the rule of law and to ensure adequate protection of minority rights. It is advisable that new commitments should be made and implemented in this regard, as this approach at the current stage of the negotiations will help to avoid complications and additional requirements at a later stage. The introduced reforms not only serve to meet the formal requirements imposed by the EU on the candidate countries, but also bring specific benefits for society and the economy. It is worth emphasizing here the pursuit of the principles of democracy, which is manifested, inter alia, in the activity of citizens and the presence of constructive opposition or freedom of the media, which are an inseparable component of democracy. In the case of Serbia, it is also worth mentioning its role, its role in stabilizing the region and its development deserves to be emphasized. For this reason, the normalization of the situation in Serbia and a constructive dialogue with Kosovo constitute the basis for the development of favorable and rational economic and political strategies for neighboring countries that are the EU's close neighbors and partners.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ This is still the initial stages of what is an incredibly long process, which I don’t suspect is going to be concluded for some time to come. It has been well documented that conditionality pressure from the EU has massive benefits for the development of democratic institutions and in the fight against corruption. But, of course this is not a linear process, and in a time of increasing populism around Europe, knock-backs will happen. Indeed, this report adds to this pressure by drawing attention to problems in the country, such as media freedom, deteriorating conditions for freedom of expression, lack of transparency in the funding of political parties and election campaigns, and calls on Serbia to make further efforts to improve the situation of their political institutions.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report, but this explanation of vote arises as a critique of the current system of evaluating the work of MPs in the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities emphasized in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual qualityactions.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing - The European Council decided on 28 June 2013 to open negotiations with Serbia on EU accession, with the country's monitoring process ending in March 2015, and now the Commission has submitted a 2015 progress report to Serbia and Serbia. has taken a major step towards normalizing relations with Kosovo, making significant progress in the business environment, reducing the budget deficit and the labor market, including labor law and employment policy. The rule of law, an independent judiciary, is of key importance to Serbia. Here, despite some progress in adopting provisions on the evaluation of judges and prosecutors, the level of influence remains high, so Serbia needs to implement a national judicial reform strategy so that judges and prosecutors are not influenced by politicians and the government. Concerns are raised about corruption and organized crime, which are obstacles to Serbia's democratic, social and economic development. The report appreciates the Serbian government's constructive approach to relations with neighboring countries, which has enabled significant progress to be made in deepening regional cooperation and strengthening relations with the EU.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: in writing. - The motion for a resolution concerns the Commission's 2015 report on Serbia. In the report, the Commission outlines the progress that Serbia has made in the field of European approximation and assesses its efforts to meet the Copenhagen criteria and the conditions of the Stabilization and Association Process. I agree that thorough implementation of legislation and policies remains an essential indicator of a successful integration process. That is why I think it is important that Serbian political leaders continue to reform their legislation so that it is in line with EU standards. The motion for a resolution welcomes Serbia's progress in the area of ​​the business environment and the reduction of the budget deficit in the labor market. However, the motion for a resolution also contains an important emphasis on the crucial importance of the rule of law and an independent judiciary. Some other proposals are highlighted, which reflect some of the most important European principles. As such, I can mention the need to improve the parliamentary consultation process, the proper implementation of the legal and institutional framework for the protection of human rights and fundamental freedoms, the importance of integrating national minorities, the Serbian government's constructive approach to relations with neighboring countries and building sustainable and reliable energy systems. I believe that the motion for a resolution represents an appropriate response to the above-mentioned report on Serbia for 2015, which is why I also supported the report in plenary.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. - I voted today in favor of the report illustrating Serbia's progress in the negotiation process for accession to the European Union and the need to accelerate it. Given the particularly ambitious nature of the reform agenda that the country aims to implement in the future, Serbia needs our support in this process. Indeed, among the next objectives to be achieved in the short term, Serbia sets itself the strengthening of the rule of law, the fight against corruption and the creation of better living conditions for Serbian society. As also highlighted in the resolution, it is essential that the country act quickly to improve the situation of media freedom and freedom of expression and the independence of the judiciary from any interference from political power. These assumptions represent the essential conditions for successfully continuing the integration process, in the awareness that this could lead to a significant improvement in the Serbian economy and consequently an improvement in the country's political stability.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing - I support Serbia's Euro-integration ambitions and its political and social changes.However, it is crucial that Belgrade and Pristina find a way to organize their relations.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: written. - On 28 June 2013, the European Council decided to open accession negotiations with Serbia. The first intergovernmental conference was held on 21 January 2014, the analytical review was completed in March 2015, and Serbia assembled a negotiating team in September 2015. I welcome the progress made on economic reforms, which has improved Serbia's budgetary situation, and call on the Commission to continue to support the government in its plans to implement additional reforms, in particular with regard to addressing fiscal imbalances and reforms in key sectors of the economy. Corruption and organized crime are widespread in the region and are also an obstacle to Serbia's democratic, social and economic development. I would stress the importance of the work of civil society organizations in a democratic society. I express my concern at the fact that no progress has been made in improving the situation regarding freedom of speech and the media. It is necessary to create adequate representation of minorities in local, regional and national representative and administrative bodies, ensure the possibility of using minority languages ​​in the media and education, and it is important that Serbia facilitates the search for missing persons and continue cooperation in war crimes prosecutions with the ICTY. I call on Serbia to review the disputed law, which unjustifiably extends jurisdiction to the territory of neighboring countries, including two EU members, and thus leads to legal uncertainty and jeopardizes good neighborly relations, and together with the Commission and neighboring countries to establish a legal system in line with European legal standards. .

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written. - On 28 June 2013, the European Council decided to start accession negotiations with Serbia. In its 2015 report, the European Commission found that Serbia has made progress towards European integration. In January 2015, Serbia took over the chairmanship of the OSCE. Serbia has also taken important steps towards normalizing relations with Kosovo, but further efforts are needed to finally calm those relations. Economic governance, the rule of law and public administration capacity need to be strengthened. Parliament calls on Serbia to align its foreign and security policy with that of the European Union, which includes its policy towards Russia. Serbia's active participation in international peacekeeping operations is also welcomed. Regarding Vojvodina, it is noted that the cultural diversity of Vojvodina contributes to the identity of Serbia and that the autonomy of Vojvodina should not be reduced. The report urges Serbia to continue co-operating with the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia in a spirit of reconciliation and good neighborly relations. I support the proposal for this resolution with its recommendations and guidelines for Serbia's further progress towards European integration. As one of the key countries in the Western Balkans, Serbia's involvement in European integration ensures security in the region and enables better good neighborly relations.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the resolution at the end of the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the 2015 report on Serbia. I welcome the normalization and thaw in relations between Belgrade and Pristina.This is a very important condition for membership of the European Union.With this, Serbia has made a big step on the path to the European Union.Of course, there are still many chapters to close.These include the area of justice and fundamental rights and the safeguarding of rights in relation to freedom and security.I have in mind, above all, the freedom of the media, which is very important for the existence of democracy.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the resolution on the 2015 report on Serbia, as this resolution further develops the European Commission's original report in a positive spirit of supporting Serbia's efforts to meet the conditions for EU accession. Serbia is now becoming an important partner of the EU in the Western Balkans and needs to be given sufficient support to be able to gradually fulfill all the conditions for membership. The basis here is a functioning judicial system that will ensure compliance with the newly adopted rules. Serbia has yet to make progress in this area, as well as in the fight against organized crime, as well as in the area of ​​minority rights, whose members are often a source of migratory pressure in the EU. The coherence of Serbia's foreign policy with the EU's foreign policy is also important, especially towards Russia. However, the report also notes the progress that Serbia is making in the area of ​​neighborhood relations. Good neighborly relations are a prerequisite for possible future EU membership.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: in writing. - We abstained from the relevant report as the proposals that are being promoted seek intervention within the country, creating relations of dependence instead of cooperation. Through the report, the EU calls on Serbia to continue the process of normalizing its relations with Kosovo and to proceed with its substantive recognition. Serbia is also called upon to align its foreign and security policy with that of the EU, especially with regard to Russia, and to pursue tough neoliberal economic reforms of harsh austerity, which have led to rising unemployment and poverty, and reduced productivity. and in a huge budget deficit. However, we did not vote against the report as the decision to join the EU is a right of the country itself and its people.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: in writing.- This progress report imposes on Serbia the absorption of a large wave of illegal immigrants, thus exacerbating the already aggravated situation in the Balkans.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the decision to adopt the report, given that I firmly believe that Serbia is a key partner for the EU, the stability of the Western Balkans, our economic and infrastructural relations and, in the light of recent dramatic developments, the management of migration to Europe. both in the field. This decision is therefore in an important and concrete European interest, with the European Parliament reaffirming in a positive, encouraging way the results of the reform process in Serbia so far, the steps taken to normalize with Kosovo, which allowed accession negotiations to begin at the end of last year. I believe that the parliamentary support for the Serbian accession process, as expressed in this resolution, also entitles the EP to continue to monitor the reform process there closely and to hold Belgrade accountable in the areas of civil, minority rights, justice, media and other areas. address remaining shortcomings and then assess the forthcoming early elections. For my part, I also hope from the EP's clear resolution that the European Commission will finally recognize that the case of Serbia is the best example of a mistake in brackets EU enlargement in the Commission's five-year program, as it can be seen that the pace of accession is always it is also a renewable, topical and concrete interest for the Union and for Europe as a whole.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: signed up. - The European Union encourages the European perspectives of the countries of the Western Balkans, a region considered to belong entirely to the natural area of ​​enlargement of the Union. Within this area, relations with Serbia have experienced a winding but steadily upward trend. The EU's relations with the Serbian state are currently at an excellent level, as evidenced by the opening of accession negotiations. In the last year, the opening of negotiations on Chapter 32, on financial control, and on Chapter 35, on the normalization of relations with Kosovo, is to be welcomed. Also, despite a rather complicated domestic political life, it is worth noting the pro-European attitude of most of the relevant political forces in Serbia. Progress has been made through the liberalization of the EU visa regime for Serbian citizens. However, the report for 2015 also highlights a number of issues that persist internally, such as freedom of the media, deteriorating conditions for freedom of expression, lack of transparency in the financing of political parties and election campaigns. The report also notes the need to coordinate efforts to improve the situation of the Roma minority and implement legislation to protect minorities. I believe that the document reflects the situation in Serbia and supports its adoption in this form.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the text.I welcome the opening of negotiations and chapter 32 at the intergovernmental conference in Brussels on December 14, 2015 and Serbia's continued commitment to the process of European integration.Serbia must take action to make this strategic decision known to the Serbian population.This country must also resolutely tackle systemic reforms head-on and pay particular attention to its young people in the implementation of its reforms!

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the progress report on Serbia as it supports Serbia’s European integration. Nevertheless, corruption and pressure on the media remain crucial outstanding issues. Indeed, it is essential that the country implement reforms in the areas of judiciary and fundamental rights and of justice, freedom and security. Moreover, corruption and organised crime are widespread in the region and also represent an obstacle to Serbia’s democratic, social and economic development and if progress has been made in this area, Serbia has to step up its efforts. I also believe that the negotiation of chapter 35 on normalising relations with Kosovo is of crucial importance for Serbia’s progress on its path towards EU integration.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing.- I supported my colleague McAllister's report as I share the balanced assessment of Serbia's progress on its way to the European Union.Many efforts have been made in recent years to implement economic and structural reform programs and the commitment to a more efficient public administration as well as the strengthening of the rule of law and the adoption of action plans for the normalization of relations is appreciable.with Kosovo.Serbia is also fully addressing the migration crisis, which is why it is an essential and collaborative partner of the EU in the Balkans and therefore it is essential that the Union provides resources and appropriate financial support.It is important, however, that from an internal point of view Serbia improves the cooperation between the government and civil society organizations and increases the involvement of national minorities in the decision-making process.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: in writing. - The 2015 Progress Report on Serbia welcomes Serbia's continued commitment to the European integration process and has made significant progress in this direction. The document emphasizes that serious and sustainable progress is inconceivable without the rule of law. He notes that the cultural diversity of Vojvodina contributes to Serbia’s identity. It also calls on the Serbian authorities to ensure consistent implementation of legislation on the protection of minorities throughout the country, including in the areas of education, language use, public administration representation and access to media and church services in minority languages. Given that Serbia is at the forefront of Hungarian national, neighborhood and security policy, and in defense of the interests of the Hungarians in Vojvodina, I voted in favor of the report.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing.- I supported the motion for a resolution concluding the debate on the statements by the Council and the Commission pursuant to Rule 123 (2) of the Rules of Procedure on the 2015 Report on Serbia, as it describes well the achievements so far as well as the shortcomingsEuropean convergence.It covers several areas, from the rule of law, democracy, human rights, respect for and protection of minorities, regional cooperation and good neighborly relations to energy, the environment and transport.In addition, the EU warns the country and urges which areas it needs to pay extra attention to in order for the accession negotiations to be successful.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: written.- We abstain in this vote, understanding that the paragraph of this Resolution concerning Kosovo: 1) contravenes international law since, although the International Court of Justice concluded that Kosovo's unilateral declaration of independence did not violate international law or Resolution 1244of the United Nations Security Council, and that the process of nationalization of Kosovo is irreversible, the ruling does not imply that the former province has a well-founded right to be recognized by third parties;2) not only does it not contribute anything to the necessary political resolution of the conflict, but it also interferes in relations between Russia and Serbia and hinders the proper approach to actions leading to a real and lasting stabilization of the area.Furthermore, we reject the nature and orientation of the economic measures implicit and explicit in the proposed Resolution.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: written. - On the basis of this resolution, the European Parliament issues an opinion on the Commission report in which the Commission set out Serbia's progress towards European integration. The resolution welcomes Serbia's progress so far, including improving the business environment and reducing the budget deficit. At the same time, she notes that corruption and organized crime are widespread in the region, which also stands in the way of the democratic, social and economic development of Serbia. In general, it is a good and balanced opinion that I have taken note of as such. However, I cannot identify with the fact that in the face of current problems, new accession chapters are being opened and further accession negotiations are being conducted. For a long time, EU leaders have only known one answer: ever more and ever larger Europe. In the situation when the structural deficiencies of the eurozone continue to deepen and Great Britain is considering leaving the EU, it is extremely dishonest on our part to give Serbia the prospect of accession. The EU must first be able to solve its problems, i. H. must first reform itself so that an EU enlargement can come into question. From this point of view I could not support the abovementioned parliamentary resolution and abstained from the vote.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing.- At its meeting on 28 June 2013, the European Council decided to open accession negotiations with Serbia.The first intergovernmental conference took place on 21 January 2014.The screening process was completed in March 2015.In its 2015 report on Serbia, the Commission reported on Serbia's progress in European integration and assessed the country's efforts to meet the Copenhagen criteria and the conditionality of the Stabilization and Association Process.The Commission has taken a new approach to reporting, which provides much clearer guidance to the countries concerned on what to focus on.I voted in favor of the report.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: in writing.- I emphasize the great importance of the rule of law;emphasize the crucial importance of independent judiciaries;notes that, although some progress has been made in the area of the judiciary, in particular with the adoption of rules on the evaluation of judges and prosecutors, there is still much political interference in this area;I call on the authorities to implement the national strategy for judicial reform.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because I firmly believe in Serbia´s European prospects. Access negotiations between Serbia and the EU were opened in 2013 and in December 2015 the first two chapters were opened, which is a clear signal that the country is on the right track towards EU membership. Matters of concern still remain, most notably high levels of corruption and a recent increase of political pressure on the media. Also, Serbia will have to improve its relations with Kosovo in order for negotiations to advance further. As of now, Serbia´s progress must nevertheless be acknowledged and that is why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I was satisfied to vote in favour of the 2015 Progress Report on Serbia. I fully support the proper integration of Serbia into the European family, and it is vital that Serbia continues to carry forward its ambitious reform agenda. Strengthening the rule of law, fighting corruption and providing a better standard of life for everyday Serbians will help not only Serbia, but the Balkans and by extension the rest of the Europe. For Serbia the process of integration is the best way to improve both the country's economic situation and building political stability.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: written.- I voted for this report.I support the further integration of Serbia into the European family.It is important that Serbia continues its ambitious reforms in order to strengthen the rule of law, further fight corruption and greatly improve the day-to-day life of Serbs.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - We do not follow a wide range of recitals on the process of integrating Serbia into the EU. Beyond the evaluation of the process, the resolution points to a wide range of constraints towards accession, which confirm the extent of interference and loss of sovereignty imposed on countries and peoples in the process of joining the EU. Look at the reforms in the judicial and political system, the recognition by Serbia of the existence of Kosovo, labor reforms, privatizations, the restructuring of the public sector, the protection of private investment, budget reform, the impositions within the scope of functioning of the institutions, cooperation with the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia. The successive enlargements of the EU have allowed large economic and financial groups to expand the Community's internal market, allowing new economies to dominate, creating new opportunities for the exploitation of a qualified and low-cost labor force. It is unacceptable the manorial stance with which the recitals and conditions required to satisfy the precepts regarding the integration of the country are exposed, depriving people of the legitimate right to decide their future, where the free and sovereign choice of EU membership is inscribed, but also economic and social development strategies. For these reasons, we voted against.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: written.- Kosovo is and will remain a province in the heart of Serbia.The Serb majority only became a minority through targeted infiltration.If we continue to recognize the now predominant Muslim majority in Kosovo - which came about in addition to infiltration, displacement and military conquest - as a legitimate reason for independence, then we will soon have to accept many other regions in the middle of Europe as independent.Because soon Muslims will be in the majority in many parts of Europe.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing.- Thank you President.I strongly supported Serbia's progress report in 2015. It has been an important year as accession negotiations have begun, with the opening of Chapters 32 and 35 (which includes the normalization of relations with Kosovo).Despite the progress, some gaps remain to be filled, in particular as regards freedom of the media, freedom of expression, lack of transparency in the financing of political parties.Serbia must strive to overcome these shortcomings and create an inclusive society for all, including minorities.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: written.- I did not vote in favor of the EU Parliament's resolution on the report on Serbia.I am against admitting further members to the EU as long as it has not resolved its structural and institutional problems.This also includes a new version of the European Treaties.I refuse to start accession negotiations with Serbia.I also oppose all further steps that result in making Serbia an EU member.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: in writing.- Serbia is an integral part of Europe 's cultural heritage.Serbia is on a growth path, which is increasingly converging with European standards in all areas.Of course, I supported this report, rewarding the efforts of the Serbian people.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. - The report we voted on today analyzes the Serbian situation consistently and with a realistic approach, denouncing the shortcomings of the system and listing the improvements made. The emphasis was placed on the judicial system, which is still exposed to political pressure; on corruption, rightly represented as a persistent plague; on the discrimination of vulnerable groups and the lack of respect for freedom of expression and the media, recalling the pressure and violence suffered by many dissident journalists. The need to overcome the war-mongering rhetoric and to reach an agreement, also on the historical and cultural side, between the various countries involved in the Balkan wars of the 90s is also underlined by giving judicial proceedings for war crimes, so as to guarantee truth and compensation to the families of the victims. Relations with Kosovo are described without false enthusiasm, applauding the improvements but denouncing that many steps still need to be taken. Less shareable aspects, in addition to the explicit attempt to remove Serbia from Russia without considering its effects in depth, appear to be the importance recognized to business for the purpose of normalizing the neighborhood and the privatization facilities that could undermine the importance given to policies on the work. For these reasons I thought it appropriate to abstain.

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: in writing.- I welcome the approval of Serbia's progress report in 2015 and join the call for the acceleration of the EU accession process.I am a firm supporter of the need to foster the integration of this country and I recognize the ambitious reform program that has begun.It is now more than ever necessary for Serbia to strengthen the rule of law, to make substantial progress in the fight against corruption and to create the conditions for improving the daily life of Serbian citizens.I conclude by urging the Commission to speed up the accession process initiated with Belgrade, while at the same time encouraging the Balkan country to make further efforts to resolve crucial problems, first of all respect for minority rights, with particular reference to those of the Roma community.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: in writing. - I have decided to support this report because it shows that there has been some progress in Serbia in the areas covered by the report. However, I consider it necessary for Serbia to continue to rigorously design and implement the reforms needed to comply with EU standards. I see the still high level of corruption in the public and private spheres as a big problem. I believe that it is essential to combat corruption even at the highest political levels and to significantly reduce political interference in the Serbian judiciary. I would also welcome greater progress in implementing initiatives to combat organized crime. Last year, according to the Commission's report, there has been no progress on freedom of expression, which I consider to be a truly alarming fact. Even today, journalists are physically attacked and only in a limited number of cases is anyone punished for these attacks. I agree that the efforts of Serbian officials and the progress made must be appreciated, but it is clear that Serbia still has a very long way to go to join the European Union.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing. - The motion for a resolution welcomes the general progress made in Serbia, in particular as regards the stabilization of relations with Kosovo and its commitment to the process of European integration.On the other hand, it also speaks of areas where, despite an ambitious reform agenda, tangible results have not yet been achieved, and in particular the fight against corruption, organized crime and stronger private sector development.However, I think that the European Parliament's assessment of Serbia's efforts will help motivate this country to make greater efforts for successful reforms and will bring positive results in the long term.That is why I supported this resolution.

name: Milan ZVER
text: in writing.- I supported the Progress Report on Serbia for 2015, which the country has achieved in the field of European approximation.I am pleased that Serbia is cooperating constructively in the negotiations with the EU and I wish it a successful solution to the challenges posed by the open chapters concerning corruption, judicial reform, respect for human rights and the coordination of foreign and security policy with the EU.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, I am now back on the right page. There was an item that caught my eye as being extraordinary, even by the standards that I have come to expect from EU institutions. This was the revelation of a massive corruption scandal in Kosovo involving the EU’s anti-corruption unit. Why is it that corruption is endemic in that territory, or at least in its administration? I would say for the same reason that it is endemic in the European Union. Not because it attracts bad people – not even Mr Brok is a bad person. He is a loud and oafish person, as we see from his current interruption, but I am prepared to give him the benefit of the doubt. But no, it is not that it attracts bad people: it is that there are no proper mechanisms to hold people to account. If people in positions of authority do not need to explain themselves to voters, they will focus on making themselves comfortable. Kosovo is not allowed to be a democracy because people fear partition. They do not want any recognition of the national principles, so they impose an undemocratic government which is then, inevitably, self-serving. That is what happens. Of course, we see the same principle elevated at European level, and it allows even such characters as Elmar Brok to get themselves elected.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Mr President, I am one of those politicians who believes in the need to negotiate with Kosovo and offer it the prospect of possible membership of the European Union in the long term. Although Kosovo has still not been recognized by five EU countries. I am convinced that this perspective is necessary, if at all, for democracies in this country to begin to strengthen in the future, for the rule of law to emerge and for the country to become economically viable. But I am also saying here that the road is still very far away, and indeed Kosovo will probably not be a member of the EU in the next five years or so. The report criticizes some of the things that I consider important, such as rampant corruption and a small fight against organized crime. I consider this extremely important. Building the rule of law is, in my view, even more important than economic reforms themselves. So I am glad that it is included in that report, which is why I supported the report.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: - Mr President!Colleagues, as we know, Kosovo has unilaterally declared its independence, and five Member States of the European Union have still not recognized it.But it is clear that it will not be possible to cooperate and fully implement all the documents until the Kosovo state has normal relations with its neighbors and with Serbia.But this is only the first aspect.The second aspect, of course, is the fight against corruption.The transit of drugs to Europe, the extremely high level of unemployment and other factors objectively level the progress that the country of Kosovo is getting closer to integrating into the European Union.Of course, I support this resolution by voting in favor.But it must be acknowledged that so much remains to be done for both the European Union and the state of Kosovo that there is a number of urgent tasks ahead.

name: Peter JAHR
text: - Mister President! I think it is excellent, also on the agenda, that we first talked about the progress report on Serbia and then about European integration in Kosovo. For me, this shows quite clearly what mediating role the European Union plays in this part of Europe, and yet it shows very clearly how important both states and regions are to us. I think we simply have to act as a mediator here too, and for me the progress made in Kosovo must go hand in hand with the resolution of the relationship with Serbia. In this sense, it is very important to talk to both countries. It has been said several times by my colleagues - I am particularly concerned about Kosovo that there is as yet no effective state administration. And of course we have to fight corruption in Kosovo intensively, but still speak to both countries. And we are obliged to cooperate with both countries.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: - Mr Chairman! When assessing the situation of Kosovo in the past year, the complexity of the situation must first be emphasized. On the one hand, an agreement was reached with Belgrade on the municipalities inhabited by Serb communities, an ombudsman was appointed, and laws were adopted to improve the judiciary, but at the same time the country became an example of numerous pathologies and a source of problems for the EU. Blocking the work of the Kosovar assembly by the opposition shows public disagreement over the agreement with Serbia. The mission, which was supposed to help the local administration adjust to European standards of the rule of law, turned out to be corrupt and linked to Kosovo criminals. The police and public administration are still corrupt, and the practically non-existent economy. For many years, experts have emphasized that Kosovo is a center for trafficking in human beings, drugs and arms smuggling, and a source of recruits for Islamic radicals fighting in Syria and Libya. For these reasons, the Union cannot afford to leave Kosovo to itself. I supported the resolution because the European Union must take all possible measures to bring this country out of the structural crisis it has been in since its inception. The Union cannot allow another failed state controlled by organized crime groups to emerge on its borders.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Thank you very much, Ms. Jazłowiecka!I really want to ask you not to write down more than can be said in a minute because the interpreting services cannot interpret that.Surely not only your Polish compatriots should understand what you have to say.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: - Mr President! Kosovo's rapprochement with the EU welcomed. I hope it will go quickly and that Kosovo and other Balkan countries will soon become part of the EU. In this context, I would like to remind you that dialogue and the normalization of relations with the Serbian minority in Kosovo should be a condition for Kosovo's entry. Just as the recognition of Kosovo / the normalization of relations with Kosovo is a condition for Serbia, an agreement on special rights for Serbian minorities is a condition for Kosovo. Therefore, I would like to add the following: Kosovo's legitimately elected government has made honest and sincere attempts to reach an agreement. I would like to encourage the opposition not to try to obstruct these talks for domestic political purposes. The issue of accession to the EU is bigger than that and should not be abused in an internal political struggle. All parties must take their responsibility. I choose to support the report because it expresses the will of both the EU and Kosovo to solve problems and to move the accession process forward.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Mr President, I believe that Kosovo needs a future.For this reason too, I supported the proposed resolution, and I would also like to explicitly appreciate that Kosovo has undoubtedly made a number of progress on both the functioning of the state and the improvement of public services.Undoubtedly, however, it also faces a number of problems, be it high unemployment, corruption, organized crime, which to some extent controls part of the territory.However, it is our duty to really give Kosovo a future, because today it is de facto the only locked country, as stated in the proposed resolution that we approved.For this reason, I think that the future needs to be given to the Kosovars, it is not our goal to isolate this country.And it is good to work with it also in order to help solve the migration crisis, as the report appreciates.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing.- Kosovo has recently declared its independence from Serbia, however the latter and about 50 UN nations do not yet recognize it as a sovereign state.Kosovo's European integration is still a long way off, but there are still small steps forward in social policies and in the judicial system.The main problems are found with regard to: freedom of the press, non-discrimination of minorities, youth unemployment, respect for and defense of the historical heritage of Pritzen.I decided to vote in favor of the resolution because the Union can play an important role in improving the living conditions of the citizens of Kosovo.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: written. - I voted against the Resolution on the European integration process of the self-proclaimed Republic of Kosovo as it represents an unacceptable interference, since it calls for the recognition of Kosovo by the five EU Member States that have not yet done so fact, in addition to praising Kosovo's participation in the international military coalition against IS and advocating its neoliberal agenda (structural reforms, privatizations) in the region. I consider it intolerable that the European Parliament intends to pressure the Member States that do not recognize Kosovo, including Spain, which constitutes political interference in national competences. Kosovo is the result of a criminal NATO intervention in the former Yugoslavia. Today the United States maintains one of its largest military bases in Kosovo, Camp Bondsteel, as a geostrategic enclave with access to the Middle East or the Caucasus and which allows them to control oil pipelines and energy corridors. Since with the accession negotiations addressed in this Resolution the EU implicitly recognizes Kosovo as a State, as well as its unilateral declaration of independence, in violation of Resolution 1244/1999 of the United Nations Security Council, I decided to vote against.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – I abstained on this resolution. I oppose many aspects of the report such as the call for Kosovo to align its economic and foreign policy with that of the EU and the promotion of the EULEX mission – which is developing what is essentially a colonial role for the EU in Kosovo’s governance. However, I strongly support the right of the people of Kosovo to self-determination, and this report recognises the declaration of independence from Serbia by Kosovo in 2008, so I did not want to block it. I support the right of an independent Kosovo to become part of the European Union. Kosovo has a long history of more than 100 years where its majority population struggled for an independent state, a fact that arises from the drawing of borders after the fall of the Ottoman empire, and which was ignored during the break-up of the former Yugoslavia when Bosnia-Herzegovina, Croatia and Serbia achieved independent status. This report also supports progressive reforms in Kosovo on human rights, judicial independence, and the importance of the rule of law. It calls for increased efforts to tackle human and drug trafficking and organised crime.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: in writing.- This report is a web of angelism and ideology about Kosovo and its future in the Union.This region cumulates political, economic, identity difficulties, etc.While 60% of the population has no work, the political class from the UCK terrorist organization is doing nothing to improve the lot of the population.Under these conditions, it is not surprising that the situation of the Serbs is more difficult than ever.This text nevertheless presents the situation as stabilized and allows itself honorable prospects.This denial of reality is first of all prejudicial to the inhabitants of Kosovo, Albanians as well as Serbs.Out of respect for these populations who suffer both from the corruption of the local system and from the angelism of the Union, I opposed this text.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I do not believe in Kosovan accession to the European Union. This report works towards that goal; therefore, I had no choice but to vote against the resolution.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
