text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report because I approve of the progress made by Kosovo in the process of normalizing its relations with Serbia, despite the persistent concerns over respect for media freedom and the violent protestswhich took place in the National Assembly.Although many challenges remain, I believe we can observe that the aspiration to become a member of the Union leads to greater stability and peace in the Western Balkans region.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this proposal on Kosovo's European integration process.Five EU Member States have still not formally recognized Kosovo.All EU members should recognize Kosovo and thus contribute to strengthening stability in the region and normalizing relations between Serbia and Kosovo.The EU-Kosovo Association Agreement, ratified by the EP on 21 January, promotes reforms and paves the way for Kosovo's integration into the EU.The independence of the media and the judiciary, the fight against corruption and organized crime, and labor market reforms are among the most pressing issues.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: in writing.- What is Kosovo?The historical cradle of the Serbian nation?A mafia enclave?Despite the very dark - but very realistic - portrait that this text draws up, the Eurocrats nonetheless demand the entry of this entity into the European Union.Could it be to accelerate its fall?

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing. - I approved this joint resolution which underlines the importance of the stabilization and association agreement concluded between the Union and Kosovo. It will allow enhanced cooperation in terms of political dialogue and economic exchanges, but should also help stabilize the region. Parliament also welcomes the progress made in 2015 in concluding agreements in the process of normalizing relations between Kosovo and Serbia and calls on the Commission to maintain its support for reforms and cooperation in the Western Balkans . However, he strongly recalls the importance of parliamentary work to implement reforms and calls on all political actors to resume constructive dialogue in order to come out and the government to respect Parliament's resolutions. Likewise, while it welcomes the adoption of the Law on Protection against Discrimination and on Gender Equality, Parliament underlines its concerns about hate speech against LGBTI people and the meager progress made in this area. freedom of expression or the media, or the lack of any significant progress in the fight against grand corruption and organized crime.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: written. - This document urges to recognize the independence of Kosovo to those EU countries, such as Spain, that still do not validate an independence that was declared unilaterally and contrary to international law. The Resolution considers that the recognition of Kosovo as an independent State of Serbia would contribute to reinforcing stability in the region. However, I believe that a solution negotiated by all parties, including the Serbian authorities, would have been the most friendly and positive way to achieve a good neighborhood policy, respect the rights of minorities and not violate international law. To approve this Resolution would be to de facto recognize the independence of Kosovo and promote its participation in EU programs, with a view to future integration, when it presents very serious problems of corruption, organized crime, gender violence and sex trafficking of women and girls. , among others. For these reasons I have voted against it, since I support the Spanish position regarding Kosovo and the ideology of my party, which defends the international right to territorial integrity.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. - The signing of the stabilization and association agreement between the EU and Kosovo in October 2015 represented an important step in the perspective of an ever closer participation of the country in the stabilization and integration project of the Balkan area in the European dimension. The process of normalization of relations between Kosovo and Serbia represents a further confirmation of the Kosovar desire to become the protagonist of a vast political change in the various sectors of foreign and domestic policy. I voted in favor of the resolution on the European integration process of Kosovo because I believe that the commitment of the Republic of Kosovo in the legal, constitutional and social fields must be valued. While numerous critical issues remain, especially in the area of ​​freedom of expression and participation of civil society in decision-making processes and political life, progress is evident in the field of combating international terrorism. Strengthening the market economy remains a priority to which the Commission's package supporting reforms and regional cooperation in the Western Balkans can be a valuable aid.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: written.- We abstain in this vote because, although the International Court of Justice concluded that the unilateral declaration of independence of Kosovo did not violate international law or Resolution 1244 of the United Nations Security Council, and although the process of nationalization ofKosovo is irreversible, the ruling does not imply that the former province has a well-founded right to be recognized by third parties.The situation in Kosovo has a complex political background and, therefore, must be addressed and resolved politically, through an agreement that in any case integrates Serbia, which neutralizes Serbian and Kosovar nationalisms that pose a permanent internal threat to peace,to safeguard the rights of ethnic minorities in the area and to guarantee the exit of foreign military powers from the area in the medium term.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: written.- I have supported this Resolution on Kosovo's European integration process, which urges Kosovo to continue with reforms and also urges Member States that have not yet recognized Kosovo to do so.It is essential for the integration of the area to overcome obstacles since, little by little, different phases in the relationship with Serbia are being reestablished.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing. - I was obviously opposed to this resolution which, irresponsibly, continues to envisage the accession to the Union of a territorial entity not recognized as sovereign by at least five Member States of the Union and two States of the UN Security Council. Even more recently, on November 12, 2015, fifty UNESCO Member States refused Kosovo the status of permanent Member State of this institution. In addition to these shortcomings of "form", it is unthinkable, at a time when the Union is destabilized by disturbances of all kinds, to integrate within itself a territory which has still not responded to the massacres committed against the minority. Serbian between 1999 and 2004, nor those towards Christian and Orthodox minorities, again this week the victim of an attempted attack. Apparently, in the case of Kosovo, respect for human rights and the fundamental values ​​of the Union is not a sine qua non for joining the Union. We cannot decently consider integrating into the Union an unstable territory, plagued by corruption and suspected of being the "European base" of jihadist networks.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing.- The resolution being voted on is unbalanced and has various critical issues, so I did not intend to support it.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: written.- I have abstained.I believe that Kosovo's integration process, and possible future membership of the EU, will be decided by the people of Kosovo.Integration requires many economic, social and political changes that affect the whole of society.In the end, the best form of a popular decision is a referendum.That's why I abstain.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: written. - The Resolution starts from an act that the Spanish State does not recognize: the unilateral declaration of independence of Kosovo of 2008. For this reason, part of this Resolution encourages the five EU Member States that do not recognize Kosovo to do so. Spain did not recognize the unilateral declaration of independence because it considered that it was contrary to international law and violated the principles of sovereignty and territorial integrity recognized in Serbia and guaranteed by the Helsinki Final Act. This position is also consistent with that of the United Nations, since there is a Security Council Resolution in force (Resolution 1244 of June 10, 1999) that opposes a unilateral act of these characteristics. Furthermore, recognizing such independence would not be consistent with the actions of the international community in Bosnia and Herzegovina in relation to the Republika Srpska or in other similar situations such as Ossetia, Abkhazia and Crimea. Of course, all the positive aspirations for the people of Kosovo that the report contains could be supported, but these cannot lead to acceptance of the unilateral independence of Kosovo. For all these reasons, I have voted against this Resolution.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this resolution because it assessed Parliament's progress in 2015 towards EU membership. Parliament welcomed the fact that in 2015 The EU-Kosovo Stabilization and Association Agreement was signed in 2015, marking the first contractual relationship. November 2 It was quickly ratified by the Assembly of the Republic of Kosovo. Parliament emphasized that the Stabilization and Association Agreement would facilitate Kosovo's integration into the EU, provide a strong impetus for the implementation and institutionalization of reforms, and facilitate cooperation with the EU in various areas, alongside improving relations with neighboring countries and helping the region to maintain political stability. and closer trade integration. Parliament therefore called on the Kosovo government to pay close attention to the implementation of the comprehensive reforms needed to fulfill its obligations under the Stabilization and Association Agreement.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing. - The report on Kosovo's European integration process welcomes the signing of the EU-Kosovo Stabilization and Association Agreement on 27 October 2015, which prepares Kosovo for EU integration and strongly encourages the implementation and institutionalization of reforms. However, it is concerned that no substantial progress has been made in the fight against high-level corruption and organized crime. The document encourages the five Member States that have not yet done so to recognize Kosovo, in the belief that this will further facilitate the normalization of relations between Belgrade and Pristina. Given that the report emphasizes the need for Kosovo to catch up with the Union in all respects, to respect human rights and, above all, to grant the Serb community living on its territory the rights it rightly demanded from the then Serbian state in its previous minority status, with my vote I supported the report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: in writing. - Members of the majority supported the progress report on Kosovo. It must be openly acknowledged that Kosovo has managed to make important strides in certain areas, the biggest of which is in relations with Serbia and solving key interstate problems related to energy, telecommunications, vehicle insurance and the Serbian minority in the north. This young country still has a long way to go to reform, but they have shown the will to do so. An EU-Kosovo Stabilization and Association Agreement was also signed last year, which will be an important impetus for the implementation and institutionalization of reforms, as well as helping to start cooperation with the EU in a number of areas. High unemployment remains a huge problem, especially among young people and women. More efforts will be needed to prosecute corruption and organized crime, to promote small businesses more actively. entrepreneurship. By supporting the report, I also hope that the citizens of Kosovo will accept all the help and advice of the EU and thus succeed in improving their quality of life.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: in writing. - How can the candidacy, or in any case the progress of EU accession negotiations, be supported by a country to which, according to security experts' estimates, at least 300 jihadists have returned after having fought in the ranks of the Islamic State since 2011 in Syria and Iraq. It is also known that over 150 Kosovar Islamic extremists are fighting in Syria alongside the jihadist formations of the Islamic state, including 42 women. A country that, between corruption, crime and, indeed, terrorism, is totally in disarray. The resolution is concerned with protecting and granting more rights to the Roma community. For heaven's sake, everyone at home does what he wants, but why not remember the Christian churches destroyed in the Kosovar cities, why not also protect the Christian community in Kosovo? These are some of the reasons for my vote against the resolution. I also ask: in the light of the above, does the High Representative not consider it appropriate to suspend all types of accession negotiations with this country?

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: written.- I support this statement which provides support in the process of European integration of Kosovo.The Kosovo authorities must remain committed to the necessary reforms, in particular to strengthen the rule of law, the fight against corruption and organized crime, discrimination and unemployment.Media freedom is also an area that needs to be worked on persistently in order for the media to become independent and free to express themselves.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this document because I believe that the progress made by Kosovo, especially in the normalization of relations with Serbia, represent important steps towards the accession of the Balkan country to the European Union.The prospect of accession to the European Union of the Balkan countries is one of the main factors of stability in the region and, therefore, must be supported by both European and national authorities.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: in writing. - The Stabilization and Association Agreement (SAA) paved the way for Kosovo's integration into the Union. In order to achieve full integration of Kosovo into the European Union, this agreement aims to promote the application of European standards concerning the award of public contracts, intellectual property and the establishment of a free trade area. However, in view of the overwhelming facts which are listed in this text, this motion for a resolution should be an indictment against Kosovo's accession to the European Union. Indeed, it is recalled to what extent respect for human rights, in particular in terms of freedom of expression, the suppression of discrimination against women as well as the fight against criminal, terrorist and Islamist networks are far from be the priority of local authorities. Even if we are absolutely opposed to the interference of the Union in the affairs of Kosovo, we believe that all of these arguments should be enough to convince MEPs to abandon the idea of ​​its integration and membership. I therefore voted against this motion for a resolution.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. - I voted against this resolution which urges Member States that have not yet recognized the Republic of Kosovo to take action in this direction. It welcomes the work done by the Kosovan authorities on the visa liberalization action plan and urges the Commission to step up work related to the Kosovo visa liberalization process, supporting the continuation of discussions on the conclusion of a framework agreement allowing Kosovo to participate in EU programs (also accessing EU funds). Furthermore, it is concerned about the extremely limited progress in the area of ​​freedom of expression and the media over the past year. On the other hand, there are gaps in the fight against corruption and organized crime, the Kosovar authorities are urged to continue their efforts in the fight against the radicalization of terrorism, in particular youth unemployment and violent extremism. same authorities to prevent the mobilization of potential foreign fighters and Islamic terrorists, after, according to the Kosovo Minister of the Interior, about 300 Kosovars have enlisted in the ranks of jihadists in Syria and Iraq, and finally the measures taken by the government are welcomed to impose prison sentences on citizens who have been engaged in terrorist activities.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of this resolution because I am convinced that Kosovo's European integration process is on the right track. The signing of the EU-Kosovo Stabilization and Association Agreement on 27 October 2015 paves the way for Kosovo's integration into the EU and will provide a powerful incentive for implementation and institutionalization of reforms, enabling cooperation with the EU in a wide range of areas, in order to intensify political dialogue and strengthen trade integration, as well as intensify relations with neighboring countries and contribute to the stability of the region. However, I regret the current violent obstruction in this House. The smooth running of parliamentary business is the prerequisite for implementing all aspects of Kosovo's reform agenda. All political actors should resume political dialogue in order to find a solution that restores the functioning of the Kosovar Assembly. Finally, I express concern at the lack of progress in the fight against corruption and organized crime. I call on the authorities to adopt a comprehensive and strategic approach to the fight against endemic corruption, which continues to represent an important obstacle for Kosovo to the democratic, social and economic development of the country.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution as I acknowledge the importance of the reforms already adopted in Kosovo. However, there are still many areas that need to improve and hopefully the recent EU-Kosovo Stabilisation and Association Agreement will provide sufficient incentives for this. I am also hoping that the authorities will increase their engagement with the civil society as it is one of the most crucial steps towards a well-functioning democracy.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing.- The report, which analyzes the situation of Kosovo in its European integration process, pays great attention to elements such as: the fight against corruption and organized crime, scourges that still seriously affect the Kosovar system;the judicial system, which has improved but is still subject to political pressure;the very high youth unemployment;non-discrimination and the protection of minorities.Although there are some doubts about some aspects, the overall report is very good and my final vote was in favor.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing.- We vote against the motion for a resolution and recall that the Republic of Cyprus does not recognize Kosovo's unilateral declaration of independence and remains fully committed to respecting the sovereignty and territorial integrity of all states, including Serbia.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing.- I felt it my duty to vote in favor of the motion for a resolution of the European Parliament on the 2015 report on Kosovo.I am convinced, in fact, that the Stabilization and Association Agreements (SAA) have drawn a precise course for the integration of Kosovo into the EU and provide a powerful incentive for the implementation and institutionalization of reforms, allowing for thecooperation with the EU in a wide range of areas in order to intensify political dialogue and strengthen trade integration, as well as intensify relations with neighboring countries and contribute to the stability of the region.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing.- I like to remember that Mother Teresa of Calcutta was born in Kosovo, while the popular imagination associates this patch of land only with the bombings of 1999 and the fights between Albanians and Serbs.I am pleased to see that this state is slowly overcoming its problems and is trying to build on the rubble, even going so far as to sign an agreement with the EU.I am looking forward to looking at the map of Europe and saying about the Balkans what I would say about the countries of the former Iron Curtain and that I never imagined I would say 30 years ago.With this hope, I voted in favor of this resolution.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: written.- I voted for the resolution because, alongside the Stabilization and Association Agreement between the EU and Kosovo, we should not miss any efforts to support Kosovo on its way to integration into the EU.There is still a long way to go until then: Kosovo must apply the rule of law consistently, corruption and organized crime must be combated, the rights of all ethnic minorities must be guaranteed and all forms of discrimination must be prevented.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing.- Considering that in the previous plenary I voted in favor of the SAA, which is the first step towards the integration of Kosovo which will later become an association agreement, I also expressed my favorable vote on this occasion as it is necessary to support the policiesKosovo aimed at standardizing their internal legislation and external action according to European guidelines.In order to achieve the objective within a reasonable time and with methods in keeping with the democratic practice of the Union, I hope that the States which are resisting the integration of Kosovo will change their attitude and opt for cooperation.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ Kosovo’s process of integration within the EU started in October 2015 with the EU-Kosovo Stabilisation and Association Agreement. The European Union has continually indicated its willingness to assist Kosovo in developing its political and economic structures through a clear European perspective which is based on firm respect for the rule of law. The report considers a number of issues on which Kosovo has made positive progress as well as other processes which are still considered to be in a precarious situation. It seeks, however, to propose a way forward for national systems that are based on good governance values. I have thus voted in favour.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. - The report analyzes the situation of Kosovo in its European integration process. Being green, we find a great deal of attention regarding: the fight against poverty and the emphasis given to social policies, tools that tackle both extremism and migration problems at the root; freedom of expression and denunciation of violence against dissident journalists; non-discrimination and the protection of minorities; the fight against corruption and organized crime, which are represented as plagues that still seriously affect the Kosovar system; the judicial system, which has improved but is still subject to political pressure; respect for the historical heritage of Prizren, denouncing illegal building which endangers it; the social calamity given by the very high youth unemployment. Not all aspects of the report are positive and some doubts remain regarding certain aspects but, considered as a whole, my vote can only be favorable if the aim is to safeguard an improvement in the living conditions of the Kosovar population and accompanying the country on its path towards (distant) accession to the EU.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: written. - I voted against the Resolution on the European integration process of the self-proclaimed Republic of Kosovo as it represents an unacceptable interference, since it calls for the recognition of Kosovo by the five EU Member States that have not yet done so fact, in addition to praising Kosovo's participation in the international military coalition against IS and advocating its neoliberal agenda (structural reforms, privatizations) in the region. I consider it intolerable that the European Parliament intends to pressure the Member States that do not recognize Kosovo, including Spain, which constitutes political interference in national competences. Kosovo is the result of a criminal NATO intervention in the former Yugoslavia. Today the United States maintains one of its largest military bases in Kosovo, Camp Bondsteel, as a geostrategic enclave with access to the Middle East or the Caucasus and which allows them to control oil pipelines and energy corridors. Since with the accession negotiations addressed in this Resolution the EU implicitly recognizes Kosovo as a State, as well as its unilateral declaration of independence, in violation of Resolution 1244/1999 of the United Nations Security Council, I decided to vote against.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the 2015 progress report on Kosovo, which welcomes the 2015 constitutional amendments that allowed for specialist (judicial) chambers to be set up for cross-border crimes, a commitment made in the context of the 1999 Kosovo conflict, and welcomes the progress achieved in relations with Serbia and visa liberalisation and the measures to curb irregular migration to the EU. The report highlights some challenges, too: that efforts to reform the public administration are commended but politicisation remains a concern; the lack of competitiveness, the informal economy and high unemployment are seen as the main economic flaws.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: in writing.- In this motion for a resolution, MEPs reiterate their attachment to the enlargement policy and to the countries of the Balkans.The European Parliament highlights areas in which the country lags in reform, such as the rule of law, freedom of expression and the fight against corruption.Considering that this resolution is balanced, I voted in favor.

name: Rachida DATI
text: in writing.- I supported this resolution on the process of European integration in Kosovo.With this resolution, the European Parliament recalls the positive repercussions of the Stabilization and Association Agreement between the European Union and Kosovo.It is particularly important to support Kosovo in putting in place a strategy to combat terrorism and prevent radicalization.Like the European Union, Kosovo is affected by the departure of its nationals to the combat zones in Syria and Iraq.This is why it is all the more crucial for the European Union to engage in the stabilization of Kosovo.

name: Luis de GRANDES PASCUAL
text: written.- In my own name and right, and representing the Spanish Delegation of the PPE Group as Secretary General, I want to state that we have voted against the Resolution on the process of European integration in Kosovo, as it contains a series of statements regardingof that territory that are contrary to the positions of those member states that, like Spain, do not recognize Kosovo as an independent state.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: in writing. - The association agreement between the European Union and Kosovo will make it possible to intensify our links with this neighboring country in many areas such as governance, judicial cooperation, consumer protection, intellectual property, energy cooperation , or the protection of the environment. This agreement will also provide support to this Balkan country in its process of political and economic reform. Seven years after declaring its independence, Kosovo remains marked by serious economic difficulties, widespread corruption and a significant emigration movement of its population to neighboring countries. It should be remembered, however, that the European Commission made a wise commitment in 2014 to take a break from enlargement in order to consolidate what has been achieved between the 28. This is why, in line with our commitments made during the European campaign, the French delegation of the ALDE group chose to abstain on the final vote.

name: Andor DELI
text: in writing.- The report on Kosovo's European integration process welcomes the signing of the EU-Kosovo Stabilization and Association Agreement on 27 October 2015, which prepares Kosovo for EU integration and strongly encourages the implementation and institutionalization of reforms.However, it is concerned that no substantial progress has been made in the fight against high-level corruption and organized crime.Given that the report emphasizes the need for Kosovo to catch up with the Union in all respects, to respect human rights and, above all, to grant the Serb community in its territory the rights that it itself rightly demanded from the then Serbian state in its previous minority status, I voted in favor.the report.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: in writing. - This resolution provides a well-argued and detailed point on the way forward following the signing, on 27 October 2015, of the stabilization and association agreement between the Union and Kosovo, the first contractual relationship between the two parties, and its swift ratification by the Kosovo Assembly on November 2, 2015. This agreement paves the way for Kosovo's integration into the Union. It constitutes a powerful incentive for the implementation and institutionalization of reforms allowing for enhanced cooperation and further trade integration of Kosovo. The text describes the various steps to be climbed, including the fight against corruption and organized crime and respect for fundamental rights, including that of journalists and various minorities. I strongly support this text as a member of the EU-Balkans Friendships, because it will help strengthen ties with neighboring countries and help stabilize the region.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing.- It should be remembered that Kosovo is not recognized by the United Nations, nor by two of the permanent members of its Security Council, namely China and Russia, nor by four of the Member States of the Union.While this text rightly underlines the presence of a mafia which is plaguing Kosovo, it at the same time defends its integration into the European Union, while practicing unacceptable interference in Serbian internal affairs.Finally, he pleads for the liberalization of visas for citizens of Kosovo.Being opposed to this irresponsible approach which goes against the interests of the nations and peoples of Europe, I voted against this text.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: In written form. - As rapporteur in the shadow of the European Parliament's resolution on Kosovo's European integration process, I am pleased with the final text of the resolution, as many of my amendments and suggestions have been taken into account. I am extremely pleased that the resolution mentions the Bulgarian community, the so-called Gorani, and calls for respect for their rights and freedoms. Although I support Kosovo's European integration, I have chosen to abstain, as the resolution contains a text with which I do not fully agree, namely the call on the European Commission to liberalize the visa regime with Kosovo as soon as possible. Both I and my colleagues in the Group of European Conservatives and Reformists are of the opinion that the country has to meet a number of requirements and commitments in the fight against organized crime before the European Commission takes steps towards visa liberalization. The situation is further complicated by the fact that of all the countries in Europe, the largest number of foreign Islamic State fighters come from Kosovo. That is why I believe that the visa regime should not be liberalized at this stage.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: in writing.- It is proposed to vote against the Kosovo progress report as it (indirectly) seals the recognition of Kosovo's statehood.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: in writing. - The report on Kosovo's European integration process welcomes the signing of the EU-Kosovo Stabilization and Association Agreement on 27 October 2015, which prepares Kosovo for EU integration and strongly encourages the implementation and institutionalization of reforms. However, it is concerned that no substantial progress has been made in the fight against high-level corruption and organized crime. The document encourages the five Member States that have not yet done so to recognize Kosovo, in the belief that this will further facilitate the normalization of relations between Belgrade and Pristina. Given that the report emphasizes the need for Kosovo to catch up with the Union in all respects, to respect human rights and, above all, to grant the Serb community in its territory the rights that it itself rightly demanded from the then Serbian state in its previous minority status, I voted in favor. the report.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing.- 110 of the 193 member states of the United Nations, including 23 of the 28 EU member states, recognize the independence of Kosovo, which has signed a Stabilization and Association Agreement (SAA) with the EU.The progress made with regard to the conclusion of agreements within the framework of the process of normalizing relations between Kosovo and Serbia, in particular on the establishment of the association / community of Serbian majority municipalities in Kosovo, on energy, onMitrovicë / Mitrovica bridge, on telecommunications, on car insurance and on the judicial system.On the other hand, the high number of people who disappeared during the war and the little progress made in this regard remains a concern, with states cooperating in this area, bearing in mind that full cooperation in finding the truth about missing persons isfundamental to mutual reconciliation.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: in writing.- I voted against this report because it is in line with Kosovo's membership of the European Union, membership to which I am radically opposed.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - The report comes in the context of developments in relation to Kosovo, which includes the Stabilization and Association Agreement (SAA) signed between the EU and Kosovo in October 2015. It arises in the context of negotiations with a view to the future accession of Kosovo to the EU and, to that extent, unravels the usual list of impositions (which includes the “deterrence of migration”), in the usual position of interference. The report values ​​the signature of the AEA - against which we were. It should be stressed that several EU Member States do not recognize Kosovo's independence. Issues such as the imposition of macroeconomic policies by the EU that are deeply contrary to the interests of the peoples of the region are not addressed in this report, nor were we expected to do so; the condemnation of the formalization of the establishment of relations with a territory, as if it were a legitimate country, after the very serious precedent that was opened in international law with the unilateral declaration of independence of the Serbian province of Kosovo, and that the EU has sought to legitimize. An illegal decision, which we do not recognize, that created a protectorate through aggression and military occupation by the USA, NATO and the EU. A glaring violation of international law, the Helsinki Final Act, the UN resolutions on the issue, among others.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against as I disagree with the approach.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing.- I vote against the resolution, attention is paid to non-priority issues.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: in writing.- I am voting against the Kosovo progress report as it (indirectly) seals the recognition of Kosovo's statehood.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ All these countries from Eastern Europe have to and will join the European Union one day. It is in the interests of Europe and of all these countries. I would like to congratulate Ms Mogherini for the historic agreement that she brokered in August last year between Serbia and Kosovo, working towards the complete normalisation of relations between Belgrade and Priština. However, Belgrade did not recognise the independence of Kosovo, and there are five European Union countries that have still not recognised Kosovan independence. So this mechanism which we are now implementing is a sui generis mechanism to bring Kosovo closer to the European Union. Probably the Commission and the Member States will have to find a way for this country to start accession negotiations with the European Union without it having been recognised by all Member States.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: written.- I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution after analyzing the progress made by Kosovo, as well as the signing of the Stabilization and Association Agreement (SAA) between the EU and Kosovo, which paves the way for the integration of Kosovo into the EU andIt will provide a powerful incentive for the implementation and institutionalization of reforms and will enable the establishment of cooperation with the EU in a wide range of fields, with a view to strengthening political dialogue and trade integration, as well as strengthening relations with countriesneighbors and help ensure regional stability.The Government of Kosovo should continue to work on implementing the comprehensive reforms necessary to meet its obligations under the SAA.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing.- The relaxing climate and the progress made in normalizing relations between Serbia and Kosovo are certainly positive data.We all still have in mind the horrors of the war that devastated the Balkans in the 1990s. It is essential that Belgrade and Pristina continue the dialogue and promptly implement the agreements reached so far, in order to stabilize the area definitively.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing.- I strongly supported the text presented by my colleague Lunacek on the EU-Kosovo negotiations.It is essential, for the stability of the entire Balkan area and to respond to the many regional challenges open today (refugee emergency, energy, fight against terrorism), that the influence of Europe is solid and contributes to strengthening internal governance in Kosovo.A few months ago, Europe signed the Stabilization and Association Agreement with Pristina.This tool is a powerful incentive for reform implementation, enabling cooperation with the EU to be strengthened and expanded in many areas.With this vote, we are giving a sign of support for reforms and regional cooperation in the Western Balkans, in the hope that progress towards the rule of law and stability in the country will always continue during the term.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the resolution of the European Parliament, presented following statements by the Council and the Commission under Rule 123 (2) of the Rules of Procedure, on the 2015 Progress Report on Kosovo. In the light of the approval of the EU-Kosovo Stabilization and Association Agreement by the European Parliament at the last plenary session, I believe it is necessary to provide the country with all the necessary assistance in order to allow the small Balkan state to start on the road to European integration. In recent years, the Kosovar Republic has made gradual steps forward in the legal and social sphere through the adoption of important legislation on human rights, respect for minorities, gender equality and LGBTI people, which we hope will give concrete results on society and culture as soon as possible. Although Kosovo is in its early stage of economic development, I welcome the timid progress in industry and SMEs and in the implementation of policies to encourage entrepreneurship and growth. However, I note my concern at the persistence of many gaps, especially with regard to freedom of expression and treatment of the press and with regard to the participation of civil society in the political life of the country.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: written.- I abstained from the vote on the European integration process for Kosovo because, although I welcome long-term accession prospects, I consider some of the approaches in the report to be premature.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: written.- I support the goal of integrating Kosovo into the EU.However, there is no question that there is still a long way to go.In addition to negotiating the Association Agreement, there are other problems to be tackled, such as the still high crime rate.Only then is further integration possible.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution which calls for swift and comprehensive implementation of the EU-Kosovo Stabilisation and Association Agreement signed in October 2015. As a country in the Western Balkans, the future of Kosovo is inextricably linked to that of the EU. Therefore it is of crucial importance to implement the reforms called for under the SAA, particularly with regard to ensuring media and judiciary independence, fighting high-level corruption and organised crime and implementing labour market reforms. It is important to note that Kosovo authorities have undertaken important efforts to end the trend of irregular migration, which peaked at the beginning of 2015. Now it is crucial to ensure that short-term measures aimed at dissuading the population from leaving are accompanied by job creation in order to encourage citizens to stay in Kosovo and build a future in their country.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: written.- We abstain in this vote because, although the International Court of Justice concluded that the unilateral declaration of independence of Kosovo did not violate international law or Resolution 1244 of the United Nations Security Council, and although the process of nationalization ofKosovo is irreversible, the ruling does not imply that the former province has a well-founded right to be recognized by third parties.The situation in Kosovo has a complex political background and, therefore, must be addressed and resolved politically, through an agreement that in any case integrates Serbia, which neutralizes Serbian and Kosovar nationalisms that pose a permanent internal threat to peace,to safeguard the rights of ethnic minorities in the area and to guarantee the exit of foreign military powers from the area in the medium term.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, as I strongly support the European integration process of Kosovo. Kosovo’s authorities have to pursue the necessary reforms with commitment, and strengthen the rule of law, the fight against corruption, discrimination, unemployment, and structural economic reforms for the benefit of citizens.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of European integration process of Kosovo. The Parliament welcomes the progress made in 2015 in reaching agreements in the framework of the process of normalisation of relations between Kosovo and Serbia an the signing of the EU-Kosovo Stabilisation and Association Agreement on 27 October 2015. There is important now to provide a powerful incentive for the implementation and institutionalisation of reforms and allow the establishment of cooperation with the EU in a wide variety of areas, with a view to enhancing political dialogue and closer trade integration in addition to strengthening relations with neighbouring countries and helping to ensure regional stability.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE / NGL), in writing. - The report presents Kosovo as an independent state and calls on the five Member States that have not recognized independence to do so immediately. This, in our view, is an intervention in the talks between Belgrade and Pristina to find a mutually acceptable solution to the problem. We support this process and believe that there should be no outside interventions that affect the whole climate, but pure support for the process itself. We tried to send this message through amendments that we tabled, which, however, were not accepted by the majority of the Plenary. For these reasons, we consider it appropriate to vote against the report.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution on the 2015 Report on Kosovo. 23 out of 28 EU Member States, including my own, recognise Kosovo’s independence. With the signing of the EU-Kosovo Stabilisation and Association Agreement at the end of last year we have paved the way for the integration of Kosovo into the EU. The SAA will allow the EU to work with Kosovo in a wide variety of areas, including closer trade integration as well as strengthening relations with neighbouring countries.  Kosovo must now implement the reforms necessary to fulfil its SAA obligations. Freedom of expression in the media, corruption and organised crime, the efficiency and independence of the judicial system, social and economic structural reforms and gender equality and gender mainstreaming are just some of the areas which the Kosovar must now implement.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: written.- The association agreement primarily includes the establishment of a free trade agreement between the EU and Kosovo.ALFA stands for an EU of sovereign states with an integrated internal market.We therefore welcome the Association Agreement between the EU and Kosovo.However, ALFA rejects full membership of Kosovo within the current EU.That is why I voted against Parliament's resolution, which includescalls for integration into the EU or visa liberalization with Kosovo.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written.- I reject this report because it is completely unbalanced, especially with regard to the Serbian partners.I also miss the mention in the report of the continuous destruction of Serbia's cultural heritage in this region, as well as the discrimination against the Serb minority in northern Kosovo.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: written.- The association agreement primarily includes the establishment of a free trade agreement between the EU and Kosovo.ALFA stands for an EU of sovereign states with an integrated internal market.We therefore welcome the Association Agreement between the EU and Kosovo.However, ALFA rejects full membership of Kosovo within the current EU.That is why I voted against Parliament's resolution, which includescalls for integration into the EU or visa liberalization with Kosovo.

name: Petr MACH
text: in writing.- I do not agree with enforcing EU policy on Kosovo, such as the ombudsman's office or the LGBTI agenda, or with preparing Kosovo for possible EU membership.I voted against.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written.- The European Parliament supports the signing of the EU-Kosovo Stabilization and Association Agreement on 27 October 2015 as the first contractual relationship.The Stabilization and Association Agreement paves the way for Kosovo's EU integration, provides a strong impetus for the implementation and institutionalization of reforms, and enables cooperation with the EU in a number of areas to improve political dialogue and closer trade integration as well as strengthen relations with neighboring countries.countries.I supported the resolution, which emphasized in particular the need to provide additional assistance to young entrepreneurs in Kosovo under IPA funds, including measures to facilitate networking with entrepreneurs from EU Member States and the inclusion of Kosovo business associations in the European Confederation of Young Entrepreneurs, in particularafter the entry into force of the Stabilization and Association Agreement.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I would like to express my concerns regarding the low level of processing and investigation of cases of hate speech and discrimination against LGBTI and minority communities. I would also like to urge local authorities to make progress regarding the number of missing persons from the war period in order to make steps towards mutual reconciliation.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written. - I voted for the report on Kosovo for 2015, given the importance of the situation in Kosovo for stability in Southeast Europe. I particularly welcome the signing of the EU-Kosovo Stabilization and Association Agreement on 27 October 2015, followed by the adoption by the Commission of a package of measures to support reforms and regional cooperation in the Western Balkans; the progress made in 2015 in reaching an agreement within the normalization of relations between Kosovo and Serbia; in particular agreements regarding the association / community of Serb-majority municipalities in Kosovo; progress in implementing the Visa Liberalization Action Plan; continuing discussions on a framework agreement that would allow Kosovo to participate in EU programs; adoption of the Law on Gender Equality, etc. The report also highlights certain problems: approximately 300 Kosovo citizens who joined the jihadist ranks in Syria and Iraq; the limited progress made in the past year in the area of ​​freedom of expression; the need for additional efforts to fully protect and guarantee in practice the rights of all ethnic minorities in Kosovo through the full implementation of relevant legislation, and in particular the major problem of the lack of visible progress in the fight against high-level corruption and organized crime.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: in writing.- This report is a web of angelism and ideology about Kosovo and its future in the Union.This region combines all the political, economic, identity difficulties, etc.Indeed, 60% of the population has no work, the political class resulting from the UCK terrorist organization does not improve the lot of the population and the situation of the Serbs is more painful than ever.This text nevertheless presents the situation as stabilized and allows to evoke honorable prospects whereas the denial of reality is first of all prejudicial to the inhabitants of Kosovo, Albanians as Serbs.Knowing about the file, but also out of respect for these populations who suffer both from the corruption of the local system and from the angelism of the Union, I voted against this text.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – My colleagues and I at UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such I voted against.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution which is quite critical of the progress made by Kosovo in the perspective of future membership of the European Union.Indeed, the country has only weakly strengthened its legislation in the area of freedom of expression and the media.While efforts have been made, particularly with regard to the fight against terrorism and the country's relations with its Serbian neighbor, the prospect of future membership will have to involve greater conformity of the country's legislation with that of Brussels.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, as I strongly support the European integration process of Kosovo. Kosovo's authorities have to pursue the necessary reforms with commitment, and strengthen the rule of law, the fight against corruption, discrimination, unemployment, and structural economic reforms for the benefit of citizens.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: written.- The association agreement primarily includes the establishment of a free trade agreement between the EU and Kosovo.ALFA stands for an EU of sovereign states with an integrated internal market.We therefore welcome the Association Agreement between the EU and Kosovo.However, ALFA rejects full membership of Kosovo within the current EU.That is why I voted against Parliament's resolution, which includescalls for integration into the EU or at least visa liberalization with Kosovo.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: in writing. - The report on Kosovo's European integration process welcomes the signing of the EU-Kosovo Stabilization and Association Agreement on 27 October 2015, which prepares Kosovo for EU integration and strongly encourages the implementation and institutionalization of reforms. However, it is concerned that no substantial progress has been made in the fight against high-level corruption and organized crime. The document encourages the five Member States that have not yet done so to recognize Kosovo, in the belief that this will further facilitate the normalization of relations between Belgrade and Pristina. Given that the report emphasizes the need for Kosovo to catch up with the Union in all respects, to respect human rights and, above all, to grant the Serb community in its territory the rights that it itself rightly demanded from the then Serbian state in its previous minority status, I voted in favor. the report.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ GUE/NGL does not recognise Kosovo as State. Our group tabled amendments on this particular subject. Furthermore, we do not agree with the neoliberal economic reforms in the 2015 report on Kosovo. I voted against this report, since I reject the structural political and economic program for Kosovo’s progress in light of European enlargement negotiations.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - The EU-Kosovo Stabilization and Association Agreement (SAA), signed on 27 October 2015 and ratified by the Kosovo Assembly on 2 November 2015, aims to promote European standards in areas such as competition, procurement, property intellectual property and consumer protection, as well as creating a free trade area as a concrete step towards economic integration of Kosovo into the EU. I decided to vote in favor as, in addition to the various advances in these areas, the adoption of the legislative package on human rights was welcomed, which strengthens the institutional framework for monitoring the protection and respect of human rights . The EU places the rule of law at the heart of its enlargement policy and it can certainly be said that several efforts have been made in this regard. However, I believe that much still needs to be done in areas such as freedom of expression and the media, the rights of all ethnic minorities, as well as to step up the fight against corruption and organized crime.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: in writing.- I voted against the resolution on the process of European integration of Kosovo.This text should be a stand against the entry of the Kosovo entity into the European Union in view of the overwhelming facts that it recalls.In fact this report preaches for the entry of this entity while making a fairly faithful portrait of a mafia enclave.We should be consistent, and therefore clearly underline that Kosovo has no place in the European Union.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: in writing.- I voted against this resolution because it liberalizes the issuance of visas to citizens of Kosovo.On the other hand, it has the fault of pleading for the entry of Kosovo into the Union even though it recognizes that it is a mafia state!

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing. - In addition, the pseudo-state of Kosovo has unilaterally declared its independence, which is contrary to UN Security Council Resolution 1244, which provides for the autonomy of Kosovo within the Serbian territory. We also note that in a relevant report of the Council of Europe, the current Minister of Foreign Affairs and former Prime Minister of the pseudo-state Hashim Thaçi is accused of setting up a network for trafficking in human organs. We note the systematic persecution and threats experienced by Kosovo Serbs, the majority of whom are Serbs. We note that Kosovo is on the list of the ten countries with the highest percentages of people directly involved in Daesh Islamic terrorism. We also note that the nationalist Vetevendosje movement seeking union with Albania receives 14% of the vote. So these data show that they are prohibitive for any European course of such an outcast state.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ In voting for this resolution I note that five Member States have not formally recognised Kosovo.

name: Georg MAYER
text: written.- Kosovo is and will remain a province in the heart of Serbia.The Serb majority only became a minority through targeted infiltration.If we continue to recognize the now predominant Muslim majority in Kosovo - which came about in addition to infiltration, displacement and military conquest - as a legitimate reason for independence, then we will soon have to accept many other regions in the middle of Europe as independent.Because soon Muslims will be in the majority in many parts of Europe.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the EP resolution assessing Kosovo's progress towards EU membership in 2015.In my opinion, the Stabilization and Association Agreement will facilitate Kosovo's integration into the EU, will strongly encourage the implementation of democratic reforms in the country, will ensure the stability of the region, and will promote closer trade relations.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: in writing. - Parliament takes a position here on Kosovo's "progress" report, which sees the Stabilization and Association Agreement signed in October as the "first formal step" towards European integration. Rather, it is the last step in the creation of a free trade area across all the Western Balkans and yet another economic annexation which puts all the neighboring countries under the shock of structural adjustments amplifying at the same time the movement of social dumping in the Union. The resolution therefore calls for speeding up the restructuring of state-owned enterprises and reforms of the labor market and universities in a territory where a third of the population is unemployed. The EU has acquired a loyal pupil of its positions, committed to its side against Russia and in the international coalition. Considering the presence of the largest American base in Europe, its interests are therefore equally respected. As usual, Parliament is pushing as a bonus for recognition of Kosovo’s independence by all Member States. I vote against

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: in writing.- This report is a statement full of ideology on Kosovo and its future in the Union.This region combines all the political, economic, identity difficulties, etc.Indeed, more than half of the population is without work, and the situation of the Serbs is more painful than ever under the authority of the political class resulting from the terrorist organization UCK.However, on reading this text, the situation now seems stable and it allows itself to consider honorable prospects while the denial of reality is first and foremost prejudicial to the inhabitants of Kosovo, Albanians as well as Serbs.Out of respect for these populations who suffer both from the corruption of the local system and from the angelism of the Union, I voted against this text.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing.- I presented my vote of abstaining on the 2015 Kosovo report.I welcome the progress made in 2015 with regard to the conclusion of agreements in the framework of the process of normalizing relations between Kosovo and Serbia.However, I still have some doubts about the process of European integration in Kosovo, as it stands, which is why I decided to abstain from this vote.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because it is important to establish a European integration process to support Kosovo. The resolution highlights and commends the normalisation of relations between Kosovo and Serbia which is a great achievement for both parties.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: in writing. - I welcome the progress made in Kosovo thanks to a series of reforms implemented by the government, in particular as regards the process of normalization of relations between Pristina and Belgrade. In 2013, the authorities of Serbia and Kosovo reached a first comprehensive agreement to improve their relations on a lasting basis. The roadmap signed in May of the same year by the two Prime Ministers to implement this historic agreement was a major turning point for these two countries. Each step in this direction is one more step towards the stability of the whole region. However, there is still work to be done, in particular as regards freedom of the media, the independence of the judiciary, good governance, etc. The European Union must continue to give its full support to the countries of the Balkans if it wants to prevent this region from turning into a gray zone, the soft underbelly of Europe allowing the particularly connected jihadist propaganda and recruitment networks to come together. develop.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing - Kosovo was formed in a non-standard way when it declared independence from Serbia. I consider this precedent to be dangerous because it introduces instability into the perception of the way new states are created and can serve as a model for other areas with separatist tendencies. In this way, new states can emerge in Europe, which is not in the interests of the unity of the European Union. The Slovak Republic does not recognize Kosovo and I fully share this view. I have spoken out more against the recognition of Kosovo, as well as its accession to the EU. I will remain consistent in these statements. However, the non-recognition of Kosovo is not the only reason why I am against Kosovo's integration into the European Union. Kosovo is an unstable country that is very far from meeting all the requirements required for EU accession. I will mention, for example, the high level of corruption and organized crime, or the lack of reforms, and we have not seen any significant progress in these areas for a long time. For these reasons, I am voting against the resolution.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the European integration process of Kosovo, which in my opinion has a balanced text and welcomes the signature of the EU-Kosovo Stabilisation and Association Agreement (SAA) on 27 October 2015. The SAA will provide a powerful incentive for the implementation and institutionalisation of reforms and will allow setting up cooperation in a wide variety of areas. It welcomes the progress done in 2015 in the framework of the process of normalization of relations between Kosovo and Serbia.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing. - The EU-Kosovo Stabilization and Association Agreement was signed on 27 October 2015 and ratified by the Kosovo Assembly on 2 November 2015. On 10 November 2015, the European Commission issued its 2015 Progress Report on Kosovo. In its motion for a resolution, the Committee on Foreign Affairs proposes that Parliament welcome, inter alia, the signing and swift ratification of the agreement, the results of the process of resolving relations between Serbia and Kosovo, the adoption of the human rights package, the law on protection against discrimination and gender equality, and the stepping up of efforts to combat terrorism. It also called on Parliament to express its concern at the lack of political will to effectively involve civil society, the lack of progress on freedom of expression and the media, high levels of corruption and organized crime, and unemployment, especially among women and young people. due to its high level and the delicate energy supply situation in Kosovo. I voted in favor of the motion.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. - Kosovo unilaterally declared its independence in 2008, following the failure of international negotiations. Several countries such as Portugal, France, Germany and the United States have recognized it as a sovereign state. However, there are still countries like Spain, Russia that consider Kosovo part of Serbia. For the reasons explained above, Kosovo is only a potential candidate for the Union. However, the Union has been supporting its economic and social development through not only financial aid, but also through EULEX's presence in the territory, with the aim of implementing reforms to achieve the rule of law, and the presence of the Union Special Representative in Kosovo. I congratulate Kosovo and Serbia on the progress they have made. The dialogue between Pristina and Belgrade must continue to maintain stability in the region. However, there are still elements in the judicial sphere that undermine the implementation of the rule of law, namely full independence, transparency, impartiality and efficiency of judges and magistrates.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: in writing.- This motion for a resolution on the process of European integration of Kosovo preaches its entry into the Union, even though it paints an unflattering portrait of this country and highlights the role of the mafia that thrives there.It would have been more judicious to propose the non-membership of this country to the Union given the situation it is experiencing.I therefore voted against this text.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report on the process of European integration in Kosovo.This text recalls that the stabilization and association agreement concluded at the end of 2015 between the Union and Kosovo will promote reforms in many areas.In particular, it will strengthen political dialogue, better trade integration and improve relations between the Balkan countries.This text also welcomes Kosovo's participation in the fight against terrorism and the measures adopted to prevent the radicalization of young people.He calls on the authorities to closely monitor and prevent the mobilization of foreign fighters and Islamist terrorists, which I fully support.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. - By adopting this report, we welcome the signing of the EU-Kosovo Stabilization and Association Agreement on 27 October, which we believe can provide a strong incentive for the implementation and institutionalization of reforms , allowing for cooperation with the EU in a wide range of areas, in order to intensify political dialogue and strengthen trade integration. Indeed, the Commission's aid package intends to support the political and economic reform process in Kosovo, as well as to promote European standards in areas such as competition, procurement, intellectual property and consumer protection, as well as to create an area of free trade as a concrete step towards a forthcoming economic integration in the EU. We encourage all political forces to act constructively in the interests of the country, its democratic institutions and its citizens. Specifically, we welcome the adoption of the Gender Equality Law and call on the Kosovar authorities to address gender mainstreaming as a matter of priority and to ensure that governing bodies and authorities lead by example. We must, in fact, underline the low representation of women in decision-making positions, as well as the lack of progress in the fight against domestic and gender-based violence.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: in writing.- The resolution on the situation in Kosovo highlights the reform efforts made by the country within the framework of regional cooperation and the process of joining the European Union.I therefore voted in favor of this resolution which takes stock of the current situation and future challenges.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ On 27 October 2015 the EU-Kosovo Stabilisation and Association Agreement was signed. I have abstained on this motion for a resolution due to the fact that five Member States (Cyprus, Greece, Romania, Slovakia and Spain) do not recognise its sovereignty.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: written.- I voted against this report because I find it too unbalanced towards the Serbian minority in Kosovo.For example, the constant destruction of Serbia's cultural heritage is just as neglected as the aspirations for autonomy of the Serbs in northern Kosovo.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: in writing. - I welcome the report on the progress made in Kosovo. It is to be welcomed that Kosovo has made significant progress in strengthening its economic dialogue with the EU and has presented its first economic reform program. This is a good sign that Kosovo is moving towards the EU, but many reforms still need to be carried out in order to meet European standards in areas such as competition, public procurement, intellectual property and consumer protection. In particular, the high number of missing persons during the war is still not adequately addressed. In addition, more measures are needed to ensure adequate protection of the rights of all religious minorities, including Kosovo Christians. Insufficient progress has also been made in the fight against high-level corruption and organized crime. It should be noted that the Commission should step up its efforts to address the visa liberalization process in Kosovo, taking into account Kosovo's progress in implementing the Visa Liberalization Action Plan.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing.- On 28 June 2013 the European Council decided to start accession negotiations with Serbia, a country that aspires to become a member of the EU.Two years later, the Commission reported on the excellent progress made by the country towards European integration, I would therefore have voted positively, declaring admiration and support for this country.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: in writing. ‒ Kosovo was able to make a huge step towards the EU with our EP's approval of the Stabilization and Association Agreement, two weeks ago. Kosovo's step towards the EU meant that Kosovo had to overcome big internal and external barriers - Congratulations! Building bridges between Kosovo and Serbia will continue to be a high priority and it is the EU that can help most! It is the European principle of respect for the dignity of different identities that will lead to reconciliation between Kosovo & Serbia. I strongly recommend Kosovo, to keep all internal political issues under discussion within the national assembly and make considerable efforts in the fight against corruption.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written.- I welcome the European Parliament's resolution on the 2015 Kosovo report.I think it is important that the European Union recognizes the efforts that Kosovo has made in dialogue with Serbia, clarifying war crimes, fighting terrorism and stopping mass illegal emigration to Western European countries.The continuation of Kosovo's European path, as well as other countries in Southeast Europe, is one of the important factors for achieving peace and stability in that part of Europe, and therefore I welcome the signing of the Stability and Association Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Kosovo.I also hope that after the signing of the Stabilization and Association Agreement, the Kosovo authorities will continue to implement the reforms necessary to move closer to the European Union, work to respect human rights, strengthen democracy and freedom of speech, dialogue with neighbors and normalize interethnic relations in Kosovo.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: in writing.- This report is yet another hallucinating example of the blindness of the European Union in the Balkans.Kosovo is rightly described as a mafia enclave where all kinds of trafficking proliferate and where certain minorities are mistreated.Nevertheless, he calls for visa liberalization and, ultimately, Kosovo's entry into the European Union.It is obvious that I completely disagree with such irresponsible positions and I am therefore voting against this text.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. - The external action of the Union aimed at supporting the economic and political development of Kosovo and the package envisaged by the Commission on the issues of regional cooperation, are a fundamental element for the normalization of relations with the countries of the Western Balkans and are moving in the right direction , for greater integration of Kosovo into the EU. As a market economy in the early stages of its development, Union support is essential to enable the country to strengthen its economy and reverse the unemployment curve that particularly afflicts young people and women. I voted in favor of this resolution because I believe it is necessary for the Union, in line with the Stabilization and Association Agreement, to continue to support Kosovo on the path of the reforms it has undertaken. The implementation of all aspects of the agreement must be accomplished by achieving full respect for the rule of law, and it is also important that Member States, 23 out of 28 to date, recognize the country's independence. Kosovo will also have to achieve visa liberalization objectives in order to tackle irregular migration and, finally, it should develop the political will to interact with civil society and adopt strategies for the protection of minorities and vulnerable groups.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written. - I thank my colleague Lunaček for the report, which comprehensively shows the situation in Kosovo and the progress made in the past year. Certainly the most important moment is the signing of the Stabilization and Association Agreement, which we recently ratified here in the European Parliament. It is a kind of reward for Kosovo's commitment to full membership and a European future. But further progress will depend on the commitment and constructive cooperation of all political stakeholders, which is not the case now. Unfortunately, once again, the “regional” problem of the opposition's participation in parliament is emerging. The legislative framework has improved over the past year, the success of which will depend primarily on implementation, but organized crime, the level of corruption, high unemployment, especially among young people, and vulnerable free media remain strong. The measures adopted to combat terrorism and radicalization, the reduction in the number of illegal migrants and asylum seekers in the EU, and the progress made in meeting the visa waiver criteria for Kosovo citizens are commendable. I hope that by the next report, this issue will also be closed. Throughout the transition process, communication of adopted measures with citizens is extremely important in order to facilitate their implementation on the ground, increase citizen participation and information, but also further contribute to building a multiethnic society in Kosovo, especially in education and employment of minorities.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing.- This motion for a resolution is part of the continued formalization of relations with a territory, Kosovo, as if it were a legitimate country, after the very serious precedent that was opened in international law with the unilateral declaration of independence of that Serbian province.of Kosovo.An illegal decision that we do not recognize, which created a protectorate through aggression and military occupation by the USA, NATO and the EU, which at all costs have sought to legitimize.Kosovo's self-proclamation as a state violates the Helsinki Final Act and several United Nations Resolutions - notably Security Council Resolution 1244 of June 1999, which enshrines respect for Serbia's territorial integrity and sovereignty over Kosovo.We voted against

name: Pavel POC
text: in writing. - The future of the countries of Central and Eastern Europe, which have already succeeded in becoming members of the European Union, as well as the countries of the Western Balkans, lies at the heart of the European family. That is why I voted in favor of the Resolution on the Kosovo Report 2015. European integration is a process that has been contributing to the stabilization of neighborly relations in the Western Balkans region for several years, a key element for the Union and the prosperity of the Balkans. I am therefore very pleased that the Stabilization and Association Agreement was signed at the end of last year. I believe that this step will provide Kosovo with even greater motivation to continue the fight against organized crime, corruption, discrimination, unemployment and the independence of the media. Only in this way will Kosovo be able to create conditions that will benefit not only further integration efforts, but also the people of that country. The rule of law and the establishment of quality education are other important prerequisites in this regard. Kosovo's parliament needs to play its role and not be prevented from doing so. There is also a need to respect the rights of minorities and to combat the radicalization and extremism that currently forms the Achilles' heel in several Member States of the European Union. The Union, but Kosovo in particular, must work to give the young generation a perspective on the future.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing.- The Association Agreement between the EU and Kosovo, ratified by the European Parliament on 21 January 2016, provides a powerful incentive for reforms and paves the way for Kosovo's integration into the European Union.Furthermore, recognition of the country by other states could help strengthen stability in the region, further facilitate the normalization of relations between Serbia and Kosovo and strengthen the credibility of the EU in its foreign and neighborhood policy.For these reasons, I voted in favor of this motion for a resolution.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing.- I supported the resolution on Kosovo.However, that does not mean that I support the entry of Kosovo into the Union.It is only a question of maintaining a zone of stability at the external borders of the Union.This stage and this strategy are all the more important in this difficult period with the influx of migrants.We need stability so that Kosovo is a safe country so that Kosovar migrants return home and the country can support the Union in controlling the flow of migrants.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
