text: in writing. - I welcome this document, which addresses the Stabilization and Association Agreement (SAA) between the EU and Kosovo, signed on 27 October 2015. I voted in favor of this document because it states the need for the Kosovo Government to focus on implementing the comprehensive reforms necessary to fulfill its obligations under the SAA, which aims to promote European standards in areas such as competition, public procurement, intellectual property and consumer protection, as well as to establish a trade zone as a concrete step towards Kosovo's economic integration into the European Union. I also welcome the reinforced efforts and the firm commitment to fight terrorism. However, I agree that the progress made in the area of ​​freedom of expression and the media, as well as efforts to protect and guarantee in practice the rights of all ethnic minorities in Kosovo, are still insufficient. In this regard, I voted in favor of this document which calls on Kosovo to follow the lines of the EU's Common Foreign and Security Policy.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: written. - The Resolution starts from an act that the Spanish State does not recognize: the unilateral declaration of independence of Kosovo of 2008. For this reason, part of this Resolution encourages the five EU Member States that do not recognize Kosovo to do so. Spain did not recognize the unilateral declaration of independence because it considered that it was contrary to international law and violated the principles of sovereignty and territorial integrity recognized in Serbia and guaranteed by the Helsinki Final Act. This position is also consistent with that of the United Nations, since there is a Security Council Resolution in force (Resolution 1244 of June 10, 1999) that opposes a unilateral act of these characteristics. Furthermore, recognizing such independence would not be consistent with the actions of the international community in Bosnia and Herzegovina in relation to the Republika Srpska or in other similar situations such as Ossetia, Abkhazia and Crimea. Of course, all the positive aspirations for the people of Kosovo that the report contains could be supported, but these cannot lead to acceptance of the unilateral independence of Kosovo. For all these reasons, I have voted against this Resolution.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing.- I abstained on this resolution on Kosovo, which was adopted this midday by 403 votes in favor, 130 votes against and 104 abstentions.The text of the resolution underlines that the EU-Kosovo Association Agreement paves the way for Kosovo's integration into the European Union.However, I supported the efforts made (and still to be made) in terms of the independence of the media and the judiciary, the fight against high-level corruption and organized crime, or the reforms of the labor market, whichare just a few of the areas of great concern.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution because I believe it lays the groundwork for further rapprochement between Kosovo and the EU.2015October 27The signing of the EU-Kosovo Stabilization and Association Agreement in 2006 is an excellent basis not only for establishing the first contractual relationship, but also as a powerful impetus for reform, a way of establishing cooperation in various fields.I believe that this resolution is a good indication of the EP's strong willingness to cooperate with Kosovo, as well as its full support for helping to resolve Kosovo's fundamental problems.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. - (PT) This motion for a resolution concerns the process of Kosovo's integration into the EU, and there are several signs that demonstrate the country's clear intention to follow the path of European integration. Right from the start, the signing of the Stabilization and Association Agreement in October 2015, the progress made in the process of normalizing relations between Kosovo and Serbia, the political and economic reforms aimed at European integration and the approval of a legislative package on human rights. On the other hand, the Commission's effort to create a support package for reforms and regional cooperation in the Western Balkans, with a view to its accession to the European Union, as well as to reinforce the work on the visa liberalization process and support from the Kosovo exemption regime. Much work remains to be done, but the content of this motion for a resolution is, in itself, clear on the aspects of the evolution of the integration process and, to that extent, it welcomed and voted for me.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this resolution on the process of European integration in Kosovo. It should be recalled that the negotiations for the signing of the Stabilization and Association Agreement between the Union and Kosovo were completed in May 2014 and that the agreement was initialed in July 2014. This resolution sets out an assessment of the situation. As such, it is crucial that the establishment and proper functioning of the Special Court as well as cooperation with it be the priorities of the Kosovar government. I supported this resolution because it recalls the reforms that Kosovo must pursue: the fight against organized crime, the reform of the judicial system, the fight against criminal networks, the fight against high unemployment which is around 30%, or again the fight against terrorism. Indeed, Kosovo must also face a phenomenon of radicalization and the departure of young people who will join the ranks of the "Islamic State" group. It is essential that the Union continues to support the Balkan States in their reforms for more democracy and the rule of law.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: written.- We abstain in this vote because, although the International Court of Justice concluded that the unilateral declaration of independence of Kosovo did not violate international law or Resolution 1244 of the United Nations Security Council, and although the process of nationalization ofKosovo is irreversible, the ruling does not imply that the former province has a well-founded right to be recognized by third parties.The situation in Kosovo has a complex political background and, therefore, must be addressed and resolved politically, through an agreement that in any case integrates Serbia, which neutralizes Serbian and Kosovar nationalisms that pose a permanent internal threat to peace,to safeguard the rights of ethnic minorities in the area and to guarantee the exit of foreign military powers from the area in the medium term.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: in writing.- I welcome the adoption by the Commission of a package aimed at supporting reforms and regional cooperation in the Western Balkans - a package that reflects the EU's commitment to support the political and economic reform process of the Western Balkan countries on their path to EU membership.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support the European integration process of Kosovo. The public authorities of Kosovo must develop on their reforms and strengthen their commitment to strengthening the rule of law, the fight against corruption and organised crime. The report does point out some of the major political issues, principally the fact that five of the 28 EU Member States don’t actually recognise the Republic of Kosovo while such recognition would most definitely strengthen stability in the region and normalise relations between Serbia and Kosovo.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report, but this explanation of vote arises as a critique of the current system of evaluating the work of MPs in the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities emphasized in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual qualityactions.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing - Despite the signing of the EU-Kosovo Stabilization and Association Agreement on 27 October 2015 as the first contractual relationship and its ratification by the Kosovo Assembly on 2 November, it should be emphasized that five Member States, including Slovakia, did not recognize Kosovo as a state. Kosovo must first and foremost seek to normalize relations between Kosovo and Serbia, because only then can it make progress in recognizing them by other Member States. In other areas, too, Kosovo is in its infancy - whether it is a functioning economy, high unemployment, especially among young people and women, insufficient skills needed for the labor market, insufficient business environment, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises. The report states that there is a very weak political will on the part of the institutions to actually cooperate with civil society, which is considered one of the key areas in the integration process. Also of concern is the very limited progress made in the area of ​​freedom of expression and the media. Kosovo must also make greater efforts to protect the guarantees of the right of all ethnic minorities in Kosovo. I did not support the report in the final vote, because I consider it most important that Kosovo first seeks cooperation and a settlement of relations with Serbia.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: in writing. - Kosovo's independence has so far been recognized by 110 of the 193 UN member states, including 23 of the 28 EU member states. On 27 October 2015, a Stabilization and Association Agreement was signed between the EU and Kosovo, paving the way for Kosovo's integration into the EU and an important call for the implementation and institutionalization of reforms. This agreement encourages the launch of Kosovo-EU cooperation in a number of areas, which will strengthen political dialogue and achieve closer trade cooperation. Relations with neighboring countries will also be strengthened, contributing to stability in the region. The purpose of this agreement is to promote European standards in the areas of competition, public procurement, intellectual property and consumer protection, as a tangible step towards Kosovo's economic integration into the EU. In 2015, the Kosovo authorities took important steps towards meeting their obligations under the Stabilization and Association Agreement, although further efforts are still needed. I believe that these efforts are needed in the areas of the fight against corruption and organized crime, freedom of expression and the media, the protection and effective protection of the rights of all ethnic minorities in Kosovo, and so on. The motion for a resolution is an appropriate response to the conclusion of the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the 2015 Kosovo report, which is why I also supported it.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of the resolution on the integration process of Kosovo into the European Union, which comes after the ratification by the European Parliament of the recently concluded EU-Kosovo Association and Stabilization Agreement. The agreement contains important incentives for the implementation and institutionalization of the reforms necessary to allow the country to move forward in the process of moving closer to the European Union. Among the reforms indicated, the stabilization process of relations between Kosovo and Serbia, the fight against corruption and organized crime, the reduction of discrimination and the guarantee of media independence are particularly relevant. Kosovo also faces several economic problems including poor competitiveness, the shadow economy and a high unemployment rate, the overcoming of which requires an important effort and requires international support. I believe that the greater recognition given to Kosovo's integration policies can contribute to the normalization of relations between Serbia and Kosovo and thus to the strengthening of stability in the region.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing - Kosovo, as in the case of Serbia, is making progress in the integration process.With the signing of the Stabilization and Association Agreement, relations between Kosovo and the European Union have been strengthened and brought to an institutional level.I consider the mutual agreement of both countries to be important.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: written. - The EU-Kosovo Stabilization and Association Agreement was signed on 27 October 2015 and ratified by the Kosovo Assembly on 2 November 2015. The Stabilization and Association Agreement paves the way for Kosovo's EU integration, offers a strong impetus for implementation and institutionalization of reforms and enables the establishment of cooperation with the EU in a number of areas in order to improve political dialogue and closer trade integration as well as strengthen relations with neighboring countries and contribute to stability in the region. Therefore, I call on the Government of Kosovo to focus on implementing the comprehensive reforms needed to meet its obligations under the Stabilization and Association Agreement, and to pursue a common EU security and defense policy. It is important for Kosovo to complete the development of the legislative framework for the civil service and to fully implement the strategic framework for public administration and the action plan. The authorities should promote merit-based professionalisation in all public institutions and ensure sound financial management of public institutions and transparency in the Assembly's oversight of budget execution. Progress in labor market reforms, together with reforms in the education system, is key to addressing high unemployment rates and low labor market participation rates.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written. - Kosovo has so far been recognized by 110 of the 193 member states of the United Nations, including 23 of the 28 member states of the European Union. The Stabilization and Association Agreement between Kosovo and the European Union was signed on October 27, 2015, as the first contractual relationship. The agreement paves the way for Kosovo's EU integration and allows for co-operation with the Union. Discussions are under way on a framework agreement that would allow Kosovo to participate in European Union programs. Parliament welcomes the progress made in 2015 in reaching an agreement on the normalization of relations between Kosovo and Serbia. Concerns are also expressed about the lack of visible progress in the fight against corruption and organized crime, which remains a major problem. The Kosovo government must show that the country is systematically fighting corruption at all levels. Also, Kosovo faces the problem of high unemployment rates, especially among young people and women, and general discrimination against women in society and in the labor market is to be condemned. I support the proposal for this resolution and its recommendations for the further integration of Kosovo into the European society of nations. Kosovo's integration into European integration is essential to ensure peace and security in the region.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the resolution at the end of the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the 2015 report on Kosovo. The future of Kosovo lies in the European Union, but much remains to be done.The normalization of relations with Serbia is an encouraging and positive step, which must be followed by other important reform steps.Among other things, it must step up the fight against corruption and organized crime, improve dialogue with civil society, which is an important part of a modern democratic order, step up efforts for media and judicial independence and implement economic reforms, as Kosovo faces high unemployment.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE / NGL), in writing.- The situation in Kosovo is a continuation and consequence of invasive policies.It is a clear violation of international law that sets a bad precedent by risking being used as a model in other cases.Of particular concern is the fact that various circles link the case of the "TRNC" with Kosovo.The report urges Member States that have not recognized Kosovo, including Cyprus, to do so.That is why we voted against the report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: in writing.- It is an insult and a joke and we are only talking about the prospect of integration of the Kosovo-Metohija region into the European Union.Enlargement promoted under the guise of European integration and cohesion serves the interests of economic and geopolitical centers of power.

name: József SZÁJER
text: in writing. - The report on Kosovo's European integration process welcomes the signing of the EU-Kosovo Stabilization and Association Agreement on 27 October 2015, which prepares Kosovo for EU integration and strongly encourages the implementation and institutionalization of reforms. However, it is concerned that no substantial progress has been made in the fight against high-level corruption and organized crime. The document encourages the five Member States that have not yet done so to recognize Kosovo, in the belief that this will further facilitate the normalization of relations between Belgrade and Pristina. Given that the report emphasizes the need for Kosovo to catch up with the Union in all respects, to respect human rights and, above all, to grant the Serb community living on its territory the rights it rightly demanded from the then Serbian state in its previous minority status, with my vote I supported the report.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - I supported the adoption of the report presenting and assessing the state of Kosovo's European integration process, given that recent developments, the escalating refugee crisis along the EU's southern borders, have shown that the EU has an important and direct interest in the Western Balkans, including the European integration of an independent, democratic Kosovo with normal relations with its neighbors. I believe that active parliamentary support for this process, including the effective implementation of the Association Agreement with Kosovo, provides a basis for the EP to continue to closely monitor and hold the Pristina leadership to account for shortcomings in the democratic rule of law and, in particular, for political violence as soon as possible. The decision clearly advocates maintaining and strengthening Kosovo's European perspective. I hope that this will shed light on the fact that the effectiveness of the EU's involvement in the Western Balkans in this area is being undermined by the fact that five Member States have still not recognized the independent statehood of Kosovo. Both the report and the parliamentary debate pointed out that the credibility of the EU's enlargement policy also depends on these Member States finally resolving the historically and politically far-reaching and pointless blockade.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: in writing. - In October 2015, the Stabilization and Association Agreement between the European Union and Kosovo was signed, which paves the way for Kosovo's integration with the Community and provides a strong incentive to implement and institutionalize reforms, enabling cooperation with the EU in many areas. The European Union has repeatedly reaffirmed its will to assist Kosovo's economic and political development within a clearly defined European perspective. However, the integration process requires resolving a number of pressing issues, such as violation of human rights, intolerance, corruption, organized crime, the problem of civil service and inefficient public administration, high unemployment, especially among women and young people, discrimination, inefficient infrastructure, etc. There is also no doubt that the integration process is to some extent slowed down due to the non-recognition of Kosovo by five EU Member States. Recognition of Kosovo would certainly help to strengthen stability in the region, facilitate the further normalization of relations between Serbia and Kosovo and increase the credibility of the Union's external policy. Due to the conclusion of the Stabilization and Association Agreement, the last year can certainly be considered a turning point in terms of rapprochement between Kosovo and the Union. However, much still needs to be done on both sides. The report of the European Parliament properly identifies the existing problems, challenges and recommendations for the future, which is why I have decided to vote in favor of it.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the text.However, I would like to reiterate that it is important that Kosovo and Serbia find durable solutions for refugees, in line with the findings of the United Nations Refugee Agency (UNHCR) in this regard and in line with the 2014 report of theUN Special Rapporteur on the Human Rights of Internally Displaced Persons.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls political actors in Kosovo to find a solution to the crisis there. The opposition has been violently obstructing the work of the Kosovar Parliament since September 2015 and it is now time for Kosovo’s political leaders to act responsibly. Moreover it is of crucial importance that the Kosovar government pursue its reform agenda, especially on freedom of the media and of the judiciary, reform of public administration, tackling high-level corruption and organised crime, and reform of the labour market. By voting on this text I also welcome the progress made in reaching agreements with Serbia and the need to move forward with the full implementation of all the agreements already reached, and to continue the normalisation process.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing.- The integration of the Balkans into the European Union is an obligatory stage for our future.The European Union has a historical and moral obligation towards its Balkan neighbors.However, Kosovo still has a long way to go in this regard.It is up to the European Institutions to monitor and evaluate its path, providing support but remaining firm on the principles of respect for minorities and human rights.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: in writing. - The report on Kosovo's European integration process welcomes the signing of the EU-Kosovo Stabilization and Association Agreement on 27 October 2015, which prepares Kosovo for EU integration and strongly encourages the implementation and institutionalization of reforms. However, it is concerned that no substantial progress has been made in the fight against high-level corruption and organized crime. The document encourages the five Member States that have not yet done so to recognize Kosovo, in the belief that this will further facilitate the normalization of relations between Belgrade and Pristina. Given that the report emphasizes the need for Kosovo to catch up with the Union in all respects, to respect human rights and, above all, to grant the Serb community in its territory the rights that it itself rightly demanded from the then Serbian state in its previous minority status, I voted in favor. the report.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written.- I believe that few in the European Union, but also in Kosovo, think that the process of European integration of the youngest European country will go smoothly.Kosovo faces major challenges in establishing true democracy, the rule of law and a market economy, the fight against corruption, organized crime and terrorism, and the protection of civil and media freedoms.In all these areas, Kosovo is expected to make great strides that Pristina must make, primarily for its citizens and their future prosperity.But, although the day of Kosovo's entry into the EU is still far away, I think it is wrong to perform with a fig in your pocket.Kosovo cannot have a European future without first being recognized by all member states and candidate countries, including Serbia.It is time for us all to finally acknowledge that a free and independent Kosovo is a reality, because any different approach would reflect a hypocrisy that should have no place among friends and partners.That is why I supported this report.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing.- I supported the motion for a resolution concluding the debate on the statements by the Council and the Commission pursuant to Rule 123 (2) of the Rules of Procedure on the 2015 Kosovo Report, as it describes the EU's achievements, shortcomings and calls to KosovoEuropean standard.Only through the country's efforts to make progress and good cooperation with EU Member States will Kosovo's economic integration be possible, especially in the light of the establishment of a free trade area.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: written.- We abstain in this vote because, although the International Court of Justice concluded that the unilateral declaration of independence of Kosovo did not violate international law or Resolution 1244 of the United Nations Security Council, and although the process of nationalization ofKosovo is irreversible, the ruling does not imply that the former province has a well-founded right to be recognized by third parties.The situation in Kosovo has a complex political background and, therefore, must be addressed and resolved politically, through an agreement that in any case integrates Serbia, which neutralizes Serbian and Kosovar nationalisms that pose a permanent internal threat to peace,to safeguard the rights of ethnic minorities in the area and to guarantee the exit of foreign military powers from the area in the medium term.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: written.- The association agreement primarily includes the establishment of a free trade agreement between the EU and Kosovo.ALFA stands for an EU of sovereign states with an integrated internal market.We therefore welcome the Association Agreement between the EU and Kosovo.However, ALFA rejects full membership of Kosovo within the current EU.That is why I voted against Parliament's resolution, which includescalls for integration into the EU or visa liberalization with Kosovo.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing.- 110 of the 193 UN member states, including 23 of the 28 EU member states, recognize Kosovo's independence.The EU-Kosovo Stabilization and Association Agreement was signed on 27 October 2015 and ratified by the Kosovo National Assembly on 2 November 2015.The European Parliament will give its consent to the agreement in January 2016.I voted in favor of the related document.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because I am supportive of Kosovo´s European integration process. Kosovo finds itself in a more complicated situation compared to other Western Balkan countries: it still hasn´t been officially recognised by 5 Member States, it is the only country to still have an active Visa regime in place with the EU and faces very high levels of corruption and unemployment. Relations with Serbia have improved but a lot more needs to be done, particularly in the fields of judicial and law enforcement cooperation. Nevertheless, I believe that further European integration can only benefit Kosovo, and will lead to improvements in relations with its neighbours as well as to greater stability within the wider region.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: written.- For the Liberal Group in the EP, I am responsible for Kosovo (ALDE coordinator).I voted in favor of this report because I am a strong supporter of Kosovo's European integration process.The Kosovar government must implement the necessary reforms to strengthen the rule of law, further strengthen the fight against corruption and implement structural economic reforms to combat the high unemployment rate.This will benefit the Kosovars themselves in the first place, but ultimately also the entire region and by extension the European Union.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing.- This motion for a resolution implies the continuation of the formalization of the establishment of relations with a territory, Kosovo, as if it were a legitimate country, after the very serious precedent that was opened in international law with the unilateral declaration of independence of the provinceKosovo, which the EU has sought to legitimize.An illegal decision, which we do not recognize, which created a protectorate through aggression and military occupation by the USA, NATO and the EU.We do not recognize the existence of Kosovo as a state.This existence violates the Helsinki Final Act and several United Nations Resolutions on this issue - namely Security Council Resolution 1244 of June 1999, which enshrines the respect for territorial integrity and Serbia's sovereignty over Kosovo.That is why we voted against it.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: written.- Kosovo is and will remain a province in the heart of Serbia.The Serb majority only became a minority through targeted infiltration.If we continue to recognize the now predominant Muslim majority in Kosovo - which came about in addition to infiltration, displacement and military conquest - as a legitimate reason for independence, then we will soon have to accept many other regions in the middle of Europe as independent.Because soon Muslims will be in the majority in many parts of Europe.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: written.- It cannot be in the interest of Europe to bring Kosovo, which has been declared “independent” at the expense of Serbia, to the EU as an independent state unit and to integrate it at all levels in the process.In particular, any commitment by the Kosovar leadership to an anti-Russian foreign policy course must be rejected.That is why a clear “no” was required here.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: written.- I did not approve the resolution of the EU Parliament on the report on Kosovo.I am against admitting further members to the EU as long as it has not resolved its structural and institutional problems.This also includes a new version of the European Treaties.I reject the Stabilization and Association Agreement between the EU and Kosovo.I also oppose all further steps that result in making Kosovo an EU member.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the adoption of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement with Kosovo. Apart from enhancing political dialogue and opening new forms of cooperation, the Agreement will create opportunities to enhance contact between people, which is no less essential to the bringing down of barriers than cooperation between experts and governments. Citizens and civil society must be included in the process of implementation of the Agreement, and citizens must be informed about the process in a transparent manner. I deeply believe that more consideration must be given to the power of civil society to pursue inter-cultural exchange, people-to-people dialogue, and initiatives bringing together citizens from EU Member States and Kosovo. The EU can be a key player in this kind of exchange: able to share, support and develop best practice, particularly in respect of young people. Kosovan youth are the promise of its future: they are the ones who stand to gain from the ongoing dialogue. A young generation of Kosovars have grown up with a European vision. They must not be let down.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. - This report analyzes the situation of Kosovo in its European integration process. We find a great deal of attention to the fight against poverty and the emphasis given to social policies, to the tools that tackle at the root both extremism and migratory problems, freedom of expression and the denunciation of violence against dissident journalists and non-discrimination. and the protection of minorities. The fight against corruption and organized crime is also reaffirmed, which are represented as scourges that still seriously affect the Kosovar system. The judicial system, although it has undergone significant improvements, is still subject to strong political pressure. Another theme rightly touched upon by this report is youth unemployment. Although not all aspects of the report are positive and some doubts still remain regarding certain aspects, my vote was favorable considering also that the objective of the report is to safeguard the improvement of the living conditions of the Kosovar population and the accompanying the country on its way to EU membership.

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: in writing.- I welcome the approval of the resolution on the Kosovo integration process.I find it important to strengthen Kosovo's bond with the Union and I believe that the Stabilization and Association Agreement signed on 27 October 2015 will give a strong impetus to the implementation of fundamental reforms for the country.I particularly share the reference to the progress made in relations with Serbia and I hope that both countries will proceed rapidly towards a full normalization of their relations.I end my speech by urging the Kosovan government to continue with determination the reform process it has begun, fighting in particular against corruption and organized crime, making a firm commitment to prevent all forms of discrimination and guaranteeing an adequate level of media independence.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: in writing. - I could not support this report. I completely disagree with the liberalization of the visa regime for the people of Kosovo, which is mentioned several times in this resolution. The conditions met should include ensuring that Kosovars en masse in the Union, as in previous years, combating organized crime or preventing discrimination against the Serb population. Tens of thousands of young people have already traveled to Europe. The outflow of people was stopped only by the tightening of the visa requirement. I believe that if visas for the citizens of Kosovo are abolished, Europe can expect another wave of migration from the Balkans. The outflow of young people from Kosovo, plagued by high unemployment, instability and economic problems, is understandable. In my opinion, however, it is another major problem for the European Union. I therefore believe that it is more than necessary to thoroughly discuss and consider all the pros and cons of lifting the visa requirement for the people of Kosovo.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing - The motion for a resolution on the 2015 Kosovo Report assesses progress to date and welcomes the recent ratification of the EU-Kosovo Stabilization and Association Agreement. While identifying some of the goals that have been achieved in Kosovo, such as normalizing relations and improving the dialogue between Kosovo and Serbia, he stresses, on the other hand, that many problems remain in Kosovo despite reforms. The biggest concerns are associated with the challenges of radicalization, lack of competitiveness, but also alarmingly high unemployment. I think that Kosovo's integration into the European Union has a major impact on stabilizing the whole region, and I supported the recent ratification of the Stabilization and Association Agreement, despite the fact that the Slovak Republic is one of the remaining five Member States that have not yet recognized Kosovo. However, I abstained in the vote on this resolution, especially on some points with which I do not agree, such as the liberalization of the visa procedure.

name: Milan ZVER
text: in writing.- I supported the European Parliament's resolution on the report on Kosovo, as I agree with the European Parliament's response to the report on the progress of Kosovo's EU integration process.The EU-Kosovo Stabilization and Association Agreement is an opportunity for Kosovo to carry out comprehensive reforms, strengthen political dialogue and trade relations with the EU, and contribute to stability in the Balkans in general.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Mr President, yesterday, during the debate on Libya, I spoke of only one phenomenon of problems in this country, and that is the abduction of Europeans. Unfortunately, one Czech who has been missing for more than a year and two months was also abducted in this way. However, I did not have time to comment - and that is why I spoke today - on the text of the resolution itself, which I supported, because I think it is good that, at a time when a political agreement was proposed here at the end of last year for all the warring parties. in Libya, and this agreement has unfortunately been rejected by the Tobruk Parliament or the Government of National Unity, the European Union has raised its voice in the international arena, making it clear that the opposing parties should honor this agreement and try to form a Government of National Unity and create a fragile peace. Without this, the situation in Libya cannot improve at all, which is why I supported the resolution, and I hope that the parties in Libya will hear it.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: - Thank you very much, Mr President. As we know, there is a brutal civil war going on in Libya for another year, there is violence, thousands of people are becoming refugees. And it is not entirely clear whether the agreement signed on 17 September through the United Nations on the Council of Deputies and the new General National Congress can bring the long-awaited peace to the Libyan people. However, this is currently the only document on the table. Libya is potentially one of the richest countries in Africa in general and a large country in the Middle East in general. In abstraction, but certainly not forgetting the problems that existed during the reign of Muammar Gaddafi, the standard of living in the country at that time, under Gaddafi, was very high. While this also depended to a large extent on hydrocarbon prices, a similar level is again achievable. Therefore, we must all unite to help Libya return to the family of civilized nations.

name: Peter JAHR
text: - Mister President! There is a saying in German vernacular that means: The opposite of well done is well meant. Of course, it was right to remove the dictatorship in Libya - it was well meant. Of course, it was also the right thing to take action against human rights violations there, but the situation in Libya shows us very clearly what mistakes can actually be made after breaking away from a dictatorial system. And we did a lot wrong there. For us, this means that the challenge goes to ourselves: If you are helping to remove dictatorial systems in a country, then you have to be intensively involved in building democratic conditions - or have the appropriate partners. And the grotesque thing we have in Libya: firstly, we do not have a functioning state system, and secondly - my colleague said it earlier - the people's standard of living has tended to fall. In this respect, Libya is not a good example of a European foreign policy. We should urgently learn our lessons from this.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. - Since 2011, the Libyan territory has been the scene of a bloody civil war that continues to bring the country's population and economy to their knees. According to the 2015 World Report, published by Human Rights Watch, 2.44 million people are currently in need of protection and various forms of humanitarian assistance. The humanitarian emergency is further aggravated by the strong political instability that characterizes the transitional institutions, supported by the international community, but opposed by the power and unrest of local militias. Furthermore, the spread of the activity of terrorist groups has only worsened the political, social and humanitarian situation of the country, making European intervention indispensable. Although the resolution presented addresses important issues, I believe that the EU should devise a more incisive strategy, categorically condemning an individual intervention by Member States as well as the creation of additional national armed forces to control the territory. That is why I voted no.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted to abstain this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is supportive of the UN backed plan to return Libya to stable and democratic governance and hopes that all sides will fulfil their obligations under the agreement. However we do not support the EU's attempts to get involved in Libya and expand their foreign policy role. We are also mindful of the situation in Libya's impact on the current migration crisis. As such we abstained on the resolution as whole.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP voted to abstain on this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is supportive of the UN-backed plan to return Libya to stable and democratic governance and hopes that all sides will fulfil their obligations under the agreement. However we do not support the EU’s attempts to get involved in Libya and expand their foreign policy role. We are also mindful of the situation of Libya’s impact on the current migration crisis. As such we abstained on the resolution as whole.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: written. - I voted against the Resolution on the situation in Libya, since it defends the military intervention of NATO in 2011 and considers that the bombings and the death of thousands of Libyans, the situation of chaos and destruction of the country, the risk of fracture and the progression of the misnamed Islamic State (IS) five years later, the destabilization of countries and the uncontrolled flow of weapons in the region were worth it. Not only does it not recognize Western responsibility in the conflict, but it seeks to add pressure for a rapid implementation of the Libyan Political Agreement that, far from prospering, has proposed a government that has already been rejected by the Tobruk Parliament. The EU intends to press for the rapid formation of a single puppet government that has international legitimacy and that can, on the one hand, admit that the Eunavfor Med Sophia operation of externalization of borders and obstacle to the arrival of refugees to the EU patrols in territorial waters Libyans and, on the other, even justify a new foreign military intervention in the country, this time under the pretext of fighting IS. This is why I have voted against.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: in writing. - As regards foreign policy, the reports of the European Parliament should be limited to giving a common European position on a given situation in the world without seeking to take the place of the Member States. In this case, it would have been useful, as our group did, to recall that the Western powers, Nicolas Sarkozy in the lead, are primarily responsible for the dramatic situation that this country is currently experiencing, the fall and death of Gaddafi having led to chaos, poverty, the explosion of migratory flows to Europe, and especially the civil war between the tribes and the various Islamist factions. It would have been good to invite the member states of the European Union to take real measures in order to fight illegal trafficking and to accept that Western democracy is not exported all over the world. People indeed have lifestyles and a genius of their own which it is not up to us to change through force, destruction and chaos. Therefore, I voted against the joint motion for a resolution.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on the final vote due to excessive calls for European Union action as opposed to action by the Member States. I do recognise the need for co-operation between nations on this issue, but the appropriate vehicle for this would be NATO.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: in writing.- It is crucial to stabilize the political situation in Libya.I voted in favor of this resolution because it is a prerequisite for any effective Union intervention aimed at stemming the flow of migrants who risk their lives crossing the sea to reach Europe and dealing with the activities ofterrorist groups in the region.Europe has destabilized this region by dismissing its leaders; it must therefore be a main actor in the lasting return of peace.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this proposal, which seeks to continue to provide assistance to Libya.I agree that in 2015December 17The UN-backed political agreement on Libya, signed in 2006, is an important step in supporting the building of a democratic and peaceful country.It is important to support the national unity government formed by the consensus of the Libyan parties as the only legitimate government in Libya.The security implications of the Libyan conflict remain one of its most pressing challenges in its immediate neighborhood, in particular Egypt and Tunisia, as well as in Algeria.The intensification of activities by extremist organizations and movements in Libya is also very worrying.These groups pose a major threat to the stability and security of the whole region in Europe.I support the calls for continued humanitarian, financial and political assistance to Libya.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted to abstain this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is supportive of the UN backed plan to return Libya to stable and democratic governance and hopes that all sides will fulfil their obligations under the agreement. However we do not support the EU's attempts to get involved in Libya and expand their foreign policy role. We are also mindful of the situation in Libya's impact on the current migration crisis. As such we abstained on the resolution as whole.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: in writing.- This text is only a pretext to confer more power on the European External Action Service (EEAS) and therefore entrust the foreign policy of the Member States to the unelected technocrats of the Commission.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing.- I supported this joint resolution which welcomes the Libyan political agreement signed on December 17, 2015 with the United Nations and which asks the House of Representatives to make compromises and to continue the debate with a view to the approval of thegovernment of national unity, in accordance with the Libyan political agreement.This responds to the desire to engage the country on the path of peace and stability and to defend all free citizens.The European Union, like the entire international community, must indeed spare no effort to put an end to the violence and stabilize the region.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. - The end of Colonel Gaddafi's regime did not represent the start of an agile path towards democracy for Libya. The prolongation of the civil war, the persistence of regional divisions with the contrast between Tripolitania and Cyrenaica, the presence of tribal ties and finally the affirmation of terrorist groups on Libyan territory, have constituted and still constitute important obstacles for the stabilization and initiation process. country security. The recent political agreement signed in December 2015 undoubtedly represented a fundamental turning point, laying the foundations for the start of the peace process. I supported and signed the resolution on the situation in Libya to reaffirm Europe's support for this difficult path undertaken by the two entities representing Libyan citizens. The appointment of a national unity government can represent a great opportunity to affirm democracy in the country and limit the risks of expansion of instability throughout the southern Mediterranean area. The EU must strongly support the agreements by guaranteeing all possible aid, particularly in the areas of humanitarian aid and the common security and defense policy.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: written.- The Libyan Parliament rejected the UN Resolution which sought to implement a stabilization plan in the area that included a unity government.The European Commission itself lamented in public statements an irresponsible attitude on the part of the Libyan representatives.We voted against, since, in our opinion, the resolution of the Libyan political conflict and the formation of a unity government should be sine qua non conditions prior to the adoption of any resolution or action by the EU.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: written.- I want to thank those who have worked on this Resolution on the situation in Libya for their work.I have supported this resolution condemning the destabilizing terrorist attacks perpetrated by Daesh against the Libyan population, including minorities and infrastructure.We must focus on rebuilding the country, for which collaboration between different institutions and agencies is essential.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing. - I rejected this resolution concerning the situation in Libya. Indeed, once again, European parliamentarians seem to be in amnesia concerning the origins of the destabilization of the Middle East; it is their offensive in Libya that has turned this part of the world into a powder keg. After having set the whole area on fire, the European Union dreams of being a firefighter, as we can see with the proposals in this resolution aimed at replacing the Member States with their powers in matters of diplomacy and defense. But the real project is not a "powerful Europe" but rather, as paragraph 11 of this resolution indicates, to become the armed wing of NATO, and therefore of American interests, despite all geopolitical realism. The deputies of all political stripes, Greens, republicans, socialists, agree to sell off the sovereignty of France and make the Union the little soldier accomplishing the dirty work of NATO, using the Libyan conflict to bring the recalcitrant states in the face of such diplomacy.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing.- While identifying the correct problems and challenges to address the Libyan situation, which places us in front of the spread of terrorism and an increasingly uncontrolled destabilization of the area, it identifies solutions that I do not agree with and that would not lead to improvements.This is why I expressed myself with an abstention.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: written.- I have abstained.The resolution contains several important proposals and positions.But it lacks a self-critical analysis of how the military intervention of the United States, NATO and several EU countries was carried out, as well as the lack of a plan for how democracy and a functioning state would be built in Libya after the events of 2011. Because such an analysisis missing and also supports NATO intervention, I choose to abstain.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: written. - Since NATO's military intervention and the overthrow of Muammar Gaddafi in 2011, various political parties, tribes and militias have been vying for power and control of the country's oil and gas fields. In December, an agreement was reached to form a government of national unity thanks to the mediation of the UN, the United States and Italy. The compromise was signed by members of both sides, but many continue to oppose the pact. Despite these timid advances, anarchy continues to have enormous costs and the number of people killed, kidnapped or imprisoned without due process continues to increase. Furthermore, Libya is a transit country for refugees and migrants from Africa and the Middle East; The uncontrolled trafficking of arms and combatants through the Sahel is also worrisome. Faced with this situation of chaos, this Resolution firmly condemns the recent terrorist attacks perpetrated in Zliten and urges the Presidential Council to form a Government of national unity as soon as possible, since it is the only way for Libya to return to the path of peace. stability and prosperity. That is why I have voted in favor of this Resolution.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this resolution because it assessed Parliament's situation in Libya. In Libya, after the overthrow of Gaddafi's dictatorship, political emptiness and the absence of a stable government have been exploited by Daesh, which includes foreigners and Libyan terrorists returning to the country after the fighting in Iraq and Syria. In Libya, Daesh's forces have become the largest outside the Middle East, and the country is the group's main force on the southern shores of the Mediterranean, posing a serious threat to neighboring countries in the Sahel and Sahara, as well as to Europe, due to terrorist acts. Parliament deplored the rejection by the House of Representatives in Tobruk of the first proposal for a united government and called on the two main Libyan authorities to support the proposal, which is an important step in implementing the Libyan political agreement and moving towards peace and stability in the country and protecting all Libyan citizens. Parliament therefore warned of recognizing and supporting the Libyan party's consensus-building national unity government as the only legitimate Libyan government, stressing the need for Libya to govern the political process itself and the importance of continuing to ensure that it is inclusive and constructive. including tribal councils, the positive participation of women and civil society, the contribution of political and local actors to the timely amendment and adoption of a constitution that enshrines democracy, human rights and civil liberties.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: in writing. - After the failed attempt to form a government of national unity in Libya, which would at least seemingly stabilize the country, Libya is again in a practically hopeless situation. Sectarian conflicts, anarchy and the threat to the Islamic State are sending many of the people of this country on a deadly journey through the Mediterranean towards Europe. The situation we are witnessing today also shows the recklessness of European foreign policy or. its individual countries in the past. After the fall of the Gaddafi regime, which I do not apologize for in any way, the country has only gone downhill. After five years, we have such a situation, which poses a major security threat to Europe. Libya was a successful country, it did business with many western countries, and during the former Yugoslavia, a lot of Slovenes went to work there. Unfortunately, today Libya is only a shadow of what it was. Our task is to do everything in our power to help Libyans and Libyans to establish such a government that will succeed in establishing peace in the country and effectively fighting Islamic extremists. Otherwise, not only Libyans and Libyans will suffer, but also Europeans.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: written.- I support this statement which welcomes the signing of the Libyan political agreement for the formation of a national government.Reforms, consolidating the rule of law, fighting terrorism, improving the human rights situation and the phenomenon of migration, fighting human traffickers are just some of the great challenges that await Libya in the future, so this is a moment when a big step forward has been made in the fight for a better future.of this country.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this document because I believe that the current situation in Libya represents a great factor of instability for the whole Mediterranean, Maghreb and Mashreq region and, consequently, for Europe.Therefore, I am convinced that the European Union must work to try to support the Libyan people and to find a solution that brings peace to the country.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: in writing. - This motion for a resolution correctly describes the current dramatic situation in Libya, where heavily armed militias as well as Islamic State cells have seized power since the fall of the Gaddafi regime. The current political instability has reinforced criminal, terrorist and Islamist networks, which pose an indisputable threat to ethnic and religious minorities. I would also like to recall that the presence and growing influence of Islamic fundamentalists in Libya constitutes a serious danger for women, whose freedoms have been considerably restricted. However, I regret that at no time is the heavy responsibility of the European Union and some of its member states mentioned in the text for the fall from power of Gaddafi, which led to the arrival of the Islamists in Libya. Like a good pyromaniac firefighter, the European Union now wants to make up for its mistakes. However, we consider that it is preferable that it abstains from any diplomatic intervention in view of its results in terms of foreign policy. Only cooperation between the various powers in the region and the United Nations will make it possible to put an end to the Libyan chaos and definitively eradicate Islamist fundamentalism. I therefore voted against this text.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: signed up. - The situation in Libya is marked by strong internal conflicts, instability and political dissension. This situation has been perceived favorably by various extremist forces, which threaten peace and security throughout the region. One of the most visible terrorist groups is Daesh, which has launched major offensives on Libya's extremely important oil facilities. Moreover, the human rights situation continues to deteriorate across the country, including cases of arbitrary detention, abduction, extrajudicial executions, acts of torture and violence against journalists, officials, political figures and human rights defenders. At the same time, multiple cases have been reported in which smugglers have exploited refugees trying to reach Europe. The European Union is deeply concerned about the growing presence of extremist organizations and movements in Libya. These groups pose a major threat to the stability and security of the entire region and also to the security of Europe. Thus, the EU needs to continue to provide humanitarian, financial and political support in order to make it possible to resolve the humanitarian crisis in Libya and to respond adequately to the suffering of people and refugees, as well as civilians facing disruption of access to basic services. for which I spoke in favor of this motion for a resolution.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. - I abstained on this resolution because it correctly considers the problems and challenges that the situation in Libya places before us, but identifies wrong solutions. The imposition of a government not shared by the parties but supported by external international actors poses major democratic problems. The threat to impose sanctions on local authorities and personalities who do not accept such a government is the opposite of the democratic confrontation (the Tripoli faction belongs to the Islamic Brotherhood and has imposed by force and with the use of barbaric religious extremism the own control over the population of that part of the territory). The goal is clear: the usual globalist and financial circles want to get their hands on Libya's resources by bypassing the Libyan people. In Libya there is a problem, the European Parliament has also noticed it, but we have other solutions, such as military collaboration with the Libyan army recognized in stemming the advance of ISIS, targeted bombing of the areas occupied by terrorists, the joint patrolling of the coasts and the implementation of a transitional government that really stops the clandestine invasion of Europe and that truly respects the will of the Libyan people and not the ambitions of the international economic powers.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution on the situation in Libya. The resolution underlined the importance of signing the Libyan political agreement on the formation of a Government of National Accord (GIN) as Libya's only legitimate government, an event that represents a unique opportunity for a democratic civil state through a national consensus. . Only in this way can Libya begin to recover from an unsustainable situation and remedy the suffering of its population. The House of Representatives and its presidency continue in this direction and commit themselves to the support of the government of national agreement. Once the agreement is consolidated, there will be opportunities to consolidate the rule of law, fight terrorism more vigorously, improve the human rights situation and tackle the phenomenon of migration in a determined way. To facilitate the establishment of the new government of national understanding, the European Union and its Member States must continue to work with the Libyan authorities and develop a coordinated package of measures to support them. The resolution highlighted these elements and I therefore decided to vote in its favor.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted to abstain this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is supportive of the UN backed plan to return Libya to stable and democratic governance and hopes that all sides will fulfil their obligations under the agreement. However we do not support the EU's attempts to get involved in Libya and expand their foreign policy role. We are also mindful of the situation in Libya's impact on the current migration crisis. As such we abstained on the resolution as whole.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution as I am deeply concerned about the current situation in Libya. The lack of a stable government and the wider political circumstances are of a significant advantage to Daesh and other similar groupings, and all of this contributes to the deteriorating human rights situation. I welcome the UN-backed Libyan Political Agreement signed in December 2015 and I hope it will be successfully implemented, as it should result in greater political stability. I believe that economic recovery plays a significant part in greater political stability. I also hope that the wider international community will actively support Libya in state- and institution-building.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. - The economic breakdown and violence in Libya are allowing extremist organizations to flourish, not to mention that the ongoing conflicts on Libyan soil are also destabilizing the Sahel region. With this report, on which I voted in favor, the European Parliament calls on the EU and the international community to continue to provide humanitarian, financial and political assistance to address the difficulties of internally displaced persons and refugees and those of civilians facing the '' interruption of access to basic services. The European Parliament also supports the newly formed Government of National Accord and the national institutions that must guide Libya towards a post-revolutionary transition, bringing it back on the path of building a democratic, peaceful, stable and prosperous country. This is the priority objective, bombing and deploying our armies would only end up making Islamic militias coalescing around the Daesh catalyst and we cannot allow the catastrophe of a senseless emergency war to strike us again.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing. - We support the joint motion for a resolution on the situation in Libya and express our serious concern about the fate of migrants, asylum seekers and refugees in Libya. We call on the EU and the Member States to take steps to deal effectively with the growing migration and refugee flows from North Africa, and in particular from Libya. At the same time, we call on the Commission and the European External Action Service to focus their support on state-building and institutions and, together with the Member States, the UN, NATO and the regional partners, to contribute to security sector reform. and the creation, under the control of the Government of National Unity, of an effective national army and police force capable of securing control over the entire territory and territorial waters of Libya.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the resolution because I believe that economic recovery is an essential stage for a democratic transition in Libya and in any case for its political stabilization, objectives which today seem far from being achieved.Positioning itself as the main actor in the Mediterranean basin, the Union should therefore make itself available to offer immediate support, in the sectors that will be considered priorities, in agreement with the new Libyan government of national agreement, once it is established.If this does not happen in the times that Europe and the world wish, the serious and already unsustainable situation of migrants, asylum seekers and refugees in Libya will inevitably continue to worsen.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing.- I am very concerned about the situation in Libya.All the more so for how relations with our country have evolved in the recent days of Gaddafi.We have a special bond with them and this charges us with responsibility, while I must admit that in the past, perhaps some light mistake was made and now we are paying the consequences.I appreciated the tone and intent of this resolution, to which I voted in favor, because I believe that Libya is one of the nodes to be overcome to stabilize the area, fight the advance of the Islamic State, and solve the problem of migrants.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted to abstain this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is supportive of the UN backed plan to return Libya to stable and democratic governance and hopes that all sides will fulfil their obligations under the agreement. However we do not support the EU's attempts to get involved in Libya and expand their foreign policy role. We are also mindful of the situation in Libya's impact on the current migration crisis. As such we abstained on the resolution as whole.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. - The Arab Spring, which crossed a large part of the north of the African continent, determined the end of decades-long dictatorial regimes. Libya was yet another example of these breaks with the past. However, almost five years after Gaddafi's assassination, the country is still grappling with war, hunger and torture and with a state far from consolidated. It will certainly not be possible in the immediate future to stabilize this country and consolidate the regime transition. The consequences for its citizens and for the region, including the European Union, are vast. Its territory has become a mantle of internally displaced persons, who seek refuge in other territories; in a haven for terrorist organizations like Daesh and al-Qaeda; in a hub for trafficking in people and weapons. For peace and prosperity to be possible in Libya, it is therefore crucial to make efforts at the international level, starting with the legitimation of democratically elected bodies. On the other hand, it is necessary that the various internal tribal alliances are able to resolve their differences. The Union and the Member States, in particular, can only be asked for full commitment. If for no other reason, because the source of the refugee crisis is also attacked.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution concerning the situation in Libya as I believe it is necessary to increase the level of cooperation with all EU and UN missions present in that territory in order to achieve greater stability in that country.Libya is currently in difficulty not only due to internal political rivalries but also due to the infiltration of Daesh into the territory, which is arousing considerable concern.Libya is located a few miles from Italy and therefore also to increase security in our country it is important to give all possible support to the operations currently underway and to consider new strategies to achieve effective results in the shortest possible time in order to avoidrepercussions in Europe.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ This motion for a resolution recognises the challenges that the breakdown of governance in Libya poses to other States. It welcomes the UN-backed Libyan Political Agreement signed in December 2015, but identifies areas of concern. These include the growing presence of Daesh in Libya which continues to destabilise the country and threaten neighbouring countries as well as the porosity of Libya’s borders due to a lack of central political control. Both these circumstances greatly affect the European Union and its citizens as it threatens to bring terror to European territory and facilitates the proliferation of weapons and the movement of armed groups. The resolution also encourages the Commission and the European External Action Service to focus their efforts on supporting State building and institution building in Libya and to cooperate with UN in these efforts. I have thus voted in favour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: written. - I voted against the Resolution on the situation in Libya, since it defends the military intervention of NATO in 2011 and considers that the bombings and the death of thousands of Libyans, the situation of chaos and destruction of the country, the risk of fracture and the progression of the misnamed Islamic State (IS) five years later, the destabilization of countries and the uncontrolled flow of weapons in the region were worth it. Not only does it not recognize Western responsibility in the conflict, but it seeks to add pressure for a rapid implementation of the Libyan Political Agreement that, far from prospering, has proposed a government that has already been rejected by the Tobruk Parliament. The EU intends to press for the rapid formation of a single puppet government that has international legitimacy and that can, on the one hand, admit that the Eunavfor Med Sophia operation of externalization of borders and obstacle to the arrival of refugees to the EU patrols in territorial waters Libyans and, on the other, even justify a new foreign military intervention in the country, this time under the pretext of fighting IS. This is why I have voted against.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: signed up. - Human rights and the humanitarian situation in Libya have deteriorated amid escalating violence and the presence of an increasingly volatile political environment. Libya is home to hundreds of thousands of refugees and asylum seekers of various nationalities, many of whom live in precarious conditions, becoming a transit point for human trafficking, which has killed thousands of people trying to cross the Mediterranean to to get to Europe. It is important that the Libyan Political Agreement be implemented in good faith, with sustained political will and inclusion. Its implementation will provide the necessary tools to address the urgent challenges of reforming and building state institutions, strengthening the rule of law, combating terrorism, improving the human rights situation, combating trafficking in human beings and stimulating economic growth. I strongly support the intensification of humanitarian funding at European and international level to meet the most urgent needs of those severely affected by the Libyan conflict, as well as the need to provide funding to humanitarian organizations for a better assessment of the situation and improvement. interventions to the needs on the ground.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: in writing. - The European Parliament's motion for a resolution adopted today welcomes the UN-sponsored political agreement in Libya on 17 December 2015, which is a key step in the implementation of the Libyan political agreement. A secure and politically stable Libya is essential not only for the Libyan people but also for the security of the whole region and the European Union. The motion condemns the destabilizing terrorist attacks on the Libyan people by Daesh, including the minorities and the oil facilities in Alsraida and Ras Lanuf, and all attempts to disrupt the stabilization process. He believes that the Union must use its diplomatic and foreign policy instruments in the framework of the common security and defense policy and seek to stabilize the region. Since anarchy raged in Libya, the country has become an even more transit zone for human trafficking to Europe’s southern borders. It therefore calls on the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees to play a stronger role in coordinating UN efforts and calls on the EU and its Member States to address effectively the sudden surge of migration and refugee flows from North Africa, especially Libya.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing. - The change of the system after the fall of the regime in 2011 is marked by the collapse of the rule of law and widespread violence. The power vacuum and instability that were created meant that many different military units took over the power over various parts of the territory, and in Tripoli and Tobruk two opposing governments and separate parliaments were created, with the international community recognizing only the government in Tobruk. In recent months, international efforts to end violence and political deadlock have been intensified, including the signing of the Libyan Political Agreement on December 17, 2015, which opens the way to the establishment of the institution of the Presidential Council. The international community hopes that the appointment of a new government will stabilize the situation in the country and allow it to deal with the growing threat posed by ISIS ISIS (Da'esh), which is trying to fill the power vacuum that has arisen. In addition, Libya has become the country with the most migrants to travel across the Mediterranean to EU countries, and at the same time ISIS (Da'esh) has gained another foothold for its organization by taking advantage of rampant violence and political turmoil - which endangers security in the region on an increasingly large scale. Bearing in mind the internal situation in Libya and the threats resulting from the destabilization of the country in terms of Libyan citizens, I supported the resolution.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The situation in Libya has continued to worsen over the past months. I believe that the issue had to be addressed earlier if all Libyan parties reached a compromise. I still believe in a deal for the Libyans by the Libyans, as I have always emphasised. My biggest concern is that if sanctions are set at this point in time, the matter could again get out of control, due to a negative counter-reaction from the Libyans. It is a fact that the Daesh presence in Libya makes it a matter of urgency for efforts against it to take off as soon as possible. However, this cannot be done if there is no genuine agreement among the Libyan parties that can hold. More efforts are needed to bring all the disparate forces on board. For these reasons I abstained on this resolution.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. - I support the Resolution on the situation in Libya which expresses grave concern over the decision of the Tobruk Parliament to reject the composition of the government of national agreement proposed by Prime Minister Al-Sarraj. An unexpected step back from the Marrakech agreements, signed under the aegis of the United Nations, which once again risks precipitating the situation within the complex and fragmented Libyan mosaic. In this delicate moment, the European Union and its representatives will have to continue to work with constancy and determination to accompany Libya towards a political transition, with the aim of creating a new lasting institutional order. The commitment of the European institutions will have to focus on assisting towards a reform of the justice system and the security sector, including the creation of a police and military force capable of ensuring control of the territory. The Libyan people urgently need a unitary government and stable institutions capable of facing the delicate challenges that have been destabilizing the whole country for several years: first and foremost the spread of Da'esh and numerous extremist movements. A finally safer and more democratic Libya will be one of the decisive building blocks for the security of the entire Mediterranean and Middle Eastern chessboard.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: in writing.- This motion for a resolution reacts to the recent constitution of a government of national unity in Libya, at a time when the country is facing political instability unprecedented since the fall of the Gaddafi regime.In a country still marked by many regional and local conflicts, the deputies welcome the new government of unity recognized by the UN.It is an essential step in the implementation of Libya's political agreement and towards the post-revolution transition to build a democratic, stable and prosperous country.Supporting these goals, I voted in favor of the resolution.

name: Rachida DATI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution on the situation in Libya, where chaos has followed chaos.A hub for terrorism and arms trafficking over which the Islamic State group is trying to extend its influence, Libya finds itself in a particularly serious and worrying situation.The European Union must continue to encourage it in its stabilization process with a political solution.Member States must engage alongside the European Union to support the democratic transition in Libya.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing.- I welcomed the Libyan political agreement reached last December 17 which provided for the birth of a government of national agreement with the task of guiding Libya towards the construction of a democratic, peaceful and stable state.The continuous and growing presence of extremist organizations and movements in Libya is however extremely worrying, not only for the stability of the country but also for the repercussions that the civil war is causing on the security of neighboring states.That is why I have decided to vote in favor of this motion for a resolution which calls on the international community to continue providing humanitarian, financial and political assistance to address the dangerous situation in Libya.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing.- This text formulates a lucid observation of the chaotic situation in Libya.Unfortunately, it takes advantage of this to unjustifiably lend an international role to the European Union, at the risk of practicing illegitimate interference, or of taking an unacceptable substitute for the foreign policy of the Member States.Being attached to the defense of the sovereign powers that remain in the States, I voted against this text.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: In written form. - We are discussing the situation in Libya. There is no situation in Libya, simply because there is no longer Libya. This country, which was a friend of all Western democracies, no longer exists. On the territory of former Libya, today we have a war, a war between various tribal alliances supporting one or another terrorist organization and / or those who are fighting against them. And here we must say in plain text who is to blame for this. We must now deal with these consequences, but we must also learn the lessons and help this country work again. And this goes through the suspension of Daesh and its aides like Turkey. I hope this will happen, which is why I supported this resolution.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: in writing.- We are voting against the Motion for a Resolution, the Union and many of the Member States, after first destroying Libya to serve their own interests, today appear ready to launch another military intervention, which will plunge the country into greater chaos.We therefore strongly disagree with the Union's approach.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
