text: in writing. - Libya's situation remains unstable and, since August 2014, two political bodies (the CoR in Tobruk, recognized by the international community, and the new CGN, which imposed itself in Tripoli) are claiming the direction of the country, both supported by various militias heavily armed, linked to regions, cities and tribes, with different backgrounds. The political vacuum and the absence of a stable government have been exploited by Daesh, whose ranks include returning foreign and Libyan terrorists, after fighting in Iraq and Syria and have been conducting major offensives against major oil installations in Libya, with the aim of increasing its war treasury and controlling the huge oil installations. For this reason, I condemn Daesh's destabilizing terrorist attacks against the Libyan people, including minorities, as well as against oil infrastructure and any attempt to disrupt the country's stabilization process.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - This resolution shamelessly omits the EU's responsibilities in military aggression, which was legitimized by this Parliament in 2011, and the very serious problems of political and economic instability that are plaguing the region and which resulted from foreign intervention by NATO, the USA and the EU . A war of imperialist aggression that created a huge tragedy for the civilian population, with thousands of deaths and the destruction of this country's social and economic infrastructure. It also omits the responsibilities of the great powers in spreading terrorist groups in the region, namely through the continued sale and export of arms. We are facing an imperialist offensive against the Arab world that enshrines the neo-colonialist stance of the West in relation to North Africa and the Middle East, motivated by geostrategic control and exploitation of the immense wealth of the region, namely its oil reserves. Finally, the resolution opens doors and legitimizes the possibility of a new external military intervention in Libya, which everything seems to be in preparation. We reaffirm the right of the Libyan people to decide on their destiny, their right to sovereignty and peace, free from outside interference. We voted against.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the resolution as a whole.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing - Islamic State militias have used the civil war and the power vacuum to expand their presence in the country, increasingly committing terrorist acts and brutally abusing the local population. In early January 2016, these groups launched an offensive against large oil facilities on the Middle East coast and carried out the most tragic terrorist attack in Libya since 2011, killing dozens of new Zlitene police officers. I welcome the signing of the Libyan political agreement to form a national agreement government as the only legitimate government, as the most effective response to the presence of radical militants in Libya is ultimately the creation of inclusive domestic institutions capable of the rule of law, public services and local security and combat effectively. against groups that threaten the stability of the country and the wider region. This government must work for reforms in the country to meet the challenges of terrorists and militias.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing.- I abstain because, despite the correct issues regarding Libya, the resolution proposes different actions with respect to our positions.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing.- I am voting against the motion for a resolution, since the Union and many of the Member States, having first destroyed Libya to serve their own interests, today appear ready to launch another military intervention, which will plunge the country into greater chaos..I therefore strongly disagree with the Union 's approach.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I believe we must support the Government of National Accord and fully back the mediation efforts of the Special Representative of the UNSG aimed at facilitating a Libyan-led political solution in finding a negotiated settlement to resolve the crisis and to ensure unity, governability, stability and peace. I therefore welcome the signature of the Libyan Political Agreement (LPA) to form a Government of National Accord (GNA), as the sole legitimate government of Libya. I invite the House of Representatives and its Presidency to show a spirit of compromise and convene and discuss proposed cabinet with a view of an endorsement of the Government of National Accord. It is crucial the Libyan Political Agreement be implemented with inclusiveness; This will provide the necessary tool to address the urgent challenges of reforming and building state institutions, consolidating the rule of law, fighting terrorism, improving the human rights situation and the phenomenon of migrations, combating human smugglers as well as of stimulating economic growth.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: written.- I voted in favor bearing in mind that, after the fall of the dictator Gaddafi, a political vacuum was created without a stable government, a fact that has been taken advantage of by Daesh, which exercises full control in an area of more than 200 km around Sirteand which also has a training base west of Tripoli.There is no doubt that the Libyan Political Agreement aims to guarantee democratic rights, establish a consensus government based on the principle of separation of powers and empower state institutions.We must support the Government of National Consensus formed by consensus among the Libyan parties as the only legitimate Government in the country and contribute as much as possible to the stabilization of the country.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing.- I welcome the Libyan political agreement signed on 17 December 2015 which supports the newly formed Government of National Accord and the national institutions that must guide Libya towards a post-revolutionary transition, bringing it back on the path of building a peaceful country, stable.It is time for the international community to realize the mistakes of the past and to support the efforts of the Libyans in the peace and stabilization process.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. - I supported the joint resolution on the situation in Libya with great conviction, because I believe that the political agreement, signed last December by the representatives of the Tripoli and Tobruk parliaments, represents a fundamental starting point for the stabilization of Libya. After years of civil war, the Government of National Unity, which is being formed in recent weeks, urgently needs support from the international community and, in particular, from the EU, because it truly constitutes the only hope for a stable peace. and the only way out towards the democratic transition in the country. ISIS continues to gain positions in the field and it is at this time the news that thousands of foreign fighters are flocking to the city of Sirte. It is therefore an urgent threat, also for the security of Europe itself, and it is for this reason that we must hope that the government will be installed quickly and that the EU will give it all the necessary support. Certainly the country's reconstruction process will be long and not without difficulties: the restoration of state structures, the consolidation of the rule of law, the improvement of the situation on human rights and the phenomenon of migration are all ambitious and far-reaching challenges.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: written.- I voted for the resolution on the situation in Libya because I consider further stabilization and pacification of the North African area to be absolutely necessary and I welcome the declared support from the EU.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: written.- The situation in Libya is extremely worrying.I am particularly concerned about the current power vacuum and the significant deterioration in the human rights situation.Libya is also one of the largest host countries for refugees and is therefore particularly burdened.Against this background, it is up to the EU to provide Libya with sufficient support.Here one has to work closely with other organizations.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution urging all stakeholders in Libya, the region and the international community to move the Libyan political transition forward. We cannot afford any further delay in implementing the Libyan Political Agreement and establishing a Government of National Accord. There is an urgent need to start reforming and building state institutions, consolidating the rule of law, improving the human rights situation and tackling human trafficking. It is deeply concerning that Libya has become home to the largest Daesh forces outside of the Middle East and forms a Daesh bridgehead on the Mediterranean south coast, posing a major threat to neighbouring countries in the Sahel and Sahara, as well as to Europe. We will not be able to tackle this unless a stable, inclusive government is put into place that receives full support from the international community and upholds high standards on human rights.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: written.- The Libyan Parliament rejected the UN Resolution which sought to implement a stabilization plan in the area that included a unity government.The European Commission itself lamented in public statements an irresponsible attitude on the part of the Libyan representatives.We voted against, since, in our opinion, the resolution of the Libyan political conflict and the formation of a unity government should be sine qua non conditions prior to the adoption of any resolution or action by the EU.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution. Time is running out to stabilise Libya. The security, humanitarian and economic situation has become dreadful. ISIS is rapidly seizing territory and now has access to significant oil reserves. Although not perfect, the Agreement on unity government must be upheld, so that Libya’s situation does not become hopeless. The EU should continue providing the necessary humanitarian and development assistance.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour to the motion on situation in Libya. The Parliament welcomes the UN-backed Libyan Political Agreement signed on 17 December 2015. There is important, however that all parties in Libya must commit to the protection of civilians at all times, and they should be treated in accordance with international human rights and humanitarian law. The motion stressed that the attacks intentionally directed against personnel involved in humanitarian assistance or a peacekeeping mission in accordance with the UN Charter are under the protection of the Rome Statute of the ICC.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE / NGL), in writing. - The situation in Libya is a result of the intervention of the USA and its allies in the name of the so-called Arab Spring. As we have all seen, no Spring has taken place, on the contrary, the country is being pushed more and more into chaos. At the same time that the presence of IS in the country is a matter of deep concern and terrorist attacks and violence are a daily occurrence, reports indicate further military intervention by the United States, France, Great Britain and Italy. We insist that the only way is to continue the dialogue between all parties to find a solution that will ensure Libya's territorial integrity and independence. Unfortunately, in the joint resolution put to the vote, these important issues were absent, while on the contrary, among other things, the role of NATO in 2011 is praised. For these reasons, we believe that the appropriate position was to vote against the motion for a resolution.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the resolution on the situation in Libya. Stabilising Libya is crucially important not just for its people but in the wider context of the refugee/migrant crisis. With the dispute between the House of Representatives and the new General National Congress continuing the atmosphere of political instability, Daesh have taken advantage of this power vacuum. Libya has become home to the largest Daesh forces outside of the Middle East, which poses a significant threat to European security. While expanding its territory Daesh has launched a local campaign of terror – with beheadings, shootings and bombings. The human rights situation has deteriorated, with Libya a transit ground for human and weapons trafficking. It is essential that stability is brought to Libya and the wider region to stem the flow of desperate refugees and migrants risking their lives with smugglers and that we unite to fight Daesh. Regrettably the UN-backed unity government proposal was rejected by the HoR. However, they have signed the Libyan Political Agreement, the key aim of which is to establish a consensual government. The EU has made available a EUR 100 million package and is ready to offer immediate support to the new Libyan Government of National Accord once formed.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support the Commission and EEAS – as coordinators of Member States in Libya – to focus on state-building and institution-building. Furthermore, Progress in terms economy is central to a Libyan democratic transition. However, the proxy war and the presence of Daesh in the region have slowed down considerably both the progress made by the economy and a clean transition to democracy.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written.- I voted in favor of the joint motion for a resolution in accordance with the Rules of Procedure and Rule 123 on the situation in Libya, because this motion fulfills the desire to bring peace and stability to the country and to protect all Libyan citizens.Libya had the largest arsenal on the southern shores of the Mediterranean, which became the main source of illicit arms trafficking, and a supply zone for all terrorists and extremists in the Sahel (Mali, Niger, Nigeria) and opposition movements in Sudan, Chad and Syria.This proposal is a key step in implementing the Libyan political agreement, so I support calling on the international community, the UN, the EU, the AU and the Arab League member states to be ready to support Libyans in their efforts to implement the agreement successfully, while respecting democracy, human rights and civil liberties.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: in writing. - When it comes to foreign policy, European Parliament reports should be limited to giving a common European position on a particular situation in the world without getting involved in the foreign policy of states. In this case, it would have been good, as our group has done, to recall that the Western powers, particularly France when it was led by Nicolas Sarkozy, are primarily responsible for the dramatic situation that this country is currently experiencing. , the fall and the death of Gaddafi having caused chaos, poverty, the explosion of migratory flows towards Europe, and especially the civil war between the tribes and the various Islamist factions. It would have been good to invite the Member States of the European Union to take real steps to combat human trafficking and to accept that Western democracy is not exported all over the world. People indeed have lifestyles and a genius of their own which it is not up to us to change through force, destruction and chaos. Therefore, I voted against the joint motion for a resolution.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – My UKIP colleagues and myself voted to abstain this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is supportive of the UN backed plan to return Libya to stable and democratic governance and hopes that all sides will fulfil their obligations under the agreement. However we do not support the EU's attempts to get involved in Libya and expand their foreign policy role. We are also mindful of the situation in Libya's impact on the current migration crisis. As such I abstained on the resolution as whole.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. – I voted in favour and even co-signed the resolution on the situation in Libya. I believe this text is a strong call for the stabilisation of Libya, which is urgently needed, both for the Libyans and the international community. This stabilisation process must pass by the instauration of a solid, inclusive and legitimate governance in the country. Only a credible government can effectively improve the living conditions of the population and combat the terrorist groups profiting from the current no-man’s-land in the area. If the EU wants to effectively stem the flow of migrants who risk their lives to reach our continent, it must take a more active role in the region – together with the UN and other international actors, it must bring an end to the current conflict.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution concerning the situation in Libya.Indeed, this country, at the gates of Europe, sees the installation day after day of Islamist militias which threaten our continent in a context of civil war.The European Union therefore needs to get involved and act in a coordinated manner to push for the creation of a government of national unity and to provide humanitarian aid to the local population.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written.- I am abstaining on this resolution.Although it offers some good approaches to stabilizing the situation in Libya, it avoids naming the real causes of the dissolution of Libya, which in my view creates an overall opaque and flawed look.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution. Time is running out to stabilize Libya. The security, humanitarian and economic situation has become dreadful. ISIS is rapidly seizing territory and has now access to significant oil reserves. Although not perfect, the Agreement on unity government must be upheld, so that Libya’s situation does not become hopeless. The EU should continue providing the necessary humanitarian and development assistance.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ The situation in Libya is disturbing. Just across the Mediterranean Sea, anarchy, chaos and violence are spreading. Nowadays in Libya there is an ongoing civil war, an enormous migration crisis and the presence of a brutal terrorist organisation, Daesh. Because of growing instability oil-rich Libya can be considered a failed state. There is no doubt that in this complicated situation the EU should act quickly in order to avoid the spread of instability and terror in the region and beyond. We should bear in mind that this neighbouring failed state represents a real threat to the EU’s security and stability. Therefore, the EU should urge Libya’s rival politicians to accept the creation of an UN-backed unity cabinet. A united Libyan cabinet will have a significant chance to restore stability and peace in a war-torn country. In case that unity cabinet is formed, the EU has to provide extensive development assistance and aid in order to support the future institution-building process in the country.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: in writing.- I voted against the joint resolution on the situation in Libya.Not only does this text intend to use the Libyan problem to put the foreign policy of the member states in a straight line, it does not mention any solution to the problem of illegal immigration to Europe.This is why the ENL group tabled an amendment to stress the importance of concluding readmission agreements with Libya as soon as possible.Libya is one of the most important transit countries for illegal immigration.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: in writing.- I voted against this resolution because the Union exploits the Libyan problem in it to interfere in the foreign policy of the Member States.

name: Petr MACH
text: in writing.- The complicated situation in Libya is largely due to the intervention of the EU states against the regime of Muammar Gaddafi.It is not appropriate to adopt a meaningless resolution.I abstained during the vote.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written.- The human rights situation in Libya is deteriorating, with cases of arbitrary detention, kidnapping, unlawful killings, torture and violence against civilians, journalists, officials, politicians and human rights activists for which all parties are responsible almost daily.Since anarchy reigned in Libya, it has become a transit area for human trafficking to the southern border of Europe.There are hundreds of thousands of migrants and asylum seekers of various nationalities in the country, many of whom live in tragic conditions and thus represent a target group for smugglers.It is important that the international community double its funding for humanitarian assistance to meet the urgent needs of those most affected by the conflict in Libya, which is particularly encouraged and supported by this resolution.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing - The absence of a stable government is contributing to the confusing situation in Libya, which allows terrorist groups and organizations to operate on its territory.The EP has made it clear that it will recognize and support the government of national unity formed by consensus between the Libyan parties as the only legitimate government of Libya.The Commission, the European External Action Service, which coordinates the action of the Member States in Libya in cooperation with the UN and regional partners, must focus its assistance and support on that country on state and institution-building so that legitimate government gains control of the territory andgradually normalized the country.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing.- I am voting against the Joint Motion for a Resolution on the situation in Libya, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the Plenary Session of the European Parliament on 3/2/2016 and because this Joint Motion for a Resolution is not complete and substantiated.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this resolution, which ‘Regrets the on-going proxy war between foreign Sunni parties; calls on regional players to refrain from actions which might exacerbate divisions and undermine the transition to a stable, inclusive and democratic Libya, and which might destabilise neighbouring countries; upholds its strong commitment to Libya’s sovereignty, territorial integrity, national unity and democratic transition’.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: in writing.- I voted against this resolution because it continues to insist on a solution for Libya that undergoes military intervention, under NATO's mandate, together with the UN, the Member States and regional partners, with the aim not only of strengthening securityof the country, but also to control the entire border territory and waters of Libya, namely migratory flows, refugees and asylum seekers, in a context in which the EU has enormous responsibilities under the current situation in which the country finds itself.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: written.- The situation in Libya, where there is a difficult economic situation and intense violence, forces the EU and the international community to support this country so that it can move forward.I support the Resolution approved in this Parliament, in which we show our satisfaction with the political agreement signed in December 2015. Hopefully the Government in this country will be able to tackle the problems it is currently experiencing and be able to take measures that lead tothe construction of a democratic, peaceful, stable and prosperous country.

name: Georg MAYER
text: written.- Resolution offers some good approaches, but avoids naming the real authors of the dissolution of Libya and simply does not go far enough.Overall a half-hearted approach.Therefore I abstain from voting.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the European Parliament resolution assessing the situation in Libya. Following the overthrow of Gaddafi's dictatorship, the terrorist group Daesh has emerged in this country, posing a serious threat not only to the country's population but also to neighboring countries and to Europe. In the resolution, the European Parliament calls on the Libyan political forces to unite, to form a government based on legal principles that will ensure peace and stability in the country and protect all its citizens. In a resolution, the European Parliament called on the Commission to focus on building Libyan state institutions and working with Member States, the UN, NATO and regional partners to reform the security sector, create an effective national army and police force controlled by the government of national unity and protect its borders. The resolution emphasizes that the EU should also give priority to supporting the reform of the Libyan justice system, as well as other areas that are crucial for democratic governance. I believe that the EU's contribution is important in ensuring political stability in Libya and other countries in the region, as it is one way of managing the flow of refugees and migrants to the EU.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: in writing.- Since the fall of Gaddafi, Libya has become the center of Daesh's main forces outside the Middle East and constitutes for Daesh a bridgehead on the southern shore of the Mediterranean.The resolution denounces the terrorist attacks and is concerned about the situation for the civilian population.In all hypocrisy, she "invites the European Union and its Member States to face the spiraling flow of migrants and refugees from North Africa, and in particular from Libya" even as it erects walls for its own sake.'protect it.Finally, the resolution advocates collaboration with NATO, which is nevertheless a factor of destabilization in the region.I vote against.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: in writing.- When it comes to foreign policy, European Parliament reports should be limited to giving a common European position on a particular situation in the world, without getting involved in the foreign policy of states.In this case, it would have been good, as our group did, to recall that the Western powers, particularly France when it was ruled by Nicolas Sarkozy, are primarily responsible for the dramatic situation that this country is currently experiencing..It would have made sense to call on the Member States of the European Union to take real action to fight illegal trafficking and to accept that Western democracy is not exported all over the world.People have indeed a culture and a genius of their own that it is not up to us to change by force, and by inconsistent offensives.I therefore voted against the joint motion for a resolution.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the resolution on the situation in Libya.After the fall of Colonel Muammar Gaddafi's dictatorial regime, Libya has been experiencing moments of great tension and instability.The political vacuum and the lack of a stable government have been exploited by Daesh and other extremist forces, which threaten peace and security across the region, as well as in Europe.The EU must pay particular attention to developments in developments in Libya, reinforcing the necessary support for the country in the fight against terrorism.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I signed and supported this cross party resolution on the situation in Libya that expresses the Parliament's commitment to supporting the Libyan people during a time of serious crisis. An important point that the resolution makes is that of Libyan ownership of the political process which must be promoted at every stage and at every level.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: written. - After the unrest in Tunisia in 2010, the Arab Spring blew over to Libya, followed by a 9-month civil conflict. Since then the country has been in a complete state of decomposition. Terrorist organizations such as Da'esh, Ansar-al-Sharia and al-Qaida used the political vacuum to make Libya an additional home and base and, like Da'esh, to take control of the immense oil supplies with the aim of defending their war chest. bacon. The human rights situation in the country is getting worse and worse. Executions, torture and violence against journalists and officials are among the practices of all parties involved in the conflict. In the meantime, Libya has become a colony and transit country for people smugglers. In the interest of the country, of the region and of Europe, it is imperative that Libya becomes a safe and politically stable country. In this joint resolution, the European Parliament asks the two main Libyan institutions to implement last year's political agreement. Parliament is also sending out a signal that a government of national unity has its support. A definitive guarantee of a stable political climate is only possible if an international coalition combats the growing presence of Daesh in Libya.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing - Libya, this large and rich country in North Africa, has been in poor shape for five years.The quality infrastructure that Libya could be proud of is destroyed.Attacks by Islamists, various terrorist organizations and other groups carrying out violence against the general population are a daily reality here.The country and its diverse population need stability after a long period of unrest so that they can breathe in and start over.We must not forget the number of migrants that Libya has to deal with, and given Europe's security, it is desirable for Libya to succeed at a high level.The European Union can help Libya in this direction by providing a financial package as well as peacekeeping missions.Nevertheless, I am of the opinion that interference with the functioning of the state should be kept to a minimum.I agree with the rapporteur in assessing the situation and in my views on providing assistance to Libya.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ Libya is in a complete chaos. The country has turned to a smuggling hub for refugees, a springboard for smugglers and a flourishing environment for terrorist organisation and growing threat of Daesh. I supported the Libyan Political Agreement on a national unity government. For me this long waited agreement was a vital step in bringing political, social and economic stability within Libya. Libya's has strategic position, not only for my country, but for the Mediterranean region and for Europe as a whole.  A united Government in Libya will address the dramatic humanitarian, economic and security situation in the country and will ensure security and peace in the Mediterranean region.  I appeal to the House of Representatives to show a spirit of good cooperation and to endorse the agreement. But we should understand that forcing an agreement on the Libyan fractions and imposing sanctions on Libya is also going to lead us to a dead end. As I disagree with some of the provisions in the Resolution, I had to abstain at the final vote.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing.- The motions for resolutions have been tabled by the ECR, ALDE, Verts / ALE, PPE, S&D, ENF, GUE / NGL and EFDD groups.Of these, the first five political groups agreed on a draft compromise.I voted in favor of this motion.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. - I argue that the international community should support Libya in its effort to implement the agreement successfully, hoping that Member States and international institutions will only have official contacts with parties to the Libyan Political Agreement, in order to ensure the transition to a democratic, stable and inclusive Libya. I endorse full support in the struggle of the new Libyan authorities against terrorists, in order to ensure the necessary protection of Libya's people and critical economic infrastructure, considering that economic recovery is a decisive factor for Libya's democratic transition. The European Union and the United Nations must assist Libya in state-building, security and peacekeeping, as well as training on the creation of capacities to respond to emergencies and disasters, respect for human rights and the state. right. I believe that a safe and politically stable Libya is an imperative need for Libyan citizens, but also for the security of the entire region, as well as of the European Union.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: in writing.- This proposal concerns the situation in Libya following the disastrous and scandalous intervention of the West.The current situation gives pride of place to the tribal conflicts on which ISIS thrives.As a result, the Union is subject to both an unprecedented influx of migrants from Libya, as well as the terrorist threat.All of this was obviously predictable and had been predicted elsewhere.Basically, this text lends the Union an international role that it must be denied when we look at the Iraqi precedent, where 88% of the countries of the Union defended intervention in Iraq.This proposal is therefore just one more pretext to put the foreign policy of the Member States in a straight line.So I voted against it.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution on the situation in Libya.This text supports in particular the actions carried out by means of the European Union military operation in the southern part of the central Mediterranean (EU NAVFOR MED operation SOPHIA) to stem the migratory crisis and fight against the smugglers who exploit the distress of migrants..He also recalls that the success of this operation is directly linked to the return of peace and stability in the country.I particularly endorse the provisions calling for the constitution of a Libyan government of national unity in order to restore the rule of law in Libya and to put in place urgently the measures essential to the fight against illegal immigration.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: in writing.- The current situation in Libya remains extremely worrying, however I would like to express my support for the Presidential Council and for the future government of national unity that the Libyan parties will be able to form.I voted in favor of the resolution, also calling on Member States to act in concert with the European Union and the High Representative to support the country's political transition.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ Libya has been plagued by instability, infighting and sectarianism since the fall of Colonel Muammar Gaddafi in 2011. The lack of a stable government has been exploited by IS/Daesh and other extremist forces that threaten peace and security in the entire region. I have voted for this motion for a resolution that calls on Libya’s UN-led talks parties to work together in order to achieve national unity, stability and inclusivity.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: written.- I abstained from voting on this report because the resolution offers some positive approaches, but does not address the real authors of the state dissolution of Libya at all.This is incomprehensible to me insofar as I believe that these states have an overriding responsibility for restoring the state integrity of Libya.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: in writing.- The situation in Libya remains extremely difficult.It is therefore very important to implement the political agreement as soon as possible.It is a necessary tool to help the country move on the path to peace and stability and to ensure the security of all Libyan citizens.It is vital that the national unity government is recognized by the fighting political forces.In order to prevent the Daesh group from gaining a foothold, it is necessary to join forces not only at the national level but also at the international level to form an international coalition.In addition, increased international support should be provided for state and institution building, security and peace and justice reform, as well as other areas crucial to democratic governance.Humanitarian funding should also be increased to meet the basic needs of those hard hit by the conflict in Libya.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. – UKIP voted to abstain on this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is supportive of the UN-backed plan to return Libya to stable and democratic governance and hopes that all sides will fulfil their obligations under the agreement. However we do not support the EU’s attempts to get involved in Libya and expand their foreign policy role. We are also mindful of the situation of Libya’s impact on the current migration crisis. As such we abstained on the resolution as whole.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing.- The appointment of the national unity government is the result of the process of the international community's attempts to eliminate the divisions between the two parliaments and create a single government.Only some of the members of the two parliaments accepted the peace process, while others opposed it in a sometimes violent manner.To date, the risk is that political immobility will arise that is unable to face the danger deriving from the Libyan crisis.But if Europe is far away, Italy is close.Only a few hundred nautical miles separate us from the borders of Libya.Resolving the situation is therefore for me a fundamental question for the security of the country.I would have voted positively for these reasons.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – The situation in Libya is particularly alarming - human rights situation is deteriorating throughout the country and violence against civilians, journalists, officials, political figures and human rights defenders perpetrated by all parties are a tragic reality. International community, along with the EU, should stand ready to support Libyans in their efforts to successfully implement Libiyan Political Agreement. That is the reason i vote in favour of the resolution.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: in writing. ‒ A safe and politically-stable Libya is an absolute need for Libyan citizens! In current geopolitical conditions it is of utmost importance that the EU deploys all its support for the border management of Libya and mobilise the international community for the economic reconstruction of the country.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - I welcome this resolution and fully support it. Libya's civil war has claimed casualties among civilians on a daily basis, and both women and children have been exposed to violence. The humanitarian catastrophe and the constant conflicts are forcing civilians to flee to Europe, and many are losing their lives. On the other hand, the European Union today is facing a severe refugee crisis that is largely the result of both the civil war and the suffering of civilians in Libya. I believe that the European Union should be more actively involved in the process of reconciling the warring parties and through diplomatic efforts to support the creation of a government of national unity, which is the first step towards ending the conflict and normalizing life in this North African country. I am concerned about the increased activity of terrorist groups, such as Daesh and Al-Qaeda, which have found fertile ground for their activities due to the resulting political vacuum in Libya. As extremism and terrorism are threats not only to Libya, but also to the surrounding countries and to Europe, I believe that resolving the Libyan crisis and establishing lasting peace is of great importance for the European Union and the security of its citizens.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: in writing.- This report contains some exact considerations on the dramatic situation in Libya since the catastrophic intervention decided by Nicolas Sarkozy and then supported by the entire French political class, including François Hollande, with the notable exception of the National Front, only party to have foreseen the way are the situation would evolve.As might be expected, the advocated solution is to give even more power to the European Union in matters of foreign relations.Thus, the peoples would lose even more sovereignty and the Member States would be involved in the disastrous decisions that the technocrats in Brussels would inevitably take.I am obviously voting against this text which can bring no improvement to the Libyan situation, quite the contrary.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. - Recent Libyan events have thrown the country into total chaos. The failure of the Tobruk House of Representatives to ratify the political agreement supported by the international community, which envisages a government in agreement with Tripoli, multiplies the difficulties of conducting an inclusive reconciliation process. The dangerous political vacuum that derives from it has dramatic economic and humanitarian consequences, the terrorist groups IS and Al-Qaeda expand by appropriating the oil resources whose enjoyment should be destined for the Libyan population, now torn apart and put to flight, and they use the large arsenal of weapons present in the country despite the embargo. Understanding the Libyan scenario means, however, being aware of the responsibilities of the international community, from the NATO intervention in 2011 in complete violation of international law, to the external policy of the European Union including the EUBAUM migrant management mission, which has translated into in a militarization of the borders. I voted in favor of this resolution because I consider it urgent to analyze the mistakes made and to devise new strategies that make use of humanitarian and civil assistance, which urge the parties involved to comply with the obligations of international humanitarian law and urge neighboring states to cooperate in order to implement inclusive strategies.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written. - In Libya, due to the outbreak of violence and the increasingly unstable political environment, there has been a deterioration in terms of governance, human rights and the humanitarian situation. In January 2016, the UN Refugee Agency (UNHCR) estimated that approximately 435,000 people had been displaced across Libya. In addition, there are hundreds of thousands of refugees and asylum seekers of various nationalities, many of whom live in difficult conditions and their numbers are increasing. Unfortunately, Libya has also become a transit area for human trafficking, resulting in the deaths of thousands of people who tried to reach Europe via the Mediterranean. In view of all the catastrophic circumstances we are witnessing in Libya, I welcome the signing of the Libyan political agreement to form a government of national unity as Libya's only legitimate government consisting of a cabinet and a presidential council headed by Fayez al-Sarai and enjoying the support of other state institutions. are the House of Representatives and the State Council. As part of the implementation of the agreement, special attention should be paid to the obligation of all parties in Libya to protect civilians at all times, as well as to treat all detainees in accordance with international human rights and humanitarian law. At the same time, I welcome the EU's strong commitment to the realization of Libya's sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity, as well as the announced aid package of EUR 100 million.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. - The resolution voted in Parliament, shamelessly omits its responsibilities and that of the EU in the military aggression, which was legitimized here in 2011, and in the very serious problems of political and economic instability that plague the region and which resulted from the foreign intervention led NATO, USA and EU. A war of imperialist aggression that created a huge tragedy for the civilian population, with thousands of deaths and the destruction of this country's social and economic infrastructure. An imperialist offensive against the Arab world that enshrines the neo-colonialist stance of the West towards North Africa and the Middle East, motivated by geostrategic control and exploitation of the region's immense wealth, namely its oil reserves. It also omits the responsibilities of the great powers in spreading terrorist groups in the region, namely through the continued sale and export of arms. On the other hand, the resolution opens doors and legitimizes the possibility of a new external military intervention in Libya, which everything points to is in preparation. We reaffirm the right of the Libyan people to decide on their destiny, their right to sovereignty and peace, free from outside interference. We voted against.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing.- The growing presence of terrorist organizations and extremist movements in Libya has become the main threat to the stability and security of the entire Mediterranean region.Following the fall of Gaddafi, Libya has become a transit land for human trafficking.Political conflicts within the country also favor the destabilization of the Sahel region, allowing extremist organizations to grow.A secure and politically stable Libya is absolutely necessary not only for Libyan citizens, but also for the security of the entire region and the European Union as a whole.For this reason, I am in favor of the formation of a government of national understanding, supported by the consensus of the various political factions, which can guide Libya towards a post-revolutionary transition, capable of allowing the construction of a democratic, peaceful and stable country..

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing.- Libya has been sinking for several years into a crisis so deep that it now threatens the Union's Mediterranean borders.The "Islamic State" group is establishing itself day after day in some Libyan cities, taking advantage of the chaos left by a civil war.It is a question of taking this situation into account as soon as possible.Let's take a step back and see the world on our borders: isn't it chaotic to the point of wanting to strengthen the European Union to better defend ourselves?The strategy of retreating and breaking up the Union will never bring the power we need to face these neighboring conflicts.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. - The power vacuum introduced by the Arab Spring that culminated in Libya with the fall of the Muammar Gaddafi government and regime, has been exploited by tribal militias and Islamic-inspired jihadist groups. In this context, the tensions resulting from the dispute between Islamic-inspired radicalist factions, on the one hand, and secular and liberal forces, on the other, give rise to the growing civil unrest, resulting in the displacement of some 440,000 people who, in the hope to escape armed conflict and poverty, have crossed the Mediterranean since 2014. This exodus of refugees is compounded by the influx from conflict zones in the Middle East and constitutes a humanitarian disaster that requires concerted action by the European Union and its Member States . In order to tackle the region's political instability and the growing divide between Libya's east and west, it is necessary for the EU to devise a clear and coordinated strategy to support the political transition. Also in this regard, the rapporteur considers that the current situation in Libya is the product of a series of significant errors, resulting from the aforementioned lack of coordination and foreign interference in the Libyan process. I voted in favor.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted to abstain this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is supportive of the UN backed plan to return Libya to stable and democratic governance and hopes that all sides will fulfil their obligations under the agreement. However we do not support the EU's attempts to get involved in Libya and expand their foreign policy role. We are also mindful of the situation in Libya's impact on the current migration crisis. As such we abstained on the resolution as whole.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. - Based on the Libyan Political Agreement supported by the United Nations, which was signed on 17 December 2015, this Resolution highlights the importance of the United Nations, the European Union, the African Union and the Arab League member states in supporting the Libyans in their efforts to successfully implement the agreement. I voted in favor of this document because it condemns Daesh's destabilizing terrorist attacks against the Libyan people. In this regard, I agree that economic recovery is an important step in Libya's democratic transition, with special emphasis on the new Libyan authorities against terrorists, in order to ensure the necessary protection of Libya's people and critical economic infrastructure. In this way, I voted in favor of this resolution because it underlines the importance of the international community doubling humanitarian funding in order to respond to the most urgent needs of people seriously affected by the conflict in Libya, and for that, Member States should respect its commitments to the EU Emergency Trust Fund for Africa.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: written. - Since NATO's military intervention and the overthrow of Muammar Gaddafi in 2011, various political parties, tribes and militias have been vying for power and control of the country's oil and gas fields. In December, an agreement was reached to form a government of national unity thanks to the mediation of the UN, the United States and Italy. The compromise was signed by members of both sides, but many continue to oppose the pact. Despite these timid advances, anarchy continues to have enormous costs and the number of people killed, kidnapped or imprisoned without due process continues to increase. Furthermore, Libya is a transit country for refugees and migrants from Africa and the Middle East; The uncontrolled trafficking of arms and combatants through the Sahel is also worrisome. Faced with this situation of chaos, this Resolution firmly condemns the recent terrorist attacks perpetrated in Zliten and urges the Presidential Council to form a Government of national unity as soon as possible, since it is the only way for Libya to return to the path of peace. stability and prosperity. That is why I have voted in favor of this Resolution.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution put to a vote this afternoon, which calls on the Union and the international community to stand ready to support the efforts of the Libyans to implement the Libyan Political Agreement.Signed on December 17, 2015, this agreement supports the newly created Single Government of National Accord and national institutions, which must guide Libya through its post-revolution transition and put it back on the path to building a democratic country,peaceful, stable and prosperous.The European Parliament's text also calls for continued humanitarian, financial and political aid from the Union and the international community to remedy the humanitarian situation in Libya, the plight of displaced persons and refugees and that of civilians.whose access to basic services is severely disrupted.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. - Libya has been affected by strong internal instability since the fall of dictator Muammar Gaddafi in 2011, with this political vacuum and lack of government stability being exploited by Daexe and other extremist forces threatening peace and security across the region. The spread of terrorist groups, such as Daexe, in the country represents a serious threat to the security of Libya, North Africa, the EU itself and even the rest of the globe, so it is essential to adopt measures capable of stopping this wave of violence. violence. Considering the current situation of gross systematic violation of human rights, which has worsened in recent months, the call to end the violence is essential to curb the growing presence of extremist organizations and movements in Libya. Cooperation between the EU and Tunisia is also an important factor to take into account in this peace process, as well as continued support in terms of humanitarian, financial and political aid from the EU and the international community. I globally endorse the measures contained in the motion for a resolution, and I therefore voted in favor.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this resolution on Libya which calls on the two parliaments of Tripoli and Tobruk, which have been fighting each other for months, to adopt and implement the Libyan political agreement. Libya is currently going through a complex phase. This resolution is an opportunity to urge Tripoli and Tobruk to find an agreement as quickly as possible in order to implement the political agreement reached on January 7 and respond to the terrorist threat from the "Islamic State" group. This agreement will also help protect the country's resources, as well as restore stability and security throughout the country, and also in the region. I supported this text which reminds us that the Union is committed to supporting the future government of national unity and is ready to provide immediate and substantial support; a package of aid measures amounting to 100 million euros is already available. Finally, the text calls for the activation of the third phase of the Sophia EURONAVFOR MED mission, in order to intensify cooperation between the Union and Libya to fight against smugglers and human trafficking.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing.- It is essential to stabilize the situation in the country, to stem the flow of migrants and the illegal activities of smugglers, to curb the recruitment of new ISIS troops, to set a good example for other international institutions to move to resolve a situation totallyout of control.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: written.- The Libyan Parliament rejected the UN Resolution which sought to implement a stabilization plan in the area that included a unity government.The European Commission itself lamented in public statements an irresponsible attitude on the part of the Libyan representatives.We voted against, since, in our opinion, the resolution of the Libyan political conflict and the formation of a unity government should be sine qua non conditions prior to the adoption of any resolution or action by the EU.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: in writing.- I support the Libyan political agreement and the UN-led discussions and call on all parties to work together for national unity, stability and inclusivity.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: written. - I voted against the Resolution on the situation in Libya, since it defends the military intervention of NATO in 2011 and considers that the bombings and the death of thousands of Libyans, the situation of chaos and destruction of the country, the risk of fracture and the progression of the misnamed Islamic State (IS) five years later, the destabilization of countries and the uncontrolled flow of weapons in the region were worth it. Not only does it not recognize Western responsibility in the conflict, but it seeks to add pressure for a rapid implementation of the Libyan Political Agreement that, far from prospering, has proposed a government that has already been rejected by the Tobruk Parliament. The EU intends to press for the rapid formation of a single puppet government that has international legitimacy and that can, on the one hand, admit that the Eunavfor Med Sophia operation of externalization of borders and obstacle to the arrival of refugees to the EU patrols in territorial waters Libyans and, on the other, even justify a new foreign military intervention in the country, this time under the pretext of fighting IS. This is why I have voted against.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I, and Labour’s Sister Parties in the S&D Group, welcome the signature of the Libyan Political Agreement (LPA) to form a Government of National Accord as the sole and legitimate government of Libya. I join in the invitation for the House of Representatives and its Presidency to show a spirit of compromise and convene to discuss the proposed cabinet with a view to endorsing the Government of National Accord. One of the principle advantages of such an agreement is that it will provide the necessary mechanisms to tackle the issues that come with reforming and actually building State institutions, but also being involved in the fight against terrorism, reaching part of the solution to the problems that are affecting that region at the moment.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: written.- I have chosen to abstain from this Report, and this explanation of vote arises as a critique of the current system of evaluating the work of Members of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities highlighted in Croatia.representative action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing - The situation in Libya since 2011, when Libyans took to the streets as part of the so-called The Arab Spring is still uncertain, destabilizing and the country is at war, where the terrorist attacks of the Daesh group on the population are on the agenda. It is the presence of the Daesh Group in Libya that undermines the country's stability and poses a threat not only to the neighboring Sahel and Sahara countries, but also to the EU. The fate of Libyan migrants, asylum seekers and refugees, whose already unbearable situation continues to deteriorate, is also a cause for concern. Therefore, the involvement of the UN refugee office and the joint efforts of all EU Member States to address the situation in Libya must focus on Libya's economic recovery and support the Libyan authorities in the fight against terrorism in order to provide the Libyan people with the necessary protection and key economic infrastructures. The EU has provided € 100 million to Libya and stands ready to offer immediate support in areas that will be identified as a priority together with the newly formed Libyan Government of National Unity. I supported the motion for a resolution.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: in writing. - Ever since 2011, when rebel groups overthrew Muammar Gaddafi with the help of NATO, there have been severe political, institutional and security crises in Libya. Since the summer of 2014, there have been increasingly serious clashes across the country between two disbanded and fragmented opposing groups (the forces of Operation Pride and the "Libyan Dawn" coalition). Both opposing camps defend their goals and invoke the legitimacy of opposing governments and parliaments, based in Tripoli and Tobruk. In the country, militias associated with the t.i. Islamic State, took advantage of the aforementioned civil war and the emptiness of power and increased its presence. They are increasingly carrying out terrorist attacks and brutally abusing the local population. Since Libya slipped into civil war, the human rights situation there, as well as the humanitarian situation, has deteriorated sharply. The motion for a resolution sets out some appropriate proposals for action, such as the establishment of inclusive internal institutions capable of upholding the rule of law, the creation of a comprehensive disarmament, demobilization and reintegration program, the conferral of jurisdiction on the ICC in Libya, etc. However, as paragraph 12 on the deployment of EUNAVFOR was not withdrawn from the motion for a resolution in plenary, I abstained.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of the resolution on the situation in Libya, which intends to support the signing of the Libyan political agreement with a view to the formation of a government of national unity, as the only legitimate government of Libya. After a year of negotiations, the political agreement was finally signed last December and constitutes the necessary framework to allow the various political parties involved to reach a compromise for the creation of the national government. The challenges facing the Libyan government, once formed, are numerous and serious: rebuilding government institutions and consolidating the rule of law, combating terrorism and trafficking in persons, guaranteeing respect for human rights in the area of ​​migration. For this reason, with the resolution approved today we offer not only the support from the European Union and the international community to the efforts of the Libyan political forces in view of the goal of forming the government of national unity but also the commitment to support its action once it goes into operation.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: in writing. - I unequivocally supported the text, in my opinion, of a very balanced resolution on the situation in Libya. It draws attention to the stalemate following the failure of the agreement on the government of national unity. The resolution appeals to EU leaders and the international community as a whole to help the process of reaching a viable compromise in this chaotic country. The absence of a legitimate government is destabilizing the whole region, especially neighboring states such as Tunisia and Egypt. The Libyan vacuum is fertile ground for IS-linked extremist organizations and also an alternative for IS fighters who are gradually being pushed out of Syrian territory. And not only that. Unprotected borders in the south are often an open gateway to economic migrants from sub-Saharan and West Africa. In the current chaos, smuggling gangs are free to operate, including the 1,770 km long Libyan coast of the Mediterranean. Until there is a government of national unity, the impact of the EU naval mission against smugglers (EUNAVFOR Sophia) will be very limited. Only the legitimate Libyan government can allow mission vessels to enter the territorial waters where the smugglers operate the most and also return the vessels to the places from which they departed.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: written. - Since August 2014, both political bodies (the Tobruk House of Representatives recognized by the international community and the new General National Congress that appeared in Tripoli) claim to govern the country and both support several heavily armed paramilitaries linked to regions, cities and tribes of different affiliations. Libya has become the seat of Daesh’s largest force outside the Middle East and forms its bridgehead on the southern Mediterranean coast, posing the greatest threat to neighboring countries in the Sahel and Sahara region, but also in terms of terrorist activity and Europe. A secure and politically stable Libya is essential not only for the citizens of Libya but also for the security of the entire region and the European Union. I welcome the Libyan political agreement signed on 17 December 2015, which was supported by the UN and the Presidential Council. I call on the Commission and the European External Action Service, which coordinates the action of the Member States in Libya, to focus their support on state and institution building and, together with the Member States, the UN, NATO and regional partners, to help reform the security sector and create effective national military and police forces under the control of the government of national unity, which can control the entire Libyan territory and its leaders and secure state borders.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written. - Since the fall of dictator Muammar Gaddafi in 2011, Libya is in an unstable situation in which there is deep division. Despite the parliamentary elections held in June 2014, the country is divided between two opposing governments based in Tripoli and Tobruk. Daesh and other extremist organizations are taking advantage of a situation of political vacuum and the absence of a stable government that threatens peace and security throughout the region. If the expansion of the influence of extremist groups continues, it could pose a major threat to security in the region and the European Union. Human rights continue to be violated, so cases such as kidnappings, illegal killings and torture continue to occur. The European Parliament is extremely concerned about the humanitarian crisis in Libya and calls on all parties to stop the violence and to refrain from actions that create further divisions, as well as to find a solution through political dialogue. I support the proposals made in this debate because I believe that the coordinated efforts of the Member States should focus on building strong institutions that will ensure a stable state. Also, member states, the UN, NATO and regional partners should work together to create effective security services under the control of the central government, which will ensure peace and stability in the country.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the joint motion for a resolution on the situation in Libya.I support the political agreement in Libya signed by the two sides of the conflict, which will end the political split in Libya.The agreement calls for the formation of a government of national unity and a previous government of a nine-member presidential committee, consisting of a prime minister, five deputies and three ministers.I particularly welcome the fact that the agreement was adopted under the auspices of the UN.I join the call in the resolution for the House of Representatives in Tobruk and the Presidency to support this agreement, which is a key step in implementing Libya's political agreement and which corresponds to the efforts to achieve peace and stability in the country and defend all Libyan citizens.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: in writing.- I supported the resolution on the situation in Libya, as the efforts of the international community and various Libyan groups to end the civil war and form a government of national unity need to be supported at this time.The European Union must support the stabilization of Libya here, as only a stable Libya will ensure that trafficking in human beings is curtailed, that there is control over the arms trade and that there is a real fight against terrorist groups operating in North Africa and the Sahel.It is important here that the individual Member States speak with one voice in support of the current government, because only uniform support will ensure the transition of Libyan society to a parliamentary form of government.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE / NGL), in writing. - We voted against the joint resolution as it supports the military intervention of the states under the auspices of NATO in Libya in 2011, while supporting the stay of foreign forces in the region as a security shield. As EEC / BPA and AKEL, we once again condemn the criminal military intervention in Libya, which led to the destruction of the country and the destabilization of the region. NATO intervention has further deepened the civil war as Libya is still subject to an international embargo imposed by the UN Security Council in 2011, NATO members and their allies have significantly disarmed armed groups, a violation of international law. At the same time, the EU set up the EU Border Assistance Mission in Libya, with the aim of providing military assistance to the Libyan authorities at a cost of 30 million euros, which is spent on private security companies. The purpose of Western intervention in Libya is none other than the control and domination of the region's rich energy sources. The result is the humanitarian crisis in Libya, which has forced thousands of refugees to flee the country and face enormous risks in their quest for a better tomorrow.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: in writing.- The Union and many of the Member States, having first destroyed Libya to serve their own interests, now appear ready to launch another military intervention, which will essentially only succeed in sinking the country into anothermore chaos.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the adoption of the report and the course of action contained in it, recognizing that it directly affects the interests of the European Union and its Member States in several respects. The report points out that monitoring and influencing the war and humanitarian situation in Libya is an important task for the EU, as it is today one of the main sources of migration to Europe, a terrorist threat, a major contributor to destabilizing the entire Mediterranean region. they have become a base for arms trafficking and human trafficking. I trust that, with this resolution, the European Parliament will also contribute to the conciliation plan drawn up under the auspices of the United Nations in December 2015, at least for the second time, with the support of the Libyan opposition and parliament. I agree that in the next period, the development of state and institutional functioning will come to the fore, in which the EU can play a significant role. I believe that our decision rightly calls on the governments of the EU Member States to continue their efforts to promote the peace process and the fight against terrorism in Libya, in coordination with the work of the EEAS and the High Representative, and to avoid detached political actions.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: signed up. - The civil conflict that has been going on in Libya for several years has generated a series of negative effects for the European Union, such as the intensification of migration, the illegal trafficking of persons and the spread of the terrorist phenomenon. The signing of the Libyan Political Agreement is an important step towards normalizing the situation and placing at the negotiating table the various legitimate camps in conflict. The formation of a Government of the National Agreement in the next period would be a guarantee for the respect of the interests of the various Libyan political groups. That is why it is very important that the Presidency and the House of Representatives in Libya support this initiative. The European Union, through the High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Vice-President of the Commission, is working with the Libyan authorities and UN structures to develop a coordinated package of measures to support the new Libyan government. However, there is a need to supplement humanitarian funding in order to rebuild the country and normalize the lives of its citizens. In this regard, the Member States of the Union must support these measures, provided that the new government in Tripoli will take measures to reform state institutions, strengthen the rule of law, fight terrorism (including ISIS activity in Libya), respect for human rights , combating human trafficking and controlling the phenomenon of migration. I support the adoption of the present resolution.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution. I deeply regret that the first cabinet proposed by the Presidential Council was rejected by the House of Representatives but at the same time welcomes the endorsement in principle of the political agreement; strongly condemns the abduction of House of Representatives MP Mohamed al-Ra’id and calls on all influential actors to spare no effort to ensure his immediate and unconditional release; opposes any strategy put in place by any actor to undermine or slow down the political process leading to the creation of a new Government of National Accord.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted today in favour of the resolution I co-authored on the situation in Libya. This text welcomes the UN-backed political agreement reached in December last year. Despite all the efforts, the House of Representatives rejected the first proposal of a unity government endorsed by the United Nations. Indeed, stabilising Libya is of crucial importance, both for its people and for the international community. Only a stable government would be able to improve living conditions in the country, end tribal and sectarian violence and face the terrorist groups operating in the region. It is also a prerequisite for any effective move by the EU aimed at stemming the flow of migrants who risk their lives to cross the sea and reach Europe. This resolution is a clear and strong message urging the EU and its Member States, the UN and other international actors to step up their efforts in assisting the Libyan people to form an inclusive cabinet and bring an end to the ongoing conflict.  It sends a strong signal that we must avoid the mistakes we have made in the recent past.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing.- It is very comforting that on the Libyan question there is a great deal of convergence among all the countries represented on the need to consolidate the open negotiation path.The risk is that Daesh will multiply its presence and terrorist actions in Libya, for this reason the European Union, the Member States and all the main international players must ensure full cooperation with the new Libyan government in various fields, in particular security.The key is a political process, a government of national unity that has the support of the parliament and collaborates with the international community for the stabilization of the area.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written.- I supported this resolution which emphasizes that the situation in Libya stems from a series of serious mistakes that began with the military intervention in 2011 when several international actors clearly showed their intention to support military intervention against IDIS / Daesh in Libya as soon as a new government is formed.Namely, I express deep concern about the current situation, and I believe that the future government should explore the possibility of introducing an institutional structure that would guarantee regional and local authorities a certain degree of autonomy, as is the case in federal forms of government.I also believe that regional actors must not act in a way that could deepen divisions and jeopardize Libya's transition to a stable, inclusive and democratic country.I strongly condemn the latest terrorist attacks and call on the Member States, in cooperation with the UN Support Mission, to help Libya and support the development of a comprehensive strategy, and to support the transition and the new government.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing.- I supported the motion for a resolution on the situation in Libya, as I believe that the European Union's support for Libya in resolving the crisis is not only necessary but also very necessary.The situation, which affects violations of human rights and fundamental freedoms and, violence and the hardening of peace in the country, consequently threatens the security of the entire region, including the EU.Due to the growing humanitarian crisis, it is more necessary than ever to call on the EU to end violence, new divisions and find solutions through political dialogue.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: written.- The Libyan Parliament rejected the UN Resolution which sought to implement a stabilization plan in the area that included a unity government.The European Commission itself lamented in public statements an irresponsible attitude on the part of the Libyan representatives.We voted against, since, in our opinion, the resolution of the Libyan political conflict and the formation of a unity government should be sine qua non conditions prior to the adoption of any resolution or action by the EU.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I support this resolution. With this vote, I condemn the destabilising terrorist attacks by Daesh against the people of Libya. I call on the Commission and the European External Action Service, which is coordinating Member States’ action in Libya, to focus their support on state—building and institution—building and, together with the Member States, the UN, NATO and regional partners, to assist in the reform of the security sector and the creation, under the control of the GNA, of effective national army and police forces able to control the entire Libyan territory and its waters and secure its borders.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing.- Under the regime of dictator Gaddafi, Libya had the largest arsenal of weapons in the region, which fell into the hands of illegal arms dealers and terrorists after its fall.The events following the Arab Spring deserve to be arranged and given special attention.With my vote, I supported the position of the S&D Group.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: in writing.- I call on all actors in the region, including the Arab League and the African Union, to work with the UN and other international organizations to help build a stable, inclusive and democratic Libya.I welcome the Libyan political agreement and the UN-led negotiations and call on all parties to work together for national unity, stability and inclusion.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because urgent action is needed in Libya, where economic disintegration and violence are worsening its fragility and enabling extremist organisations to flourish. Spillovers from Libya’s conflicts are also destabilising the Sahel region, and could constitute a threat to the EU´s security. The Libyan conflict is in fact having repercussions in Egypt and particularly Tunisia, but also in Algeria and its oilfields, while contributing to exacerbate extremism. With this resolution we urge the EU and international community to be ready to support Libyans’ efforts to implement the Libyan Political Agreement. We urgently call for continued humanitarian, financial and political assistance from the EU and the international community to address the humanitarian situation in Libya, the plight of internally displaced persons and refugees and that of civilians facing disruptions in access to basic services.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: written.- We voted in favor of the Resolution on Libya, a fragmented country, mired in a serious political crisis and threatened by the increasingly strong presence of Daesh.The Government of national unity, which was rejected by the Tobruk Parliament a few days ago, is recognized by the Resolution as the only legitimate one in the country.The international community urgently needs a new unity government, as this would make it possible to halt the increasingly sharp advance of the Islamic State in Libya.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: written.- I voted in favor of this resolution as I believe urgent action is needed in Libya.The security situation, as well as the humanitarian and economic situation in Libya at the moment are downright terrible.ISIS benefits from this and is gaining ground every day.There is a risk that such abuses will eventually affect the entire Sahel region.This would pose a risk to the security of our entire European Union that should not be underestimated.With this resolution, we therefore urge the Commission and the international community to support the Libyan political agreement and the UN-led talks and to urge all parties to cooperate in the interest of Libya's national unity.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: in writing. - As international pressure for the formation of a so-called unity government and threats of new military intervention multiply, the European Parliament has taken stock of the situation in Libya. The least that can be said in view of this resolution is that Parliament has no intention of drawing the disastrous consequences of the previous military intervention. Not only does Parliament not say a word in this resolution about the responsibilities of the French and British authorities in the Libyan chaos, but, even worse, it welcomes NATO's action in the region and calls for even greater military action under covered with the fight against terrorism.
