In reality, the message is clear: we must "secure the resources" and allow the country to serve as a base for military actions in the region as in the past, and even more easily. Therefore, respect for humanitarian law and human rights and thereby the interests of the Libyan people seem very secondary. I refuse to support such logic. The military interventions of the so-called Western powers have done enough damage. It is time to implement other logics. So I could only vote against this resolution.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - This draft resolution raises a number of concerns regarding political instability in the region, which is the result of foreign intervention by NATO. Libya is in danger of falling into a new conflict in which there is external intervention in the country. The situation of instability that exists is a consequence of a war of imperialist aggression that created a huge tragedy for the civilian population, with thousands of deaths and the destruction of this country's social and economic infrastructure. The war unleashed in Libya was part of yet another imperialist offensive against the Arab world that aims to initiate a recolonization of Africa. Libya has the largest confirmed oil reserves in Africa and the tenth in the world. A new external intervention and a new conflict aims at strengthening the control of the country's imperialist powers and their wealth. We must reaffirm the right of the Libyan people to decide on their destiny, their right to sovereignty and peace. We must condemn any new foreign intervention.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: written.- Resolution offers some good approaches, but avoids naming the real authors of the dissolution of Libya and simply does not go far enough.Overall a half-hearted approach.Therefore I abstain from voting.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: written.- Today, a few years after the end of the Gaddafi regime, which was forced and brought about by the West, Libya is a "failed state" which is also increasingly being used by the "Islamic State" (IS) as a new deployment base.Here all efforts are to be supported to put a stop to the further deterioration of the state and social order in Libya and to bring the country back into orderly conditions, if necessary with the cooperation of the EU.Therefore, a “yes” vote was necessary.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: written.- I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution on the "situation in Libya".The last few years have been a time of political stagnation, a time of the breakdown of the rule of law and the spread of violence.In the past few months, international efforts have been increased to help Libya during this difficult time.International humanitarian aid is something that is very important to me, especially in the time of increased terror on the part of ISIS / Da'esh.It is time to take another critical look at the previous military intervention in Libya and its consequences.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ I share in my colleagues’ concern regarding the situation of asylum seekers and refugees coming from Libya and North Africa, and I support this resolution’s call for more action to be taken by the Libyan authorities, European Member States and the EEAS to address the resulting humanitarian needs and the need for safety. I wish to emphasise that refugees and asylum seekers on their way to or arriving in Europe must be treated humanely, with their dignity respected and their needs addressed. I call on the Libyan and European authorities alike to ensure the facilities and services provided to take in refugees, asylum seekers and migrants meet these standards.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: in writing.- The hope of the Libyan people for a developing state, with strengthened democratic structures and full respect for human rights and human freedoms remains alive.With this initiative, which I voted in favor of, we are sending a message of hope to our southern borders.

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: in writing.- I would like to express great satisfaction with the adoption of the resolution on the situation in Libya.I confidently welcome the signing of the political agreement aimed at forming a government of national unity and I find this to be an important first step in restoring peace and security in the country.It is now imperative that the parties involved proceed swiftly in implementing the agreement and I hope that a sense of responsibility and inclusion prevail over the conflicting interests of each faction.In conclusion, I renew the great confidence placed in the work of the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy.I am sure that, with adequate support from all Member States, he will be able to properly coordinate the support and aid for Libya.

name: Milan ZVER
text: in writing.- The current situation in Libya requires the immediate intervention of peacekeepers and the establishment of a political dialogue between the parties to the conflict.War conflict worsens the human rights situation and cripples the economy, allowing extremist groups, terrorist attacks and smuggling to grow.I support the European Parliament's resolution on the situation in Libya, as I believe that it will help to stabilize the situation in Libya.The EU stands ready to provide support to help build statehood, security and peacekeeping, and respect for human rights and the rule of law.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: - Thank you, Mr President.It must be said that the world has a huge number of different islands - continental, volcanic, coral, large, small, populated, uninhabited.And small islands are often much more difficult than large islands due to limited resources, as well as the need to develop specific infrastructure to be connected to the large land, to their country.All this clearly applies to the European Union as well, so there is a need for maximum clarity on the Community's island policy.About funding, about programs, about the classification of islands themselves and so on.Clarity is needed to establish an effective strategy for further development, and it must be said that, a little exaggerated, it can be said that the example of Nauru is one of different relations with the islands.In short, I support this document.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: – Mr President, island communities in Europe play a unique and vital role, and it is imperative that we recognise and support them. On sustainable energy resources, island communities have huge potential. If Europe is to meet its sustainability targets, we must help our islands to harness this potential. Scottish islands, with the biggest coastal exposure to the Atlantic in the UK, have some of the best renewable energy opportunities in the world. On education: access, especially to further education and higher education, is vital. Scotland is lucky to be the home of our newest university, the University of the Highlands and Islands, which is leading in delivering education remotely, attracting huge global interest. This leads me to my final point on digital access: we debate in this Chamber about the importance of the digital single market. We must ensure that our island communities have access to superfast broadband, so that they too can enjoy this digital revolution that we are all enjoying at the moment. I am proud to represent and support the Scottish island communities.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: – Mr President, I was very happy to support the call for special attention to be paid to EU islands, in particular the call for special tax arrangements, the need to tackle depopulation and the call for better air services. In this context I would like to take the opportunity to raise the issue of air access to three islands off the west coast of Ireland: Inis Mór, Inis Oírr and Inis Meáin.  Up to now, access has been by a fixed-wing aircraft, and the islanders are very satisfied with the current arrangements. However, in recent times an attempt has been made to replace fixed-wing aircraft with helicopter access, and the islanders are most dissatisfied with this proposal. Today, here, I just want to clarify that, as far as the EU regulation, under which the Public Service Obligation (PSO) operates, is concerned, the term used is ‘air carrier’, which is defined as an undertaking with a valid operating licence or equivalent. So the decision on the matter, whether fixed-wing or helicopter, lies with the national authorities, and the needs and wishes of the islanders should be complied with. Today we call for better air services. The people of Inis Mór, Inis Oírr and Inis Meáin deserve better air services.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. - Art. 174 of the TFEU recognizes the reduction of regional social, economic and environmental disparities as a fundamental objective of the EU. Enhancing the territorial peculiarities not only contributes to an enrichment of the economic and cultural heritage of Europe, but also fits perfectly into the strategies of cohesion policies. Considering that, unfortunately, economic difficulties and the complex management of the flow of migrants are added to the natural disadvantages that characterize some Mediterranean islands, European support is essential and a priority. In fact, to fully achieve the objectives of development, growth and employment, the EU should promote coordinated action and the development of vertical strategies that involve all levels of government. For these reasons I voted in favor, because I strongly believe that guaranteeing the harmonious development of the islands can represent an opportunity and a tool for growth at local and European level.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report As a party we are against the EU dictating the regional and economic plans for islands that belong to Member States, it's the individual nation's responsibility to create regional schemes for their Islands.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. As a party we are against the EU dictating the regional and economic plans for islands that belong to Member States; it is the individual nation’s responsibility to create regional schemes for their Islands.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: written. - I voted in favor of this Resolution to support European institutions working in favor of financing and specific measures to address the peculiarities of island regions that, due to their extraordinary geographical conditions, tend to suffer more economic and development problems regional and population loss, which clearly goes against the objective set in the Treaties of reducing disparities between the different regions. For this reason, the Parliament Resolution requests, among other things, a comprehensive study of the additional costs of island areas, an improvement in funding sources and a White Paper that serves to monitor and be a source of consultation for best practices of the different actors. However, I must emphasize that this Resolution does not include the criticism that should be made of a global economic model that has damaged sustainable development in island areas, especially in those belonging to the most southern countries, where in general there has been almost a commitment to exclusivity for leisure tourism, without taking into account protected natural areas, or opportunities for economic diversification and quality employment. Anyway, my vote has been in favor.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this motion, which was put forward by the Committee for Regional Development, which looks at the specific and unique needs of islands in Europe. It looks at ways to meet those needs in order to ensure sustainable development and integration by better targeted use of EU policy to ensure economic viability, the supply of necessary public services and better connectivity and accessibility of islands with nearby regions.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: in writing.- The motion for a resolution in question here uses the expression "islands of the European Union" and is based on Article 174 of the TFEU with the aim of creating a homogeneous group which would include all the island regions such asthis is already the case with the mountainous regions group.This text is therefore part of a federalist approach that we cannot support.Therefore, with my colleagues from the National Front, we voted against.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report, which is about the European Union dictating the regional economic plans for islands belonging to Member States.  As I oppose the ESIF, it is natural for me to vote against. I note that the Eurostat definition of an ‘island’ means that Great Britain is not classified as an island. I am highly tempted to invite them to walk over and discuss the matter.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this proposal on reducing barriers for EU island regions. I agree that the Commission should take concrete action to tackle the obstacles facing the EU's islands and make the most of their potential. EU islands are also peripheral regions at the EU's external borders and are particularly vulnerable to the challenges that Europe is currently facing, such as globalization, demographic trends, climate change, energy supply and, especially in the south, increasing migratory flows. I agree that, in addition to GDP, the Commission should take into account other statistical indicators that may reflect the economic and social vulnerability of islands due to permanent natural handicaps. The Commission should launch a detailed study and analysis of the additional costs incurred by the island in terms of energy supply and market access for the transport system for islands, people and goods. The Commission should set out an EU strategic framework for islands in order to link measures that may have a significant territorial impact.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report As a party we are against the EU dictating the regional and economic plans for islands that belong to Member States, it's the individual nation's responsibility to create regional schemes for their Islands.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: in writing.- The motion for a resolution speaks of "the islands of the European Union" and uses Article 174 of the TFEU to create a homogeneous group to bring together all the "island regions", like the "mountainous regions".Clearly, this text validates the federalist project of the EU and I therefore opposed it.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing.- The economic and banking crisis has reduced public investments by more than 20% and austerity policies have had a very negative socio-economic impact in disadvantaged regions, particularly the islands.This joint resolution, which I approved, therefore asks the Commission to determine the handicaps and strengths of these island regions in order to take the appropriate measures to promote economic, social and territorial cohesion.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. - European islands represent a common heritage in terms of biodiversity and culture within the Union. Very often located on the borders of the European space, these areas are particularly vulnerable to the problems of energy supply, demographic evolution, climate change and in particular migratory flows. My support for the resolution on the condition of insularity stems from the belief that strong action is needed to put an end to the disadvantages suffered by the islands, guaranteeing the achievement of economic, social and territorial cohesion policies. The Commission needs to develop a genuine "Union Strategic Framework for Islands" in order to link all the instruments that are likely to have a significant impact on the territory. The potential of the European islands must be exploited, guaranteeing the development of sustainable tourism systems, alongside seasonal tourism, without losing sight of the great opportunities offered by the islands as alternative energy sources of the ocean, wind and solar type.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: written.- We voted in favor since we agree that, in accordance with Council Directive 2006/112 / EC, certain European islands (including the outermost region of the Canary Islands) are granted a special tax regime to correctinequalities due to multiple causes related to the condition of insularity.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: written.- I supported this Resolution on the special situation of the islands - islands other than the outermost regions - because it seems to me to be very important.It encourages the Commission to provide a clear definition of the type of permanent geographic, natural and demographic handicaps that island regions may suffer.I encourage the Commission to do so.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing.- In the name of the specific nature of our national territories, and more particularly of our islands, I have obviously rejected this indecent motion for a resolution which does not fit into anything other than the European federalist project.The resolution thus proposes a scandalous standardization, as with the negation of the difference between islands and states and islands and regions.That is why I supported the amendments which aimed in particular at the importance of preserving a tax regime favorable to certain islands which are handicapped by their geographical location or which are the subject of economic adjustment programs.It is necessary to always fight to recall the national framework for the sustainable development of island regions, against the attempt to "regionalize" our territories which would serve to eliminate the State as a mediating level between the Union and the territories.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing.- Island regions need special protection, given the greater difficulties compared to continental areas in accessing services.So far there are shortcomings in ensuring such protection by the European institutions for these less favored areas.I therefore share the aim of this report in bringing this issue back to the EU's attention and I voted in favor.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: written.- The island regions, classified as NUTS-2 and NUTS-3 regions, have common characteristics and particularities that are permanently manifested and clearly distinguish them from continental territories.Article 174 of the TFEU recognizes that all island regions face permanent handicaps that require special attention.However, in the framework of the preparation of the financial programming period 2014-2020, the island regions of the EU at the NUTS-2 and NUTS-3 levels did not receive any specific funding, but only the possibility of modulation of feesof co-financing for certain types of island, in accordance with article 121 of Regulation (EU) No. 1303/2013.For these reasons, I support the resolution adopted by the European Parliament in order to correct these shortcomings.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this resolution because it assessed Parliament's special situation on the islands. The economic crisis has led to a sharp reduction in the national and regional budgets of many Member States, as funding opportunities have been limited in many sectors, leading to a 20% reduction in public investment; whereas, as stated in the Sixth Report on Economic, Social and Territorial Cohesion, the crisis has had a major impact on the development potential of many disadvantaged regions, including islands. EU islands are also peripheral regions at the EU's external borders and are particularly vulnerable to the challenges that Europe is currently facing, such as globalization, demographic trends, climate change, energy supply and the growing impact of migratory flows, especially in the south. Parliament therefore called on the Commission to provide a clear definition of the types of permanent geographical, natural and demographic handicaps facing island regions. Parliament also called on the Commission to explain how it intended to implement the wording of Article 174 of the EU Treaty on the permanent obstacles faced by island regions, which hamper the natural development of island regions and economic, social and territorial cohesion.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: in writing.- I supported the proposed resolution on the EU's island regions, as I believe that more attention needs to be paid to the islands that make up a significant part of European territory.The arguments for the preservation of island regions are similar to those I myself often point out in the issue of hilly and mountainous areas.Both islands and mountain areas face traffic and information remoteness, emigration, which has an impact on cultural and natural heritage and on an aging population.In terms of economic activity, island areas are most dependent on tourism, which is the largest employer in these regions, but due to the seasonal orientation of this industry, it is difficult to provide jobs throughout the year.The resolution therefore called for the establishment of an EU strategic framework for island regions and for a change of approach for islands under the greatest pressure from migrant waves.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: written.- I support this issue of the islands.I myself come from a country rich in a thousand islands, so I understand the specifics and problems faced by the islanders.I believe that the Commission must give an adequate answer to the questions posed in the text, because there are indeed permanent obstacles and isolation in this area, and there are already constant cases of extinction of many islands.We must find a way to keep the population on the islands, because otherwise isolation will lead to the complete extinction of the islands and the complete emigration of their population in the future.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this document because I believe that the condition of insularity and the typical characteristics inherent to it are evidence that cannot be overlooked by the European institutions but rather that they must work to find solutions aimed at compensating for the situationsdisadvantage that insularity entails compared to continental regions.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. - The European Union has within it several island regions which, pursuant to Article 174 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU), are classified as NUTS-2 and NUTS-3 regions since they have common characteristics and specificities of permanent nature that clearly distinguish them from the regions located on the mainland. The European Union therefore recognizes that these regions, due to their conformation and geographic location, suffer from concrete disadvantages which require specific attention. Despite this, when defining the financial programming for the period 2014-2020, no targeted funding was foreseen for the island regions of the EU at NUTS-2 and NUTS-3 levels, but only the possibility of modulating the rates of co-financing for certain types of islands, in accordance with Article 121 of Regulation (EU) no. 1303/2013. We believe that this decision is wrong and problematic and that the Commission must clarify which specific instruments and resources under the cohesion policy it intends to make available to overcome the disadvantages deriving from the insularity of these territories.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: in writing. - Island regions incur additional costs, in particular regarding the supply of energy and raw materials. Moreover, it is true that the islands are more vulnerable to the main challenges that the Member States must overcome, namely wild globalization, climate change, but also the massive influx of migrants in the Mediterranean. Although we share the same observation, our solutions diverge from those mentioned in this motion for a resolution. It is the sole responsibility of the Member States, in cooperation with the local authorities, to determine the sustainable development strategies of these regions as well as the infrastructure projects eligible for obtaining European structural funds. In addition, we formally contest the misappropriation of European funds for the reception of illegal migrants. This is the reason why I voted against this text.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: signed up. - The European islands have special characteristics in terms of environmental conditions, with endemic habitats and species, but also from the perspective of cultural aspects, having an architectural heritage, sites, landscapes, agricultural and non-agricultural features and remarkable geographical identities. European islands play a significant role in strengthening sustainable development in the Union, given their high potential for renewable energy production, due to specific exposure to wind, tidal and sunlight. However, some of the Union's islands also fall into peripheral regions, being vulnerable to various challenges facing Europe such as globalization, demographic trends, climate change, energy supply and, especially in the southern areas, exposure to increasing migration flows. . As a result, more efficient connectivity through sea routes, better access to ports and better air transport services are required. I believe that it is particularly important to promote the accessibility of the regions and the links between the islands so that these island areas become tourist and high-interest points. I am in favor of this report because I believe that a strategic approach is needed, for the sustainable development of European island areas by promoting innovation and competitiveness in these regions.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this resolution of the Committee on Regional Development, which arose from a question on the subject of the implementation of Article 174 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU, because it is clear to all that what is contained in that article is not it was minimally implemented by the European Commission. Both the island regions and the mountain areas maintain the conditions of difficult access to services unaltered. The merit of this resolution is to raise the case and underline how the cohesion objectives should also go through greater protection of the human presence in the islands. Of course, this principle seems to be in contradiction with the rigid discipline against state aid which the administrators who would like to favor air and sea connections in these territories clash (see cases Ryanair, Saremar and Tirrenia in Sardinia). Therefore, these are events in which the logic of the free market must be well commensurate with the need of island and continental citizens to be able to transit without problems and without particular outlays. In the case of Sardinia we can clearly state that great blame must also be attributed to the Member State in question, guilty in recent years of having invested very few resources to eliminate the obstacles deriving from the principle of insularity.

name: Alain CADEC
text: in writing.- The territory of the European Union includes many islands located on the outskirts of certain Member States.The condition of insularity requires special attention from the Union.Indeed, the geographical distance and, sometimes, the difficulties of access can generate negative economic and social consequences.I voted in favor of this resolution which calls on the European Commission to pay more attention to the islands.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution on the condition of insularity. The resolution emphasized that common specific characteristics of a permanent nature clearly distinguish island regions from regions located on the mainland and that the condition of insularity has permanent natural and geographical handicaps. The resolution highlights the need to support the balanced territorial development of island regions by promoting innovation and competitiveness in those regions, which are located at a great distance from the main administrative and economic centers and which do not enjoy easy access to transport. The resolution highlights the importance of providing support measures to counter the significant depopulation trend of island regions and calls on the European Commission to launch an in-depth analysis on the additional costs that the condition of insularity determines at the level of passenger transport systems and goods and energy supply, as well as in terms of market access, in particular for SMEs. I have therefore decided to vote in favor of the resolutions.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report As a party we are against the EU dictating the regional and economic plans for islands that belong to Member States, it's the individual nation's responsibility to create regional schemes for their Islands.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because islands within the European Union do indeed face certain problems which are not common on mainland Europe despite the ever-present struggle of the European Union for the convergence of all its regions. Islands have more natural barriers than mainland regions and therefore we need to do more in order to better exploit the available resources and opportunities so that they can overcome the obstacles to better development. For example, many of them are poorly connected to the mainland which results in economic and social marginalisation.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing.- The EU through Article 174 of the TFEU recognizes the disadvantages of island regions which hinder their development and prevent them from achieving economic, social and territorial cohesion.The text asks the Commission to undertake an in-depth analysis on the additional costs that the condition of insularity causes at the level of the transport systems of people and goods and energy supply, as well as in terms of access to the market, in particular for SMEs.In light of the above, I voted in favor.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. - Reducing the gap between the levels of development of the European regions is the main objective of cohesion policy, which, as indicated in Article 174 of the Lisbon Treaty, is aimed above all at less-favored areas, including island areas. However, the periphery of these areas can become an added value for Europe, in particular in reference to the production of alternative energies or the safeguarding of biodiversity. Cohesion policy has not yet given the right space to these areas, for which a section dedicated to addressing specificities and permanent disadvantages linked to their geographical position should instead be envisaged. I therefore find it more appropriate than ever the request made by Parliament to create a window for the islands and a European agenda for the island regions, all areas for which cohesion policy funds should be used to trigger and initiate development processes appropriate to the needs and requirements of these territories. I voted in favor of the resolution because I believe that the gap that still exists between the regions of Europe can only be bridged through policies and interventions that are more relevant to the natural development needs and vocations of these specific areas.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing. - We support the motion for a resolution and recall that reducing economic, social and environmental disparities between regions is a key objective of European cohesion policy. The impact of the economic crisis has severely affected the development potential of many disadvantaged regions, including islands, and has reversed the long-term trend of convergence of GDP and unemployment rates across the EU, leading to rising poverty and social exclusion and achieving the Union's long-term goal of economic, social and territorial cohesion. We emphasize that the islands, as peripheral regions on the EU's external borders, are particularly vulnerable to current challenges (globalization, demographic challenges, climate change, energy supply and, especially for the southern regions, exposure to increasing migratory flows). For the above reasons, we call on the Commission to draw up an "EU Strategic Framework for Islands", as we call on the Member States and regional and local authorities to play an important role in development strategies for islands based on a vertical approach that requires participation. at all levels of government, in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, with a view to ensuring sustainable development for the EU islands.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the Proposal for a Resolution on the Insularity Condition presented by me and strongly desired. The islands of the Union are peripheral territorial areas located on the external borders of the EU and particularly vulnerable to the challenges that Europe faces, such as globalization, demographic change, climate change, energy supply and exposure to clandestine immigration. The European islands contribute to the diversity of the Union both from an environmental and a cultural point of view. The European islands can contribute to the strengthening of the sustainable development of the union, given their high potential for the production of energy from renewable sources by virtue of a privileged exposure to winds, sea and sun. We strongly ask that the Commission, in the substantial application of art. 174 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, concretely recognizes the condition of Insularity through the creation, for classification purposes, of a homogeneous group including all island territories. I hope that the Commission will evaluate the European islands as a homogeneous group of regions deserving of ad hoc regional development programs, working towards the development of statistical indicators from which the extent of the disadvantages of the island condition emerges more faithfully, therefore not limiting itself to mere consideration of rigid statistical indicators measured as a percentage of GDP.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. - I am very pleased to have voted in favor of this resolution, which is the result of a joint effort in support of my colleague Salvatore Cicu, the true architect of this political document. It was time for someone to come and put pen to paper something that is visible to everyone, except for the European bureau-legislators: that the condition of insularity involves a series of difficulties which cannot be ignored in the organization of society. It is said that when, at the end of the Second World War, in Italy the famous referendum was voted to keep the monarchy or pass to the Republic, the Sardinian ballot papers were thrown overboard to distort the result in favor of the Republic, given that from Sardinia there after the counting that would take place in Rome, he expected a strongly pro-monarchical vote. Salvatore Cicu, honor to him, with this resolution he was able to establish that the will of the Sardinian people will never again be ignored and trampled on. Congratulations on a great job!

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report As a party we are against the EU dictating the regional and economic plans for islands that belong to Member States, it's the individual nation's responsibility to create regional schemes for their Islands.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. - I support the European Parliament's Resolution on the special situation of the Islands brought to us by the Committee on Regional Development. I recognize the complex situation that various island regions face and their geographical, natural and demographic limitations. I agree that the Commission is asked to carry out an in-depth study of the additional costs incurred by the characteristics of the island, in terms of the transport system for people and goods, energy supply and access to markets, in particular for SMEs; I also agree with the need for better connectivity by sea, better access to ports and better air transport services. However, I stress, as Mrs Sofia Ribeiro has already mentioned, that better attention to the problems of island regions cannot translate into less attention or even disinvestment in the outermost regions that are specifically provided for and protected in the European Treaties.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing.- I agree with what was expressed by some of my colleagues who, in the course of the debate, highlighted the need to review the priority objectives within the strategic framework of future programming.Indeed, the Commission has up to now proposed actions for the outermost regions completely ignoring the situation of the islands, which live in a situation of marginalization, not only geographic, but also economic and social.There is no regional continuity and this means a lack of services and competition, putting SMEs to the test, creating a hostile environment for low cost airlines and multinationals.Therefore, I hope that the Commission will be able to pay more attention to the condition of the islands also through the provision of specific loans.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ Investing in the digital capacity of island regions is a vital means of counterbalancing the connectivity gaps of such regions, as industry may alleviate dependence on physical economies of scale.  Investments in infrastructure to ensure broadband access on islands and the full participation of islands in the digital single market are of crucial importance.  These will generate quality jobs for our graduates and address the brain drain issues which island regions like Gozo have been experiencing for years. Even in the case of small Member States like Malta, the difference between the sister islands of Gozo and Malta shows significant divergences in the socio-economic sphere. This justifies the importance of supporting the sensitive development of island regions, including those which are densely populated. I support the call for the setting up of an ‘islands desk’ linked to the Commission’s Directorate-General for Regional and Urban Policy (DG REGIO) made up of a small group of officials in order to coordinate and analyse issues relating to island regions. This will bring the EU closer to islands which often face insularity or double insularity. I have thus voted in favour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: written. - I voted in favor of this Resolution to support European institutions working in favor of financing and specific measures to address the peculiarities of island regions that, due to their extraordinary geographical conditions, tend to suffer more economic and development problems regional and population loss, which clearly goes against the objective set in the Treaties of reducing disparities between the different regions. For this reason, the Parliament Resolution requests, among other things, a comprehensive study of the additional costs of island areas, an improvement in funding sources and a White Paper that serves to monitor and be a source of consultation for best practices of the different actors. However, I must emphasize that this Resolution does not include the criticism that should be made of a global economic model that has damaged sustainable development in island areas, especially in those belonging to the most southern countries, where in general there has been almost a commitment to exclusivity for leisure tourism, without taking into account protected natural areas, or opportunities for economic diversification and quality employment. Anyway, my vote has been in favor.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing. - According to the resolution, all islands have an accessibility factor that is below the European average, even when taking into account shipping. Human capital is a serious problem for the islands, especially the Mediterranean islands: education levels are particularly low even in the islands with high GDP levels at the University's disposal. Insularity should therefore be recognized as a natural feature that negatively affects, directly and indirectly, the attractiveness of islands by creating obstacles to their sustainable development performance. This creates for these territories, I support a more targeted and more efficient use of existing funds as well as additional resources. Moreover, I believe that the proportion of funds spent under Cohesion Policy on isolated regions should be focused on the poorest EU Member States, and not on well-defined French, Spanish and Portuguese territories. Resolution incl. Calls on the Commission to establish an 'EU Strategic Framework for Islands' with a view to combining instruments that can have a significant territorial impact and Member States and regional and local authorities to play an important role in island development strategies based on a vertical approach involving all levels of governance; in line with the subsidiarity principle to guarantee the sustainable development of the EU's islands. Given the gravity of the problems that exist, I voted in favor of the resolution.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution that lists the European Parliament's priorities surrounding the specific characteristics and features of island regions and their implications for these islands.  Some of these characteristics and features distinguish islands from the mainland regions and serve as permanent handicaps that require particular attention from the European Commission. EU islands are many times particularly vulnerable to the challenges which Europe is currently facing, such as globalisation, demographic trends, climate change, energy supply and, especially for the southern areas, exposure to increasing migration flows. In this regard, I believe that further studies are required to see how additional flexibility can be inbuilt in the new cohesion policy post-2020 to address the specific challenges faced by territories suffering from permanent disadvantages, including island Member States and island regions.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I support the overall policy aims of the European regional policy of supporting less developed areas. However, I feel I have to abstain on this motion as the calls in the resolution for a new EU agenda, a new framework and additional white papers and studies that could open the door to additional financial support being pumped into this area. In the current challenging times where national governments are having to cut expenditure and bring down deficits across Europe, it would not be responsible to call for additional money to be allocated.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: signed up.- Based on the existence of permanent handicaps in island regions, due to their small size and remoteness from continental European coastal areas, handicaps which constitute obstacles to the physical development of islands and prevent them from achieving economic, social and territorial cohesion,The rapporteur's proposal to set up a homogeneous group of all island territories is beneficial.In order to carry out studies and analyzes on the additional costs generated by the insularity situation, I consider that other statistical indicators are needed to be taken into account, which may reflect the vulnerability of the islands, not only their gross domestic product.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: in writing.- This motion for a resolution puts forward a series of additional indicators to better reflect the specificities of island regions in the criteria for funding European programs.Although Article 174 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union specifies that island territories suffer from permanent handicaps which require special attention, the 2014-2020 financial programming does not provide for specific funding for these regions, but only thepossibility of modulating the co-financing rates for certain types of islands.MEPs propose, for example, to introduce the regional competitiveness index, which measures the economic and social vulnerability of these regions.Considering that island regions suffer from permanent and particular natural handicaps which hamper their development, I supported this resolution.

name: Rachida DATI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution on island regions.It is in fact necessary to take into account the difficulties, particularly economic ones, linked to the geographic particularities of island regions.I am particularly in favor of strengthening transport routes allowing better connectivity of these island regions with the rest of European territory.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this motion for a resolution to invite the European Commission to outline concrete measures for the permanent handicaps facing European islands.The approval of this resolution is an important step for our major Italian islands, Sicily and Sardinia, as their "condition of insularity" is recognized.Based on this recognition, the two islands will have the opportunity to have greater opportunities in terms of European resources and funds.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the resolution on the specific situation of the islands.Indeed, this Resolution underlines the specificities of the islands and the need for specific measures to respond to the challenges they face: climate change, connectivity, migration.In addition, following this vote, it is planned to publish a white paper on the development of islands, based on good practices and involving local, regional and national authorities.A real European strategic framework for the islands will thus be put in place.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing.- Despite laudable amendments defending appropriate taxation for island regions, this motion for a resolution validates the federalist project of the European Union.For example, it rejects the distinction between island-states and island-regions.In addition, it creates a homogeneous category relating to island regions.Being opposed to the federalist approach which opposes the nation-state and the necessary sovereignty which is attached to it, I voted against this text.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: In written form. - I abstained on this resolution because I do not fully agree with some of the proposals made in it. I agree that the EU's islands, as peripheral areas, are particularly vulnerable to the challenges that Europe is currently facing. In particular, the southern regions are exposed to increasing migration flows. These island regions are also leading tourist destinations, which also contribute to the EU's diversity in terms of both culture and the environment; have the capacity to contribute to sustainable development with their potential for energy production from renewable sources or due to their specific location. However, I do not think that the European Commission has yet to create special instruments to help these areas. In view of the crisis facing the EU, I believe that a better solution would be for Member States with such island territories to develop a strategy for better absorption of European funds and better work with existing instruments.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: in writing.- It is proposed to vote against the report as the text dictates the financial support of the island areas in order to deal with the large influx of illegal immigrants.This fact will cause a significant increase in the number of illegal immigrants that our country will receive.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: written. - The island regions, which I know well from coming from the Balearic Islands, have peculiar common and permanent characteristics, which clearly distinguish them from other continental areas. In this regard, the Commission should provide a clear definition of the type of permanent geographical, natural and demographic handicaps that island regions may suffer, pursuant to Article 174 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU). The problems arising from insularity are reflected in multiple areas, such as access to regions and connections within islands, transportation costs and energy supply. They are also regions far from the main administrative and economic centers, in which a balanced territorial development must be supported through innovation and competitiveness. In-depth studies and analysis should be promoted on the repercussions generated by the condition of insularity and the possible creation of an EU strategic framework for the islands that articulates the instruments that may have a significant territorial impact.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing.- The special situation of the islands deserves a series of measures that take into account the permanent natural and geographical limitations of these regions that distinguish them from the continental territories.The need for better connectivity by sea and better air transport services are fundamental to attract investment, create new jobs and reduce the costs of air and sea transport of people and goods.The situation of agriculture, livestock and fishing, the impacts of climate change, tourism, local production, the enormous potential of wind, solar and ocean energy, the impact of the economic crisis, the investments in infrastructure necessary to guarantee thebroadband access in the islands and the promotion of innovation and competitiveness in these regions are other measures to be taken into account.I voted in favor.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - This resolution focuses on the particular situation of the islands, as peripheral regions located at the EU's external borders, being particularly susceptible to the constraints resulting from globalization, demography (very significant depopulation), climate change, energy supply and the migration crisis. This situation is more serious in countries intervened by the troika. These regions, which are already more fragile, suffer from the general disinvestment of the EU in cohesion strategies. The resolution proposes the use of European Structural and Investment Funds, in synergy with other financing, to strengthen cohesion in these territories. Good intentions, but unfortunately few means. Some observations regarding the European Commission's approach to the situation of insularity: the understanding of the islands as a homogeneous territorial group, from the point of view of intervention, without considering regional specificities and the strategy of the Member States in which they operate for these regions; the danger of some bureaucratization, with little concrete action and, above all, scarcity of effective (namely financial) means. The experience of Portugal and the application of European policies on the islands shows that there are other factors to be unblocked, such as the agricultural issue (milk) in the Azores and the creation of responses and social services and economic diversification that can contribute to greater cohesion. This resolution is clearly insufficient, but in a generally positive sense.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution as a whole.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing - Island regions have in common and specific characteristics and features that clearly distinguish them from continental regions and therefore require special attention.It is therefore important for the European Commission to explain how it intends to apply the wording of Article 174 TFEU with regard to the permanent handicaps of island regions, which hinder their natural development and prevent them from achieving economic, social and territorial cohesion.I therefore support the European Parliament's call for the European Commission to present a communication containing a program for the islands of the European Union and, consequently, a White Paper on monitoring island development, based on best practice and involving local, regional and national authorities and other relevant actors, including economic andsocial partners and representatives of civil society.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing.- I am voting in favor of the report to ask for greater attention to island regions and mountain areas.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: in writing.- I am voting against the relevant report as the text dictates the financial support of the island areas in order to deal with the large influx of illegal immigrants.This will cause a significant increase in the number of illegal immigrants that my country will receive.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Island regions have common and specific characteristics and features that clearly distinguish them from mainland regions such, as certain permanent handicaps which require particular attention. This is why I believe it is very important to know which are the specific instruments and the resources of cohesion policy to tackle the handicaps arising from the insularity and how will deal the EC in the future with the permanent handicaps of these regions, as a permanent obstacle which may affect the achievement of the objectives of the Cohesion Policy.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: written.- I voted in favor convinced that it is necessary to provide a clear definition of the type of permanent handicaps of a geographic, natural and demographic nature that island regions may suffer, in accordance with Article 174 TFEU.It is important to bear in mind the importance of providing support to combat the trend of significant depopulation in island regions.The Commission should establish an EU strategic framework for the islands with the aim of linking instruments that can have a strong territorial impact.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing.- The recognition by the European Parliament of the condition of insularity as a situation of structural deficit that requires appropriate economic corrections is an important step in the battle in favor of the Italian islands.I congratulate my colleagues and in particular my colleague Salvatore Cicu for the effort and tenacity shown.It is now important to act in the appropriation chapters of regional policy so that the condition of island status is also supported financially.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: written.- I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution on island regions because I know the special demands and conditions of such regions from my own home in Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania and EU policies have to take this into account.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: written.- Island regions must have a good infrastructure.This is essential for the effective use of the oceans for energy generation.At the same time, islands offer great potential for further economic development.That is why I am committed to ensuring that islands and their economic development will gain even more importance and support in the future.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I support this report, which underlines that island regions have common and specific characteristics and features that clearly distinguish them from mainland regions, such as certain permanent handicaps which require particular attention. It is vital that the Commission takes account of these characteristics when developing instruments and resources in the framework of the cohesion policy to tackle the handicaps arising from the insularity.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: written.- We voted in favor since we agree that, in accordance with Council Directive 2006/112 / EC, certain European islands (including the outermost region of the Canary Islands) are granted a special tax regime to correctinequalities due to multiple causes related to the condition of insularity.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour to the resolution on insularity condition. The parliament recognises, in accordance with the Eurostat definition, the difference between islands in general and islands with a national capital, and the importance of providing support to tackle the significant depopulation trend in island regions. Moreover, the Commission is encouraged to provide a clear definition of the type of geographical, natural and demographic permanent handicaps that insular regions can suffer from, with reference to Article 174 of the TFEU.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE / NGL), in writing. - We supported the report on Insularity as it proposes concrete measures to address the permanent disadvantages faced by the European islands. The text also points out the unique difficulties faced by the increased migration flows of the southern island regions of Europe and calls for the continuation of the special tax arrangements for the islands, "especially of the countries subject to economic adjustment programs". In particular, calls on the Commission (a) to set up, under Article 174 TFEU, which recognizes the permanent disadvantages of island regions, a homogeneous group of all island regions, (b) to take into account, in addition to GDP, and other statistical indicators that reflect economic and social vulnerability as a result of natural permanent handicaps, (c) conduct an in-depth study / analysis of the additional costs of living in island regions transport, energy supply and market access and finally to present a communication on the "EU Islands Agenda" and then a White Paper on monitoring the development of islands.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this resolution because I welcome an efficient and effective plan with regards to insular regions. Studies must be made in order to determine the levels of energy supplies, transport, access to markets, and even the impact of the 2015 refugee wave.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written. - I voted in favor of the Resolution on the Islands on the basis of an oral question, given that I was one of the initiators of asking such a question to the Commission and preparing a European Parliament resolution, which I supported as ALDE Group coordinator on the REGI Committee. I believe that the EU needs to address this issue more specifically, given that citizens living on the islands have different and more difficult living conditions than EU citizens living in the mainland. Of course, a distinction needs to be made between the different types of islands in the EU that vary in size, population, distance from the mainland, and some islands represent member states. In addition, there is a different sensibility to this issue, given that some Member States either do not have islands or they are uninhabited and therefore do not represent a relevant political issue. I am particularly interested in pointing out the problems of islands, such as in Croatia, which have a problem of depopulation and numerous difficulties such as shortages of public services, expensive goods or services. Therefore, I fully agree that the EU should also show additional sensibility through cohesion policy and enable balanced social and economic development and the preservation of the quality of life of citizens living on islands through its measures.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: in writing.- The motion for a resolution in question uses the expression "islands of the European Union" and is based on Article 174 of the TFEU with the aim of creating a homogeneous group which would include all the island regions, as is already the case with the mountainous regions group.This text is therefore part of a federalist approach that we cannot support.Therefore, with my colleagues from the National Front, we voted against.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – My fellow UKIP colleagues and I voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. As a party we are against the EU dictating the regional and economic plans for islands that belong to Member States, it's the individual nation's responsibility to create regional schemes for their Islands.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written.- I am voting in favor of this resolution because islands, especially in view of the prevailing influx of refugees, need better support.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing.- The economic crisis has severely limited the availability of financing in many sectors, generating a collapse in public investment.This state of affairs has strongly affected the development of many disadvantaged regions, and especially of the islands.I therefore decided to strongly support this motion for a resolution to ask for favorable measures that take into account the specific characteristics of the islands and the territorial discontinuity.Our first objective must be to exploit the synergies between the various European resources, to develop our infrastructures and improve connections in terms of air, rail and sea transport.We must be able to use the available funds effectively, within a strategic vision, and not to plug budget gaps.Only from these conditions can the revitalization of our territories start again.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: in writing.- I voted against the resolution on island regions.This motion for a resolution speaks of "the islands of the European Union" and uses Article 174 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union to create a homogeneous group comprising all the island regions, like the mountainous regions.This motion for a resolution attempts to validate the federalist project of the European Union.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: in writing.- I voted against this resolution because it reveals the federalist project of the Union by creating a common framework for what it calls the "islands of the European Union", whereas these are islands whichcome under the sovereignty of their respective states.Corsica and Martinique, to take just these two examples, are French islands and not "Union islands"!

name: Petr MACH
text: in writing.- It is pointless for the EU to have a policy towards the islands of the Member States, nor do I agree with the redistribution of money through the Structural Funds as such.It is unbelievable what nonsense Members of the European Parliament are able to write on paper.For example, Parliament "encourages the Commission to […] provide a clear definition of the permanent geographical, natural and demographic handicaps suffered by island regions" (point 1), "calls on the Commission to launch a thorough study / analysis on the excessive costs to islandsin connection with passenger and freight transport, energy supply and access to markets "(point 4) and, best of all," calls on the Commission to submit a proposal for a European Year of Islands and Mountains "(point 16).Voters will surely get a picture of the meaningfulness of these MEPs' challenges.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing - Island countries belonging to the European Union require a special approach due to their specific location features.In order to address islands' problems and the costs involved in a transparent way, the Commission needs to define the geographical, natural and demographic permanent handicaps of islands, which prevent them from achieving economic, social and territorial cohesion.Such a definition will form the basis for the elaboration of a strategy for EU islands.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing.- I support the Motion for a Resolution on the special situation of the islands for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech in the Plenary Session of the European Parliament on 4/2/2016 and because this Motion for a Resolution is complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing.- I voted against this text.The motion for a resolution speaks of "the islands of the European Union" and uses Article 174 of the TFEU to create a homogeneous group bringing together all the island regions, as it had already done for the mountainous regions.This motion for a resolution validates the federalist project of the Union, and amalgamates all the regions, thus forgetting their particularities and their specific needs.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this resolution, which ‘Calls on the Commission to submit a communication containing an “Agenda for EU Islands” and, subsequently, a White Paper to monitor the development of islands, based on best practice and involving local, regional and national authorities and other relevant actors, including economic and social partners and representatives of civil society’.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: written.- The island regions need special treatment and solidarity from the whole of the European Union to compensate for the differences that cause their inhabitants to have fewer opportunities than those who live on the continent.Europe must continue working to promote a harmonious development of all its territories and for this reason it is necessary to take measures for those regions that suffer from geographical disadvantages, such as the islands of course.In this sense, particular sensitivity is required by the islands that also have the status of outermost regions, as is the case of the land from which I come, the Canary Islands.My support, therefore, for this motion for a resolution in which we collect a large part of the challenges that these territories face and the need for the EU to continue supporting their development.

name: Georg MAYER
text: written.- The core of the application is that the island regions should receive additional funds and that further bodies such as the "island department" should be set up.Regions that are particularly suffering from the migration storm should be given more support.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the resolution in which the European Parliament assessed the special situation of the islands, which had a major impact on the development potential of many disadvantaged regions, including islands.EU islands, peripheral regions at the EU's external borders, are particularly vulnerable to the challenges that Europe is currently facing, such as globalization, demographic trends, climate change, energy supply and, especially in the southern regions, the growing impact of migratory flows.In the resolution, the European Parliament called on the Commission to provide a clear definition of the types of permanent geographical, natural and demographic handicaps faced by island regions and to explain how the Commission intends to address them in order to promote island development and economic, social and territorial cohesion.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: in writing. - This resolution calls for better consideration of the particularities of island regions, whether they be the geographical, natural and demographic handicaps of the islands as well as their inherent potential. The islands are all facades open to the world, particularly in the French case. With 11 million km2 of maritime surface, France is the second largest maritime territory in the world. I proposed, especially during Assises de la Mer, to make this new border a major axis for the ecological revival of activity. The resolution goes in this direction: development of alternative energies (marine, wind and solar), local markets essential by their insularity, new maritime routes and sustainable management of fishing. Many islands have special tax regimes to compensate for their natural and demographic handicaps. My comrade Nikolaos Chountis called for the maintenance of these regimes, in particular in Member States, such as Greece, which are the subject of memoranda. I deeply regret that his amendment did not pass. Support for sustainable activity is once again hampered by EU austerity. However, I am voting for the text which goes in the right direction.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: in writing.- The motion for a resolution in question here uses the expression "islands of the European Union" and is based on Article 174 of the TFEU with the aim of creating a homogeneous group which would include all the island regions, as is already the case with the mountainous regions group.Also, I cannot accept the federalist vocation of this text.Therefore, I voted against.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the resolution on the special situation of the islands.Island regions have common characteristics that distinguish them from continental territories.It is extremely important for the EU to establish a strategic framework for the islands, with the aim of ensuring their sustainable development.In view of the specific situation of the islands, financial reinforcement in the next multiannual financial framework will be extremely important.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ Coming from one of the Union's island Members I voted in favour of this resolution because it is vital to support European islands. The resolution calls attention to, among others, sustainable development on the islands, accessibility of regions, migration, climate change, and access to markets.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: in writing. - Island regions group together islands within the EU which have common characteristics such as permanent nature, cultural diversity, environmental diversity. Suffering the full brunt of the economic and migration crises, they have now become particularly vulnerable. It is therefore necessary to bridge economic, social and environmental gaps in order to ensure their development, in particular by fully exploiting their high potential for producing renewable energies. Reducing the gap between these regions means not only supporting agriculture, animal husbandry and fishing, which are major sectors for island economies, but also strengthening connectivity by improving maritime routes, access to ports and air transport services. The project submitted to us will improve economic growth, job creation and sustainable development; three factors which are crucial for the future of the Union.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing - Island regions are an exceptional asset for European culture. The historical heritage of Europeans and the original way of life are preserved in a special way in these places, they represent a kind of entry into European culture. However, these areas are exposed to many pitfalls. They face harsh weather conditions and natural disasters, insufficient job opportunities, as they often live off tourism that thrives only at certain times, and are now largely the first contact of migrants coming from the Middle East or Africa by sea with European soil. Islands that do not have sufficient financial or human resources will find it very difficult to deal with such serious issues. I agree with the rapporteur that the situation of the islands requires a solution at European level and that the Commission should adopt instruments that will bring about positive change through the creation of appropriate programs and financial assistance.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Insularity condition urging the European Commission to take concrete steps to address the permanent handicaps that EU islands face and make full use of their potential. I believe that we need to stress the unique difficulties that southern insular regions face due to the increased migration flows and that special tax regimes should continue. I also strongly support the creation of "a homogenous group made up of all island territories", based on EU Treaty Article 174, which recognises the permanent handicaps of insular regions. In addition, the southern areas such as Malta are particularly exposed to increased migration flows, therefore we need a EU-wide joint approach to support those areas and islands.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing.- The motion for a resolution tabled by the Committee on Regional Development proposes that Parliament draw the attention of the Commission, the Member States and regional and local authorities to the disadvantages of islands in the European Union.This disadvantage includes, inter alia, the trend of depopulation, the additional costs of the transport system, energy supply and market access, interconnections by sea, problems of access to ports and air transport, access to the digital single market, education, migration.prevails.It calls on the addressees to draw up a strategy and take measures to make a major contribution to the development of island regions and to overcoming these disadvantages.I supported the resolution.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. - The Regional Development Commission wanted to analyze and discuss the preponderance that the Islands assume in European territory, using Article 174 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) which recognizes the specific permanent natural and geographical limitations due to the situation of Islands. I vote in favor of this motion for a resolution because I believe it is necessary to improve connectivity by sea, increase the development of ports and air transport services, as well as enhance the development of sustainable tourism, in addition to seasonal tourism, focusing on the promotion of cultural heritage and specific artisanal economic activities. It is also important to note that the Islands have been undergoing severe climatic changes, including an increasing number of natural disasters, have a strong potential in terms of renewable energies and investments to be made in the area of ​​the sea economy. Nonetheless, it is important to safeguard that any existing support for the islands can never undermine what already exists for the Outermost Regions that have much deeper economic, social and natural constraints than the Islands.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: in writing.- This motion for a resolution on island regions adds another stone to the Euro-federalist edifice.Indeed, it speaks of "islands of the European Union" (whereas they are islands belonging to States…) and uses article 174 of the TFEU to create a homogeneous group bringing together all the regions.islanders, like the group of mountainous regions.I therefore voted against this text, because the only framework for sustainable development of island regions must remain the national framework.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution on the specific situation of islands in the European Union.This text underlines the handicaps, but also the natural advantages specific to island regions.He calls for this to be taken into account and for measures to be taken, in particular fiscal measures, to develop activities in the areas of the environment and connectivity.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: in writing.- In my opinion, the specific features of the islands justify the use of specific measures to respond as accurately as possible to the challenges they are facing.I therefore voted in favor of the resolution.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ European Islands are peripheral regions situated on the EU’s external borders that are particularly vulnerable to challenges that Europe is facing, such as demographic trends, globalisation, climate change, energy supply and, especially for southern areas, exposure to increasing migration flows. I have voted for this motion for a resolution that calls on the Commission to provide a clear definition of the type of geographical, natural and demographic handicaps that insular regions suffer from in order to provide targeted support.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: In written form. - I supported this resolution because I strongly believe that disadvantaged areas, which include most rural areas in addition to islands, areas affected by the industrial transition, as well as regions affected by severe and permanent adverse natural or demographic conditions, with cross-border and mountain areas deserving of special attention by the Community, which must have a financial and planning impact. These regions often have unique livelihoods, traditions and characteristics. In pursuit of sustainable economic growth, Europe is investing more and more resources in highly urbanized and already favored areas for a number of reasons. However, geographically more remote or isolated areas are not only a periphery, but are also about to become objects of economic and social isolation, because they cannot always meet the criteria for economic return, which in most cases are based on experience and statistics from urbanized and highly developed regions. I also support the call for this year to declare a 'Year of the Islands and Mountains', because such an initiative and the accompanying other initiatives would help to overcome the economic and social difficulties facing these specific regions.

name: Dan NICA
text: signed up. - The economic crisis has had a dramatic impact on national and regional budgets in many Member States by limiting the availability of funding in many sectors, leading to a 20% drop in public investment. The crisis has also severely affected development opportunities in many disadvantaged regions, including the islands, increased poverty and social exclusion and hampered the Union's long-term goal of economic and territorial cohesion. Given the islands' high potential for renewable energy production due to specific exposure to wind, tidal and sunlight, European islands can become important alternative energy sources. The islands can help strengthen sustainable development in the Union, guarantee their energy autonomy and energy at more affordable prices for the inhabitants. An essential means of counteracting the disadvantages of island regions' connectivity is digital capacity. I stress that investment in infrastructure is needed to ensure broadband access to the islands and their full participation in the digital single market.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report because it not only promises a fairer distribution of burdens and grants for the island regions that are currently particularly burdened, especially in the Mediterranean, of course, but also suggests positive effects for mountain regions at the same time.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. As a party we are against the EU dictating the regional and economic plans for islands that belong to Member States; it is the individual nation’s responsibility to create regional schemes for their Islands.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing.- On 28 June 2013 the European Council decided to start accession negotiations with Serbia, a country that aspires to become a member of the EU.Two years later, the Commission reported on the excellent progress made by the country towards European integration, I would therefore have voted positively, declaring admiration and support for this country.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - As this is about solving the everyday problems that the inhabitants of the island regions face, I believe that it is necessary to provide clear support measures to the regions NUTS-2 and NUTS-3. The NUTS-2 category includes island regions with a population ranging between 800,000 and 3,000,000 inhabitants, while the NUTS-3 category includes island regions with a population ranging between 150,000 and 800,000 inhabitants. Due to all the difficult conditions facing the islands of these regions, I believe that it is necessary not only to adopt support measures but also to implement them in order to help the local population as much as possible in facing their daily life challenges.
