The islands classified in the island regions NUTS-2 and NUTS-3 have common and specific permanent characteristics and elements that clearly distinguish them from the mainland regions. Therefore, I believe that the problems that the island population has to face every day require full attention and great effort in solving them, ie the islands should benefit from special measures and additional funding to neutralize the negative social and economic situation to which they are exposed.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: in writing.- This report aims to create a special category for the islands which are in the territory of the Member States of the European Union.It is therefore a further step towards federalism and the destruction of nations for the benefit of a regionalization decided without the approval of the peoples, or even against their opinion (like the Treaty of Lisbon overriding the will of the French andof the Dutch).It does not make sense to create an "island" category as if Ireland, the Isle of Sein, Malta, the Balearics, Great Britain and Corsica were in identical situations.I am therefore voting against this text, which is as pernicious as it is insane.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written. - There are a lot of problems faced by islanders, from the fact that islands lag behind the mainland GDP on average through depopulation, poor connectivity and access to health care to high cost of living, access to education, etc. But GDP is not a sufficient criterion of the island because it does not include other parameters that make life on the island more complex and difficult. However, each island is a unique natural, cultural and economic whole. We can discuss different definitions, but I think we have not done enough for the European islands to meet the obligations of Article 174 of the Lisbon Treaty. In the EU institutions, policies towards islands have never taken root in full. I come from Croatia, a country with over 1,200 islands, and I join the calls for the Commission to make an analysis of the cost of living on the islands and adjust financial support and programs accordingly. We need a strategic program and a special EU agenda for the islands to at least partially make up for lost time and help them reach their full potential. In conclusion, I support this resolution because it provides a good basis for continuing action and improving European policies towards the islands. At the same time, I hope that the Commission will react soon and respond to the demands it makes.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. - The particular situation of the islands, peripheral regions located at the EU's external borders, which are more susceptible to the constraints resulting from globalization, demographic fluctuations, climate change, the supply of energy or the migratory crisis stands out. A reality that is aggravated in the countries intervened by the troika. Regions of enormous fragility that suffer from the EU's general divestment in cohesion strategies. The resolution proposes to strengthen cohesion in these territories through the mobilization of European Structural and Investment Funds, in synergy with other financing. "Wills" expressed to which the means do not correspond. The European Commission's approach to the situation of insularity has some limitations: the understanding of islands as a homogeneous territorial group from the point of view of intervention, without considering regional specificities and the strategy of the respective Member States; the danger of bureaucratization of the mechanisms, which will result in limited concrete action and scarcity of means, namely financial. The experience of Portugal and the European policies for insularity shows that there are other factors to unblock, such as the agricultural issue (milk) in the Azores and the creation of social and economic diversification responses and services that can contribute to greater cohesion. This resolution, although manifestly insufficient, has a positive general sense.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: written. - One of the tasks of the Commission should be to provide a clear definition of the types of geographical, natural and demographic permanent handicaps that may affect island areas, with regard to Art. 174 of the Agreement on the Functioning of the EU. It would also be very helpful for the Commission to explain how it plans to implement Art. 174 of the above-mentioned Agreement, which deals with the permanent handicaps of island regions which slow down the development of the region in terms of natural development and the achievement of economic, social and territorial cohesion. The EU's islands are peripheral regions located at the EU's external borders and are particularly vulnerable to the challenges facing the EU, such as globalization, demographic trends, climate change, energy supply and exposure to growing migration. The European islands contribute to the diversity of the Union in ecological and cultural terms and therefore better connectivity through maritime routes, improved access to ports and better air transport services are essential. It is also important to emphasize the need to support the balanced territorial development of island regions by promoting innovation and competitiveness in these regions and strengthening local products for local markets. It is important that this resolution helps the activities in Croatia in order to connect the islands with the mainland, but also with each other, and to use all available instruments to finance the development of the island from EU funds.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. - The island regions, classified at Community level, as NUTS-2 and NUTS-3 regions, have common characteristics and specificities that clearly distinguish them from regions located on the mainland. Article 174 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) recognizes that they suffer from concrete disadvantages that require specific attention. I voted in favor of this motion for a resolution to ask the Commission to provide a clear definition of the type of permanent natural or demographic handicaps, under Article 174 TFEU, which island regions are considered to face. It would be desirable to launch an in-depth analysis of the additional costs incurred by islands, such as those related to the transport system or energy supply, and to establish a "European strategic framework for islands" which includes a number of concrete instruments that they could have a strong territorial impact. The islands of the European Union are very often also peripheral regions located on the external borders of the EU and therefore particularly exposed to the arrival of migratory flows. For this reason, I believe it is appropriate to maintain the special tax regimes aimed at offsetting not only their permanent geographical disadvantages, but also the costs due to the huge migratory phenomena underway.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing.- I fully supported the resolution on island regions, which did not raise any particular difficulty.It underlines the specificities of the islands and the need to plan specific measures to respond to the challenges they face (climate change, connectivity, migration, etc.).Let us remember that the European Union has, thanks to France, outposts throughout the world.This gives us a strength of representativeness and constitutes a showcase in remote areas.The resolution also proposes a European Year of Islands and Mountains.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. - This European Parliament resolution expands and emphasizes the concerns expressed in the question submitted to the Commission on the situation of insularity in the territories of the European Union at NUTS-2 and NUTS-3 levels. According to the rapporteur, the specific situation of the islands was not taken into account when preparing the proposal for the current multiannual financial framework and, therefore, it is essential to define the terms that, in relation to insularity, allow the preparation of the next multiannual financial framework. In this sense, Parliament is now calling for a clear definition of the types of permanent natural or demographic limitations faced by island regions, as well as the determination of the procedures envisaged by the Commission to address the permanent handicaps faced by the islands. Also in this case, the letter of the treaties, which, in Article 174 TFEU, recognizes the particular attention required by island territories must be respected. In light of the provisions and considering that the report is in line with the main objectives of cohesion policy, in general, and the needs of the autonomous regions of Portugal, in particular, I voted in favor of the report under consideration.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report As a party we are against the EU dictating the regional and economic plans for islands that belong to Member States, it's the individual nation's responsibility to create regional schemes for their Islands.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. - This document encourages the Commission to provide a clear definition of the type of permanent geographical, natural and demographic limitations that can affect island regions, with reference to Article 174 TFEU. Firstly, I voted in favor of this resolution as it refers to a set of measures that are crucial for island regions: greater connectivity by sea, better access to ports; better air services; low taxes and bureaucracy reduction policies as key incentives to attract investment; development of sustainable tourism; and creating synergies between the European Structural and Investment Funds and the other instruments of the Union. Secondly, by agreeing with the recommendations that are addressed to the Commission, especially the preparation of the proposal for the next multiannual financial framework, in which it should be taken taking into account the specific situation of the islands. Thirdly, because at no time is there an attempt to equate the concept of islands with that of the Outermost Regions (RUP), recognizing that they present greater constraints and limitations in all the points previously mentioned. I therefore agree that it is necessary for Member States and regional and local authorities to play an important role in the islands' sustainable development strategies.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: written.- The island regions, classified as NUTS-2 and NUTS-3 regions, have common characteristics and particularities that are permanently manifested and clearly distinguish them from continental territories.Article 174 of the TFEU recognizes that all island regions face permanent handicaps that require special attention.However, in the framework of the preparation of the financial programming period 2014-2020, the island regions of the EU at the NUTS-2 and NUTS-3 levels did not receive any specific funding, but only the possibility of modulation of feesof co-financing for certain types of island, in accordance with article 121 of Regulation (EU) No. 1303/2013.For these reasons, I support the resolution adopted by the European Parliament in order to correct these shortcomings.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing. - Yesterday, we voted for a resolution on island regions with a view to drawing the attention of the European Commission to the specificities and handicaps facing European islands. The voted text regrets that the characteristics and particularities common to the islands, however provided for in Article 174 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU), are not taken into account for the period 2014-2020, while these are "markedly" distinct from the characteristics of continental regions. In this context, we have asked the Commission: - to clearly define the type of natural or permanent demographic handicaps referred to in Article 174; - determine the specific instruments and means of cohesion policy with a view to correcting the handicaps of insularity; - to clarify the means it intends to implement to verify compliance with the conditions referred to in Article 174; - take into account indicators other than GDP, which would incorporate the specificities of island regions, such as the regional competitiveness index.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution because it draws attention to the difficult situation of islands in the European Union.The text refers to the influx of large numbers of migrants into the Mediterranean islands, many of them are still on the fringes and do not have adequate digital capacity, they do not exploit the potential of wind, solar and water, which can become important sources of alternative energy.In my opinion, this is a very important aspect that would allow the islands to at least partially solve their problems and help their inhabitants to save money.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing.- It is well known that island regions have common particularities that manifest themselves permanently and distinguish them from continental territories, thus presenting permanent natural and geographical limitations due, precisely, to their island condition.It is important that there are economic indicators other than GDP and better connectivity by sea and air, capable of guaranteeing a more balanced territorial development and greater competitiveness in these regions.I therefore consider it important to consider the existence of a European strategic framework for the islands, establishing synergies between the different financial instruments of the Union, and a strengthening of the role of Member States and regional and local authorities, respecting the principle of subsidiarityand ensure their sustainable development, economic growth and job creation.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing.- The resolution voted today stems from the need to respect the peculiarities of each individual country and region.The island areas, by their nature, have different geographical conditions from the others, which means that they also have different needs for this reason it is necessary that the legislation takes into account these specificities.With this text, we ask the Commission to review the objectives for the island territories, to create greater synergy between the structural funds and other instruments made available by the EU and to establish a Union strategic framework for the islands.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: written.- We voted in favor since we agree that, in accordance with Council Directive 2006/112 / EC, certain European islands (including the outermost region of the Canary Islands) are granted a special tax regime to correctinequalities due to multiple causes related to the condition of insularity.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. ‒ The removed paragraph stating that ‘certain handicaps are more difficult to cope with for islands than for island states’ was spurious and less than valid, with reference to island archipelagos with a population of less than say 2 million, as I vouch from personal experience. Let me note too the significant problems that arise for islands without a national capital attached to an island state. Here, given the double insularity, depopulation persists even when economic growth prevails. Purely quantitative measures fail to account for this problem. I refer to the island of Gozo. Even now, with economic growth running at over 4 per cent per annum in the Maltese islands, young people in Gozo tell you they have no future on their island. Depopulation will become irreversible unless exceptional measures are allowed which do not necessarily comply with wider EU rules and policies.  These would involve a deeper economic intervention of the public sector in partnership with private business to create new enterprises, new jobs especially for young people. Digital ventures, financial services, artisanal and farming enterprises, and health services could all be targeted to reverse depopulation, both when the national economy is performing healthily and when it is weak.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: in writing.- In line with Eurostat's definition, I recognize the difference between islands in general and islands with a national capital, as well as the importance of supporting efforts to reverse the depopulation trend in island regions.I would like to remind you that certain disadvantages, including those related to their limited size and distance to the European mainland, are more difficult to deal with for islands than for island states.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: written. - I voted in favor of this Resolution to support European institutions working in favor of financing and specific measures to address the peculiarities of island regions that, due to their extraordinary geographical conditions, tend to suffer more economic and development problems regional and population loss, which clearly goes against the objective set in the Treaties of reducing disparities between the different regions. For this reason, the Parliament Resolution requests, among other things, a comprehensive study of the additional costs of island areas, an improvement in funding sources and a White Paper that serves to monitor and be a source of consultation for best practices of the different actors. However, I must emphasize that this Resolution does not include the criticism that should be made of a global economic model that has damaged sustainable development in island areas, especially in those belonging to the most southern countries, where in general there has been almost a commitment to exclusivity for leisure tourism, without taking into account protected natural areas, or opportunities for economic diversification and quality employment. Anyway, my vote has been in favor.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. - Island regions have common characteristics and specificities that clearly distinguish them from regions located on the mainland. However, the European Union has so far made little effort to adjust its policies taking into account the singular difficulties many islands face in successfully competing with continental territories. I refer in particular to disadvantages such as accessibility to services, higher prices due to transport costs, difficulty in accessing the single market, lack of infrastructure, vulnerability to environmental risks, scarcity of raw materials and defense. from illegal immigration. All these challenges facing islands on a permanent basis have not yet been adequately taken into account by European legislation. I therefore voted in favor of the report because it calls for the difficulties linked to the condition of insularity to be recognized and all possible synergies between the European Structural and Investment Funds and the other Union instruments to be exploited. I hope that with improved existing policies and more efficient use of available resources, island regions can overcome their obstacles in terms of economic growth, job creation and sustainable development.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing.- The development of an economic and social model capable of promoting social and territorial cohesion is an anchoring foundation for the European Union.As cultural, economic and territorial diversity is one of the greatest assets of the European space, the intensification of differentiated policies in response to different realities tends to constitute a positive contribution to the desired harmonious development.The challenge of attending to the characteristics and particularities of island territories, immediately distinguishing those that are the sources of permanent disadvantage makes perfect sense.Economic, social and territorial disparities must be given special treatment.The densification of article 174 is necessary and may become significant.It is, therefore, pertinent the path that is now proposed to proceed.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing - This special situation of islands must be taken into account as a natural feature which negatively affects, either directly or indirectly, the attractiveness of islands and consequently creates obstacles to their sustainable development.This does not offer equal opportunities for these areas and for the rest of the European Union.Nevertheless, I abstained in voting on this resolution.I think we should focus on all regions of the EU where there are specific obstacles that hinder their sustainable development.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing - The main objectives of cohesion policy are to reduce economic, social and environmental disparities between regions and to achieve polycentric harmonious development. Island regions are classified as NUTS 2 and NUTS 3 regions and have permanent and distinctive features that clearly distinguish them from inland areas. Islands face constraints, but also benefit from territorial potential, which should be used as an opportunity for development, growth and job creation. Today, many Mediterranean islands have experienced huge numbers of incoming migrants and have to face this situation, so a holistic EU approach is needed, including EU support and the joint efforts of all Member States. It is important for the development of islands to exploit all possible synergies between the European Structural and Investment Funds and other Union instruments in order to offset the disadvantages of islands and improve their situation in terms of economic growth, job creation and sustainable development. I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution because I consider the development of the islands and the creation of conditions for their development to be very important from the point of view of regional development.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of the resolution on the condition of insularity, which contains some recommendations to tackle the problems related to it, such as economic and social vulnerability, the additional costs incurred for transport, energy supply and access to the markets. As an elected representative of two island regions, I believe it is necessary to support the islands, which show greater difficulties than other regions in overcoming a physiological delay in development and in pursuing growth in line with the objectives of European cohesion policy. Among the priority issues are the distance from the main production centers and the difficulty of accessing the large European networks, but also the problems linked to migratory flows to which many Mediterranean islands are exposed. Instruments such as special tax regimes - previously granted to certain island regions - are for example useful devices to counterbalance the natural and demographic handicaps of island realities. I am convinced that it is possible to overcome the disadvantage caused by insularity by putting islands on the network immediately, that is, by guaranteeing them access to digital, energy and transport networks. That is why I hope that the Commission will carefully consider the proposals contained in this resolution and take concrete initiatives quickly.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: written. - Island regions have common and permanent special features that distinguish them from continental areas. The EU's islands are also peripheral regions at the EU's external borders and are particularly vulnerable to the challenges currently facing Europe, such as globalization, demographic trends, climate change, energy supply and, in particular, the southern regions. , exposure to increasing migratory flows. Intensive tourism that takes place only at certain times of the year and is not properly planned out of season can pose a threat to the sustainable development of island regions. Digital capacity is a key means of compensating for the problem of connectivity of island regions. Infrastructure investments are needed to guarantee broadband internet access on the islands and the full participation of the islands in the digital single market. The islands face constraints, but they also have territorial potential that should be used as an opportunity for development, growth and job creation. In this context, in addition to seasonal tourism, the development of sustainable tourism is mentioned, with a focus on promoting cultural heritage and special craft economic activities, also the huge potential of ocean, wind and sun energy and the possibility of islands becoming important sources of alternative energy. more autonomous and, above all, to guarantee their residents a cheaper energy supply.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written. - The islands of the European Union can be considered as peripheral regions located on the external borders of the Union. As such, they are particularly sensitive to the challenges that Europe is currently facing, such as globalization, climate change, energy supply. The southern areas are particularly exposed to migratory waves. The islands contribute to the Union's environmental and cultural diversity. Also, European islands can contribute to strengthening sustainable development in the Union as they have significant potential for renewable energy production such as wind, waves and sunlight. Parliament calls on the Member States, but also on regional and local authorities, to play an important role in island development in order to guarantee the sustainable development of the European Union's islands. I support the proposals made in this debate because I believe that the islands have the potential to be used for development, growth and job creation, not only in the context of seasonal tourism but also sustainable tourism. The focus should be on promoting cultural heritage and specific craft activities. It is important to note the huge energy potential of the sea, wind and sun, which could enable the islands to become important and autonomous sources of alternative energy.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution on the oral question on the special situation of the islands.I agree with the call on the Commission to draw up a clear definition of the types of permanent adverse geographical, natural and demographic conditions that may affect island regions, and to launch a thorough study / analysis of the additional costs of insularity in passenger and freight transport.energy and market access, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: in writing. - The resolution relates to the Member States where there are islands in their territory and which are facing huge problems in the face of current challenges. The resolution calls for immediate consideration of the shortcomings faced by the islands in planning the financing of the European Structural and Investment Funds in order to pursue best practices. It also calls on the Commission to immediately define the type of geographical, natural and demographic disadvantages that the islands have in relation to the mainland, which are obstacles to achieving their economic, social and territorial development. In addition to the challenges of the economic crisis which has created greater problems in reducing the island population and further problems in transport and transportation, the last two years the islands mainly in Greece and Italy are called to face the growing refugee flows, without substantial support and plan of the EU, which is sought through the relevant report. Also important are the reports on the creation of a strategic framework for the islands as well as the emphasis placed on the protection of habitats. That is why we voted in favor of the report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: in writing.- This text dictates the financial support of the island areas in order to deal with the large influx of illegal immigrants.However, this fact will cause a further increase in the number of illegal immigrants already arriving in our country.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: signed up. - The islands are specific geographical regions, which face a number of permanent natural handicaps, compared to the mainland. These generate economic, social and environmental disparities for island areas, making it difficult for tourists and businesses to access. The islands are also particularly vulnerable to the challenges facing Europe today, including migration flows, demographic trends (depopulation), climate change, energy supply. At the same time, in these regions there is a great potential for the production of wind, solar and wave energy, but also in the field of tourism, in addition to the traditional sectors of agriculture, animal husbandry and fishing. In this context, in line with the Union's objective of reducing regional disparities, the Commission is invited, through this motion for a resolution, to take the necessary measures to support the balanced development of those regions, in particular by supporting intermodal transport, investment in digital infrastructure, investment in education, the creation of an "island office" within DG REGIO and the development of coherent development strategies for island areas, involving local, regional and national authorities, as well as other relevant civil society actors, from the economy and the social environment. I think it is a necessary initiative and I support its adoption.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing.- I spoke in favor of the text.The Commission must now clearly define the permanent geographical, natural and demographic handicaps, referred to in Article 174 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU), which are likely to affect island regions.It must also indicate how it intends to apply the terms of Article 174 of the TFEU with regard to the permanent handicaps which hamper the natural development of island regions and which prevent them from striving for economic, social and territorial cohesion.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution insisting on the need for special EU attention for island regions within the EU and in the context of the EU cohesion policy, because of their specificities and the fact that such regions face permanent handicaps which require particular attention. It stresses the fact that common and specific permanent characteristics and features clearly distinguish island regions from mainland regions. Therefore the Commission is called on to take actions in order to enhance a better use of the specific cohesion policy instruments and resources that are available to tackle the handicaps arising from insularity. On the other hand this motion also calls not only to consider difficulties but also the potential of EU island regions and how this could be best harnessed for the achievement of the European Union’s long term objectives of economic, social and territorial cohesion.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing.- I supported the motion for a resolution on oral question B8-0106 / 2016 pursuant to Rule 128 (5) of the Rules of Procedure on the special situation of islands, as I believe that, due to their natural specificity, remoteness and sensitivity, islands need a specific policy.Only with special treatment of countries and an adapted financial framework will the Union be able to exploit the potential that these islands offer, despite some limitations.In particular, they will achieve development, growth and become more competitive within the Union through the development of tourism, the promotion of cultural heritage, the development of craft and economic activities and the potential of alternative energy.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: written.- We voted in favor since we agree that, in accordance with Council Directive 2006/112 / EC, certain European islands (including the outermost region of the Canary Islands) are granted a special tax regime to correctinequalities due to multiple causes related to the condition of insularity.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing.- The economic crisis has had a dramatic impact on the national and regional budgets of many Member States by limiting available funding in a number of sectors and leading to a 20% reduction in public investment.EU islands are also peripheral regions at the EU's external borders and are particularly vulnerable to current challenges facing Europe, such as globalization, demographic trends, climate change, energy supply and, especially for the southern states, migratory flows.I voted in favor of the document.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe it is important to take concrete steps to address the permanent handicaps that EU islands face and make full use of their potential. We must take into consideration the unique difficulties that southern insular regions face due to the increased migration flows. This is why we called upon the Commission, among other things, to maintain special tax regimes for islands. We also ask the Commission to: 1)set up a homogenous group made up of all island territories, which recognises the permanent handicaps of insular regions, 2) take account of other statistical indicators, besides GDP, which will reflect the economic and social vulnerability of these regions, 3) launch an in-depth analysis of the extra costs incurred as a result of being an island and 4) establish an “EU Strategic Framework for Islands” which would link up instruments that could have a major territorial impact, and submit a communication on an “Agenda for EU Islands” and subsequently a White Paper to monitor the development of islands.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: written.- Insular regions, in accordance with Article 174 TFEU, should be the subject of an exhaustive study and analysis by the European Commission in the coming months, in order to better understand the current situation in order to be able, in this way, to adapt thefuture actions relevant to a changing reality.I believe that this request is important and therefore I consider it necessary to vote in favor of said Resolution.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ Today, I voted in favour of this resolution because European islands contribute to the diversity of the Union in both environmental terms (specific habitats and endemic species) and cultural terms (languages, architectural heritage, sites, landscapes, agricultural and non-agricultural features and geographical identities). This resolution also helps European islands to strengthen sustainable development in the Union, given their high potential for producing energy from renewable sources due to specific exposure to wind streams, ocean swell and sunlight.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: written.- I voted in favor of this resolution which lists the priorities of the European Parliament around the specificities and characteristics of the island territories and the consequences of these specificities and characteristics for these islands.Some of these characteristics should be recognized as permanent disabilities and receive tailor-made treatment from the European Commission.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - Today, the people of Europe are suffering the consequences of austerity policies and support for the financial sector and large economic groups. It is in this context that island regions are most penalized because they are those that start at a disadvantage in a context of complete liberalization of the economy. In Portugal, we have two archipelagos, the Azores and Madeira, which suffer doubly from insularity and the effects of the troika and its adjustment program in recent years. In the Azores and Madeira, people have sought to overcome adversity, continuing to produce and trying to survive in this liberalized world. However, and as we had the opportunity to verify directly through a visit by the Agriculture Committee of this parliament, it is not possible to continue to pretend that we are going to solve the problems, creating a European year of the islands, or to believe that tourism will solve all the problems. In the name of territorial cohesion, specific policies are needed to support productive activities, particularly in terms of transport, so that island populations can have the same opportunities as other peoples in Europe.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: written.- The core of the application is that the island regions should receive additional funds and that further bodies such as the "island department" should be set up.Regions that are particularly suffering from the migration storm should be given more support.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: in writing.- Insularity is a key feature of my homeland of Greece.The islands, especially the smaller and more remote ones, are in many cases pockets of life and culture on Europe's borders.We must motivate citizens, especially islanders, to stay in their place and preserve their natural and cultural heritage.I voted in favor of this report.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing - The oral question on the conditions of isolation, such as islands and peripheries, concerns many Member States, which feel some guilt about the natural conditions that negatively affect them compared to other Member States.Island regions have to deal not only with the problem of difficult transport or water supply, but also with lower education or the outflow of labor to other, less disadvantaged regions, where there is a greater possibility of employment.That is why I consider it useful for the set of these disadvantages to be clearly defined, and thus to clarify the conditions that entitle these regions, for example, to draw on Eurofund funds.For these reasons, I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution.

name: Milan ZVER
text: in writing.- The European islands face a number of challenges due to adverse climatic conditions, the economic crisis, migrant flows and remoteness from Europe's mainland coasts.That is why I supported the Resolution calling on the European Parliament to draw up a development program for the EU's islands.It is necessary to stop migration from island regions, promote sustainable development on islands and create new jobs.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: - Mr President! The European Structural and Investment Funds have a budget of € 454 billion for 2014-2020. Employment, the internal market, energy, the economy, monetary issues, migration, everything are identified. And the focus is on both rural and urban areas, but the fact is that every year, cities are playing an increasingly important role in policy-making at all levels. And that is why we pay the most attention within the framework of the EFSI. If I were to abstract a little from the fact that my fellow citizens in my country, Latvia, are also emigrating en masse from Latvia to mostly Western European countries, the EFSI gave a huge step forward to the development of my country's cities. Especially in the digital field, housing renovation, municipal infrastructure renovation and so on. Therefore, I support this direction, I voted in favor. And given that the Commission must be this key factor in shaping the EFSI, we clearly need to pay the most attention.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: – Mr President, local and regional authorities play a pivotal role in the delivery of public services across Europe. They are closest to local communities and are an asset which must be protected. It is with this in mind that I find myself disheartened by the current treatment of local authorities in Scotland where, under the Scottish Nationalist—led Government, funding of local authorities is being slashed. The Convention of Scottish Local Authorities is currently resisting a budget cut by the Scottish Government of GBP 500 million. Yesterday in the Scottish Parliament we saw that the Government failed to support Labour proposals to address the funding shortfall, and vital frontline services will suffer due to the SNP’s austerity budget. We are already seeing slipping standards before this GBP 500 million cut comes into place, with 6 000 children leaving school in Scotland unable to read properly. Our children are our future, and the SNP is failing too many of Scotland’s children. The importance of the role of local authorities cannot be underplayed.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Mr President, as a member of a movement that is very much embedded in the regional and local authorities at national level, I have, of course, fully supported this report.I want to emphasize the role of municipalities and cities, they really play an irreplaceable role, precisely the role of subsidiary creator and co-creator of European policy.And it is undoubtedly important that we link policies that enable territorial development.Here I would like to emphasize the method of community-based development that is being adopted in Europe is working.It is a method that involves entrepreneurs, municipalities, non-profit organizations in drawing European funds.However, some countries are withdrawing from this method, and I would like the Commission to actually carry out an analysis of how this method allows regions to develop.It is very crucial for us, I think, for the future of Europe as a Europe of regions.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing.- Cohesion policy plays a fundamental role in the realization of European objectives, contributing to the creation of a growth process that enhances local realities.Setting up incentive and cooperation policies between European and local institutions certainly allows for the reduction of the economic, social and territorial disparities currently existing between European states and their regions.In fact, adopting a more inclusive strategy can not only improve the quality of life of citizens, but above all make innovation and technology the most suitable tools to stimulate the European market and create new jobs.For this reason, I voted in favor.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. As a party we are against the EU deciding where to invest when that decision should be the preserve of Member States.  On that point of principle we voted against.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. As a party we are against the EU deciding where to invest when that decision should be the preserve of Member States. On that point of principle we voted against.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: written. - The Resolution presented allows for a further step in the correct and more efficient allocation of the European Structural and Investment Funds by local and regional entities, through an increase in their participation in all phases of the project, as well through new tools such as integrated territorial investments or participatory local development. However, it is always good to remember that regional development and cohesion policy must be subject to the principle of reducing disparities between European regions. However, the need for synergies of these funds with the European Fund for Strategic Investments (Juncker Plan) is beginning to be heard frequently, while the new Dutch Presidency of the Council promotes a pact that gives preference to large urban areas, which which will undoubtedly tend to worsen disparities, if not remedied. In spite of everything, I consider that the Resolution itself is positive and can lead to better communication and administrative and financial cooperation between local, regional and state entities, as well as with European institutions. Therefore, I voted in favor of it.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this motion, which was put forward by the Committee for Regional Development. It highlights the importance of community-led and directed allocation of Structural Funds, in particular the importance of using initiatives such as community-led local development (CLLD) and integrated territorial investments (ITI) to better combine funding streams, target local initiatives and ensure a bottom-up, grass-roots approach across multiple levels of governance.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: written. - As a representative of a border region I can report from experience that local and regional authorities are close to the needs of the people. When carrying out projects, this guarantees that meaningful goals are targeted and controls can be simplified. Municipalities and regions are often dependent on European funds to finance their projects. In many countries, investments by municipalities make up the lion's share of the total number of investments. In my home country Belgium, the proportion is as high as 40 percent. The municipalities only contribute five percent of the total debt. Given the so-called SEC standards, which are a major challenge for many municipalities, the Commission and the Investment Bank need to propose concrete and workable solutions to local authorities in order to continue investing. Municipalities and regions also often do pioneering work for cross-border projects. We must continue to encourage them to do this, instead of hindering them through excessive bureaucracy.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: in writing.- This motion for a resolution recommends strengthening governance, at European level in particular, in the management of European structural funds.In addition, it welcomes the adoption of an EU urban calendar although urban policy is not part of its remit.I therefore voted against.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This Motion for a resolution calls for the increased involvement of local and regional investment funds in the ESIF.  As I oppose the ESIF, I voted against.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution on the role of local and regional authorities in the European Structural and Investment Funds.EU Cohesion Policy 2014-2020The programming period is the most important investment instrument for all EU regions to ensure sustainable economic growth, support job creation, entrepreneurship and innovation.I agree with the need for greater synergies and complementarities between the ESI Funds and other EU programs, in which local and regional authorities can play an important role in achieving the objectives of cohesion policy.I also support the calls on the Commission to ensure that local and regional authorities, their administrations and bodies are provided with capacity-building support so that they can play a significant role in the implementation of cohesion policy.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. As a party we are against the EU deciding where to invest when that decision should be the preserve of Member States.  On that point of principle we voted against.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: in writing.- This motion for a resolution calls for the strengthening of governance at several levels in the management of structural funds and welcomes the adoption of an EU "urban agenda" while no article of the Treaties devotes any competenceof the EU in urban policy.I voted against this additional step towards the federalization of the EU.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing.- I obviously supported this resolution which underlines the important role that local and regional authorities play in the management of the ESI Funds and the policies of the Union in general.For example, my municipality of Farciennes is obviously involved both in the definition and in the management of the major European projects deployed in its territory and which are vital for its revitalization.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing.- The European Structural and Investment Funds (ESI Funds) are the main instrument of investment policy and are a pillar of the European Union's cohesion policy.I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution because I regard the role played by local and regional authorities in this area as fundamental.The multilevel governance achieved by cohesion policy makes it possible to achieve a good balance between EU objectives and the territorial impact of policies while strengthening the democratic dimension of the EU institutions.The Commission will have to work in the coming years to strengthen the role of regional and local authorities in the management and implementation of ESI Funds through partnership agreements and operational programs.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: written. - We voted in favor of this proposed Resolution, since it vindicates the role of regional and local entities in the management of ESI Funds, given that these entities are the ones that are closest to the public and have competencies to carry out great part of the policies for which these funds are designed. We believe that citizen participation is key in the management of these funds and in European policies in general, and that ESI Funds are of great importance in the search for development and cohesion between different regions and peoples. However, we express our reluctance by voting against paragraph 2, which leaves, in a veiled way, a door open to the reduction of these funds on the basis of criteria of coherence and efficiency. This is contrary to our vision that these funds should always be increased and oriented according to criteria of social cohesion, development and redistribution, giving more resources to local entities so that they can carry out these objectives.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: written.- I have supported this motion for a resolution on the role of local and regional authorities in the management of the European Structural and Investment Funds.These entities play a key role in shaping and implementing the EU strategy.Furthermore, the synergies and complementarity between ESI Funds and other EU programs can be very useful for local and regional authorities to play a fundamental role in the European construction.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing.- This resolution is part of the European federalist project.So I rejected it.The text is in fact part of a dynamic of short-circuiting States by strengthening governance at the local level.Brussels is thus seeking to make the regions the armed wing of its decentralized power.While I am deeply attached to our regions and our territories, their responsibilities cannot and must not replace the role of the strategic State, for the sake of coherence and equality of the territories.In addition, the text is only self-congratulation, illegitimate in addition, on the adoption of an urban agenda of the Union, even though no article devotes any competence of the Union in terms of urban policies..

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing.- I believe that local and regional authorities play a key role in ensuring that the European funds bring real benefit to European citizens in the Member States.Therefore, I support this text, which highlights the very important function of local governance in the EU.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: written. - Regional and local entities with a federal structure have a greater margin of maneuver to elaborate national policies that have an impact on the regional and local levels. As far as cohesion policy is concerned, the level of development of consultations of regional and local authorities has increased over time. However, this level of development varies between states. Regional and local authorities are closer to citizens and have a better understanding of their own needs in order to improve the lives of citizens and promote economic growth and sustainable job creation. These entities therefore need greater budgetary support and level of co-financing of the projects. For these reasons, I support the Resolution approved by the European Parliament in order to correct these deficiencies and define what specific support it intends to offer to regional and local entities in the management of ESI Funds during the 2014-2020 period, as well as to undertake a public consultation on the modalities to strengthen the role of regional and local entities.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution because it assessed the role of local and regional authorities in the implementation of the European Structural and Investment Funds.EU Cohesion Policy 2014-2020remains the most important investment instrument for all EU regions during the programming period,quality of life of citizens, build solidarity and strengthen the development of EU regions.Parliament reiterated the key role of local and regional authorities in shaping and implementing EU strategies, while recognizing the role of various stakeholders from Member States and community groups.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing.- I would like to emphasize the key role of local and regional authorities in implementing EU strategies, while recognizing the role of a wide range of stakeholders from Member States' community groups.I also believe that the proximity of these authorities to citizens and the diversity of governance at local and regional level are of value to the EU.In the light of the above, I voted in favor of the report.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution because I believe that the involvement of local and regional authorities in the ESI Funds is one of the main strengths of the administration and management of these funds and I am therefore convinced that their role shouldbe strengthened also, and above all, by virtue of their greater knowledge of local needs.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing.- As you know, the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESI Funds) are the main instrument of the European Union's investment policy.There is a need for the Commission to launch a public consultation - hopefully followed by coherent and effective action by the Commission itself - on how to strengthen the role of local and regional authorities in EU cohesion policy and for local and regional authorities to besupported to strengthen their role and impact in relation to the management of the European Structural and Investment Funds in the period 2014-2020, taking due account of their respective responsibilities and the specificities of the various Member States, in order to create economic growth and jobssustainable work.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: in writing.- In this motion for a resolution, the European Union once again reiterates its desire to strengthen its links with local and regional authorities to the detriment of the Member States.We are absolutely hostile to the interference of European institutions in national affairs and to a federalization of Europe.In addition, this motion for a resolution calls for the strengthening of governance at several levels in the management of structural funds and welcomes the adoption of an urban agenda for the Union, while no article devotes any competence ofthe Union in terms of urban policies.As usual, the Commission tries to grant itself prerogatives that it does not have.Our duty is therefore to remind him of this.That is why I voted against this text.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution as it emphasizes the crucial role of local and regional authorities in defining and implementing EU strategies, while recognizing a wide variety of stakeholders, from Member States to participatory groups.I also believe that the proximity of these authorities to the citizens and the diversity of governance at local and regional level are a strength of the EU.Although the chapter of "EU territorial cohesion" is very often an example of financing projects of dubious utility, I can only support one of the few formal calls from the European Parliament to the importance of "local" governance, hoping for greater capacityterritorial in the use of these tools.

name: Alain CADEC
text: in writing.- The participation of local and regional authorities in the management of European Structural and Investment Funds is very important.Indeed, these actors are closer to European citizens and find themselves directly confronted with the realities on the ground.Structural funds are used directly for citizens.They exist both to correct the inequalities that persist between regions within the Union, but also to help European citizens to implement their projects.It is therefore important to involve the different levels of power in the management of these funds.I voted in favor of this resolution.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of this resolution to underline the crucial role of local and regional authorities in defining and implementing EU strategies. I believe that the proximity of these authorities to the citizens and the diversity of governance at local and regional level are a strength of the EU. We need to allow our Municipalities and Regions to negotiate, within a stable legal framework, investments in priority areas that are essential to the development of our societies, such as research and innovation, the transition to a low-carbon economy. and social inclusion. For the policy to deliver results, it is essential that local and regional authorities are involved in the design, implementation and monitoring phases of programs, setting up mixed task forces, for example, bringing together the different levels of governance. Strengthening administrative capacity and remedying the structural weaknesses of local and regional authorities are key aspects for increasing the absorption rate of the European Structural and Investment Funds. I therefore call on the Commission to ensure support for the development of the capacities of local and regional authorities and their administrations and institutions so that they can play a significant role in cohesion policy.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. As a party we are against the EU deciding where to invest when that decision should be the preserve of Member States. On that point of principle we voted against.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because I agree that the local and regional authorities play a very important role in the implementation of EU policies and strategies and that their role in the management of the European Structural and Investment Funds should be strengthened as they are the closest to the people living there.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing.- Cohesion policy aims to reduce the economic and social disparities of the Member States through, in particular, the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESI Funds) which bring together the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF), the European Social Fund (ESF), the Cohesion Fund (CF), the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD) and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund (EMFF).To this end, my colleague Mihaylova's report recognizes the importance of multi-level governance which supports these goals (economic growth, social progress and sustainable development) by strengthening the democratic dimension of the EU and increasing the effectiveness of its political action.;therefore I voted in favor.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. - Local authorities are the main recipients of the Structural and Investment Funds, which represent a real and concrete possibility of development for the economic revitalization of regions and municipalities. These are huge and secure resources, allocated on the basis of the criteria established by cohesion policy. Very often, however, these funds remain unspent and not only due to administrative shortcomings, which also affected some regions, but also due to the difficulty of achieving the objectives decided ex ante by the Commission. Several times this Parliament has asked for the participation of local authorities to be strengthened in defining objectives and priorities for growth, development and employment. If you want to overcome the risk of failure to achieve the spending objectives, it is essential that regions and municipalities actively participate already in the phase of defining the objectives, in order to allow local authorities to present, based on the difficulties encountered in the implementation phase, priorities and feasible goals. Next year the process for the review of the post-2020 cohesion policy will begin and therefore we need to start reflecting already for a greater involvement of local actors. I fully agree with the contents of the resolution and therefore voted in favor.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing. - We support the motion for a resolution and emphasize the crucial role of local and regional authorities in shaping and implementing EU strategies. EU cohesion policy is a good example of multi-level governance with a bottom-up approach, where local and regional authorities, in dealing with the European Structural and Investment Funds, strike a balance between the EU objective of greater economic, social and territorial cohesion and the territorial impact of EU policies. Finally, we highlight the challenges facing local and regional authorities such as globalization, climate change, energy security, migration flows and increased urbanization.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing.- I decided to support the measure as I firmly believe that local and regional authorities must have a fundamental role in the definition and implementation of EU strategies, being the proximity of these authorities to the citizens and the diversity of governance atlocal and regional essential elements for a correct application of the subsidiarity principle expressed in the Lisbon Treaty.As regards the European Structural Investment Funds (ESI), I am absolutely in favor of the synergies and complementarity of these funds with other EU programs, in which local and regional authorities can contribute positively to the achievement of the objectives of the cohesion policy.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing.- The European Commission heavily bases its work on the subsidiarity principle, as established by the Treaties.In other words, it is good that each issue is addressed and resolved in the smallest possible territorial context that allows for an effective solution.However, until now the mechanisms of coordination and collaboration with smaller entities (and therefore with less budget) had not been defined, and this political document is a step forward in this direction.For this reason, I voted in favor.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. As a party we are against the EU deciding where to invest when that decision should be the preserve of Member States.  On that point of principle we voted against.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. - The EU's cohesion policy in the 2014-2020 programming period represents the main investment instrument covering all regions of the EU contributing to sustainable growth, the bottom-up logic supporting job creation, entrepreneurship and innovation at the level of local and regional economies, improving the quality of life of citizens and creating solidarity and further development in EU regions. Local and regional authorities have, both in the context of the ESIF, in the design and implementation of EU strategies, a key role in helping to balance the Union's objective of greater social and territorial economic cohesion and the impact of EU policies. Union in their territories. I support this Resolution, which recognizes the importance of these synergies and complementarities between the ESI Funds and other EU programs, raising the role of local authorities in fulfilling this aim and recognizing the various challenges that the regions face as the phenomenon of globalization, energy security, migratory flows, climate change and intrinsic specificities of its territorial nature.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing.- In managing the European Structural and Investment Funds, local and regional authorities play a key role in implementing the Union's objective of greater economic, social and territorial cohesion and ensuring an effective territorial impact of EU policies.The European Commission needs to continue to improve the scope of ESI Funds as it is an important tool, including through public consultations, in order to identify measures to strengthen the role of regional and local authorities in the management andimplementation of the funds foreseen for the period 2014-2020.For these reasons I have decided to vote in favor.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ Local and regional authorities are key players in shaping and implementing EU strategies without whom EU policy and action may not be relevant to the local communities to whom they are addressed. This resolution seeks to encourage the Commission to follow more synergies with local and regional authorities even in the implementation of European Structural and Investment Funds.  I have voted in favour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: written. - The Resolution presented allows for a further step in the correct and more efficient allocation of the European Structural and Investment Funds by local and regional entities, through an increase in their participation in all phases of the project, as well through new tools such as integrated territorial investments or participatory local development. However, it is always good to remember that regional development and cohesion policy must be subject to the principle of reducing disparities between European regions. However, the need for synergies of these funds with the European Fund for Strategic Investments (Juncker Plan) is beginning to be heard frequently, while the new Dutch Presidency of the Council promotes a pact that gives preference to large urban areas, which which will undoubtedly tend to worsen disparities, if not remedied. In spite of everything, I consider that the Resolution itself is positive and can lead to better communication and administrative and financial cooperation between local, regional and state entities, as well as with European institutions. Therefore, I voted in favor of it.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing. - The resolution emphasizes the key role of local and regional authorities in the design and implementation of EU strategies, while recognizing the role of a wide range of stakeholders, from Member States to local communities. It is very important to say that the close contacts of these authorities with citizens and the diversity of government at local and regional level are an asset for the EU. Parliament supports synergies and complementarities between the European Structural and Investment Funds and other EU programs where local and regional authorities can play a useful role in achieving the objectives of cohesion policy. At the same time, the resolution emphasizes that improving the administrative capacity and addressing the structural weaknesses of local and regional authorities are essential for the programming and implementation phases of operational programs and for achieving a higher absorption rate of ESI funds. Therefore calls on the Commission to ensure that local and regional authorities and their administrations and institutions receive support for capacity building, enabling them to play a significant role in cohesion policy, especially when delegating executive tasks to lower levels of administration, especially municipalities . I voted in favor of the theses contained in the resolution.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ Local and regional authorities play a very important role within the framework of the European Structural and Investment Funds as they are close to citizens and best understand their needs. On the other hand, due to their limited means they are in need of budgetary support for co-financing of projects. The motion for a resolution, which I voted in favour of, is addressed to the Commission and asks questions as to how the EC is going to support regional and local authorities in order to strengthen their role and impact in managing ESI funds, with the aim of creating economic growth and sustainable jobs.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this resolution, which rightly focuses on the good position local and regional authorities are in to assist in the use of European Structural and Investment Funds due to their local knowledge. The resolution is also accurate in its attention to the many challenges facing EU local and regional authorities, from energy security to administrative capacity, red tape and complexity in public procurement. In some Member States there is a real need to tackle structural weaknesses to increase the absorption rate of ESI Funds, and thus improve the value for money to taxpayers of these investments, whilst at the same time ensuring subsidiarity is respected.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: signed up.- The role of local and regional authorities, as well as a wide range of partners - from Member States to Community groups - is essential in the process of drawing up and implementing European Union strategies.On the other hand, the diversity of modes of governance at local and regional level is an advantage for the European Union and I consider the principle of a strengthened partnership and the European Code of Conduct on Partnership to be very important.They set out the legal involvement of local and regional authorities and set out the minimum requirements for their involvement in all stages of the preparation and implementation of operational programs in order to achieve the highest possible rate of absorption of ESI funds.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. - The European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) is one of the Juncker Commission's priority policy initiatives; a first important response to the economic situation, which the Group of Socialists and Democrats has supported since its presentation, which will serve to relaunch European growth, create new jobs and promote greater social cohesion. In the framework of the programming of investments financed by the Commission, I believe that local and regional administrations can play a fundamental role for several reasons: their proximity to citizens, their knowledge of their specific needs and their strong link with the territory. In fact, as the Resolution I supported highlights, local and regional governance must actively participate in the process of preparing and implementing operational programs, given that it has the right skills to assess the territorial impact of these policies and to explore all its potential. Local and regional authorities constitute an inestimable added value for identifying with meticulousness and precision the real needs of the territories, citizens and businesses: it will be important to provide them with the appropriate tools so that they can provide this additional contribution to achieve the objectives set by the EFSI plan.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: in writing.- In this motion for a resolution, MEPs make a series of recommendations with a view to strengthening the role of local and regional authorities in European Structural and Investment Funds (ESI).In particular, they propose to increase synergies and complementarities between the ESI funds and other Union programs, in which local and regional authorities can play a useful role in achieving the objectives of cohesion policy.MEPs also call on the European Commission to strengthen the administrative capacity of local and regional authorities in the management of ESI funds.Supporting these goals, I voted in favor of this resolution.

name: Rachida DATI
text: in writing.- The European Structural and Investment Funds are a fundamental instrument of the European Union's cohesion policy.This resolution on the role of local and regional authorities in the European Structural and Investment Funds (EIFS) underlines their key role in the implementation of European strategies.For a better optimization of these funds, it is necessary that synergies be created and that the local and regional authorities provide an adequate framework for their implementation.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: in writing. - The former regional president that I am can only welcome the adoption of such a report, which recalls the fundamentals of cohesion policy and the necessary proximity to be organized between the managers of European funds, project and citizens. Indeed, local authorities are in direct contact with many of the issues surrounding the current programming of regional policy: administrative simplification, extended use of financial instruments, the notion of partnership and deepening of multi-level governance. They are better able to detect, instruct and drive the Union's strategic policies. The report focuses on urban areas - a priority for the incoming Dutch Presidency. These must urgently address the challenges of globalization, climate change, energy security and migratory flows. Without underestimating this reality, I would like to draw attention to the specific realities of rural and isolated territories, which, for their part, face the challenges of accessibility and attractiveness. I have always advocated a balanced approach to the territories. We must think of the city-countryside link rather than seeking to segment public policies.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing.- Insofar as no article devotes any competence of the European Union in the area of urban policies, I do not associate myself with this motion for a resolution, which provides for a strengthening of governance at several levels in the management of fundsstructures and welcomes the adoption of a Union urban agenda.I therefore voted against this text.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: In written form. - I supported the resolution on the role of local and regional authorities in the European Structural and Investment Funds, as the Committee on Regional Development calls on the European Commission to build on existing past and present initiatives in the field. The resolution also emphasizes the importance of available information for achieving the EU's objectives in the areas of economic and social cohesion. Attention is also paid to the difficulties faced by local authorities in terms of their absorption.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: in writing.- We are voting in favor, we consider the development of the province a basic condition for a sustainable development of the Member States.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing.- EU cohesion policy in the 2014-2020 programming period continues to represent the main investment instrument covering all regions of the EU and provides an opportunity to create a process of sustainable growth, supporting job creation, entrepreneurshipand innovation at the level of local and regional economies, improving the quality of life of citizens and creating solidarity and further development in EU regions.For the realization of these assumptions, the role of local and regional authorities in the design and implementation of EU strategies is fundamental, while recognizing the role of a wide range of stakeholders, from Member States to community groups.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - This resolution addresses the role of local and regional authorities in promoting regional development and territorial and social cohesion. Cities are areas of high population concentration (over 75% of the EU population lives in an urban context), with growing needs in terms of political, social, economic and cultural organization, with new demands, both institutional and from different population sectors. In the European context, there are cities that, alone, have more population and infrastructure than certain EU countries or regions. The city context is, therefore, increasingly important in the management of public affairs, not only because of the material and territorial dimension, but also because cities correspond to spaces of greater proximity and mobilization, of citizenship, gaining an important political expression. There is a negative tendency to establish direct communication between the European Commission and "cities", without the intermediation of Member States and the necessary definition of priorities and strategies for their regions. It is intended that the creation of two specific lines of financing for cities - Community-Led Local Development and Integrated Territorial Investments - will contribute to better access by cities to financing. The sense of cohesion policies should favor Member States and their regional development strategies and not an agenda for promoting the EU and its institutions.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing - Local and regional authorities play a very important role in the European Structural Funds and Investment Funds, as they are closest to the citizens and should therefore have the best understanding of their needs.On the other hand, they have limited possibilities and therefore rely on financial and budget support to co-finance projects.It is therefore very important how the European Commission wants to support local authorities and regional authorities in the future, in order to strengthen their role and influence in the management and use of the Structural Funds, to maintain and increase economic growth and to promote sustainable jobs.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: in writing.- I am voting in favor of the report, as I consider the development of the province to be a key precondition for the sustainable development of the Member States.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Local and regional authorities play a very important role within the framework of the European Structural and Investment Funds as they are close to citizens and best understand their needs. On the other hand - due to their limited means - they are in need of budgetary support for co-financement of projects. It is important to know how the EC is going to support regional and local authorities in order to strengthen their role and impact in managing ESI funds, with the aim of creating economic growth and sustainable jobs. Furthermore, we also need to know if the EC envisage a public consultation, followed by an initiative, on this matter.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: written.- I voted in favor considering that cohesion policy is also aimed at reducing economic, social and territorial disparities between the EU Member States and their regions through an inclusive strategy.In this strategy, local and regional authorities play a fundamental role in shaping and implementing EU strategies, of which local authorities are partners.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. - My administrative, as well as political, experience has given me a deep awareness of how fundamental the role of local and regional authorities is in the ability to relate to citizens and to know their urgencies. In fact, local authorities represent the link between the needs of the territories and the response to political intervention and are in fact the first tool through which it is possible to put the program and political action into practice. But to give life to projects and changes in the territory, local administrations need great economic resources.
