I therefore find the oral question proposed to the Commission absolutely acceptable, in the spirit of offering strong support to local and regional authorities, recognizing their full ownership in the identification of priorities and programming of structural funds and maximum protection, trying to limit redirection also only partial of the funds earmarked for cohesion.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the EP Resolution on the role of regional and local authorities in the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESIF) because EU cohesion policy in the 2014-2020 programming period represents the main investment tool in EU from which European territories will benefit (according to very specific distribution rules) and aimed at creating a sustainable bottom-up growth process aimed at creating jobs, developing entrepreneurship and innovation at the local level. Local and regional authorities are facing new and important challenges imposed by globalization, climate change and the migration emergency. Therefore, thanks to the process of legal rationalization to which it has undergone, cohesion policy will be able to respond better to these important challenges than in the past. Undoubtedly, strengthening the administrative capacity of local and regional authorities is fundamental, both in the planning phase and in the implementation phase of the cohesion policy. The EU as a whole, in order to definitively emerge from the crisis and return to being an area of ​​growth and attraction for non-European investors, strongly needs cohesion policy, since, based on multilevel governance, the latter makes it possible to achieve political objectives EU fundamentals.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I support this report, which calls attention to the fact that local and regional authorities are instrumental to the functioning of the European Structural and Investment Funds, as they are close to citizens and best understand their needs. Therefore it is important that the Commission provides support to regional and local authorities in order to strengthen their role and impact in managing ESI funds, with the aim of creating economic growth and sustainable jobs.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: written. - We voted in favor of this proposed Resolution, since it vindicates the role of regional and local entities in the management of ESI Funds, given that it is these entities that are closest to the public and have competencies to carry out great part of the policies for which these funds are designed. We believe that citizen participation is key in the management of these funds and in European policies in general, and that ESI Funds are of great importance in the search for development and cohesion between different regions and peoples. However, we express our reluctance by voting against paragraph 2, which leaves, in a veiled way, a door open to the reduction of these funds on the basis of criteria of coherence and efficiency. This is contrary to our vision that these funds should always be increased and oriented according to criteria of social cohesion, development and redistribution, giving more resources to local entities so that they can carry out these objectives.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ With my Socialist colleagues, I voted in favour of this resolution because smart cities and smart specialisation strategies are two innovations that have been quickly taken on board by policymakers and translated into specific EU policies or initiatives. Moreover, the EU ministers’ agreement on the Riga 2015 declaration paved the way for an EU Urban Agenda, which is now expected to lead to the ‘Pact of Amsterdam’. The latter is a future-oriented programme in which the participation of European cities is a central element, and through which the Dutch Council presidency of 2016 aims to establish a bottom-up approach.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour on the role of local and regional authorities in the European Structural and Investment Funds. Regional and local authorities are close to citizens and better understand local needs as well as policies and initiatives aimed at improving citizens’ lives. Cities are engines of economic growth and employment, breeding grounds for art, culture and creativity, and the perfect platform for innovation and start-ups.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE / NGL), in writing.- We voted in favor of this resolution because we agree with the philosophy of the structural policies pursued through these funds and we also agree with the way this policy is underlined by the resolution, ie multi-level governance with a bottom-up approach.We also agree with the resolution when it calls on the Commission to help develop institutional capacity by local authorities in the Member States implementing structural policies.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution on the role of local and regional authorities in the European Structural and Investment Funds. With a budget of EUR 454 billion for 2014-20, the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESIFs) are the European Union’s main investment policy tool. EU cohesion policy promotes a bottom-up approach and I was pleased to see that in this resolution the importance of the Community-Led Local Development initiative, in which local authorities are partners, was highlighted. I believe it is crucial that a genuine bottom-up approach where local actors have real decision making powers is used in order to respond directly to local needs and challenges in a more focused and appropriate way. The new ITI and CLLD tools should enable local stakeholders to combine funding streams and plan well-targeted local initiatives. I also support the resolution’s call for the Commission to ensure that support is provided for capacity building for local and regional authorities and their administrations and institutions, so that they are in a position to play a meaningful role in cohesion policy.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written. - I voted in favor of the Resolution on the role of local and regional authorities in the European Structural and Investment Funds on the basis of an oral question, given that I initiated the question to the Commission and the preparation of a European Parliament resolution. I believe that this issue is extremely important and that the European Commission does not pay enough attention to the position of local and regional authorities. Although the issue is focused on European funds, I believe that this is only part of the issue in which local and regional authorities are in a subordinate position to the state administration and where local and regional authorities in recent years, especially due to the economic crisis, are deprived of rights and resources. by the central government. Subsidiarity implies that everything that can be done at lower levels of government should be left to lower levels of government, including the necessary resources. In addition, subsidiarity also strengthens democratic relations, as in this way the authorities and decision-making are closer to citizens who are better informed and can participate more easily in decision-making. Today, the situation varies from state to state, from strongly centralized to decentralized states. Decentralization is one of the preconditions for better economic and development results.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: in writing.- This motion for a resolution recommends strengthening governance, at European level in particular, in the management of structural funds.In addition, it welcomes the adoption of an urban calendar of the Union, although urban policy is not part of its competences.I therefore voted against.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – My UKIP colleagues and I voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. As a party we are against the EU deciding where to invest when that decision should be the preserve of Member States. On that point of principle I voted against.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. – With a budget of EUR 454 billion for 2014-2020, the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESIFs) are the European Union's main investment policy tool. This resolution recalls the key role local and regional authorities play in shaping and implementing EU strategies. Indeed, for the funds to have maximum impact, national, regional and local authorities in EU countries must work together closely and help EU countries to focus on funds where the need is greatest and to make optimum use of resources. Regional and local authorities are close to citizens and are aware of the local needs. They bring the EU closer to citizens and help make our Funds be more effective on the ground. I voted in favour of this text because it takes into account all these elements and call for the Member States and the Commission to strengthen this involvement.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written.- I am voting in favor of this motion for a resolution.Finding synergies in ESIF seems important to me for a more efficient deployment and use of funds, as is the greater involvement of regional authorities in project design.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ Local and regional authorities play a very important role within the framework of the European Structural and Investment Funds as they are close to citizens and best understand their needs. I voted in favour of the report, as it calls to strengthen their role and impact in managing EU funds, with the aim of creating economic growth and sustainable jobs.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: in writing.- I voted against the motion for a resolution on the role of local and regional authorities in the European Structural and Investment Funds.This text calls for the strengthening of governance at several levels in the management of structural funds and welcomes the adoption of an urban agenda of the European Union, while no article devotes any competence of the Union inurban policy.This is a competence of the Member States.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: in writing.- I voted against this resolution because it welcomes the adoption of an urban agenda for the Union, while no article of the Treaties establishes any competence of the Union in the area of urban policy.The Union is really involved in everything!

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: in writing. - Poland is the best example of how European funds can change the country within a dozen or so years. Local government units are the most important entities in this activity, both in Poland and other EU countries. It is the regional authorities that most often have the task of distributing and managing huge resources from the funds, e.g. through regional operational programs, and good performance of these tasks often determines a significant civilization leap for many regions. One of the most important beneficiaries of European funds are "small homelands", ie communes. Activities carried out by municipal units, such as investments in road, water and sewage infrastructure, municipal infrastructure, education or cultural and tourist offer, are most easily perceived and felt by the inhabitants, as they serve the entire community. One cannot forget about the role of local governments, which is information and intermediation in obtaining European funds by natural and legal persons, therefore, supporting local governments in their activities, I voted in favor of adopting the document on the role of local and regional authorities in the European Structural and Investment Funds.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written. - Cohesion policy is based on the principle of partnership and multilevel governance, and in decision-making and strategic documents it is necessary to involve the local level and align with national goals, working on the principle of "bottom-up" and vice versa "top-down". It is crucial to provide support for developing additional administrative capacity so that local and regional authorities can participate in cohesion policy. Currently, local and regional authorities face major problems such as globalization, climate change, energy security, the migration wave and accelerated urbanization. Local and regional authorities are closer to EU citizens, have a better understanding of citizens' needs as well as the services that need to be introduced. Each state should strive to change national operational programs into regional ones and to involve local and regional authorities as concretely as possible in defining investment priorities. Due to the importance of involving local units in the definition and implementation of cohesion and economic policy with the aim of achieving sustainable economic growth and development, I supported the motion for a resolution by rapporteur Mihaylova.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing - Multilevel governance and partnership principles support the pursuit of the EU's fundamental policy objectives of economic growth and sustainable development through the involvement of local and regional authorities.Local and regional authorities have the best knowledge of the problems of their regions, are able to identify them and take an active part in solving them.At the same time, they face solutions to problems that go beyond their regions.I therefore consider it important to create the conditions for cooperation and to strengthen the role of local and regional authorities in the management and implementation of the ESI Funds.

name: Louis-Joseph MANSCOUR
text: in writing. - While the implementation of the 2014-2020 operational programs has just started, this text makes it possible to take stock of the role of local and regional authorities (LRAs) in the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESI Funds). To achieve economic, social and territorial cohesion within the European Union, the intervention of the ESI Funds must be geared as closely as possible to the needs of citizens and businesses. In fact, LRAs are in direct contact with many of the issues surrounding the current programming of regional policy: territorial vision of development, administrative simplification, deepening of multi-level governance. While the resolution emphasizes the central role of cities, to which 5% of ESI Funds are reserved, it nevertheless strikes a balance on the issue of equal access to the Funds between territories. It is indeed important for the regions, in particular the outermost regions, which have seen their investment capacities seriously retracted, to recall that cohesion policy must retain its primary spirit of territorial solidarity. This text constitutes a constructive contribution to the debate on the place to be given to LRAs in the definition and management of ESI Funds. I therefore give him my support.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing.- I support the Motion for a Resolution on the role of local and regional authorities in the framework of the European Structural and Investment Funds, because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing.- I voted against this proposal.Indeed, it calls for the strengthening of governance at several levels in the management of structural funds, which means more controls on the part of the Union.In addition, it welcomes the adoption of a Union urban agenda when no article devotes any competence of the Union in terms of urban policies!It is, as often, one more way of eating away at the sovereignty of member states.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ This report highlights the importance of the Community-Led Local Development initiative, in which local authorities are partners, and underlines that it should remain a bottom-up approach while establishing objectives for interventions related to local and regional needs.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: in writing.- The EU's cohesion policy in the 2014-2020 programming period continues to represent the main investment instrument covering all regions of the EU, and in which its bottom-up governance model has proven to be effective insustainable growth process, supporting job creation, entrepreneurship and innovation at the level of local and regional economies.These synergies and complementarities between the ESI Funds and other programs, as well as their openness to local and regional government decision, must be fostered, as they constitute the best strategy for implementing the objectives of growth and improving the quality of life of its citizens.I voted in favor.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: written.- Local and regional authorities play an essential role in the development and implementation of EU strategies.Its proximity to citizens and the diversity of governance at local and regional level is an asset for the EU.I support the motion for a resolution on the role of these entities in the distribution of the European Structural and Investment Funds, as local and regional authorities play a key role in the success of cohesion policy.

name: Georg MAYER
text: written.- With the new initiatives of integrated territorial investments and the local development led by the local population, gradual changes in the possibilities of local actors, sources of finance can be bundled.The report emphasizes that local and regional authorities play a central role in the design and implementation of EU strategies, while recognizing the role of a wide range of stakeholders, from Member States to citizens' groups.The proximity of these local authorities to the citizens and the diversity of governance at local and regional level are beneficial to the EU.I therefore agree with this report.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: in writing.- This resolution recalls that, in accordance with the Regulation on Common Provisions (CPR) of the current programming period (2014-2020), Local and Regional Authorities (LRAs) have seen their influence increased.It notes, however, that although the LRAs have been consulted in most cases during the negotiations on partnership agreements and operational programs, their participation is uneven according to the regions and states.It therefore asks the Commission to ensure that the administrative capacities of local and regional authorities are strengthened.I'm voting for.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: in writing.- This motion for a resolution seeks to strengthen governance in the management of the Structural Funds, in particular at European level.It also welcomes the adoption of an urban calendar for the Union, although urban policy is not part of its competences.Therefore, I voted against.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing.- (PT) I voted in favor of the resolution on the role of local and regional authorities in the context of the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESIF).EU cohesion policy in the 2014-2020 programming period represents the main investment instrument covering all EU regions, with the advantage of reducing economic, social and territorial disparities between EU Member States andtheir regions.Local and regional authorities have a key role to play in implementing EU strategies.Local authorities are excellent partners in community-based local development.There are several challenges facing local and regional authorities, but they are the ones who can best deal with challenges such as globalization, climate change or energy security, taking into account that each locality or region has its needs.and specific characteristics.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I supported to this resolution because it is integral for supranational authorities within the Union to work together with local and regional authorities throughout Europe to improve economic and social development while tackling issues that affect different regions across the continent.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: in writing.- The Union's cohesion policy continues to be, for the 2014-2020 programming period, the main investment instrument covering all regions of the European Union.Local and regional authorities have a central role in the design and implementation of EU strategies.This is why this type of governance at all levels should be encouraged.It is by being as close as possible to citizens that we can best identify their needs, whether in economic or social terms.The principle of subsidiarity is fundamental in helping social progress, sustainable development and economic growth.Of course, the local and regional authorities must be provided with sufficient resources.I believe that a public consultation on multi-level governance would be one of the tools to best identify their needs in order to strengthen their capacities and their effectiveness.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing - The importance of local and regional authorities in using the Structural and Investment Funds is undeniable.Local authorities are best aware of the shortcomings, as well as the promising areas of the city or region, and know best where help is needed.I emphasize that the motion for a resolution mentions the need to strengthen administrative capacity.The lack of qualified staff causes delays and opacity in the processing processes, which is often the reason why people find the use of these funds inefficient and too demanding.I believe that by improving the functioning of local authorities in the area of the Structural and Investment Funds, it is possible to reduce the regional disparities that plague many Member States.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ Local and regional authorities play a very important role within the framework of the European Structural and Investment Funds as they are close to citizens and best understand their needs. On the other hand - due to their limited means - they are in need of budgetary support for co-financement of projects. Therefore, I voted in favour of the Resolution on the role of local and regional authorities in the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESIF).

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing.- The Committee on Regional Development proposes that Parliament's resolution draw attention to the key role of local and regional authorities in implementing EU strategies, the importance of a community-led local development initiative and the principle of multilevel governance that supports fundamental EU policy goals such as economic development.growth, social progress and sustainable development, as well as strengthening the democratic dimension of the EU and enhancing the effectiveness of its political action.I voted in favor of the draft.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing.- EU cohesion policy in the 2014-2020 programming period continues to represent the main investment instrument covering all regions of the EU and provides an opportunity to create a sustainable growth process in which the basis fortop is more pronounced.I voted in favor of this motion for a resolution because it recognizes the importance that multi-level governance represents in the European political spectrum, reinforcing the democratic dimension of the EU and increasing the efficiency of its political action.I further argue that local and regional authorities should be directly involved in the design and implementation of EU strategies, while recognizing the role of a wide range of stakeholders, from Member States to community groups.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: in writing.- This motion for a resolution on the role of local and regional authorities in the European Structural and Investment Funds calls for the strengthening of governance at several levels in the management of the structural funds and welcomes the adoption of an urban agenda ofthe Union even though the latter does not have in any article of positive law the competence in matters of city policy.I therefore voted against this text which encroaches on the powers of the Union and which seems to me to be contrary to the Treaties.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution on the role of local and regional authorities in European structural and investment funds.This text underlines the importance of fully involving cities and regions in the preparation and implementation of cohesion policy, the objective of which is to reduce economic, social and territorial disparities between Member States and regions.between them.One of its provisions notably encourages the use of new instruments available: integrated territorial investments (ITI) and local development led by local actors (CLLD).

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. - We welcome the resolution in favor of greater involvement and support of regional and local authorities. In fact, they represent the institutions closest to citizens as well as those able to understand and better define their needs. Their centrality is also defined at the European level, thanks to the affirmation of the principle of subsidiarity, which establishes the obligation of the institutions to take decisions as close as possible to the citizen. In the case of the European Structural and Investment Funds, too, the local dimension must be central. The European Commission must consider further measures to support their action and to be able to improve the management of the Structural Funds. If the Commission were to intervene with additional mechanisms, there could be positive effects on economic growth and employment in the Member States. Finally, it is possible and desirable that the Commission consider launching a public consultation on the issue, in order to give a voice to citizens and their needs.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: in writing.- Local and regional authorities have a huge role to play in the implementation of cohesion policy.In my capacity as Deputy President of the Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur region, I know the importance of these authorities.I therefore voted in favor of the resolution, which highlights this fundamental role and sheds light on the actual resources available to these authorities.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The EU cohesion policy between 2014 and 2020 continues to serve as the main investment instrument that covers all regions of the EU, creating sustainable growth, supporting the creation of jobs, entrepreneurship and innovation at local and regional economies level. I have voted for this motion for a resolution that reiterates the key role of local and regional authorities in shaping and implementing EU strategies.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: In written form. - I supported the resolution on the role of local and regional authorities in the European Structural and Investment Funds, because I believe that the use of these funds, which is aimed at European citizens, must take place in consultation with these authorities. According to some studies, it is the local and regional institutions that are closest to the citizens and enjoy their trust the most due to their geographical and cultural proximity. These are also the bodies that know best the problems of local communities and would be one of the most competent bodies for shaping regional priorities. They are the ones who make the connection and strike a balance between the Union's objectives and their achievement by the citizens. There are problems such as depopulation, the effects of climate change and the changing balance between urbanized and non-urbanized communities, of which local and regional authorities and institutions are the direct victims. That is why I join the call for the European Commission, through this resolution, to involve representatives of these institutions more actively, in order to seek faster and lasting solutions to the problems facing the European Union.

name: Dan NICA
text: signed up. - EU cohesion policy for 2014-2020 is the main investment instrument covering all EU regions and an opportunity for job creation, entrepreneurship and innovation in local and regional economies, improving the quality of life of citizens and ensuring solidarity and more pronounced development in EU regions. I voted in favor of the synergies and complementarity between the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESI) and other EU programs, in which local and regional authorities can play a useful role in achieving the objectives of cohesion policy. We emphasize that any reprogramming of ESI Funds should be carried out in accordance with the rules of the Common Provisions Regulation (DRC) and that new initiatives should not weaken the essence of ESI Funds. We draw attention to the challenges facing local and regional authorities, such as globalization, climate change, energy security, migration flows and increasing urbanization, given that each region has specific needs and characteristics. We call on the Commission to continue to build on previous and ongoing initiatives, including public consultations, to identify measures to strengthen the role of local and regional authorities in the management and implementation of ESI Funds through partnership agreements and operational programs.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: PPE), in writing. - The report emphasizes the key role of local and regional authorities in developing and implementing EU strategies. The role of urban areas is emphasized, as is the fact that EU policies have an important role to play in creating the right framework for the growth and development potential of urban areas in Europe. The report calls on the Commission to work on identifying measures to strengthen the role of local and regional authorities in the management and implementation of the European Structural and Investment Funds, through partnership agreements and operational programs. I support this report.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report because I expect it to significantly strengthen regional authorities in overarching decision-making processes.I believe that this is particularly necessary in the light of constant calls for greater consideration of the subsidiarity principle.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the resolution as I agree with the approach taken regarding the importance and criticality recognized in the role of EU local and regional authorities. under the European Structural and Investment Funds. In this context, I recognize the particular importance of the remarks made regarding Member States' compliance with the requirements of the enhanced partnership principles, in order to ensure the utmost active involvement and involvement of local and regional authorities in the preparation of the and the implementation of operational programs, as well as the importance of Commission support initiatives to address the administrative and structural weaknesses of local and regional authorities, so that they can maximize the impact of GRNETs and their greater degree of absorption.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. As a party we are against the EU deciding where to invest when that decision should be the preserve of Member States. On that point of principle we voted against.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing.- On 28 June 2013 the European Council decided to start accession negotiations with Serbia, a country that aspires to become a member of the EU.Two years later, the Commission reported on the excellent progress made by the country towards European integration, I would therefore have voted positively, declaring admiration and support for this country.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – Regional and local authorities are close to citizens and better understand local needs as well as policies and initiatives aimed at improving citizens’ lives. Therefore, the role of local and regional authorities is of high importance in shaping and implementing EU strategies. I am in favour of synergies and complementarity between the ESI Funds and other EU programmes, in which local and regional authorities can play a useful role in attaining the objectives of cohesion policy. Therefore, I vote in favour of the resolution.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - I supported this resolution because I believe that it is necessary to give greater powers to local and regional authorities when it comes to the use of European structural and investment funds. Giving greater powers would reduce the pressure on the centralized system, ie relieve the state-level authorities and give greater responsibility to local and regional authorities. Support needs to be given to regional and local authorities in order to strengthen their role and influence in applying for European Structural and Investment Funds, especially for the period 2014-2020, which I believe would result in economic growth and the opening up of sustainable jobs. According to the data from the financial report of the European Commission, in 2014 Croatia withdrew a total of EUR 584.3 million from the European Union budget, while in 2013 that amount was EUR 290 million. Last year, 313.9 million euros were withdrawn from the European Union budget in the name of economic, social and territorial cohesion. Given the numbers and opportunities provided by withdrawing funds from EU funds, I believe that encouraging greater initiative, especially from local and regional authorities, would lead to many projects that would have a positive impact on the whole local or regional community.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: in writing.- With this resolution, the European Union seeks to acquire powers in the area of urban policy when it does not have any.We are increasing the levels of governance of the European Structural Funds and investment, while the only way to conduct coherent and effective policies, at least in France, would be to have a long-term global vision at the national level.I therefore vote without hesitation against this text.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written. - EU cohesion policy for the 2014-2020 programming period remains the main investment instrument covering all EU regions and an opportunity to create a more bottom-up sustainable growth process, which would support job creation, entrepreneurship and innovation at the level of local and regional economies, which would improve the quality of life of citizens in the regions of the European Union and lead to solidarity and more successful development. I believe that regional and local authorities are closer to the citizens and better understand local needs and policies and initiatives designed to improve the lives of citizens in the field of employment, innovation, health, environment, energy, transport. Smart cities and smart specialization strategies are two innovations that policymakers have reluctantly embraced and translated into concrete EU policies and initiatives. About 70% of Europe's population lives in cities and urban agglomerations. They are a driver of economic development and will decide on the future strength of the EU at global level, which is why their exceptional role in the European Structural and Investment Funds needs to be recognized and supported to participate as effectively as possible in the withdrawal and use of these funds. funds.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. - More than 75% of the EU population lives in an urban context, which makes cities spaces of high population concentration, with growing needs in terms of territorial, political, social, economic and cultural organization. Cities are increasingly important in the management of public affairs, not only because of the material and territorial dimension, but also because they correspond to spaces of greater proximity and mobilization, of citizenship, gaining a political expression that cannot be neglected. The creation of two specific lines of financing for cities - Community-Led Local Development and Integrated Territorial Investments - aims to contribute to better access by cities to financing. We reject the growing tendency to establish direct communication between the European Commission and "the cities", without the intermediation of the Member States, in the continued logic of upholding the sovereignty of States, seeking to remove from them their responsibilities and the necessary definition of priorities and strategies for their regions. We reaffirm that cohesion policies must privilege Member States and their regional development strategies and not an agenda to promote the EU and its institutions.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. - For the first time, in the 2014-2020 period, a coherent framework was created, called the "Common Provisions Regulation" (CPR), which defines common rules for the five European Structural and Investment Funds (ESIF): the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF), the European Social Fund (ESF), the Cohesion Fund (CF), the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD) and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund (EMFF) . It is important to identify measures aimed at strengthening the role of regional and local authorities in the management and implementation of ESI Funds through partnership agreements and operational programs. This will allow local and regional authorities to strike a balance between the Union's objective of greater economic, social and territorial cohesion on the one hand, and the special needs of local communities on the other. Given the importance of the role played by local authorities and the desire to strengthen the implementation of the subsidiarity principle, I voted in favor of this resolution.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing.- The Union's cohesion policy offers a good example of governance at several levels, following a bottom-up approach, where local and regional authorities - in their relations with the ESI funds - strike a fair balance between the objective of theUnion of stronger economic, social and territorial cohesion and the impact that European policies will have on their territory.It is for this kind of approach that I support this resolution on the role of the authorities, which is essential for absorbing the available European funds.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. - The proximity of citizens to local and regional power allows to maximize the impact and efficiency of public spending, which, under the auspices of the institutions and administrations of the aforementioned authorities, is oriented to local needs, in proximity to citizens. In this sense, the role of local and regional authorities in the design and implementation of European Union strategies was covered by the provisions of Article 5 of the Regulation on Common Provisions, which sets the standards for the five European Structural and Structural Funds. Investment (FEEI). Given the above, and in order to be able to guarantee the application of Community funds, it is expected that the Commission, as guardian of the treaties, will strive to strengthen the capacities of local and regional authorities, endowing them with the conditions to fulfill the envisaged role. . This report comes in the context of the question of the Committee on Regional Development, which, in terms of strengthening the limited resources of local and regional authorities, asks the Commission to clearly define which "concrete support" measures are envisaged. I voted in favor.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. As a party we are against the EU deciding where to invest when that decision should be the preserve of Member States.  On that point of principle we voted against.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. - This resolution highlights the fundamental role of local and regional authorities in the design and implementation of EU strategies, recognizing that the proximity of these bodies to citizens and the diversity of governance at local and regional level is an advantage for the EU . I believe it is important to achieve synergies and complementarity between the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESIF) and other EU programs, where local and regional authorities can play a useful role in achieving the objectives of cohesion policy. In this regard, I believe that the EU's cohesion policy is a good example of multi-level governance, with a bottom-up approach, in which local and regional authorities, within the framework of the ESIF, achieve a balance between Union's objective of greater economic, social and territorial cohesion and the territorial impact of EU policies. This ensures compliance with key EU policy objectives, such as economic growth, social progress and sustainable development. In view of the above, I voted in favor of this document.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: in writing. - This resolution aims, through a plurality of proposals, to support the role of local and regional authorities in the European Structural and Investment Funds. Cohesion policy is the main instrument of investment directed towards the territories and the population of the Union in order to support them in their development. However, local and regional authorities play a key role in its design and implementation; it is therefore necessary to support them through appropriate action levers. We therefore ask, among other things, that the Commission ensure that it provides these authorities with support in improving their capacities. The Commission must also promote, through the necessary measures, a strengthening of the role of these actors in the management and implementation of structural and investment funds through partnership agreements and operational programs. We also underline the qualitative leap represented by initiatives such as that of participatory local development, now eligible for funding from the ERDF and the ESF. The involvement of local and regional authorities in the implementation of Union strategies is an asset that must be valued; that is why I voted in favor of this text.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: written. - Regional and local entities with a federal structure have a greater margin of maneuver to elaborate national policies that have an impact on the regional and local levels. As far as cohesion policy is concerned, the level of development of consultations of regional and local authorities has increased over time. However, this level of development varies between states. Regional and local authorities are closer to citizens and have a better understanding of their own needs in order to improve the lives of citizens and promote economic growth and sustainable job creation. These entities therefore need greater budgetary support and level of co-financing of the projects. For these reasons, I support the Resolution approved by the European Parliament in order to correct these deficiencies and define what specific support it intends to offer to regional and local entities in the management of ESI Funds during the 2014-2020 period, as well as to undertake a public consultation on the modalities to strengthen the role of regional and local entities.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing.- Yesterday, we voted by show of hands a resolution to strengthen the role of local and regional authorities in the management of European structural and investment funds for 2014-2020, but which also asks the Commission to initiate a consultationpublic - followed by a possible initiative - in order to reflect on the means available to allow such reinforcement.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: in writing.- I voted in favor because it is an important resolution that draws attention to several aspects.First of all, it emphasizes the need to ensure the high-quality involvement of local and regional authorities in the decision-making process at national level.Secondly, it emphasizes the need for partnership, which must be based on the specific needs and characteristics of the region, as different regions face different levels of globalization, climate change, energy security, migration flows and increasing urbanization or other challenges.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. - Cohesion policy reform will be the EU's main investment tool for achieving Europe 2020 goals. Acting at the regional level as an opportunity mechanism for a sustainable growth process, supporting job creation, entrepreneurship, innovation economic, the quality of life of citizens and the sustainable development of regions, the role of local and regional authorities in adapting and implementing EU strategies, cohesion policy is fundamental for an effective response to the unique needs and characteristics that each region presents . Thus, multilevel governance is an example of the democratic dimension of the EU and of how the measures outlined can have effective results. Economic growth, social progress, territorial cohesion and sustainable development are common objectives of the Union that will become more achievable thanks to a plurality of government at local and regional level, allowing the EU and each region to effectively apply the instruments at its disposal . As I agree with the measures presented in this motion for a resolution and because I consider the need to bring local and regional decisions closer to local authorities and citizens, I voted in favor of this proposal.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution which underlines the role of cities and regions in the preparation and implementation of cohesion policy.This text evokes the principle of partnership in the preparation of operational programs, emphasizes multi-level governance, and evokes the new instruments of cohesion policy, namely integrated territorial investments (ITI) and local development led bylocal actors (CLLD).

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: written. - We voted in favor of this proposed Resolution, since it vindicates the role of regional and local entities in the management of ESI Funds, given that it is these entities that are closest to the public and have competencies to carry out great part of the policies for which these funds are designed. We believe that citizen participation is key in the management of these funds and in European policies in general, and that ESI Funds are of great importance in the search for development and cohesion between different regions and peoples. However, we express our reluctance by voting against paragraph 2, which leaves, in a veiled way, a door open to the reduction of these funds on the basis of criteria of coherence and efficiency. This is contrary to our vision that these funds should always be increased and oriented according to criteria of social cohesion, development and redistribution, giving more resources to local entities so that they can carry out these objectives.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: in writing.- I would like to emphasize the important role played by local and regional authorities in the formulation and implementation of EU strategies, and I recognize the role played by a wide range of stakeholders from Member States to community groups.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: written. - The Resolution presented allows for a further step in the correct and more efficient allocation of the European Structural and Investment Funds by local and regional entities, through an increase in their participation in all phases of the project, as well through new tools such as integrated territorial investments or participatory local development. However, it is always good to remember that regional development and cohesion policy must be subject to the principle of reducing disparities between European regions. However, the need for synergies of these funds with the European Fund for Strategic Investments (Juncker Plan) is beginning to be heard frequently, while the new Dutch Presidency of the Council promotes a pact that gives preference to large urban areas, which which will undoubtedly tend to worsen disparities, if not remedied. In spite of everything, I consider that the Resolution itself is positive and can lead to better communication and administrative and financial cooperation between local, regional and state entities, as well as with European institutions. Therefore, I voted in favor of it.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. - Regional and local authorities, due to their proximity to citizens, have a better understanding of local needs and of the policies and initiatives needed to foster development and growth. It is therefore strategic to support their greater involvement in all stages of preparation and implementation of the Operational Programs, in order to increase the absorption rate of European Structural and Investment Funds (ESI) and achieve the objectives of economic and territorial cohesion of the EU . I hope that a more efficient use of European funding will parallel a reduction of the structural weaknesses present within the programming phase. Only through good multi-level governance will we be able to help local and regional authorities both to give concrete answers to global challenges such as climate change, energy security, migration flows and increased urbanization, and to address specific capacity problems. administrative and regulatory complexity. I therefore voted in favor of the European Parliament resolution.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing.- The resolution under consideration defends a desirable and necessary impulse to increase and deepen partnerships for development.In this sense, cohesion policy must involve local and regional actors in the whole process of granting and implementing European Union strategies.Only then will it be possible to work from the bottom to the top.It is important to take into account the importance of a good articulation between technical means at different levels - local, regional, national and European - in order to guarantee the full benefit of the opportunities for participation and financing.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: in writing. - Local and regional authorities in the EU Member States play a very important role, which is recognized not only in national but also European legislation, as evidenced by the active involvement of these authorities in discussions on the preparation and implementation of operational programs. The knowledge of local and regional authorities is particularly important for the development of future policies, as they are the closest to citizens and communities, know their needs best, and are able to support the work at European level by exchanging views and proposing specific policies. solutions in the context of job creation, healthcare or the environment, energy and transport. The development of urban-rural links will bring further benefits for EU citizens as this approach enables the fuller use of the potential of both cities and rural areas by providing each other specific services. The fullest possible use should also be made of international cooperation within and outside the EU. Cross-border ties and cooperation of border regions can foster many social and economic goals, while strengthening the extremely important dimension of European territorial cooperation. Also in this context, discussions and decisions should be made on the shape of the European Structural and Investment Funds, so that they are well suited to the needs and opportunities of regions, towns and villages in the EU.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ In my view, local and regional authorities play a very important role within the framework of the European Structural and Investment Funds because they are the closest institutions to the citizens and, as such, understand their needs the best. Local and regional authorities have limited means to support the local population, and by increasing the role of the local and regional authorities in this way the citizens will benefit most from the ESIF, and I welcome the agreement on the text that was made at the REGI committee by the democratic political groups.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing - In the new programming period 2014-2020, there were several changes in the distribution of structural funds. In addition to the creation of common rules for all five cohesion policy funds, more emphasis has begun to be placed on the principle of partnership and multilevel governance. This means that local and regional authorities were in most cases consulted during the negotiations on the shape of the operational programs for this period. Unfortunately, these bodies have not always been accepted as full partners in the discussion. I believe that, in order for regional policy to be truly successful, it is absolutely crucial that the attitudes of the people living in the regions themselves are taken into account. That is why I supported the resolution, which calls for the role of local and regional authorities to be strengthened in achieving the objectives of cohesion policy. Community-led local development initiatives are also important, and their role has also been strengthened during this period. The local community must be clearly involved in improving living conditions at the local level. National governments should therefore work to increase the administrative capacity of cities and regions so that they are able to create effective and long-term projects. Local and regional authorities are currently facing various challenges, from globalization to energy security to increased urbanization, for which the Structural and Investment Funds are intended.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the resolution on the role of local and regional authorities in the context of the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESI Funds), fundamental tools in responding to the needs of citizens at local level. Considering that cohesion policy continues to be the main investment tool in most European regions in the 2014-2020 programming period, it is clear that local authorities need significant economic support to co-finance their projects. If cohesion policy aims to reduce economic, social and territorial disparities between Member States and their regions, it is through an inclusive strategy that it can represent a real opportunity to create a sustainable growth process, to foster creation jobs, entrepreneurship and innovation of local and regional economies, improving citizens' quality of life and creating solidarity and greater development in EU regions.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing - Strengthening the influence and role of local and regional authorities in the management of the European Structural and Investment Funds can strengthen the economic, social and territorial cohesion of the European Union and, in particular, tackle regional disparities and contribute to sustainable and inclusive growth.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: written. - EU cohesion policy for the 2014-2020 programming period remains the main investment instrument covering all EU regions and is an opportunity to create a more bottom-up sustainable growth process, which would support was given to job creation, entrepreneurship and innovation at the level of local and regional economies, which would improve the quality of life of citizens in the regions of the European Union and lead to solidarity and more successful development. The purpose of cohesion policy is to reduce economic, social and territorial disparities between the Member States of the European Union and their regions through a comprehensive strategy. New community-led integrated territorial investment and local development initiatives represent major changes in the ability of local stakeholders to use funding flows and plan well-targeted local initiatives. Multilevel governance supports the EU's basic policy objectives such as economic growth, social progress and sustainable development, strengthens the democratic dimension of the European Union and increases the effectiveness of its political action. Urban areas are playing an increasing role in today's world and EU policies have an important role to play in establishing the right framework in which European urban areas can drive their own growth potential, and I supported the report.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written. - Cohesion policy of the European Union in the period from 2014-2020. is the main investment instrument covering all regions of the Union. It is an opportunity for local and regional economies to create new businesses, entrepreneurial and innovative innovations, as well as sustainable growth. Due to their closeness to the people, local and regional authorities have a key role to play in shaping and implementing European Union strategies. Parliament believes that multilevel governance is the basis for achieving the Union's political objectives such as economic development, social progress, sustainable development and ensuring the democratic dimension of the Union. However, local and regional authorities today face challenges such as globalization, climate change, energy security and migration waves and it should be taken into account that each region has its own specifics and special needs. I support the proposals made in this debate because I consider the Union's cohesion policy to be a good example of multilevel governance with a bottom-up approach in which regional and local authorities link the Union's objectives of greater economic, social and territorial cohesion to the real impact of Union policies. field.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the resolution on the oral question on the role of local and regional authorities in the European Structural and Investment Funds.Cohesion policy is an important instrument of the European Union and will play an important role in the 2014-2020 programming year as a major investment instrument, covering all EU regions, and is an opportunity to establish a process for sustainable growth.In particular, I support the resolution because it emphasizes the key role of local and regional authorities in formulating and implementing EU strategies, recognizing the role of a wide range of stakeholders, from Member States to local communities.We need good cooperation between all stakeholders at EU level to design and implement EU strategies effectively.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which focuses on measures to support and strengthen the role of local and regional authorities in the European Structural and Investment (ESI) Funds. It rightly highlights the importance of local knowledge in achieving overarching cohesion goals and delivering well-targeted local investment initiatives.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: in writing. - We voted in favor of the resolution as it aims to further strengthen the role of regional and local authorities in shaping national policies on local and regional issues. In the context of Cohesion Policy, the aim has been set, which has entered into legal force through Regulation 1303/2013 on the operation of GRNETs, ​​that the views and positions of local authorities should be taken into account in consultations on regulations and the approval of operational programs (programs financed by GRNET in each country). Nevertheless, the degree of involvement of local and regional authorities in these negotiations varies from one Member State to another, and further strengthening of this role is essential for the more effective implementation of Cohesion Policy objectives.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: in writing.The development of the province is a key condition for the sustainable development of the Member States of the Union.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the motion because I believe that local and regional authorities have an important role to play in formulating and implementing development strategies. I also confirmed this view during the debate on the subject, and emphasized that party politics should be excluded from the allocation of development resources. I also consider this important because in Hungary 80–95% of investments are currently made with the support of the European Union, but the efficiency of development programs is low. This ultimately contributes to the increase in corruption, such as the practice of overpricing projects. I agree that EU cohesion policy will continue to be the main investment tool in this programming period, covering all EU regions and offering opportunities for sustainable growth and bottom-up development. I believe that the EFSI should stimulate growth and job creation. But it also requires synergies and complementarities between relevant programs, as well as space for community-led local development initiatives. Projects with high social, economic and other added value should be targeted, contributing to sustainable and long-term inclusive growth, economic, social and territorial cohesion. Of course, in this process, we must not forget the lagging regions or the catching up of the countryside!

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: in writing. - The European Union's cohesion policy is the main investment vehicle for all EU regions, and its aim is to reduce economic, social and territorial disparities between EU Member States and their regions. The EU's adoption of the Multiannual Financial Framework for 2014-2020 provided an opportunity to create, for the first time in history, a coherent framework for the five European Structural and Investment Funds. It is thanks to them that the role of local and regional authorities in developing and implementing the EU strategy has been significantly increased. Nevertheless, more needs to be done to strengthen the role of local and regional authorities. Among other things, the report of the European Parliament points to the need to improve administrative capacity and to tackle structural weaknesses. In addition, community-led local development in which local authorities are not just managers, but become action partners should be supported. Multilevel governance supports the EU's fundamental political goals, such as economic growth, social progress and sustainable development, and strengthens the Union's democratic dimension and increases the effectiveness of its political action. Therefore, I have chosen to vote in favor of the report on the role of local and regional authorities in the European Structural and Investment Funds.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing. – I am in favour of this resolution. I am also in favour of synergies and complementarity between the ESI Funds and other EU programmes, in which local and regional authorities can play a useful role in attaining the objectives of cohesion policy. The European Parliament stresses, however, that any reprogramming of ESI Funds should be done in accordance with CPR rules and that new initiatives should not weaken the core of the ESI Funds. We point to the reinforced partnership principle and the European Code of Conduct on Partnership, which set out the legal involvement of local and regional authorities and provide for minimum requirements for their involvement in all phases of the preparation and implementation of operational programmes; recognise that, although local and regional authorities were consulted in most cases during the negotiations on the partnership agreements and operational programmes, their involvement did not amount to full partnership; urge the Member States, therefore, to fully comply with these requirements and increase efforts to address deficiencies.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which underlines the key role of local and regional authorities in shaping and implementing EU strategies. Indeed, I believe that the proximity of these authorities to citizens and the diversity of governance at local and regional level is an asset to the EU. I am also in favour of synergies and complementarity between the ESI Funds and other EU programmes, in which local and regional authorities can play a useful role in attaining the objectives of cohesion policy. Finally, I also believe that EU cohesion policy is a good example of multilevel governance with a bottom-up approach, where the local and regional authorities strike a balance between the Union’s goal of greater economic, social and territorial cohesion and the territorial impact of EU policies.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing.- Motion for a resolution - I supported the role of local and regional authorities in the European Structural and Investment Funds, as I believe that these authorities play an important role in achieving the objectives of European Union cohesion policy.Their participation in the preparation and implementation phases of operational programs contributes to the faster implementation of the guidelines at the national level.Only in this way will it help to create opportunities, sustainable growth, create new jobs, grow innovation and start entrepreneurship.As a result, the quality of life of EU citizens will improve, the position of the Member States and equality in all EU regions will be strengthened.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: written. - We voted in favor of this proposed Resolution, since it vindicates the role of regional and local entities in the management of ESI Funds, given that it is these entities that are closest to the public and have competencies to carry out great part of the policies for which these funds are designed. We believe that citizen participation is key in the management of these funds and in European policies in general, and that ESI Funds are of great importance in the search for development and cohesion between different regions and peoples. However, we express our reluctance by voting against paragraph 2, which leaves, in a veiled way, a door open to the reduction of these funds on the basis of criteria of coherence and efficiency. This is contrary to our vision that these funds should always be increased and oriented according to criteria of social cohesion, development and redistribution, giving more resources to local entities so that they can carry out these objectives.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing.- EU cohesion policy will continue to be the main investment instrument in the 2014-2020 programming period, covering all EU regions and offering the opportunity to create a more bottom-up process for sustainable growth, supporting job creation, entrepreneurship and entrepreneurship.and innovation at the level of local and regional economies, improving the quality of life and solidarity of citizens and increasing development in EU regions.I voted in favor of the proposal.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which lays out a set of recommendations concerning the role of regional and local authorities in the European Structural and Investment Fund (ESIF). Its main message, which I completely support, is that local and regional authorities play a key role in shaping and implementing EU strategies. The text outlines the positive synergies and complementarity between the ESI Funds and other EU programmes, in which local and regional authorities can play a useful role in attaining the objectives of cohesion policy. In order to fulfil these objectives, enhancing the administrative capacity and tackling the structural weaknesses of local and regional authorities are pivotal to both the programming and the implementation phases of the operational programmes and to achieving a higher absorption rate of ESI funds. The resolution therefore rightly calls on the Commission to ensure that support is provided for capacity building for local and regional authorities and their administrations and institutions, so that they are in a position to play a meaningful role in cohesion policy.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: written.- We are talking about a Resolution that highlights a series of necessary actions by local and regional entities in the management of the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESI Funds).Better administrative capacity, the simplification of procedures, as well as the creation of synergies between European, national, regional and local authorities are key to carrying out a good set-up of the ESI Funds.It is also necessary to highlight, as said Resolution does, the role that tools such as integrated territorial investment (ITI) or local development in charge of local communities (CLLD) play to promote synergies, by facilitating the use of various funds.The Resolution also highlights the importance that the urban agenda can play in relation to the management of these funds in the next semester.For all these reasons, I believe it necessary to vote in their favor.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ With my socialists colleagues, I voted in favour of this resolution because Smart Cities and Smart Specialisation Strategies are two innovations that have been quickly taken on board by policymakers and translated into specific EU policies or initiatives. Moreover, the EU ministers’ agreement on the Riga 2015 declaration paved the way for an EU Urban Agenda, which is now expected to lead to the ‘Pact of Amsterdam’. The latter is a future-oriented programme in which the participation of European cities is a central element, and through which the Dutch Council presidency of 2016 aims to establish a bottom-up approach.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: written.- I voted in favor of this resolution which contains a series of recommendations regarding the role of regional and local authorities in the European Structural and Investment Fund.After all, local and regional authorities play a crucial role in shaping and implementing European strategies and policy objectives.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - The role of cities in contemporary development is indisputable. They are spaces of great population representation (more than 75% of EU citizens live in an urban context), with increasing needs in terms of their political, social, economic and cultural organization, and also with new demands, both institutional and from different population sectors. . The creation of two specific lines of financing for cities - Community-Led Local Development and Integrated Territorial Investments - through the European Structural and Investment Funds will contribute to better access by cities to important financing, which could contribute to job creation , the improvement of infrastructures, the optimization of services, for their development and that of their populations. However, there is an issue that needs to be highlighted, which is the tendency to overcome obstacles to a federalist logic (by the Member States or in the definition of the treaties themselves) through direct communication between the European Commission and "the cities", without the intermediation of Member States, with their definition of priorities for their regions.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: written.- With the new initiatives of integrated territorial investments and the local development led by the local population, gradual changes in the possibilities of local actors, sources of finance can be bundled.The report emphasizes that local and regional authorities play a central role in the design and implementation of EU strategies, while recognizing the role of a wide range of stakeholders, from Member States to citizens' groups.The proximity of these local authorities to the citizens and the diversity of governance at local and regional level are beneficial to the EU.I therefore agree with this report.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: in writing.- Cohesion policy is a good example of multi-level governance.It should not be forgotten that the role of local communities is crucial for the effectiveness of European projects and the absorption of resources.Regional and local authorities must be key partners in policy-making, with the common goal of better living for citizens.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution because the role of regional and local authorities is seen as key in promoting European Union strategies and initiatives.I agree that the involvement of regions in the EU's multilevel governance, especially in the bottom-up process, contributes to sustainable development, job creation and innovation at the level of local and regional economies.These initiatives then have a direct impact on improving the quality of life of citizens in the region.In this context, I believe that we should pay far more attention to disadvantaged regions, which are suffering from the departure of large numbers of people and are at risk of depopulation in the future.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: in writing.- I support the resolution because the EU's cohesion policy is the EU's most important investment instrument.From my experience as Minister of Culture in 2007–2014, I can indeed confirm that the European Structural and Investment Funds are an extremely important tool with important benefits.I would like to emphasize that the success of the implemented projects largely depends on good cooperation of government institutions with local governments and local communities.The role of local authorities, their competences and proper training are crucial in the process of effective use of resources from structural funds.In the field of culture in Poland, we managed to use 100% of the funds allocated to investments.This is the effect of very good cooperation.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: in writing. - Efficiently operating regional and local self-governments is the key to good management and spending of European funds. It is at this level that the needs of local communities can be best identified and the planned investments weave into the overall development strategy of the country. The possibility of using many European funds intended for leveling development disproportions between regions, modernizing rural areas or increasing the level of qualifications of the inhabitants is an undeniable advantage of our membership. However, in order to use this opportunity effectively, it is necessary to properly identify the investment needs of each region. The role of local and regional authorities in this process should be strengthened, because it is at these levels that the most important decisions are made every day. It is in the authorities of the region or commune that the first line of fight against the most important problems, such as inefficient communication, natural disasters or preparation of conditions for investments that create new jobs, is located. Of course, the mere inclusion of the commune council or voivodeship assembly in the decision-making process is not enough. It is necessary to properly prepare local officials and create mechanisms of public consultations that will ensure that theory is confronted with practice. Such an approach will not only guarantee that European funds will go where they are most needed, but will also allow local entrepreneurs to be more involved in the implementation of these investments. I voted in favor of this report because I believe that Polish local governments deserve the right to vote on an issue that is so important to them.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted to abstain this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is concerned by the ongoing military and humanitarian crisis in Yemen, in particular the role played by both Saudi Arabia and Iran via proxies in the conflict. Amendment 1 calls for an arms embargo using the EU Common Position on Arms Exports 2008/944/CFSP. Whilst we are concerned by the role of western arms exports to Saudi Arabia, we cannot support the use of EU mechanisms to address the issue, so we voted against this particular amendment. Overall we abstained.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP voted to abstain on this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is concerned by the ongoing military and humanitarian crisis in Yemen, in particular the role played by both Saudi Arabia and Iran via proxies in the conflict. Amendment 1 calls for an arms embargo using the EU Common Position on Arms Exports 2008/944/CFSP. Whilst we are concerned by the role of western arms exports to Saudi Arabia, we cannot support the use of EU mechanisms to address the issue, so we voted against this particular amendment. Overall we abstained.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: in writing.- The vote on the joint motion for a resolution has been postponed until the next plenary session.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I opposed any delays to this report as I feel that the reasoning was inappropriate. I wish to clarify, however, that I wished to abstain on the joint motion for a resolution, as I object to much of the content whilst agreeing with the broad sentiment.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution on the humanitarian situation in Yemen.The Saudi-led military intervention in Yemen has created a catastrophic humanitarian situation, affecting people all over the country, with serious consequences for the region and a threat to international peace and security.At least 5,979 people have been killed since the conflict began, almost half of them civilians and 28,208 injured.I agree with the need to coordinate humanitarian action under the auspices of the UN, and I support calls for all parties to contribute to meeting Yemen's humanitarian needs.All countries must allow the import and supply of urgently needed food, medicine and other necessary assistance.I support the calls for the EU to effectively promote compliance with international humanitarian law.Saudi Arabia and Iran must work together to resolve this crisis, to act pragmatically and in good faith, and to end the fighting in Yemen.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted to abstain this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is concerned by the ongoing military and humanitarian crisis in Yemen, in particular the role played by both Saudi Arabia and Iran via proxies in the conflict. Amendment 1 calls for an arms embargo using the EU Common Position on Arms Exports 2008/944/CFSP. Whilst we are concerned by the role of western arms exports to Saudi Arabia, we cannot support the use of EU mechanisms to address the issue, so we voted against this particular amendment. Overall we abstained.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: in writing.- I voted against this tremendously angelic motion for a resolution: wouldn't this catalog of good feelings hide some bad faith?In any case, I refuse to allow the Commission to take advantage of the conflicts which shake the planet - and to the emergence of which it has often contributed through its irresponsibility - to arrogate to itself new powers and to claim a legitimacy that it does not have.not to deal with such serious international problems.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing.- Yemen has been facing a very serious humanitarian crisis for months.Food insecurity, malnutrition, indiscriminate attacks on civilians, destruction of medical and civil infrastructures are daily problems generated by the persistent state of war within the country.The presence of a large number of hybrid actors involved does not facilitate the resolution of the conflict which requires the collaboration of all the powers in the area, in particular Saudi Arabia and Iran, to start the peace process.I signed and supported the resolution on the humanitarian situation in Yemen because I am convinced that only a political, inclusive and negotiated solution can guarantee an end to violence.The EU must work to promote respect for international humanitarian law and to foster a new round of negotiations under the aegis of the UN.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
