text: written.- We voted in favor since the text calls on the EU to apply international humanitarian law, as set out in the European guidelines, and for its application to be included in the dialogue with Saudi Arabia.Furthermore, it urges the EU High Representative to launch an initiative to impose an arms embargo on Saudi Arabia to immediately put an end to human rights violations in Yemen.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing. - Apparently, the MEPs who voted in favor of this resolution have still not understood that political problems cannot be solved by declarations of good feeling. Although it has the good sense to question the strikes carried out by Saudi Arabia, so is this resolution on the humanitarian situation in Yemen, which I therefore had to reject. Tribal conflicts and the country's general insecurity will not be resolved just because the European Union looks big. This must let the United Nations play its role in favor of the peace process. The dire humanitarian situation - 153 clinics that previously provided food to more than 450,000 children at risk have closed, as have 158 outpatient clinics that provided essential care to nearly half a million children under the age of 18. five years - must not provide the Union with a pretext to go beyond the prerogatives of the Member States in their role on the international scene and Brussels has no legitimacy to impose its policy on the export of arms on the sovereign European nations .

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing.- I wanted to support with my vote the resolution that analyzes the humanitarian emergency in Yemen caused in large part by the massive presence of ISIS and the continuing conflict that has already caused over 5,700 victims, half of which were civilians.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this resolution because it spoke on the humanitarian situation in Yemen. The current crisis in Yemen is the result of the failure of successive governments to live up to the legitimate expectations of the Yemeni people in terms of democracy, economic and social development, stability and security. This failure led to the outbreak of violent conflict, the failure to form inclusive governments and the fair sharing of power, and the systematic disregard for the differences between the country's various tribes, the prevailing insecurity and economic paralysis. The military intervention in Yemen, which also involved the use of internationally banned cluster bombs and has led to a catastrophic humanitarian situation affecting the people throughout the country, has serious consequences for the region and threatens international peace and security. Yemeni civilians are the first victims of the current military conflict as insurgents belonging to the Houthi group have launched a siege of Taizé, the third largest city in Yemen, and are obstructing the sending of humanitarian aid to the city. Parliament therefore emphasized the need for coordination of humanitarian action under the auspices of the UN and urged all parties to contribute to meeting humanitarian needs. Parliament called on all parties to the conflict to allow the import and supply of urgently needed food, medicine, fuel and other necessary assistance through the UN and international humanitarian channels to meet the immediate needs of the civilian population affected by the crisis, in accordance with the principles of impartiality, neutrality and independence.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: written.- I support this Statement on the humanitarian situation in Yemen.The situation in that war-impoverished country is catastrophic, and I think we need to focus on resolving the humanitarian situation in that country.The bombings and blockades should be stopped immediately so that assistance can be provided to civilians suffering a real humanitarian catastrophe due to the siege of cities in war casualties.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. - The UN special envoy, Ismail Ould Cheikh Ahmed, has taken steps to hold UN-facilitated peace talks to mediate in the difficult humanitarian situation due to the ongoing civil war in Yemen. These mediation efforts must be sustained because the humanitarian cost in terms of civilian casualties and the destruction of residential buildings and production and trading facilities is now enormous and beyond the scope of international organizations to help. The military response cannot be the solution because all the efforts implemented so far by both the Saudi coalition and the Houti rebels and their respective allies have only aggravated the serious humanitarian crisis underway and allowed Al-Qaeda and Daesh to strengthen their presence in the 'area and to increase the effectiveness and scope of their terrorist actions, with obvious negative repercussions for both sides and for the international community. UN mediation is needed for a truce between the parties and an international humanitarian operation to rescue the civilian population of Yemen.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: in writing.- This motion for a resolution attempts to take stock of the current situation in Yemen, where community tensions have turned into a very complex ethnic conflict which has resulted in a serious humanitarian crisis now affecting almost the entire population.This text is neither more nor less than a series of banalities concerning an extremely complex conflict involving certain regional powers such as Saudi Arabia and Iran.Although we believe that these States, in close cooperation with the United Nations, are trying to calm the situation in Yemen, we consider that the European Union has no legitimacy to intervene on this subject.I therefore voted against this text.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: signed up. - Yemen is facing a critical situation, characterized by conflicts, tribal tensions, strong violence with a significant humanitarian impact on the civilian population, especially on children. The current violence has its origins in the failure of government structures to achieve the democratic, economic and social aspirations of the Yemeni people, thus generating dissatisfaction and division in society. most often in the deaths of civilians. Thus, the situation in Yemen is characterized by strong instability, by an unfortunate humanitarian crisis exacerbated by bombings and constant conflicts. It is therefore necessary to restore the situation in Yemen, to strengthen security, to have functioning government structures that make consistent efforts to combat extremism and violence in the region. I believe that in this situation, all parties must respect international humanitarian law and international human rights law and work urgently with UN and humanitarian aid organizations to provide assistance to those in need. I spoke in favor of this report because I believe that immediate action is needed to resolve the humanitarian crisis in Yemen and to restore stability and peace in the territory.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor as this resolution addresses the same issues as the resolution of the ECR Group, but more precisely, also considering explicitly that the humanitarian situation in Yemen is caused by the strong presence of ISIS (which was not mentioned in the previous resolution).

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted to abstain this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is concerned by the ongoing military and humanitarian crisis in Yemen, in particular the role played by both Saudi Arabia and Iran via proxies in the conflict. Amendment 1 calls for an arms embargo using the EU Common Position on Arms Exports 2008/944/CFSP. Whilst we are concerned by the role of western arms exports to Saudi Arabia, we cannot support the use of EU mechanisms to address the issue, so we voted against this particular amendment. Overall we abstained.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because I am concerned by the current situation in Yemen, which is a potential threat to international security and could have grave consequences. I am particularly worried about the fate of civilians that had been severely affected by the air-strikes and suffer from food and fuel shortages. The nationwide ceasefire declared in December should be reintroduced as soon as possible and negotiation discussions reopened. I am also hoping for an independent investigation into alleged war crimes, namely the deliberate targeting of civilians and civilian infrastructure such as hospitals.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing.- We support the joint resolution on the humanitarian situation in Yemen and stress that only resolving the conflict in a political way, without exclusions and after negotiations, can lead to the restoration of peace and the maintenance of unity, sovereignty, independence andterritorial integrity of Yemen.We urge all parties involved to take part as soon as possible in a new round of UN-sponsored peace talks.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing.- I have decided to vote in favor of the resolution as I strongly believe that the only long-term solution to the humanitarian crisis in Yemen is an inclusive political dialogue, in line with the framework provided by the Gulf Cooperation Council initiative, the results of the conference on national dialogue and the various conclusions of the United Nations Security Council and the European Council.The tragedy of deaths among civilians and humanitarian workers in the country and the apparently indiscriminate attacks on civil infrastructures, including hospitals and schools, must stir the consciences of European citizens and with them of the institutions that represent them so that the necessary political pressure can be exertedleading to the cessation of violence

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing.- The news coming from Yemen, although it gets less coverage than the Syrian and Libyan ones, are no longer reassuring.There the situation is different, the actors involved are others, but the country is destroyed on a humanitarian level.I voted in favor of this resolution because it highlights the problems and, without prejudice to the powers of the European Union in what happens within the borders of another sovereign state, it sets the stage for future humanitarian aid.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted to abstain this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is concerned by the ongoing military and humanitarian crisis in Yemen, in particular the role played by both Saudi Arabia and Iran via proxies in the conflict. Amendment 1 calls for an arms embargo using the EU Common Position on Arms Exports 2008/944/CFSP. Whilst we are concerned by the role of western arms exports to Saudi Arabia, we cannot support the use of EU mechanisms to address the issue, so we voted against this particular amendment. Overall we abstained.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing.- Yemen is experiencing an unprecedented humanitarian crisis, the result of the collapse of the regime and the war that is raging on its territory.The most elementary norms of international law are not being observed, contributing to aggravate the impact of this conflict on the civilian population.Schools and Hospitals attacked, preventing access to education or health;entire regions without access to food or water.Countless terrorist organizations also proliferate in the territory of this failed state, including the most active cell in Al-Quaeda.It is urgent that the international community, and the parties involved, can end the conflict.But it is even more urgent to ensure that international humanitarian law is respected, thus avoiding that the innocent, those civilians whom the war has not already killed, may not die from the consequences of the conflict.Even in war there are limits.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing.- Given the current conflict in Yemen that sees the Yemeni authorities oppose the Houti rebels, there have been numerous violations of human rights and international humanitarian law, also contemplating possible repercussions that would seriously jeopardize the stability of the geographical area of the hornof Africa, the Red Sea and the Middle East.I am in favor of the European Parliament motion for a resolution which condemns the violence and calls on Iran, Saudi Arabia and all Yemeni parties to put an end to their dispute through dialogue.It is in fact necessary to consider that only a political agreement can lead to lasting peace.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ Ongoing hostilities in Yemen are continuous causes of loss of life, bringing great suffering to the Yemeni people and also continuous destabilisation of the governance structures. These circumstances also foster a fertile opportunity for ISIS-DAESH and other terrorist and extremist organisations that wreak terror not only on Yemenis, but also on other populations. The motion for a resolution recognises the importance of coordinated humanitarian action under UN leadership, calls for compliance with international humanitarian and human rights law, and seeks protection for basic civilian infrastructure such as medical facilities and water systems. I have thus voted in favour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: written.- I did not vote because the vote was postponed.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: signed up. - The current crisis in Yemen is the result of a failure of successive governments to respond to the legitimate aspirations of the Yemeni people for democracy, economic and social development, stability and security. According to the 2016 Overview of Humanitarian Needs launched in November 2015, 21.2 million people (82% of the population) are in urgent need of humanitarian assistance. Currently, there are an estimated 2.1 million undernourished people, of whom more than 1.3 million are children suffering from severe acute malnutrition. I am deeply concerned about the alarming deterioration of the humanitarian situation in Yemen, which is characterized by widespread food insecurity and severe malnutrition, attacks on civilians and health workers, and the destruction of civilian and medical infrastructure. Coordinated humanitarian action under the leadership of the UN is needed, and all countries must contribute to meeting humanitarian needs. It is important to allow the entry and delivery of urgently needed food, medical and fuel to meet the urgent needs of civilians affected by the crisis, in accordance with the principles of impartiality, neutrality and independence.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: in writing. - In its motion for a resolution adopted today, the European Parliament expressed its deep concern at the worrying deterioration of the humanitarian situation in Yemen. The situation in Yemen also poses a serious risk to the stability of the region, in particular the Horn of Africa, the Red Sea and the wider Middle East. Despite repeated calls for an end to hostilities, air strikes by the former internal conflict, the Saudi-led coalition, have intensified, food supplies have become insecure as a result of fighting and bombing, and there has been discrimination against the civilian population and health and aid workers. attacks and the destruction of civilian and medical infrastructure. The report emphasizes the need for coordinated humanitarian action under the auspices of the United Nations and urges all countries to play their part in meeting humanitarian needs. Furthermore, urges all parties to engage in a new round of UN-led peace talks as soon as possible, in good faith and without preconditions, to resolve their differences through dialogue and consultation, to refrain from using violence for political purposes and to refrain from provocation; from any unilateral action that could undermine the political solution.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The European Parliament is concerned about Saudi-led coalition airstrikes and the naval blockade, which led to thousands of civilian deaths and the destruction of physical infrastructure in Yemen, and also by the violent actions of the Houthis. The European Parliament stresses the need for coordinated humanitarian action under UN leadership while urging both sides to comply with international humanitarian law and international human rights law for the protection of civilians. Only a political, inclusive and negotiated solution to the conflict can restore peace and preserve the unity, sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity of Yemen. For these reasons I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: in writing.- This motion for a resolution responds to the humanitarian situation in Yemen, where humanitarian organizations estimate that 21 million Yemenis (82% of the total population) are in need of humanitarian assistance and that 14 million of them are suffering fromfood insecure or in need of health care.MEPs call on member states and the international community to step up their efforts to tackle the humanitarian, security and political crisis in Yemen.Considering that international cooperation is necessary to respond to this crisis, I voted in favor.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: in writing.- I am extremely concerned by the alarming worsening of the humanitarian situation in Yemen: risk of famine, indiscriminate attacks against civilians, medical personnel and humanitarian workers, destruction of civilian and medical infrastructure following the intensification of airstrikes, ground combat and artillery fire.More than 2.51 million Yemenis have been internally displaced.21.1 million people, or 80% of the population, are in need of protection or humanitarian assistance in one form or another.Over 2.2 million children are or are at risk of malnutrition.Faced with this alarming observation, I support the demand for coordinated humanitarian action under the aegis of the United Nations, a contribution from all countries to meet the humanitarian needs of Yemen and to allow access for aid fromemergency to the population.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing.- This text contains many good intentions, but shows a lack of knowledge of the ins and outs of the situation in Yemen.In addition, it tends to impose the Union's armaments policy on the States, and to give the latter an unjustified international role.Finally, it lacks discernment vis-à-vis Saudi Arabia, a state whose role is controversial.For these reasons, I opposed this text.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: In written form. - I supported the resolution on the humanitarian situation in Yemen, because I am very concerned about the fact that security in the country is constantly deteriorating and is beginning to take on an international dimension. On the one hand, Saudi Arabia is waging an open war against the rebels, considering them Iranian warheads, while Iran is calling for an immediate halt to air bombardment by the international coalition led by Saudi Arabia. Despite UN efforts to bring peace to the country, intense land and air strikes continue. In addition to the thousands of civilian casualties, more than 1.5 million people have fled their homes. If no measures are taken and a recent peace is not achieved, there is a great danger that the situation in the country will escalate into a real civil war, and hence into a regional ethnic war between Shiites and Sunnis.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: in writing.- We are voting in favor, it is finally time for the Union to take action against Saudi Arabia, this terrorist state, and we hope that it will not just stick to words, but will indeed impose an arms embargo and, ideally, economic sanctions.In any case, we will denounce any retreat of the Union towards Saudi Arabia

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - The current crisis in Yemen is the result of the failure of successive governments to respond to the legitimate aspirations of the Yemeni people for democracy, economic and social development, stability and security. On the other hand, military intervention in Yemen conducted by Saudi forces and the use of cluster bombs has led to a dramatic humanitarian situation. Since the start of the conflict, at least 5979 people have been killed, about half of whom are civilians, and 28,208 people have been injured and the victims include hundreds of women and children. I therefore express my concern about the alarming worsening of the humanitarian situation in Yemen, characterized by a situation of widespread food insecurity and acute malnutrition, indiscriminate attacks against civilians, doctors and members of humanitarian organizations, destruction of civil and medical infrastructure caused by existing internal conflict and the intensification of air strikes by the Saudi-led coalition.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as it is positive for human rights.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing - The humanitarian situation in Yemen remains alarming, as the Saudi-led coalition unilaterally withdrew from the ceasefire agreement and demonstrably bombed the blind and deaf centers in the Yemeni capital Sana'a, as well as chambers of commerce and a school.The rebels continue to besiege the city of Taiz, which has huge humanitarian consequences for the local civilian population.In addition, a coalition led by Saudi Arabia has ordered the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights to leave the country.There must be an immediate resumption of peace talks and an end to the coalition's bombing and blockade, as well as the siege of cities by rebels.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing.- I vote in favor of all reports on the humanitarian situation in Yemen, as it is finally time for the Union to take action against Saudi Arabia, this terrorist state, and I hope that it will not just stick to words, but will indeed impose an arms embargo and, ideally, and financial sanctions.In any case, I will denounce any retreat of the Union towards Saudi Arabia.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The humanitarian situation in Yemen is extremely worrisome, since the delivery of assistance has been impacted by continued fighting. Conflict combined with poverty, forced displacement and rising food prices have aggravated an already serious humanitarian crisis during the last year. I welcome the fact that the European Commission responded to the dramatic deterioration of the humanitarian situation in Yemen with an additional €15 million in emergency funding in December. This assistance will prioritize life-saving assistance in the sectors of health, wash, nutrition and food security, which have been particularly affected by the conflict and the collapse of government services Parties to the conflict have to abide by International Humanitarian Law and to ensure protection of civilians by refraining from direct and indiscriminate targeting of civilians and civilian infrastructure. Especially, the bombing of civilians and hospitals has to be avoided by all means and represents a violation of international humanitarian law.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: written.- I voted in favor of the resolution on the humanitarian situation in Yemen because, as a human rights politician, I expressly welcome the EU's active role in the development of a peace scenario.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ It is of crucial importance that the deterioration of the humanitarian situation in Yemen is urgently addressed. Civilians are suffering from food insecurity and severe malnutrition, indiscriminate attacks, including against medical and aid workers, and the destruction of civilian and medical infrastructure as a result of the intensification of airstrikes by the Saudi-led coalition and ground fighting and shelling. Talks including stakeholders from Yemen, the wider region and the international community have to be convened urgently in order to find a sustainable solution to the conflict.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: written.- We voted in favor since the text calls on the EU to apply international humanitarian law, as set out in the European guidelines, and for its application to be included in the dialogue with Saudi Arabia.Furthermore, it urges the EU High Representative to launch an initiative to impose an arms embargo on Saudi Arabia to immediately put an end to human rights violations in Yemen.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I support this resolution as I strongly believe that the EU can and must uphold international humanitarian law. The resolution highlights that some EU Member States have continued to authorise transfers of weapons to Saudi Arabia in clear violation of the EU Common Position, despite evidence that these weapons have been used to commit human rights abuses in Yemen. Together with other MEPs, we have also raised this issue directly with the Vice President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy in a written question and I welcome the adoption of a resolution on the matter as an additional means to build up pressure on the Commission and the European External Action Service.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour on the resolution about humanitarian situation in Yemen. The resolution expresses great concern at the alarming deterioration of the humanitarian situation in Yemen, which is characterised by widespread food insecurity and severe malnutrition, indiscriminate attacks against civilians and medical and aid workers. It stresses the need for coordinated humanitarian action under UN leadership, and urges all countries to contribute to addressing humanitarian needs.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE / NGL), in writing. - A long-running confrontation is taking place in Yemen, which intensified in 2015, when Saudi Arabia, as the leader of a US-backed coalition, began bombing Yemen, while imposing an almost complete blockade of imports into the country. This situation has led the people to starvation and misery, while attacks on civilians, medical personnel and members of humanitarian organizations have caused enormous loss of life. This conflict is another attempt by the United States and its allies to maintain geopolitical control and sovereignty over the region. The EU is also complicit in this crime, which, by tolerating the dictatorships of the region and its Member States, which continue to export heavy defense equipment to Saudi Arabia, is leading to the escalation of the conflict in the country. The serious deterioration of the humanitarian situation in Yemen requires immediate humanitarian assistance, which is why we believe that voting in favor of the joint resolution is the right attitude.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly condemn the proxy war that is taking place in Yemen. The conflict has created a huge humanitarian crisis in terms of the displacement of men, women and children, and even loss of life. Iran and Saudi Arabia must come to terms and end the fighting. If this conflict continues, it will give great opportunity for terrorist groups to exploit the current crisis which would not only affect Yemen, but also have ramifications in the region.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written.- I voted in favor of the joint motion for a resolution on the situation in Yemen because the humanitarian situation is really worrying and reaches the limits of an alarming situation.80% of the population needs urgent humanitarian aid because on a daily basis due to air attacks or shelling, infrastructure, schools and hospitals are destroyed, there is a lack of basic medical care for the population and an extremely poor state of sanitation and lack of food and water.This proposal calls for an immediate halt to attacks, especially on medical facilities, and requires all parties to make a clear commitment to avoid attacks on civilians and civilian facilities in accordance with international humanitarian and human rights law.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: in writing.- The vote on this motion for a resolution has been postponed until the next plenary session.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – My fellow UKIP colleagues and I voted to abstain this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is concerned by the ongoing military and humanitarian crisis in Yemen, in particular the role played by both Saudi Arabia and Iran via proxies in the conflict. Amendment 1 calls for an arms embargo using the EU Common Position on Arms Exports 2008/944/CFSP. Whilst we are concerned by the role of western arms exports to Saudi Arabia, we cannot support the use of EU mechanisms to address the issue, so I voted against this particular amendment. Overall I abstained.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written.- I am abstaining on this resolution.Within the framework of international law, it offers approaches to stabilize the humanitarian situation and to resolve the conflict in Yemen through the increased involvement of the United Nations, but it does not specify how the humanitarian crisis can be ended immediately.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution because we all should be aware that the humanitarian situation in Yemen is as critical as the situation in Syria. In the 21st century it is an unspeakable shame for humanity that 16 million Yemenis do not have access to drinking water or sanitation because of fighting and embargo. In addition to that, it is totally unacceptable for two million children to not have proper access to education, food and medical care. For one reason or another, the whole civilian population caught in the Yemen civil war suffers from ongoing fighting, bombardment, food insecurity, dire living conditions and the disruption of essential services. In this critical situation, the EU – as the world’s leading human rights champion and aid donor – should provide emergency humanitarian assistance to the civilian population in Yemen. Together with the UN, the EU should use all of its political and economic capabilities to facilitate peace negotiations.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written.- I supported the motion for a resolution on the humanitarian situation in Yemen because the Saudi-led military intervention, which used internationally banned cluster bombs, led to a catastrophic humanitarian situation for the already poor population, has serious consequences for the region and threatens international peace andsecurity.The current crisis in Yemen has arisen due to the successive failures of governments to meet the legitimate aspirations of the Yemeni people for democracy, economic and social development, stability and security.Numerous tensions among the tribes in the country, widespread insecurity and the difficult economic situation have further fueled the outbreak of conflict that has resulted in a humanitarian crisis.This situation is unsustainable.Therefore, the crisis needs to be resolved quickly and efficiently, which is what this resolution, which I supported, calls for.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing.- I am voting in favor of postponing the vote on the Joint Motion for a Resolution on the humanitarian situation in Yemen, in line with the rapporteur's proposal.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution with its call on all parties to respect the human rights and freedoms of all Yemeni citizens and of all those working on peace and humanitarian missions in the country, including aid workers, doctors and journalists.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: written.- We in the European Parliament are very concerned about the current situation of violence in Yemen and the resulting humanitarian crisis, which affects millions of innocent men, women and children.It is necessary to create the bases for an inclusive political dialogue, as we have asked in the resolution that we have adopted in the European Parliament, in order to seek a long-term solution to the current situation.I want to express my support for the approved text, in which we call for urgent action to end the situations of violence and indiscriminate attacks that are causing so many deaths.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: in writing. - While the international community is sometimes very anxious not to support regimes which oppress their populations (as in Syria) or which violate international law, the complicit silence of European states in the face of Saudi Arabia's action in Yemen cannot go on any longer. The imposing series of operations ("Decisive Storm" then "Restore Hope") carried out by countries in the region under the leadership of Saudi Arabia with the support of American intelligence have led to constant violations of the law international as well as repeated bombing of Yemeni civilian populations by this coalition. I therefore voted in favor of the resolution on the humanitarian situation in Yemen, which recalls that the transition process developed by the United Nations was not pursued to its conclusion, and that today 21 million Yemenis, 82% of the population, are in need of humanitarian assistance. The resolution also calls for much-needed sanctions against states, namely Saudi Arabia, that do not abide by international conventions in their actions in Yemen.

name: Georg MAYER
text: written.- I share the concerns expressed in the motion about food insecurities and the attacks against the civilian population.I think the coordinated action called for by the United Nations is to be welcomed.A dialogue between Yemen and Saudi Arabia could also help resolve the crisis.I therefore support this proposal.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: in writing.- The resolution denounces the humanitarian crisis in Yemen following the military intervention led by Saudi Arabia to support President Hadi and counter the Houthi rebellion.According to the 2016 Humanitarian Needs Overview (HNO) published in November 2015, 21.2 million people (82% of the Yemeni population) are in need of humanitarian aid.To put an end to this situation, the resolution stresses the need to coordinate humanitarian action under the aegis of the United Nations.She could have added that the EU and in particular some of its member states must stop supporting Saudi Arabia in its abuses in Yemen.I vote for this text.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: in writing.- The vote on this motion for a resolution has been postponed until the next plenary session.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the resolution on Yemen.The situation in Yemen is worrying, so it is important that the EU seeks to find a political solution capable of guaranteeing Yemen's peace and stability

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I signed and supported this cross-party resolution which aims to plot the way forward in alleviating the worsening humanitarian situation in Yemen. The resolution highlights the fact that situation on the ground is being exacerbated by external actors and by extremist and terrorist forces.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing - Contemporary Yemen is another sad chapter in the history of the Middle East.Over time, the Civil War turned into an even more significant conflict.We can say without hesitation that the humanitarian situation in Yemen is catastrophic.Hospitals do not have enough electricity or fuel to run ambulances, and there is a huge number of doctors and staff who could help the injured.Poor sewerage caused by bombing can later cause the spread of dangerous diseases.This situation must be clearly addressed without undue delay.First of all, I strongly emphasize the outrage that some European countries are supplying weapons to Yemen.These deliveries must be terminated immediately.It is also necessary to ensure the entry of humanitarian workers into the country.I agree with the rapporteurs that the only and best possible solution to the whole conflict is a political solution.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing.- The groups ECR, GUE / NGL, Verts / ALE, ALDE, S&D, PPE and EFDD have tabled motions for resolutions.Six of the seven political groups, with the exception of the ECR, agreed on a draft compromise.I voted in favor of this motion.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. - The crisis in Yemen must be seen as a priority and urgent. The inability to transition to a democratic regime created conditions for an outbreak of violence, many tribal tensions, widespread insecurity and economic paralysis in the country. Military intervention in Yemen led by Saudi forces and the use of cluster bombs, which are banned internationally, has led to a dramatic humanitarian situation. In Yemen, the start of the conflict, at least 5,979 people were killed, about half of whom were civilians, and 28,208 people were injured. I endorse the alarming concern about the humanitarian situation in Yemen, characterized by widespread food insecurity and acute malnutrition, indiscriminate attacks against civilians, doctors and members of humanitarian organizations, destruction of civil and medical infrastructure caused by the existing internal conflict and the intensification of air strikes the Saudi-led coalition, ground fighting and bombing, despite repeated calls for a new cessation of hostilities. It is essential that all parties respect international humanitarian law and international human rights law, ensure the protection of civilians and refrain from directly targeting civil infrastructure, in particular medical facilities and water supply systems.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: in writing.- This motion for a resolution on Yemen is perfectly indicative of the Europeanist state of mind that reigns on the benches of the European right and left.Indeed, it asks the Union to impose on the Member States its policy on arms exports even though the Union should not have any competence in the field of defense.This is an ever-increasing desire to empty states of their sovereignty.In addition, the text presents a largely pro-Saudi (and therefore American) bias.This resolution is dripping with good feelings;its authors have no idea of the backdrop to the Yemeni case.So I decided to vote against.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. - We welcome the resolution on the humanitarian situation in Yemen. The Yemeni conflict is a complex and stratified war, representative of the dynamics that, in recent years, have been shaking and reshaping the Middle East. It is in fact an unconventional war, where hybrid actors confront each other in an internal conflict, which today seems to be resolvable only thanks to a broader regional agreement. The population of the country is devastated by a serious humanitarian crisis, which has been going on for months now and which the European Union is facing. For its action to be more effective, humanitarian aid to the population and refugees must be maintained and, if possible, intensified. In order to contribute to the signing of a lasting peace, the European Union must turn its gaze to the action of Saudi Arabia, an important trading partner of our countries which plays a key role in managing the conflict. Finally, we ask the European Council and the European External Action Service to monitor the compliance of the Member States with guidelines on international humanitarian law and European criteria for the sale and export of arms.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report because it adequately addresses the humanitarian situation in Yemen and adequately addresses aspects such as food security, medical problems and instability throughout the region.The solution to the refugee problem must be tackled in the region of origin;this report can represent a first step in this direction.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. – UKIP voted to abstain on this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is concerned by the ongoing military and humanitarian crisis in Yemen, in particular the role played by both Saudi Arabia and Iran via proxies in the conflict. Amendment 1 calls for an arms embargo using the EU Common Position on Arms Exports 2008/944/CFSP. Whilst we are concerned by the role of western arms exports to Saudi Arabia, we cannot support the use of EU mechanisms to address the issue, so we voted against this particular amendment. Overall we abstained.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing.- The ongoing conflict in Yemen originates in the failure of successive governments to respond to the democratic, economic and social aspirations of the Yemeni people, thus fueling the discontent and divisions that have resulted in the current violence.I would therefore have voted in favor, wishing an improvement in these situations.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - The political and humanitarian crisis in Yemen threatens to destabilize the entire region, and therefore I believe that it is extremely important to achieve a permanent ceasefire as soon as possible. The suffering of civilians in this country affected by bloody conflicts, where millions of people need humanitarian aid, must not leave us indifferent. First and foremost, I would like to draw attention to the suffering of children in Yemen, who are one of the most vulnerable groups affected by the Yemeni humanitarian crisis and threatened by food and drug shortages. Since the beginning of the conflict, there have been frequent cases of torture of civilians, especially members of religious minorities, attacks on journalists, their enforced disappearances, etc. Only the establishment of lasting peace and the beginning of a democratic process in Yemen can contribute to ending human rights violations. The biggest victim of the current situation in the country is the Yemeni civilian population, which already lives in difficult conditions. European foreign policy through the relevant Foreign Affairs Committee of the European Parliament next week will have the opportunity to communicate directly with the Saudi leadership and try to directly influence the situation on the ground aggravated by the military intervention in Yemen led by Saudi Arabia. That is why I welcome the postponement of the vote on the motion for a resolution on the humanitarian situation in Yemen, and I hope that the visit of a European Parliament delegation will contribute to resolving the humanitarian crisis in Yemen before this resolution is adopted.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: in writing.- This motion for a resolution illustrates the European Union's flawed position vis-à-vis Saudi Arabia and the war it is waging in Yemen.The text is satisfied with hollow good feelings and carefully avoids going to examine the reality of the situation and the role of each of the actors.It does of course include some proposals aimed at giving foreign policy powers to the European Union.I therefore vote against.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. - The crisis in Yemen has been dragging on for 10 months and has escalated since the Saudi coalition is launching air strikes to stop the advance of the rebel group Houthi, which had taken control of the capital Sana'a and forced the government into exile in Saudi Arabia. The effects of these actions are having devastating effects across the country. According to the United Nations, 82% of the population is in need of humanitarian assistance. The food situation is particularly worrying, millions of people struggle to feed themselves, 1.3 million children are acutely malnourished (1.8 million do not go to school) and there is no access to clean water or basic health care . I voted in favor of this resolution to establish an international, independent and impartial commission of inquiry that examines all violations and abuses perpetrated by the parties to the conflict and identifies the perpetrators to ensure that those responsible are held accountable. The European Union must promote compliance with international humanitarian law as foreseen in the EU guidelines and must work to recreate the conditions for a political dialogue under the aegis of the UN, including Saudi Arabia and Iran, crucial countries for encouraging end of the conflict.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written.- News and images arriving from Yemen recently are catastrophic: bombings in Sana'a, the center, shops and schools, Houthi rebels have besieged the city of Taiz, Yemen's third largest city, and are preventing the delivery of humanitarian aid.There are a large number of detained civilians who are in dire need of drinking water, food, treatment and other assistance and protection of vital importance.I express my deep concern at the alarming deterioration of the humanitarian situation in Yemen.Coordinated UN-led humanitarian action is needed and all countries should contribute to meeting humanitarian needs.At the same time, I support the position of the European Parliament, which emphasizes that only a political solution that can be reached through negotiations can restore peace and preserve the unity, sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity of Yemen.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing.- Since the start of the conflict in Yemen, at least 5,979 people have been killed and 28,208 injured.Among the victims are hundreds of women and children.Furthermore, the humanitarian impact on the civilian population, following the ongoing clashes between the various militias, the bombings and the interruption of the supply of essential services, is reaching alarming proportions.The EU has already allocated 52 million euros in humanitarian aid for the crisis in Yemen in 2015 and will allocate another 2 million to develop the UN Verification and Inspection Mechanism (UNVIM) for commercial transport to Yemen, facilitatingthus the free flow of commercial items and humanitarian aid to the country.I hope that the conflict can be resolved by reaching a political solution, by starting a new round of peace negotiations under the leadership of the United Nations as soon as possible.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing.- I voted to postpone the vote on the resolution on the humanitarian situation in Yemen.A parliamentary delegation, chaired by Mr Brok, is due to visit Saudi Arabia this week.In this context, the negotiations to reach a common text are early.We are awaiting the conclusions of this delegation to learn more about the situation.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. - The conflicts that in Yemen have led to the current humanitarian crisis are the culmination of tensions between the Zidid (Hutis) and Sunni majorities, compounded by the failure of successive governments to exercise a fair share of power and an inclusive representation of the people's aspirations . Such tensions have been exploited by Saudi Arabia and Iran, which, in a context of power depletion (resulting from the Arab Spring), support, respectively, Sunnis and Zaidites. This interference in Yemen's internal affairs resulted directly in air strikes on the country's infrastructure and, indirectly, in the confrontations between the warring factions that resulted in the climate of instability that extremist and terrorist organizations like the Islamic State and al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula. In this regard, I fully agree with the rapporteur's position, and endorse the idea that only an inclusive and negotiated political solution can restore peace and preserve Yemen's sovereignty and independence. I also add my voice to that of the rapporteur when he asks the Member States that continue to allow arms-related delivery to Saudi Arabia to cease their activity, taking into account the risk that exports will be used to violate international humanitarian law.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted to abstain this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is concerned by the ongoing military and humanitarian crisis in Yemen, in particular the role played by both Saudi Arabia and Iran via proxies in the conflict. Amendment 1 calls for an arms embargo using the EU Common Position on Arms Exports 2008/944/CFSP. Whilst we are concerned by the role of western arms exports to Saudi Arabia, we cannot support the use of EU mechanisms to address the issue, so we voted against this particular amendment. Overall we abstained.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. - The current conflict in Yemen is rooted in the inability of successive governments to satisfy the democratic, economic and social aspirations of the Yemeni people, thus fueling the discontent and division that led to the spiral of violence currently experienced in that country. This escalation of violence has, at the same time, serious consequences for the stability of the region, in particular, along the Horn of Africa, in the Red Sea and in the Middle East itself. Some 21.2 million people living in Yemen are in need of humanitarian aid, and this conflict has already led to numerous serious and systematic human rights violations. A firm effort in the negotiations is essential, so that the respect of international humanitarian law by all parties involved in the conflict is a reality. As I consider that this is undoubtedly an issue that deserves priority for treatment and an effective solution, I voted in favor of this motion for a resolution.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: written.- We voted in favor since the text calls on the EU to apply international humanitarian law, as set out in the European guidelines, and for its application to be included in the dialogue with Saudi Arabia.Furthermore, it urges the EU High Representative to launch an initiative to impose an arms embargo on Saudi Arabia to immediately put an end to human rights violations in Yemen.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: in writing.- I support the efforts of UN Special Envoy Ismail Ould Cheikh Ahmed to find a lasting and peaceful solution to the current crisis.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: written.- The violent extremist ideology of ISIS, its terrorist acts, continuous severe systematic and widespread attacks on civilians, violations of human rights and international humanitarian law, including those committed on religious or ethnic grounds, destruction of cultural heritage and trade in cultural goods are global and unprecedentedthreat to international peace and security, as confirmed by UN Security Council Resolution 2249/2015.I therefore urge all States parties to the UN Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide, signed in Paris on 9 December 1948, and other relevant international agreements, and in particular EU Member States, to prevent war crimes, crimes against humanity and genocide.I also appeal to Syria and Iraq to accept the jurisdiction of the International Criminal Court and support the resolution.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written.- The humanitarian situation in Yemen is extremely complex.Human rights violations are, unfortunately, the rule, not the exception.For a long time now, there has been a bad practice that has intensified with the strengthening of Islamism in that country.Women's rights are at a very low level.Brutal harassment of minorities is ubiquitous.According to the UN analysis, there is a great humanitarian crisis in Yemen and it is necessary to act.We should keep in mind that Yemen is a very poor country that is a victim of the geopolitical interests of neighboring countries.I support the adoption of this resolution, because the fight for human rights, the rule of law and the dignity of the individual knows no bounds.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the joint resolution on the humanitarian situation in Yemen.Yemen has found itself in a humanitarian crisis following Saudi-led coalition airstrikes, marked by inadequate food security and severe malnutrition, indiscriminate attacks on civilians and medical and humanitarian personnel, and the destruction of civilian and medical infrastructure.I support coordinated United Nations-led humanitarian action and call on States to help meet humanitarian needs, while all parties must respect international humanitarian and human rights law in order to protect civilians and prevent direct attacks on civilian infrastructure.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE / NGL), in writing. - We voted in favor of the joint resolution as the serious deterioration of the humanitarian situation in Yemen requires immediate humanitarian assistance. The country has been embroiled in a long-running feud between the Houthis and the Yemeni government, which intensified in 2015 when US-backed Saudi Arabia launched bombings in Yemen, while imposing an almost complete blockade on imports. This situation has led the people to starvation and misery, while attacks on civilians, medical personnel and members of humanitarian organizations have caused enormous loss of life. The conflict is another attempt by the United States and its allies to maintain geopolitical control and sovereignty over the region. The EU is also complicit in this crime, which, by tolerating the dictatorships of the region and its Member States, which continue to export heavy defense equipment to Saudi Arabia, is leading to the escalation of the conflict in the country. We condemn once again the stance of the United States, its allies and the ruling elites of the EU, and call for immediate action to end the humanitarian crisis in Yemen.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: in writing.- It is time for the Union to take action against Saudi Arabia, this terrorist state, by imposing an arms embargo.In any case, we will denounce any retreat of the Union towards Saudi Arabia.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this resolution because I consider it important for the European Parliament to make its voice heard on one of the most serious humanitarian disasters today and to use its international weight vis-à-vis Saudi Arabia and other parties to the conflict to improve the situation. I consider it urgent to lift the naval blockade and end hostilities throughout Yemen in order to ensure that humanitarian aid is delivered without hindrance. A particularly worrying feature of the situation is the large number of children among the victims and the serious threats to the safety of international aid workers. While agreeing that international efforts to resolve the situation in Yemen must continue under the auspices of the United Nations, I have also taken into account the fact that there are even specific responsibilities on the part of EU Member States, in particular compliance with and restrictions on arms transfers to the region. compliance. I believe that we must continue to monitor this aspect closely with the European Parliament's instruments.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: signed up. - The Arab Spring has marked an increase in hope for the democratization of Middle Eastern societies. Unfortunately, in some cases, social unrest has degenerated into violent internal conflicts, which have largely affected the civilian population and undermined the viability of some states. This is also the case in Yemen, where the confrontation has deepened old religious and political faults. The fragility of the Yemeni state has also benefited the terrorist organization Al-Qaeda, which controls a significant part of its territory. The involvement of external actors in the internal conflict was not likely to de-escalate the situation, on the contrary, it led to a battle of attrition between Saudi-backed government forces and Iran-backed rebel forces (Houthi). This struggle has generated a dramatic humanitarian situation, characterized by an exponential increase in the number of refugees, chronic poverty, the destruction of civilian targets (including centers for the blind and deaf, schools and economic targets) and the proliferation of armaments. In this situation, the European Parliament must take a firm stand against the continuation of this unfortunate state of affairs and encourage the involvement of relevant international actors in resolving the conflict. The European Union, through the Council and the External Action Service, can be directly involved in limiting arms sales and encouraging ceasefire.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing. - By failing to follow a political path of cohesion, Yemen has become entangled in intensifying tribal tensions and in the violent war in which the Houthi rebels, supported by Iran, clash through pawns, supported by Iran , and Saudi Arabia, which is waging a military campaign against the rebels that directly plunges the entire region into a complex conflict that has already been going on for several months. At the same time, Saudi Arabia sees the Houthi rebels in Yemen as an Iranian proxy force, as Iran has condemned the Saudi-led offensive and called for an immediate end to its airstrikes. The European Parliament, by this resolution, expresses all its concern at the violence which is currently raging in Yemen and at the humanitarian crisis which results from it and affects millions of innocent children, women and men; it deplores the loss of human life caused by the conflict and the suffering of those caught up in the fighting.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The vote on the resolution on the tragic humanitarian situation in Yemen could not take place as a majority of Members decided to postpone the vote to the next plenary. I expect Parliament to adopt a strong position on the topic in the near future.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written. - The current situation in Yemen is a cause for great concern. Yemen is going through an unprecedented humanitarian catastrophe - 15 million Yemenis, or more than half of the population, need humanitarian aid, primarily food, and the lives of several million people are at risk due to the inability to provide emergency care. In view of this alarming information, Member States should call on all parties to the conflict in Yemen to respect the principles of humanity, neutrality, independence and impartiality, and to ensure the protection of civilians and humanitarian workers. The European Union should contribute to addressing the needs of the Yemeni people to enable the urgent delivery of humanitarian aid and essential supplies, including fuel, food and basic necessities. It is therefore necessary to further facilitate commercial maritime access to Yemen. I also express my deep concern at the growing violations of human rights, including the constant attacks on journalists and media outlets, the exploitation of children in armed conflict, and the abduction of people in violation of the Convention against Torture, Ill-Treatment and Detention of Religious Minorities. I believe that the motion for a resolution that I have tabled with my colleagues in the ECR can help to improve the situation in Yemen.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing.- I did not support the motion for a resolution on the humanitarian situation in Yemen, as we in our EPP political group voted in favor of postponing the vote.Of course, I support the efforts of the European Union and the UN regarding the role of mediator.The difficult situation, which is deteriorating human rights and increasing violence, is seriously threatening the stability and security of the region and potentially affecting the EU as well.By calling on and striving the parties for dialogue, tolerance and the rejection of violence to achieve political goals, Yemen will achieve lasting peace and stability at both national and international levels.The resolution contained some key points that we need to improve, so I think the postponement of the vote is a good opportunity to improve the existing text.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: written.- We voted in favor since the text calls on the EU to apply international humanitarian law, as set out in the European guidelines, and for its application to be included in the dialogue with Saudi Arabia.Furthermore, it urges the EU High Representative to launch an initiative to impose an arms embargo on Saudi Arabia to immediately put an end to human rights violations in Yemen.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ For too long, Yemeni Governments have not fulfilled the democratic, economic and social aspirations of the Yemeni people. I express my deep concern at the ongoing violence in Yemen and the resultant humanitarian crisis affecting millions of innocent men, women and children I strongly support the efforts of the UN Special Envoy, Ismail Ould Cheikh Ahmed, to find a lasting and peaceful resolution to the current crisis. I believe that Saudi Arabia and Iran hold the key to resolving the crisis, and urge both to work to improve bilateral relations and to seek to work together to end the fighting in Yemen. The only long-term solution to the crisis in Yemen is via inclusive political dialogue, in line with the framework provided by the Gulf Cooperation Council initiative, the outcomes of the National Dialogue Conference, and the various UN Security Council and European Council conclusions.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing.- The rapporteur notes that the current conflict in Yemen is due to the failure of successive governments to fulfill the democratic, economic and social aspirations of the Yemeni people, thus increasing the dissatisfaction and division that has led to the current violence.In northern Yemen, the combined effects of severe land clashes, air strikes, and land, sea, and air blockades have had devastating consequences for the country.The current conflict has resulted in a serious humanitarian crisis affecting 80% of Yemen’s 26 million population.In the vote on this, I supported the position of the S&D Group.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ The vote that took place concerning the resolution on the humanitarian situation in Yemen was actually a request to postpone the vote of the resolution to the February II part session. The request was put forward by Cristian Dan Preda, on behalf of the PPE Group. Parliament agreed to the request by electronic vote (391 in favour, 226 against, 13 abstentions). I voted in favour of the postponement of the vote to the February II part-session.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: written.- It is necessary for the violence to cease and for the parties to the Yemeni conflict to be able to sit down and dialogue to resolve in this way the humanitarian crisis that the country is suffering and that affects millions of innocent men, women and children.This Resolution calls on the parties to condemn the violence and to try to resolve their differences through dialogue.For all these reasons, I consider it necessary to vote in their favor.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing.- We condemned foreign intervention in Yemen from the beginning, namely Saudi, which started in March 2015. Saudi military intervention in Yemen constitutes a violation of international law and an unacceptable interference in that country's internal affairs, representing yet another example of the interventionist tendency ofSaudi Arabia in countries in the region, as demonstrated by military intervention in Bahrain in 2011. The military aggression to which Yemen has been subjected has already caused the death of many people and caused a wave of refugees.This aggression intends to impose the domination of imperialism in the Middle East, to crush the Yemeni sovereign affirmation and to assure the control of the geo-strategic position of Yemen in the routes of transport of energy raw materials, namely of the Bab-el-Mandeb Strait.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: written.- I share the concerns expressed in the motion about food insecurities and the attacks against the civilian population.I think the coordinated action called for by the United Nations is to be welcomed.A dialogue between Yemen and Saudi Arabia could also help resolve the crisis.I therefore support this proposal.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ The humanitarian situation in Yemen has deteriorated and the plight of those trapped in the conflict is shocking, with the most vulnerable bearing the brunt of its brutal reality. Malnutrition, lack of healthcare and no access to education will affect child victims for the rest of their lives. This conflict is yet another proxy war between Iran and Saudi Arabia, in an enormously complex and fragmented region. As usual, it is the most vulnerable who suffer in the crossfire, as both sides violate international humanitarian law.  I have been in close contact with an Ethiopian Ogadeni journalist trapped in Yemen and receive frequent alerts about the situation on the ground for innocent civilians. The international community, the EU and its Member States individually, must put pressure on Saudi Arabia, Gulf states and Iran to make sure that they respect humanitarian law and do not kill or harm civilians. European Member States and other countries must ensure that they do not sell arms that end up targeting civilians in violation of international laws of conflict.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: in writing.- The EU must support with its help and assistance in every corner of the globe the right of peoples to live in a peaceful, stable and prosperous society, but also to raise humanitarian issues internationally.I supported the resolution on the humanitarian situation in Yemen.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – Mr President, I am very happy that Parliament today took the important step of calling the atrocities and mass murders carried out by ISIS or Daesh on Christians and other religious minorities genocide. Obviously I wholeheartedly supported this. Today we gave them a message of hope. It is a historic step. Yesterday we not only officially recognised the many crimes carried out by ISIS or Daesh, but we also named them as what they are: genocide. We showed that we see what is going on and that we accept the consequences as well. I would therefore like to draw your attention to very urgent situation in Rojava Canton, where humanitarian aid is much needed. The Turkish and Iraqi Kurdish borders need to be opened immediately. The whole canton, comprising approximately 2 million people, is at the moment supplied through one border crossing. We do not have a solution yet for solving the whole Syrian crisis, but we can at least save 2 million lives.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: "Honestly, I'm really fed up with the various ISIS decisions in the Middle East."Walking in the area several times and the contradiction between urgent action and our pace is simply outrageous, yet I say that we have been given a chance with the decision adopted with this resolution.We have been given a chance in Europe to really act and really do what is needed.What is it about?To this day, Europe has been reluctant to acknowledge that we have a special responsibility for Christian and other persecuted minorities, religious minorities.At last, if with a delay of several years, but we are beginning to acknowledge this.One thing you need to know!Christian and other religious minorities look to Europe, they can only count on us.It is not appropriate to refuse this hand.It is simply inhumanity.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Mr President, I supported this resolution for the reasons already mentioned here by my colleagues. When the so-called Islamic State is not a state, it is a terrorist group, so it is good that we have identified and clearly described that the actions of this group meet the hallmarks of the most serious crimes that humanity identified after World War II, and that is the crime of genocide, war crimes. and crimes against humanity. This is good for the stage when the Islamic State will be defeated and its representatives can be tried before an international criminal tribunal. That's the one position. The second thing I welcome is a number of specific things that we condemn, such as the destruction of cultural wealth and heritage. We make it clear that those who do business and help the Islamic State raise illegal money should be punished. I think this is important for individual member states, because if IS did not sell these cultural heritage things, it would not be able to trade with them.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: - Mr President! Whether the "Islamic State" literally acted on the basis of Islamic postulates or completely distorted it, one thing can be unequivocally noted: there are no normal people in it. Very simply, what is happening in the Middle East at the moment has nothing to do with humanity. While Daesh also actively oppresses Muslims, it does not compare to what these beasts do to minorities - Christians, Jesuits, Shabbaks and other unbelievers can convert to Islam or die. There are no other alternatives. Ancient communities that have existed since Islam did not exist at all are in danger of total destruction. They are seeking refuge. They fled. In this regard, I would like to thank from the bottom of my heart those who organized the transport of 149 Assyrian-Christian refugees from Northern Iraq to Slovakia last December. These people, by the way, are the last to speak Jesus, the Aramaic language. Resolution support.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: - International law knows the precise criteria by which genocide is judged.It is an act aimed at destroying a national, ethnic, racial or religious group.It involves the deliberate killing of its members, causing serious physical and mental harm with the intention of physically destroying them.Recognizing the suffering of Christians and other minorities in Iraq and Syria as genocide is a first step towards the adoption of a Security Council resolution mandating the International Criminal Court to investigate and prosecute crimes in this area.Given their importance, it is important for the European Union to create a special post whose representative will defend the rights and lives of Christians and other religious minorities around the world.I am very pleased that this proposal has been approved.The resolution adopted is the historical text of this Parliament.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing.- The terrorist organization that takes the name of ISIS / Daesh is unfortunately a real danger to all the ethnic and religious minorities that inhabit the Iraqi-Syrian region.In recent months, this organization has been responsible for serious violations of human rights that amount to crimes against humanity and war crimes.The situation is unsustainable and action is needed to protect the populations affected by this "scourge".The text, while addressing the various critical issues, focuses too much on military intervention alone, forgetting that the current situation is the result of an international policy based on the use of force alone.For these reasons I have decided to abstain.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted for this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is extremely concerned about the persecution of religious minorities by ISIS. UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report, given the resolutions lack of calls for EU action, aside from §10's call for the establishment of an EU Permanent Special Representative to which we voted against, we voted for the resolution as a whole.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP is extremely concerned about the persecution of religious minorities by ISIS. Given the resolution’s lack of calls for EU action (aside from §10’s call for the establishment of an EU Permanent Special Representative, which we voted against), we voted for the resolution as a whole.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: written. - We have abstained from this Resolution because the text appeals to the "Responsibility to Protect" (R2P), which is at the origin of the disastrous military interventions that have caused destabilization in the region. Those who supported R2P also supported the jihadist "rebels" who today attack religious minorities. We strongly condemn the killings of civilians, including religious, ethnic and minorities of any kind, but we are against the exploitation and use of certain religions by the EU. We have opposed the expansion of powers of the EU's foreign action by creating a high representative for Freedom of Religion and Belief, because we understand that her work would overlap with that of the High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy and It could be counterproductive if it reproduces the parliamentary reality, which prioritizes attention to certain confessions to the detriment of others, which can contribute to Islamophobia. For this reason we have abstained in this Resolution.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: in writing. - If I share with this text the same repulsion towards the Islamic State and its appalling crimes, I wonder on the other hand about the political use that is made by the European Union to give itself a diplomatic legitimacy that it does not has not. So I cannot support the idea of ​​creating "a permanent special representative for freedom of religion and belief" to the EU institutions, any more than I accept that the EU urges "Syria and Iraq to accept the jurisdiction of the International Court "which it is obvious that it applies a contemporary Western vision of the law to countries which are part of a very different cultural and civilizational perspective. Finally, it is quite obvious that resolutions of the European Parliament will not solve anything in the Near and Middle East. I note in this regard that apart from begging for principles, not a word on the strategy that should be followed to take back the territories controlled by the IS, while it is obvious that the Western powers should review their position on the spot. towards the Syrian, Russian and Iranian governments and stand out from Turkey, Saudi Arabia and Qatar. That's why I abstained.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This was not the subject of a roll-call vote.  In the interests of democracy, I wish to point out that I voted in favour of this report, although I specifically disagree with the original text in certain areas, not least with paragraph 10.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: in writing.- The news of massacres that reach us daily from the territories occupied by ISIS are nowadays, unfortunately, faced with a naturalness that should shock us.The terrorist acts committed by this organization against local populations, and especially against religious minorities, must be condemned and combated by the entire international community.This report by the European Parliament, which will have my vote, being just a small gesture, should be seen as a strong signal given by this house so that all organizations and entities that have a duty to safeguard the freedoms and guarantees of all beingshuman beings, therefore, make every effort to combat this organization and all those who support and help to commit these acts of barbarism.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this proposal, which seeks to strongly condemn ISIS and its human rights abuses, which it seeks to eradicate local religious and ethnic minorities, as well as their religious and cultural heritage.The treatment of religious minorities by the Islamic State must be recognized as genocide and its perpetrators severely punished.Such actions amount to crimes against humanity.I support calls on EU countries to 'actively combat radicalization' and to legally prevent their citizens from joining ISIS and to prosecute those who join or incite support for the group online as soon as possible.I agree with the need to appoint an EU Special Representative on Freedom of Religion or Belief.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted for this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is extremely concerned about the persecution of religious minorities by ISIS. UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report, given the resolutions lack of calls for EU action, aside from §10's call for the establishment of an EU Permanent Special Representative to which we voted against, we voted for the resolution as a whole.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: in writing.- If it is necessary to support the minorities martyred by the terrorists of the Islamic State, born of the chaos engendered by the Western interventions in the region, I refuse that the Commission takes advantage of it to arrogate to itself new powers and claims alegitimacy that it does not have to deal with such serious international problems.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing.- I approved this joint resolution which condemns all the crimes of the "Islamic State" group, equivalent to crimes against humanity and war crimes, and which emphasizes that the "Islamic State" group is committing genocide againstChristians and Yazidis as well as other religious and ethnic minorities who do not share his interpretation of Islam.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. - Daesh constitutes an unprecedented threat to international peace and security. The destruction of the world cultural heritage and the trafficking of works of art have been linked, from the beginning, to the immense violence practiced against the civilian population and in particular the minorities residing in the territories under its control. The extremist ideology carried on by the terrorists has manifested itself in a series of extortion, robbery, massacre and torture inflicted on members of the most diverse religious and ethnic communities. I supported the resolution on the systematic extermination of religious minorities by ISIS to strongly condemn the crimes against humanity carried out by Daesh. The EU must give its full support to the countries and populations threatened by the advance of these groups. guaranteeing the necessary conditions of security and a dignified future for all those who have been forced to leave their country of origin. Only a commitment from the entire international community can guarantee an effective return of the displaced to their own countries and safeguard their properties and their religious and cultural sites.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: written. - We abstain from voting on this Resolution considering that: 1) the call to accept the jurisdiction of the International Criminal Court should also be addressed to the United States, China, India and all States, and not limited to Syria and Iraq ; 2) any authorized intervention must be of a civil and humanitarian nature and not a military one; 3) the use of the concept of genocide with a much broader spectrum than that granted to it in the framework of the International Criminal Court (apart from the case of the Yazidis) is problematic; 4) abstention seeks to avoid influencing ethnic or religious discrimination against the victims of this atrocity, which, of course, we condemn. Targeting certain religions as victims (such as Christian) and others as culprits (Muslim, even though most ISIL crimes are committed against Muslims) only serves to fuel interfaith hatred and clash of civilizations with which advocates of texts like this one they try to base and justify their interested warmongering.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: written.- I have supported this Resolution that strongly condemns the so-called ISIL and its atrocious violations of human rights, which are war crimes and crimes against humanity.It also calls for the EU to establish a permanent special representative for Freedom of Religion and Belief.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing. - Having however at heart the situation of the Christians of the East and the real religious purification which they undergo on behalf of the so-called "Islamic State", I however preferred to abstain on this resolution. I recall that I have tried to alert the European authorities on numerous occasions to the fate of Eastern Christians and the destruction of cultural and religious property, as in Palmyra.
