However, this resolution seems to take the side of using the misery of this real human tragedy in order to strengthen the diplomatic skills of the European Union. Yet, as events have shown, the only viable solution for a peace process remains in the hands of sovereign states; Russia's diplomacy with the Syrian government is a good example. The European Union does not have to take the place of states, particularly when it has partially contributed to creating or worsening conflicts which have led to the rise of Daesh. As many crises have shown, a fortiori that of migrants, in a situation of extreme emergency, only nations are able to react in the best way for the good of populations and the resolution of geopolitical conflicts.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing.- The resolution clearly and sharply attacks Isis and the persecutions, killings, violence perpetrated against Christians and religious minorities.For years I have been fighting for Europe to recognize the state of persecution of Christian communities in the world by Islamic fundamentalists.I would have preferred a more incisive line, but I admit that it is a beginning that recognizes the reality of the facts: in the Middle East, Christians are undergoing a real extermination.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: written. - The key point of the proposed Resolution is the fight against the persecution of Christians, non-Salafi Muslims, LGBTI people and other people or groups who do not share the vision of the world of Daesh. The world must hold this terrorist group responsible for the various atrocities they have committed against religious groups and minorities in general. This Resolution urges the Gulf States and, in particular, Saudi Arabia, to reject intolerant Wahhabi teachings that distort traditional Islamic values; calls on the international community, including the EU and its Member States, to ensure the security conditions and the prospects of these ethnic and religious minorities; urges all EU Member States to update their legal systems in order to prevent their nationals and fellow citizens from traveling to join Daesh and other terrorist organizations and so that, should they do so, they are prosecuted as soon as possible; and calls on all parties to the conflict to respect universal human rights to facilitate the delivery of humanitarian aid and assistance through all possible channels. For all these reasons, I have voted in favor.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this resolution because it spoke out against the systematic massacres of religious minorities by the so-called ISIS (Da'esh). The UN Secretary-General's ideology of violent extremism by the so-called ISIS (Da'esh), its terrorist attacks, its constant, brutal, systematic and large-scale attacks on the civilian population, human rights and international humanitarian law violations, which are carried out on a religious or ethnic basis, the destruction of cultural heritage and the trade in cultural goods, have recognized a common and unprecedented threat to international peace and security. Reiterates its strong condemnation of ISIS (Da'esh) and its appalling human rights abuses, which amount to crimes against humanity and war crimes under the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court, which could also be recognized as genocide by the UN Security Council. Parliament has expressed its deep concern at the deliberate attacks by this terrorist group on Christians (Chaldeans, Syrians, Assyrians, Melchites, Armenians), Yazidis, Turkmen, Shiites, Sabbacas, Saabs, Cocks and Sunnis, who disagree with the group's interpretation of Islam as on one of the attempts to exterminate all religious and ethnic minorities in the territories under their control. Parliament also urged members of the UN Security Council to support the proposal that the Security Council refer the matter to the International Criminal Court to investigate violations against religious and ethnic minorities by the so-called ISIS (Da'esh) in Iraq and Syria.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: in writing. - The atrocities committed by the t.i. Islamic State are indescribable. The beheadings of infidels, as they call themselves, enslavement, the application of Sharia law in all its cruelty, terrorist attacks on civilians, the desecration of thousands of years of cultural heritage are just some of the cruel acts used by self-proclaimed Islamic fighters in Syria, Iraq, Libya and Europe. Islamic State also commits genocide against religious minorities such as Christians, Yazidis, Turkmen and others, and this was clearly defined by the European Parliament in this resolution. It is not, therefore, about the isolated executions of individuals who do not swear allegiance to jihadists, but about the deliberate extermination of religious minorities. The international community must not remain indifferent to these atrocities and must make every effort, by all available means, to resolve the conflict in Syria and Iraq, which is already spreading rapidly towards North Africa. The resolution that I supported also calls for the establishment of a Permanent Representative for Freedom of Religion, and calls on the Member States to strengthen their legislation in order to prevent Islamic State fighters from passing through their territories outside the EU and back. It also calls for the immediate prosecution of such individuals as potential terrorists.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: written.- I support this statement which aims to point out that it is not only Christians who are being prosecuted by the ISIS terrorist group.Yazidis, secular groups, Sunnis, Sufis, Alawites, LGBT communities, are all groups where brutal atrocities are carried out because they do not accept the rigorous Wahhabi interpretation of Islam invoked by ISIS.Therefore, I believe that these groups should also be included in the text of the resolution, because this terrorist group should be responsible for all the crimes it commits.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this document because I believe that the systematic extermination that ISIS / Daesh has perpetrated and is still perpetrating against religious minorities is shameful and that it is the duty of the European Union, as well as NATO and the United Nations, to workso that it is put to an end and that the threat represented by ISIS / Daesh is eradicated.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing.- The Islamic State has turned sectarianism into a tool of propaganda and death.Religious and ethnic minorities are among the victims most threatened by this blind violence and subject to the risk of marginalization, discrimination and disappearance.The growing level of the threat and its global character place the problem at the top of the European political agenda.The law should encourage the inclusion of minorities and minority groups should be able to count on special protection and assistance in order to preserve their presence in religion.There is a serious violation of human rights and fundamental freedoms that must be addressed by the European Union and its Member States with harshness and speed.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: in writing. - This motion for a resolution aims to condemn the "Islamic State" group for war crimes and crimes against humanity committed against ethnic and religious minorities. The Islamic State group and its members are responsible for acts of torture, mass killings, rape and human trafficking, of which women are victims in particular; the perpetrators of these crimes will have to answer before the International Criminal Court. It is obvious that we share the indignation and the emotion aroused by these acts of barbarism. Nevertheless, we wish to recall the responsibility of the European institutions and of certain Member States in the political destabilization of the Near and Middle East which has led to the strengthening of Islamic fundamentalists. This is the reason why we do not grant any legitimacy to the European Union to eradicate the "Islamic State" group. I therefore abstained on this text.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: signed up. - Genocide, crimes against humanity and war crimes, regardless of where and when they are committed, must not be left unpunished, as a concern for the Union's structures to combat these acts. In recent years, 66 churches have been attacked or blown up as part of a systematic bombing campaign against Christian churches in Iraq. A worrying result of the systematic mass execution of members of religious minorities by ISIS also translates into a significantly lower number of Christians in Syria and Iraq. Thus, in Iraq there was a decrease from 1,400,000 in 2003 to about 300,000, and in Syria from 1.25 million in 2011 to only 500,000 today. As a result, extremism and the current persecution of Christians are an increasingly significant factor in the development of the phenomenon of mass migration and internal displacement. It is necessary to recognize the inalienable right of all religious and ethnic minorities living in Iraq and Syria to be able to live in conditions of equality and security, as well as to be able to practice their religion fully and freely, which is why I in favor of this report.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this joint resolution because it heavily attacks ISIS and the persecution, killings and violence perpetuated against religious minorities, victims of these attacks.Furthermore, it calls for the recognition of the genocide for the Christians and Yazidis of the Middle East, as well as asking for actions to protect all the various minorities mentioned in the text.A suggestion from the ECR that includes support for military actions was also maintained.This, given the line of our movement, is perhaps not enough, but it is nevertheless relevant reminding us that it is a common resolution among all groups.My suggestion is that we support the resolution, while pointing out that we would have liked a stronger resolution.However, this can be a starting point given the strong condemnation, recognizing that Christians in the Middle East are undergoing a real extermination.

name: Alain CADEC
text: in writing.- The systematic massacre of Christians in Iraq and Syria must be considered genocide.In this region, religious minorities and Christians face daily atrocities from the "Islamic State" group.It is obvious that the main objective of this group is to systematically destroy these religious minorities as well as their culture.Our duty as Europeans is to come to the aid of these minorities and to protect them from this scourge.I voted in favor of this resolution which calls for measures to be taken so that the United Nations recognizes the genocide perpetrated by the "Islamic State" group on Christians, Yazidis and other religious and ethnic minorities.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of the resolution on the systematic extermination of religious minorities by ISIS. The violent extremism of the so-called ISIS / Daesh, its terrorist attacks on civilians, its religious and ethnic crimes and its work of destruction of cultural heritage constitute a global and unprecedented threat to peace, stability and international security. The deliberate attacks by this terrorist group against Christians, Yazidis, Turkmen, Shiites, Shabak, Sabei, Kakai and Sunnis, which aim to eliminate any religious minority from the areas under its control, are of great concern. The European Union must therefore support the international diplomatic efforts and the work of UN Special Envoy Staffan de Mistura to launch peace negotiations in Geneva, between all Syrian parties, with the participation of all global and regional actors, to stop the advance of ISIS / Daesh. Furthermore, I believe that the European Union should put pressure on the Gulf States to step up efforts to prevent and repress any form of support, active or passive, to ISIS / Daesh, and to address with determination the extremist ideology that distorts traditional Islamic values ​​and which, in its extreme interpretation, is used as a political-religious justification for the actions of ISIS / Daesh.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted for this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is extremely concerned about the persecution of religious minorities by ISIS. UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report, given the resolutions lack of calls for EU action, aside from §10's call for the establishment of an EU Permanent Special Representative to which we voted against, we voted for the resolution as a whole.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because I agree that the persecutions of religious and ethnic minorities by the so-called ISIS/Daesh should be recognised by the international community as genocide. While the European Parliament has done so today, I hope that the UN Security Council and other international organisations will also take such action.  We must condemn all such violence and bring the perpetrators to justice.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing.- With this resolution the international community is asked to take immediate action to combat the systematic mass extermination of religious minorities perpetrated by the so-called Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS) or Daesh.The firm condemnation of ISIS / Daesh and its shameful violations of human rights, which deliberately target Christians, Yazidis, Turkmen, Shiites, Shabak, Sabeans, Kaka’e and Sunnis, is also reiterated.The reason why I abstained on the final vote is due to the fact that, in defense of minorities, the possibility of military intervention is mentioned, which I do not agree with.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing. - We support the European Parliament's joint motion for a resolution on the systematic mass killings of religious minorities by the so-called 'ISIS / Daesh' and stress the importance of the international community providing protection and assistance to all those targeted by the so-called 'ISIS / Daesh 'and other terrorist organizations in the Middle East, such as ethnic and religious minorities. We reaffirm our full and active support for the international diplomatic efforts and the work of the UN Special Envoy Staffan de Mistura, which aim to launch peace negotiations between all parties in Syria.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing.- There are two issues that this resolution raises and which prompted me to vote in favor.The first is the attack on religious freedom.In 2016 it cannot be heard: in Europe we have gone through dark centuries of religious extremism, but luckily we have long since come out of it and freedom has become an almost absolute value, while there are still areas of the world where this is not the case.The second theme is that of foreign fighters: in the West we are so free that there are people willing to sacrifice themselves for a principle that we shun.This means that our society does not have the antibodies to defend its bases from at least paradoxical attacks.The great poet comes to mind, who sang "Freedom I am looking for that is so dear, as he knows who refuses life for her".

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted for this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is extremely concerned about the persecution of religious minorities by ISIS. UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report, given the resolutions lack of calls for EU action, aside from §10's call for the establishment of an EU Permanent Special Representative to which we voted against, we voted for the resolution as a whole.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. - The year 2015 was marked by the multiplication of violent conflicts and terrorist acts practiced by the Islamic State, violating international humanitarian law and perpetrating under an alleged religious ideology acts of extermination of ethnic communities, eradication of cultural heritage and acts of pure barbarism against being Human. I cannot, we cannot and we must not allow, as Pope Francis said, "a world where the different forms of modern tyranny seek to suppress religious freedom, or reduce it to a subculture with no right of expression in the public sphere, or even use religion as a pretext for hatred and brutality ". I support this Resolution that condemns these acts of war and genocide practiced by the Islamic State against ethnic and religious minorities such as the Yazidi, Turkmen, Christians, Kurdish, Shiites, Sabbaticals, Sunni Muslims and urges their occurrence and punishment of their perpetrators . This is not a challenge from either creed, it is a challenge from humanity, which requires cooperation from all states and entities. Globalize the attack on ISIL / Daesh, do not globalize indifference.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: written.- I voted for the resolution because I strongly condemn the Islamic State and its tremendous violations of human rights and violations of international humanitarian law.Freedom of belief and religion are essential values and must be at the core of European foreign policy.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - The situation of the geographical area of ​​the Middle East which includes Iraq and Syria is dramatic for religious minorities, and more precisely for those of Christian faith. By now, more and more information and reports are received which show that the latter is the subject of various violations of international law: Christians are permanently and systematically targeted by "ISIS / Daesh", which intentionally pursues their destruction and their cultural cancellation in the territories they control. Moreover, very often they are killed, tortured, kidnapped, enslaved (especially women), converted to Islam and subjected to other ill-treatment. For these reasons, I am voting in favor of the motion for a resolution of the European Parliament which recognizes the facts as explicit violations of the Rome Statute and thus complies with the obligations incumbent on the international community with regard to war crimes, crimes against humanity and genocide.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ This motion for a resolution clearly expresses Parliament’s disgust at the mass murder of groups of persons by terrorist organisations such as ISIS/Daesh merely because they are a religious minority. A number of attacks on religious minorities have been taking place that show the extent of the terror brought about by such an organisation and highlight the importance of a unified voice between Member States, the European Union and other third countries against ISIS. The resolution also calls upon States to ensure the security of all religious minorities. I have thus voted in favour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: written. - We have abstained from this Resolution because the text appeals to the "Responsibility to Protect" (R2P), which is at the origin of the disastrous military interventions that have caused destabilization in the region. Those who supported R2P also supported the jihadist "rebels" who today attack religious minorities. We strongly condemn the killings of civilians, including religious, ethnic and minorities of any kind, but we are against the exploitation and use of certain religions by the EU. We have opposed the expansion of powers of the EU's foreign action by creating a high representative for Freedom of Religion and Belief, because we understand that her work would overlap with that of the High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy and It could be counterproductive if it reproduces the parliamentary reality, which prioritizes attention to certain confessions to the detriment of others, which can contribute to Islamophobia. For this reason we have abstained in this Resolution.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: signed up. - Violent extremist ideology perpetuated by ISIS / Daesh, terrorist acts, systematic attacks on civilians, abuses of human rights and international humanitarian law, including those conducted on religious or ethnic grounds, eradication of cultural heritage and trafficking in cultural goods, constitute a global and unprecedented threat to international peace and security. People belonging to ethnic and religious minorities who oppose ISIS / Daesh and other terrorist groups, militias and non-state armed groups in areas under their de facto control continue to be in danger of persecution. The international community, including the EU and its Member States, must ensure the necessary security conditions and prospects for ethnic and religious minorities, who have been forced to leave or have been forcibly displaced, to be able to return to their countries as soon as possible. their. The international community must provide military protection and assistance to particularly vulnerable groups targeted by ISIS / Daesh and other terrorist organizations in the Middle East, such as ethnic and religious minorities, and the participation of these groups in finding lasting political solutions. All parties to the conflict must respect universal human rights in order to facilitate the provision of humanitarian aid and assistance through all possible channels.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: in writing. - The European Parliament's decision has been drafted and adopted in the light of the current situation in Syria and Iraq. The EP strongly condemns the so-called "ISIS / Daesh" and its human rights abuses. He urges the UN Security Council to classify these crimes as genocide. The EP is concerned that this terrorist group is deliberately targeting Christian minorities and Sunnis who do not agree with their interpretation of Islam. Parliament condemned the destruction of religious and cultural sites and objects by ISIS / Da'esh. The EP recognizes and supports the inalienable right of all ethnic and religious minorities and others living in Iraq and Syria to continue to live in dignity, equality and security in their homeland and to practice their religion and beliefs freely, and demands that this right be upheld by all. respect. In order to prevent the suffering and mass exodus of Christians, Jesuits and other communities in the area, a statement by political and religious leaders in the area supporting their further presence and rights is essential. It calls on the international community to provide the necessary security conditions for those who have been forced to leave their homeland. The report calls on the Union to create a permanent special representative for freedom of religion or belief. I supported the ideas in the text.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing. - Bearing in mind that widespread and systematic violations of human rights are still committed, in particular against minorities such as Yazidis, Christians, Turkmen, Shi'ites, Shabbaks, Sabaean Mandeans, Jarsanites and Kurds, and the fact that the violence by Da'esh does not only affect people, but extends to the destruction of places of worship and archaeological sites, the resolution calls on all governments and public authorities, including the EU (in particular the Council and the EEAS) and its member states, the United Nations, the UN Secretary General, Special Representatives and Special Rapporteurs Of the United Nations, the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights, and all other international bodies and institutions, together with their leaders and representatives, to commit ISIS / Daisz atrocities against other nations and religions and all other indigenous religious minorities they called by name: "crimes against humanity" and "genocide." The purpose of ISIS / Da'esh is to deliberately pursue the complete physical and cultural elimination of all other ethnic and religious minorities from territories under its control. Bearing in mind the calls for action to defend fundamental human rights, especially the most important one - the right to life - I supported the resolution.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, in which the European Parliament calls on the UN Security Council to take action against ISIS/Daesh because of their persecution, atrocities and international crimes against minorities, which amount to crimes against humanity and war crimes according to the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court (ICC). Parliament also denounces in the strongest terms the destruction of religious and cultural sites and artefacts by Daesh, which constitutes an attack against the cultural heritage of all inhabitants of Syria and Iraq and of humanity at large.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: in writing.- This motion for a resolution calls on the European Commission to take urgent measures to counter the systematic massacre of religious minorities by the "Islamic State" group and asks the Union to recognize these atrocities.The Islamic State group is accused of violating international human rights and humanitarian law and of perpetrating widespread violence against members of minority groups, including Christians and Yazidis, inIraq and Syria.Considering that these atrocities and attacks against religious minorities are unacceptable, I supported this resolution.

name: Rachida DATI
text: in writing.- The barbaric and systematic massacres of religious minorities by the "Islamic State" group must be condemned in the most serious terms by the European Union and its Member States.The barbarity of this group reminds us of the urgency to actively fight against terrorism and radicalization which leads European citizens to commit such atrocities.I will continue to make a strong commitment to the defense of Eastern Christians.The action of the European Union must be firmest to guarantee the rights of religious minorities and the condemnation of these massacres.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this motion for a resolution which condemns all international crimes committed against religious minorities by the ISIS terrorist group.The international community can no longer stand by, further efforts and actions are needed to be able to prosecute those responsible for these crimes and stop the aberrant genocide in progress against Christians, Yazidis and other minorities and ethnic and religious communities currently in the territoriescontrolled by the Islamic State.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: in writing. - ISIL / Daesh perpetrated systematic and widespread violence and violations of international human rights and humanitarian law against members of minority groups, including Christians and Yazidis, in Iraq and Syria . That is why I voted for the Resolution on the systematic slaughter of religious minorities by the so-called "ISIL / Daesh" group. It is essential that these blatant violations of human rights, which in my view amount to crimes against humanity, be punished under the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court. I also hope that these acts will be qualified as genocide by the United Nations Security Council. Finally, through this vote, I believe that it is urgent to provide protection and assistance to all those targeted by the ISIL / Daesh group. This assistance could, moreover, constitute part of the response to the sizeable challenge of providing temporary protection to the millions of refugees, victims of the conflicts in Syria and Iraq.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this resolution. I am indeed extremely concerned by the fact that Daesh is systematically exterminating religious and ethnic minorities who refuse its interpretation of Islam in the regions it controls, in particular the Christian communities (Chaldean / Syrian / Assyrian, Melkite, Armenian) , Yazidis, Turkmens, Shiites, Chabaks, Sabeans, Kaka'e and Sunnis. These communities have the right to live in their homelands in dignity, on an equal footing and in security, and to freely practice their religion. We must impose on the competent authorities of countries which, directly or indirectly, support the crimes of this terrorist group, cooperate in its crimes, finance them or are complicit in them, to put an end to these unacceptable acts. Finally, it is essential for Member States to actively fight against radicalization in order to prevent their nationals and citizens from joining the ranks of Daesh.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing.- If the preservation of minorities is a laudable objective, the Union must not use the massacres to acquire new diplomatic powers or an international legitimacy to which it cannot claim.Although the findings are correct, this text undermines the sovereignty of States and is unfortunately not the appropriate response to the situation;that's why I abstained.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: in writing.- We are voting against, because although the Motion for a Resolution in general is moving in a positive direction, we consider unacceptable the fact that so hypocritically and insidiously they try to pass in an otherwise good resolution the financing of Turkey, which is one of the maincauses of the conflict from the beginning.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing.- Since 2014, around 5000 Yazidis have been murdered and many more have been tortured or forced to convert to Islam. At least 2000 Yazidi women have been enslaved and victims of forced marriages and human trafficking.Girls as young as six have been raped and Yazidi children have been forcibly recruited as soldiers of the self-proclaimed "EIIL / Daesh".More than 150,000 Christians have fled the advance of the group over several villages, having been robbed of all their possessions, and that, to date, these Christians remain displaced and in precarious conditions in northern Iraq.I strongly condemn the blatant human rights violations committed by the self-proclaimed 'EIL / Daesh', which are crimes against humanity and war crimes.The EU and the international community must step up their action to end these human rights violations.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - The resolution under review blatantly omits the responsibilities that the US and the EU have in reality that we are witnessing today. We recall that the same ones that today are considered enemies, were in the past allies in destabilizing Iraq and Syria. What is needed is solidarity and support for the Syrian and Iraqi peoples, victims of the barbaric action of these groups and of the military interference and aggressions perpetrated by NATO at the behest of the USA and the EU. We absolutely reject that, under the pretext of fighting it, the same processes of interference, aggression and war, driven by the geostrategic, political and economic interests of the USA and the directory of European powers, will continue. We vehemently repudiate the extreme violence, barbarism and terrorist acts perpetrated by the so-called EIL / Daesh, which the resolution denounces. The escalation of violence that threatens to drag these peoples into an ever greater disaster, will not end without ensuring respect for the sovereignty and independence of the peoples.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing - Since 2014, following the declaration of a caliphate in Iraq and Syria, ISIS poses a threat to the world. ISIS continues to carry out ethnic cleansing in northern Iraq and systematically attacks secular populations, non-Arabs and non-Sunni Muslim communities, as well as Sunnis who do not share the barbaric and fundamentalist understanding of their religion, killing or abducting thousands and forced more than a million people to leave the territories it occupies in Iraq and Syria. I unequivocally condemn every mass murder and other human rights violation committed by ISIS, regardless of the ethnic origin or religious affiliation of minority victims. We must not turn a blind eye to the deteriorating situation of women in Iraq, which is taking place in parallel with the country's decline over the last 30 years, while women remain stuck between Iraqi society's lack of attention, exacerbated by ISIS's presence, and the vision of ISIS law condemning Iraqi women for social exclusion.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing.- I am voting against the systematic mass extermination of religious minorities by ISIS in all the reports, because although the motion for a resolution is generally moving in a positive direction, I find it unacceptable that so hypocritically and insidiously they try to get into one, otherwisegood resolution the financing of Turkey, which is one of the main reasons for starting the conflict from the beginning.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Indiscriminate killings and massive human rights violations, in particular against ethnic and religious minorities, perpetrated by ISIS on the territories under its control, have to be condemned by all means. We must make any possible effort to avoid that the mass murder continues, and we must coordinate efforts to protect all civilian victims of the conflict, regardless of their ethnicity and religion, with a particular focus on the most vulnerable groups, such as Yazidis, who were subjected to a brutal campaign by ISIL to destroy their community in Iraq. There is clear evidence of Isis assassinations of church leaders, mass murders, torture and kidnapping in the communities of Iraq and Syria and the sexual enslavement and systematic rape of girls and women. What is happening is genocide, deliberately aimed at destroying ethnic and religious minorities in the Middle East in territory controlled by ISIS.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the resolution because it is an initiative of the European Parliament which aims to appropriately qualify the actions carried out by this terrorist organization. This qualification will also provide the direction for a response from the international community. Although Daesh is not only a threat to minorities in the region, some are targeted especially because of their religion or ethnicity. The responsibility of the international community is to oppose the hatred and violence of those who justify their actions by religion, international law and unity. In terms of law, the resolution calls for legal recognition through the use of the word genocide, and on the other hand, it recalls the mandate of the International Criminal Court, competent for crimes against humanity. In terms of unity, I welcome the call to work together with the Organization for Islamic Cooperation, with the Cooperation Council for Arab Gulf States and more generally with religious leaders to promote the protection of minorities. ethnic and religious, and both ideologically and politically counter radical interpretations of Islam.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: written.- I voted in favor of the Resolution, outraged once again by the lack of humanity of the terrorist group ISIL and by the terror and pain it inflicts on the civil population in general, and especially on religious minorities, in the territories it has occupied.: their victims are murdered, sacrificed and beaten, they suffer extortion, kidnapping, torture and slavery, they are forcibly converted and victims of forced marriages and human trafficking.The list of barbarism and crimes against humanity is endless.We must fight with all the tools at our disposal against terrorism, provide aid to its victims and make it clear that the EU and the international community will never rest until we bring the guilty of such heinous crimes before the International Criminal Court.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing.- With today's vote, the European Parliament confirms its firm condemnation of ISIS / Daesh and its shameful violations of human rights, which deliberately target religious minorities in the occupied territories, first of all Christians, but also Yazidis,Turkmen, Shia, Shabak, Sabei, Kaka'e and Sunni.These atrocities are and amount to "war crimes", and "genocide" also from an international law point of view according to the statute of the International Criminal Court.It is time to stop, also through the appropriate legal instruments, not only the material perpetrators of these crimes but also those who, by supporting the terrorists, allow the perpetration of these atrocities.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the EP resolution presented following a statement by the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy (pursuant to Rule 123 (2) of the Rules of Procedure) on extermination systematic of religious minorities by ISIS. It has long been clear that the criminal and barbaric ideology of the self-styled Islamic State poses a global threat to world peace and security and that the international community has a duty to intensify joint efforts to crack down on such crimes. About two years after the occupation of Syrian and Iraqi territories removed from government control, ISIS has carried out countless acts of terrorism, abuses, serious and systematic violations of human rights, massacres of civilians and all other kinds of barbarism. Above all, ethnic and religious minorities are in the crosshairs of Daesh, and they are serving the sole fault of sharing a different vision and interpretation of the Koran. I therefore share the invitation addressed to the international community, in particular to Turkey and the Gulf States, to take more effective action to ensure the safety and decent standard of living for refugees and displaced persons and to activate channels of humanitarian assistance in against the persecuted population.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: written.- I voted for the resolution on the "Systematic mass murder of religious minorities by IS" that I personally helped to develop and introduce.I consider it to be a decision of historical importance, as the European Parliament unequivocally emphasizes for the first time "that the IS is perpetrating genocide on Christians, Yazidis and other minorities".

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: written.- Our understanding of universal human rights and religious freedom must also be an integral part of European foreign policy in the future.Therefore I condemn the inhuman acts of the IS in the strongest possible way.Especially now, all EU Member States must take a clear stand and speak with one voice.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution. Daesh has been systematically killing, torturing, kidnapping and sexually enslaving members of minority groups, including Christians and Yazidis, in Iraq and Syria. Only last month, 400 people were killed or kidnapped by them in Syria. It was also confirmed that the oldest Christian monastery in Iraq was razed to the ground. But we should also have other areas – like Pakistan and Afghanistan, where the Taliban have been rebranding into Daesh – on our radar. The EU and the UN must take urgent action to protect the Shias, Sikhs, Hindus, Muslims, Christians and other minority groups there from extremist attacks. My West Midlands colleague Rob Flello MP has been pressing the UK Government to call on the UN to treat the Daesh atrocities against religious minorities as genocide. I urge the High Representative to back this initiative. Many voices at the UN speak louder than one, and this will help send a clear message to members of Daesh that they will face justice for the atrocities that they are committing now.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: written.- We abstain from voting on this Resolution considering that: 1) the call to accept the jurisdiction of the International Criminal Court must also be addressed to the United States, China, India and all States, and not be limited to Syria and Iraq;2) any authorized intervention must be of a civil and humanitarian nature and not a military one;3) The use of the concept of genocide with a spectrum much greater than that granted to it in the framework of the International Criminal Court (apart from the case of the Yazidis) is problematic.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ The persecution of Christians, Yazidis and any Muslim not supporting the so-called ‘Salafi Movement’ is not acceptable, and this terrorist group should be held accountable for these actions. I must also add that the oppression of LGBTI individuals is massively upsetting and the brutality that they have suffered should be reflected in this resolution.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: in writing.- On Thursday February 4, I voted in favor of a resolution calling on the international community to take measures to counter the systematic massacre of religious minorities by the "Islamic State" (IS) or Daesh group.The text closes the debate on January 20 with Federica Mogherini, High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, during which many MEPs called for measures to protect all religious groups and minorities against attacksof IS / Daesh.It is urgent to encourage all measures aimed at protecting Christians, whose values we share, and who everywhere are victims of terrible persecution.While 7,100 Christians were killed around the world in 2015 for reasons related to their belief, it is more than necessary to forcefully recall the Christian roots of Europe.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour on the resolution of systematic mass murder of religious minorities by ISIS. The document stressed massive human rights abuses by ISIS, which amount to crimes against humanity and war crimes. It is extremely concerned at this terrorist group’s deliberate targeting of Christians, Yazidis, Turkmens, Shi’ites, Shabaks, Sabeans, Kaka’i and Sunnis who do not agree with their interpretation of Islam. The resolution urges the members of the UN Security Council to support a referral by the Security Council to the International Criminal Court in order to investigate violations committed in Iraq and Syria by ISIS.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE / NGL), in writing. - We condemn ISIS 'practice of mass extermination of minorities and call on the international community to fight for a political solution to the issue. We call for ways to stop funding the Organization and to stop arms sales to the region. Our position is to find a political solution in Syria that ensures the indivisibility of the country and the only way is to end the war in Syria and Iraq and find a political solution within the UN. We must not forget, however, that the strengthening of ISIS was the result of US and allied intervention in the Middle East in an attempt to expand their control over the region. Unfortunately, the joint resolution lacks key positions in our analysis and that is why we consider this abstention to be appropriate.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support this resolution on the systematic mass murder of religious minorities by so-called ‘ISIS/Daesh’. Under international law each individual has the right to live according to his or her conscience and to freely hold and change religious and non-religious beliefs. Religious and ethnic minorities, such as the Christian and Yazidi communities, among others, have been deliberately targeted by Daesh and are being slaughtered, beaten, abducted and tortured. Also hugely worrying is the targeted enslavement of the women and girls of these communities, who are subjected to horrific sexual violence and forcibly trafficked, married and converted. The international legal definition of genocide, in accordance with the 1948 UN Convention, has undoubtedly been fulfilled and I support the call for action to be taken for it to be recognised as genocide by the UN Security Council and for the Council to support a referral to the ICC in order to investigate violations committed in Iraq and Syria by Daesh against religious and ethnic minorities. It is also worth noting that this ongoing persecution of religious and ethnic groups in the Middle East is a contributing factor to the current refugee crisis.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: written.- I have voted in favor of the resolution calling on the UN, the International Court of Justice and others to regard ISIS 'eradication of religious minorities as genocide.I support that view, but at the same time I want to emphasize that the concept of genocide is a legal, legal term and that international agreements dictate both how the international community establishes that genocide has been committed and obliges states and institutions to act.If a genocide is committed in its legal sense, it must therefore ultimately be determined by the legal arrangements that exist for this.Through my vote in favor of the resolution, I call for the process provided for in the UN Convention to prevent and punish genocide and crimes against humanity from 1948 to be accelerated.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this resolution because I too strongly condemn the activity of the terrorist organization which is called ISIS or Daesh. The actions taken by these terrorists are nothing less than crimes against humanity and war crimes. Moreover, what must be recognized in the Middle East is the ongoing persecution of religious and ethnic groups that has caused mass displacement and migration. The international community must work together in order to ensure the necessary security conditions for those who have been forced to leave their homeland.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written.- I voted in favor of the joint motion for a resolution on the systematic mass killing of religious minorities by the so-called Islamic State because I believe that crimes against humanity and war crimes should be punished.Relevant measures should be taken at the national level to combat such actions, and at the same time work should be done to strengthen international cooperation, because without coordinated international action it is not possible to solve this serious problem.Several UN reports indicate that war crimes, crimes against humanity and genocide against Christians, Yazidis and other minorities are taking place in areas controlled by IDIS / Daesh.All EU Member States are called upon to make their efforts to protect persecuted peoples and their heritage, and I therefore support this motion for a resolution.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: in writing. - If I share with this text the same repulsion towards the Islamic State and its appalling crimes, I wonder on the other hand about the political use that is made by the European Union to give itself a diplomatic legitimacy that it does not has not. So I cannot support the idea of ​​creating "a permanent special representative for freedom of religion and belief" to the EU institutions, any more than I accept that the EU urges "Syria and Iraq to accept the jurisdiction of the International Court "which it is obvious that it applies a contemporary Western vision of the law to countries which are part of a very different cultural and civilizational perspective. Finally, it is quite obvious that resolutions of the European Parliament will not solve anything in the Near and Middle East. I note in this regard that apart from begging for principles, not a word on the strategy that should be followed to take back the territories controlled by the IS, while it is obvious that the Western powers should review their position on the spot. towards the Syrian, Russian and Iranian governments and stand out from Turkey, Saudi Arabia and Qatar. That's why I abstained.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – UKIP is extremely concerned about the persecution of religious minorities by ISIS. Given the resolution’s lack of calls for EU action, aside from point 10’s call for the establishment of an EU Permanent Special Representative which we voted against, we voted for the resolution as a whole.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this very important resolution which calls on the international community to take urgent measures in the face of the systematic massacre of religious and ethnic minorities by the "Islamic State" (IS) group in Iraq and Syria.Through this resolution, which I co-signed, we call on the international community to take clear action to protect the religious minorities of this group.The European Union must strongly condemn these human rights violations and urge the United Nations Security Council to qualify these acts as genocide.Communities are disappearing completely from this region and it is our duty to protect them.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written.- The terrible crimes of ISIS against religious minorities should be condemned clearly and unequivocally.I am therefore voting in favor of this resolution.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. Persecutions on religious grounds have dramatically increased. In 2015 at least 7 100 Christians were murdered purely because of their belief. Two years ago this number was 2 100. 2 400 Christian churches were demolished or closed. The Iraqi Christian population has declined in 12 years by a factor of 4 – from 1.3 million to 300 000.  Aleppo had a 400 000 Christian population 5 years ago - now ca. 6 000 are left. Christians are clearly the most persecuted and devastated religious group in the world. We notice these disastrous figures, but are we drawing conclusions? 2015 can be seen as a spill-over year: spill-over of systematic violence against freedom of belief.  The central development has been the domination of intolerance – refusal to co-exist, not to speak of equal co-existence. Today we face the grim reality that in a few years’ time Christians will be ousted from the very cradle of Christianity, their and our common ancient cultural heritage destroyed. We have to deal with militant, intolerant racism, whose acts need finally to be qualified not only as terrorist deeds but as crimes against humanity and, on some occasions, as genocide.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution, as everyone has a right to fundamental freedoms and respect of their human rights, regardless of their beliefs or ethnicity. It is our duty to stand in solidarity with the oppressed. Whether in Europe or the Middle East, communities are stronger when they work together to combat terrorist propaganda and to administer programmes that celebrate diversity and empower minorities.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, since I condemn the systematic mass murder of religious minorities by ISIS. Furthermore, I call for the establishment by the EU of a permanent Special Representative for Freedom of Religion and Belief. I stress also the importance to provide protection and aid to all groups targeted by the ISIS/Daesh organisation.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ Undoubtedly, the worst humanitarian crisis of our time is Syria. Тhe Syrian civil war is the most complex, most violent and deadliest conflict on Earth. Now in its fifth year, the conflict is more than just a battle between those for or against President Assad. It has acquired ethno-religious character, spread into neighbouring countries, drawn in the world powers, and facilitated the rise of global jihadist groups like Daesh. More often than not, these new dimensions of the Syrian conflict jeopardise religious minorities in the extensively divided country. Daesh is responsible for the systemic killing of religious minorities and, to put it simply, everyone who does not share their radical views. This brutal terror campaign against religious minorities is definitely an absolute crime against humanity. In addition, the Assad regime is continuing to commit genocide against its own people.  More than ever, as the worlds’ leading normative power, the EU should begin an extensive diplomatic push for finding a solution. This, ideally, could happen during negotiations between Syrian government and opposition in Geneva this month. There, the EU could show its global role in dealing with challenges.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - The shameful violations of human rights by "ISIS / Daesh" target Christians, Yazidis, Turkmen, Shiites, Shabak, Sabeans, Kaka’e and Sunnis. The European Union strongly condemns these actions, which are absolutely unacceptable and that is why we have decided to present a joint motion for a resolution. "ISIS / Daesh" is committing genocide against Christians, Yazidis and other ethnic and religious minorities who do not share its interpretation of Islam. We cannot allow genocide, crimes against humanity and war crimes to go unpunished and it is imperative to strengthen international cooperation in order to put an end to such atrocities. I find it deplorable the very serious and systematic violation of the inalienable right of all religious and other minorities living in Iraq and Syria. The international community has a duty to provide protection and assistance, including military assistance, in accordance with international law, to all those targeted by the so-called "ISIS / Daesh" and other terrorist organizations in the Middle East.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the resolution presented by my EPP colleague Lars Adaktusson on the systematic massacre of religious minorities by the "Islamic State" group, calling on the international community to take urgent measures for the protection of religious minoritiesagainst the organization "Islamic State", among which are the persecuted Eastern Christians.We reminded that these violations of human rights constitute, according to the UN, war crimes and crimes against humanity, and, in some cases, genocide.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: in writing. - The resolution on the mass crimes committed by Daesh against religious mirrors followed the debate in which I spoke during the previous parliamentary session. This text strongly condemns acts of genocide committed against religious minorities under the control of Daesh, and consequently calls for referral to the International Criminal Court as well as international protection for these minorities, including by military means. As in previous resolutions, he denounces all forms of financing and trafficking that can fuel Daesh, in particular archaeological looting, which destroys existing sites, and feeds the coffers of this terrorist organization. On this question, the text unfortunately does not dare to name the Gulf States, which are nevertheless the main providers of funds and materials, and is satisfied with a convoluted formula asking them to fulfill their international obligations and to stop these practices. I regret the fact that by rightly denouncing the massacres against religious minorities one does not also insist on the atrocities committed against the Sunni populations. However, the condemnation of these atrocities must be unequivocal and that is why I supported this text.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: in writing.- I abstained on the motion for a resolution on the systematic massacre of religious minorities by the "Islamic State" group.If the preservation of minorities, religious and others, is a laudable objective, the European Union does not have to use this to endow itself with new powers and an international legitimacy to which it cannot claim.

name: Petr MACH
text: in writing.- I am against the killing of people by the Islamic State, but "calling on states that support war crimes to stop" is ridiculous.Establishing a new office for freedom of religion is nonsense.I abstained during the vote.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written.- The so-called Islamic State carries out mass killings and violates international law in the field of human rights and humanitarian law.Some of these acts, according to UN experts, correspond to war crimes, crimes against humanity and can be considered genocide.Terrible violence and abuse carried out by the so-calledThe Islamic State affects not only religious minorities, but all those who disagree with their ideology.The motion for a resolution strongly condemns serious violations of international law as well as the destruction of religious and cultural sites.The resolution also stresses the importance of all parties in Syria and Iraq being held accountable for violations of international human rights law and international humanitarian law, including genocide, crimes against humanity and war crimes, in accordance with international standards.Because of all the above and the need to bring all forms of violations of international law to justice, I supported this resolution.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing - Freedom of religion and belief is one of the human rights that every democratic country must respect.It is sad that in modern history, due to religious intolerance, inhuman acts are committed and the surrounding society cannot prevent this.The difficult and lingering difficult situation in Africa is incomprehensible to many people and reduces confidence in the action and capacity of international organizations, communities and even the governments of some Member States.It is not possible to provide assistance with one hand and to worsen the situation in those countries with the other, in order to promote the interests of certain groups.I consider it necessary for all the security and diplomatic forces to come together and, with the help of international law and agreements, to start working on concrete steps that will unite the forces, regardless of the interests of certain groups.Further suffering and murder of people must be prevented.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing.- I am voting in favor of the Joint Motion for a Resolution on the systematic mass killings of religious minorities by the so-called ‘ISIS / Daesh’, because it is complete and substantiated.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this resolution, which ‘Urges the members of the UN Security Council to support a referral by the Security Council to the International Criminal Court in order to investigate violations committed in Iraq and Syria by the so-called ‘ISIS/Daesh’ against Christians, Yazidis and religious and ethnic minorities’.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: written.- Today we have asked - through this proposal to which I add my vote - that the international community take urgent measures to counter the systematic mass murder of religious minorities by Daesh.We strongly condemn the action of this terrorist group and its gross abuses of human rights, attacking those groups that do not agree with its interpretation of Islam.These violations are war crimes and crimes against humanity, which must be rigorously prosecuted.

name: Georg MAYER
text: written.- The motion for a resolution extensively and unreservedly condemns the acts of IS.Proposals such as the establishment of protection zones are welcome, as is the call to leading Muslims to call the crimes of IS by their names.I am therefore voting in favor of this report.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: in writing. - This resolution calls for "the international community to provide, in accordance with international law, protection and assistance, including military" to populations victims of Daesh and other terrorist organizations in the Middle East and support the talks underway in Geneva. However, without a UN mandate, the unilateral military operation by France and its NATO allies without coordination with the Syrian army and the Kurdish forces in northern Syria did not lead to any military or geopolitical results. concrete. The resolution obviously ignores the interventionist policy of the United States and its allies which has contributed to the disintegration of these countries in the Middle East. I regret the starting “confessional” bias of this resolution on the “systematic massacre of religious minorities”. She worries much more about the fate of Christians than of Shiite Muslims, and not a word is professed for agnostics or atheists, who are just as forced into exile, into conversion or paying religious taxes to Daesh. Likewise, I regret that she is still struggling to directly name accomplices such as Qatar, Saudi Arabia and Turkey. I refrain.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: in writing. - The Islamic State and its appalling crimes make me share the same disgust with this text. However, the political use which is made of it by the European Union to give itself a diplomatic legitimacy which it did not question me. I cannot support the idea of ​​creating "a permanent special representative for freedom of religion and belief" to the EU institutions. I do not accept either that the EU urges "Syria and Iraq to accept the jurisdiction of the International Court" which it is obvious that it applies a Western vision of the law to countries which lie in a very different cultural and civilizational perspective. Finally, it seems obvious that things will not be better advanced by Parliament resolutions in the Middle East. On this subject, I note that except for the begging of principles, nothing is said about the strategy that should be followed to take back the territories controlled by the Islamic State although it goes without saying that the Western powers should review their position with regard to the Syrian, Russian and Iranian governments and distance themselves from Turkey, Saudi Arabia and Qatar. Consequently I abstained.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the systematic mass murder of religious minorities by ISIS.I strongly repudiate the crimes of genocide committed by the self-proclaimed Daesh.I share the view that it is essential for the international community to provide protection and support, including military support, in accordance with international law, to those targeted by Daesh and other terrorist organizations in the Middle East.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I signed and voted in favour of this to cross party resolution as the international community needs to take as strong and as united a stance as possible against this terrorist organisation that is causing so much death and destruction.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: in writing. - I am relieved to see that the EP had the political courage to vote a resolution which recognizes that the Islamic State is guilty of the crime of genocide, that is to say of crimes "committed with the intention of destroying, in whole or in part, a national, ethnic, racial or religious group "; By qualifying as genocide, the ignoble and low-intensity crimes committed in Iraq and Syria by DEASH, we are forcing the international community to take all the necessary measures to ensure the protection of the communities attacked, namely "Christians, Yazidis and other religious and ethnic minorities "including that of prosecuting the culprits in order to judge and punish them. I am of the opinion that without further delay, the members of the UN Security Council must recognize the genocide and seize the International Criminal Court in order to investigate these crimes against humanity, these war crimes. history will judge us on our actions but also on our silences.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing - The action of the Islamic State in Africa and the Middle East must be called by its real name: crimes against humanity and genocide. We, in Europe, watch the suffering of millions of people through the media, but they must really fight for their bare lives, protect their daughters from sexual violence, flee their homes. They lost property, families and hope. The consequences will not only be borne by individuals or religious groups. The Islamic State has managed to disrupt the character of areas where people of different nationalities or religions have lived in harmony and peace for hundreds of years. These people, who have become refugees today, do not form a homogeneous group that would be easy to help, but are mixed with Christians, Shiites or Yazidis, as well as members of other religions who also have diverse ethnic backgrounds. I agree that those responsible for this situation should be punished in accordance with UN conventions and agreements. The situation needs to be addressed quickly and responsibly, and preparation needs to be prepared for the period to help the affected areas after these events.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ Islamic fundamentalism has become a global movement with its own ideology. We have to understand that in order to defeat terrorist organisations such as ISIL/DAESH, we must first defeat their ideology and show to the world that violence is not the answer, because, killing innocent people is not being loyal to the true  teaching of Islam. There's too much at stake. Non action is not an option. Terrorism is a global threat with cross-border implications and therefore requires to be addressed in a coordinated way relying on cooperation, common strategies and EU-wide measures as part of an overall holistic EU framework.Therefore, I voted in favour of the Resolution on the Systematic mass murder of religious minorities by ISIS.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing.- The Verts / ALE, ECR, GUE / NGL, ALDE, S&D, PPE and EFDD Groups have tabled motions for resolutions.Six of the seven political groups, with the exception of GUE / NGL, agreed on a draft compromise.I voted in favor of this motion.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. - The extremist and violent ideology of the so-called Islamic State, its terrorist acts, its continuous widespread and systematic attacks against civilians, its human rights abuses and violations of international humanitarian law, including those perpetrated for religious or ethnic reasons, its eradication of cultural heritage and trafficking in cultural goods constitute a global and unprecedented threat to international peace and security. I argue that genocide, crimes against humanity and war crimes cannot go unpunished and that their judgment must be ensured by taking measures at national level, strengthening international cooperation, as well as through the International Criminal Court and international criminal justice . I endorse the condemnation of the self-proclaimed 'EIL / Daesh' and the blatant human rights violations committed by them, which are crimes against humanity and war crimes, and it is imperative to take measures to be recognized as genocide by the United Nations Security Council.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: in writing.- This motion for a resolution concerns the systematic massacre of religious minorities by the Islamic State.These are laudable intentions and goals.However, the EU does not have to use these tragedies to equip itself with more foreign affairs skills.Indeed, the EU has no international legitimacy to push in this direction.So I decided to abstain so as not to give the EU a position it should not enjoy.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution concerning the systematic massacre of religious minorities by the Islamic State group.This text underlines the horror experienced by minorities, and in particular Christians, in areas controlled by this terrorist group: massacres, spoliations, kidnappings, torture, rape, forced marriages, slavery ... It strongly condemns these abuses and calls on the Council toUnited Nations security forces to qualify them as war crimes and crimes against humanity.We must put an end to the ongoing genocide which is deliberately targeting Christian, Yazidi, Turkmen, Shiite, Chabak, Sabean, Kaka'e and Sunni communities.This resolution calls in particular for the recognition of the jurisdiction of the International Criminal Court to prosecute and try the perpetrators of these crimes.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the resolution strongly condemning the massacres committed by the 'ISIL' group on religious minorities.The terrorist group is responsible for war crimes and genocide against these populations who do not share the abject interpretation of Islam according to ISIL.With this resolution, we recall our inalienable commitment to respect for human rights, and underline the importance for the international community of providing the necessary assistance in the fight against terrorism.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court that was signed and ratified by all EU Member States declares that crimes against humanity and war crimes represent the greatest concern of the international community as a whole. Such actions must not go unpunished. I have voted for this motion for a resolution that condemns the ISIS faction and its deplorable human rights abuses and urges Syria and Iraq to accept the jurisdiction of the International Criminal Court.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: In written form. - The actions of the Islamic State cause the loss of human lives every day. The delayed response by the international community has allowed terrorists to expand beyond the borders of Syria and Iraq. Attacks on citizens, attacks on religious and cultural grounds, the destruction of cultural sites and the trafficking of cultural artifacts shocked the whole world. Today, Christians, Yazidis and others who do not share the ideology preached by the Islamic State are being systematically liquidated. Attacks on religious and ethnic minorities can easily be described as a crime against humanity and genocide. I strongly condemn the atrocities of this terrorist group, which expelled millions from their homelands and took the lives of thousands of others. The financial flows to ISIL must be stopped at all costs. In Europe, too, we have witnessed this destructive ideology. Dozens of young Europeans went to Syria and gave their lives there. Let us join forces to stop the terrorists once and for all.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report because it is a small step in the right direction in combating ISIS tyranny.On the other hand, I decided against paragraph 10 of the report because I do not consider it necessary for the EU to create a representative for religious and ideological issues in addition to all of its positions.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: S & amp; D), in writing. - On 27 January 2016, a motion for a resolution was tabled before the European Parliament in relation to the systematic mass killings of religious minorities carried out by the terrorist organization ISIS. I could only express my support for the content of this resolution. The way ISIS treats religious minorities is macabre and genocidal. The activities of this terrorist organization are motivated by religious or ethnic motives, contribute to the elimination of cultural heritage, and pose a global and unprecedented threat to international peace and security. This daily slaughter is another slap in the face for failing to implement international humanitarian law. At this point, I would like to stress the need for further and immediate action by both the Member States and the international community to reach a solution.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. – UKIP is extremely concerned about the persecution of religious minorities by ISIS. Given the resolution’s lack of calls for EU action (aside from §10’s call for the establishment of an EU Permanent Special Representative, which we voted against), we voted for the resolution as a whole.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing.- The so-called ISIL / Daesh continues to target ethnic and religious groups in Iraq and Syria, deliberately subjecting them to a series of serious abuses and violations of international human rights law and international humanitarian law, which in some cases constitute crimes ofwar and crimes against humanity.This includes mass executions, targeted killings and torture.For these reasons I would have voted positively on the proposed resolution.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: in writing. ‒ For years we have been witnessing the horrific criminal acts which are performed in front of our eyes in the terrible war in Syria and Iraq. The time has come, that the international community is mobilized towards resolving the crisis and legally aknowledging that what is happening with Christians and other religious minorities under the reign of ISIS is "genocide", with all the implications that such a definition means. I am hopeful, that such definitions will bring consequences at the level of the UN Security Council and align all allies against the terrible criminal acts which are being done in the middle east, under the pretext of religious persecution.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - "ISIS / Daesh is committing genocide against Christians and Yazidis and other religious and ethnic minorities who do not agree with its interpretation of Islam and therefore it is necessary to take measures in accordance with the United Nations Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide" - reads the Resolution on systematic mass killing of religious minorities carried out by the so-called Islamic State, adopted today by the European Parliament. In the areas that are the cradle of Christianity and where Christianity has lived for almost two thousand years, it is now facing extinction. ISIS systematically and deliberately intimidates and attacks, kills and expels Christians while destroying their churches, so that an entire religion completely disappears from the Middle East. It's called genocide. According to the principle of the responsibility to provide protection, the European Parliament has an obligation to call these crimes by their real names and to call for active action to protect persecuted Christians, as failed by the states in whose territory the genocide took place. Parliament therefore calls on Iraq and Syria to accept the jurisdiction of the International Criminal Court, and on the international community and all signatory countries to the Genocide Convention to do everything in their power to bring all perpetrators involved in these heinous crimes to justice. .

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: in writing.- Basically, I approve of the denunciation made of the massacre of minorities by the so-called Islamic State in the territories of Iraq and Syria.But the European Union is using these crimes to equip itself with foreign policy resources, which is unacceptable.This body has no legitimacy on the international scene and would do better not to seek to solve the problems of others while the relations between the peoples locked together within the Union continue to deteriorate.Under these conditions, I therefore prefer to abstain, because I refuse to endorse the diplomatic tendencies of the European Union.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. - I share, without reservation, the firm condemnation of the ISIS / Daesh terrorist group which has made itself responsible, and continues to be responsible, for heinous crimes against humanity and war crimes which, in the case of religious LGBT, it appears more and more like a real genocide. Christians, Yazidis, Turkmen, Sufis, Shiites and Sunnis who do not share his delusional interpretation of Islam are victims of daily attacks, aimed at physically eliminating any religious minority from the territory. Likewise, they condemn the brutal persecution of members of the LGBT community and the horrific oppression of women, subjected to physical, psychological and sexual violence, forced into slavery and reduced to bargaining chips by terrorists. A condition from which many children and, in general, all the weakest sections of society also suffer. Therefore, I join my voice to the appeal that the international community, the UN, the European Union, the Member States and all the other parties involved, do everything possible to put an end to these crimes and bring those responsible to justice. At the same time, I want to reaffirm the importance of welcome and protection for those forced to flee Syria and Iraq, precisely because of such crimes.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written. - UN Security Council Resolution 2249 (2015) of 20 November 2015 confirmed that the violent extremist ideology of the so-called IDIS / Daisha, its terrorist acts, continued severe systematic and widespread attacks on civilians, human rights and international humanitarian law violations, including those committed on religious or ethnic grounds, eradication of cultural heritage and trade in cultural goods are global and hitherto an unprecedented threat to international peace and security. Genocide, crimes against humanity and war crimes concern all EU Member States that are determined to cooperate in order to prevent such crimes and end impunity for perpetrators in accordance with Council Common Position 2003/444 / CFSP. I therefore support the European Parliament's response in the form of this resolution and join the calls to respect the inalienable right of all ethnic and religious minorities and others living in Iraq and Syria to continue living in their historical and traditional homelands in dignity, equality and security. they profess their faith without any coercion, violence or discrimination.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. - Repudiamos vehemently, the extreme violence, barbarity, and terrorist acts perpetrated by the so-called EIIL / Daesh, which the resolution denounces. But the same text blatantly omits the responsibilities that the US and the EU have in reality that we are witnessing today. He forgets that the same ones today are perceived as enemies, were in the past allies in the destabilization of Iraq and Syria. What is needed is solidarity and support for the Syrian and Iraqi peoples, victims of the barbaric action of these groups and of the military interference and aggressions perpetrated by NATO at the behest of the US and the EU. We absolutely reject that under the pretext of fighting it, the same processes of interference, aggression, and war driven by the geostrategic, political, and economic interests of the US and the directory of European powers will continue. The escalation of violence that threatens to drag these peoples into ever-greater disaster will not end without ensuring respect for the sovereignty and independence of the people. As a result, the abstention vote.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing.- In Iraq and Syria, ISIS / Daesh is seriously violating human rights.One of its objectives is to exterminate Christians and any other religious and ethnic minority in the areas under its control.According to the United Nations, these violations could constitute war crimes, crimes against humanity and genocide.This resolution calls on the international community to take immediate action to combat the mass extermination of religious minorities perpetrated by the so-called Islamic State and to appoint a permanent special representative for freedom of religion and belief.As this is a genuine humanitarian emergency, which must be stopped without further delay, I could not fail to vote in favor of this motion for a resolution.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: in writing. - I would like to mention here that the basic principles of the European Union are the protection of freedom of religion, respect for international humanitarian law, tolerance of others and non-condemnation of others solely on the basis of their faith. I am unequivocally against any hateful excesses and moods, whether it is the mass murder of Christians in Daesh-controlled territory or the anti-Jewish and anti-Islamic sentiment in the European Union. What is happening in Syria and Iraq, however, are genocide crimes that are unprecedented in today's world.
