Such crimes, in which members of individual religious minorities are murdered, raped and displaced, are to be unanimously condemned by the international community, including the body in which we are currently located. It is this resolution that should not end our work. The international community must be persuaded and the UN Security Council called on the UN Security Council to take strong action against the activities of Daesh and to end the flow of funds to this terrorist organization. In conclusion, I would like to point out that, unfortunately, the killing of Christians and other members of religious minorities does not only take place in Syria and Iraq, and it is our moral duty to condemn similar acts so as not to allow another tragedy of Rwanda or former Yugoslavia.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing. - It is obvious that I supported this resolution. But I would prefer not to have to vote on resolutions in which practices from another era are mentioned. These massacres, tortures, executions for religious reasons recall the 30 years war in Europe. Why? Because the different conceptions that clash around the questions of knowing what is good for the region in terms of religion, model of society, power, politics, coalition, will never find any common answer. Europe in the 17th century, in this same irreconcilable situation, chose not to seek to know what was good, but to know how to avoid evil. That is to say how to avoid violent death (war and diseases which result from it). ISIS is slowly embodying this evil because it affects all parties. But those responsible for its creation who thought to avoid this evil have blood on their hands and will make reconciliation in the region difficult. So let's defend what will prevent civilizations from dying a violent death.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. - This resolution reflects the European Parliament's common position on the genocide of religious minorities by Daesh who, in the areas under his control and under the cover of jihad, murder, massacre, beat, extort, kidnap, torture and enslave religious minorities and ethnic who adhere to an interpretation of Islam other than yihadist fundamentalism, or who simply profess another faith. In order to prohibit any assistance to the self-proclaimed Islamic State, the rapporteur recalls United Nations Security Council Resolution 2253 (2015) which establishes the legal duty of member states to prohibit the provision of arms and financial assistance - including the illegal oil trade - counterparts suspected of using arms and financing to commit violations of international humanitarian law. In particular, the report denounces the systematic mass murder of Christian religious minorities, Yazidis, Turkmen, Shiites, Shabak, Sabbat, Kaka'i and Sunnis. Given the above, I voted in favor of the resolution now under consideration in the expectation that the crimes perpetrated in the name of the extremist ideology of the so-called Islamic State will be called by their name - genocide - and that their accomplices will be considered criminals.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted for this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is extremely concerned about the persecution of religious minorities by ISIS. UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report, given the resolutions lack of calls for EU action, aside from §10's call for the establishment of an EU Permanent Special Representative to which we voted against, we voted for the resolution as a whole.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. - (PT) I voted in favor of this resolution, in which international persecutions, atrocities and crimes are considered to represent war crimes and crimes against humanity. I agree that the fact that the self-proclaimed "EIIL / Daesh" commits crimes of genocide against Christians and Yazidi, who do not agree with their interpretation of Islam, requiring the adoption of measures under the United Nations Convention for the Prevention and Suppression of Crime Genocide, 1948. Therefore, I consider it important that the members of the UN Security Council refer to the International Criminal Court the investigation of violations in Iraq and Syria against Christians, Yazidi and religious and ethnic minorities by the self-proclaimed "EIIL / Daesh" . In addition to agreeing to the creation of a permanent Special Representative for freedom of religion and belief, I would like to point out that the constant persecution of ethnic and religious groups in the Middle East is an important factor in mass migration and internal displacement. In view of the above, I voted in favor of this resolution because it expresses the importance of the international community ensuring protection and support, including military support, in accordance with international law, to those targeted by the self-proclaimed "EIIL / Daesh".

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: in writing. - I voted for this resolution, vigorous condemnation of the ISIL / Daesh group and of the war crimes and crimes against humanity of which it is guilty. This group poses a global threat of unprecedented gravity to international peace and security. He embodies the absolute antithesis of civilization. Among the sadly recorded atrocities, we point out here those specifically committed against religious and ethnic minorities, such as the Christian, Yazidi, Turkmen, Shabaks, Kaka'e, Sabean-Mandaean, Kurdish and Shiite communities, as well as many Arabs and Sunni Muslims. Systematically, these minorities are targeted: massacres, spoliations, kidnappings, torture, slavery, forced conversions or even trafficking in human beings, without mentioning the destruction of religious and cultural sites. Crimes against humanity and war crimes, wherever and whenever they occur, cannot go unpunished. We appeal to the international community! We urgently need to seize the ICC, put in place humanitarian corridors, take measures so that these acts are qualified as genocide by the Security Council. Today we feel helpless. Let’s not give up: one day humanity will be able to bring the guilty to justice.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: written. - The key point of the proposed Resolution is the fight against the persecution of Christians, non-Salafi Muslims, LGBTI people and other people or groups who do not share the vision of the world of Daesh. The world must hold this terrorist group responsible for the various atrocities they have committed against religious groups and minorities in general. This Resolution urges the Gulf States and, in particular, Saudi Arabia, to reject intolerant Wahhabi teachings that distort traditional Islamic values; calls on the international community, including the EU and its Member States, to ensure the security conditions and the prospects of these ethnic and religious minorities; urges all EU Member States to update their legal systems in order to prevent their nationals and fellow citizens from traveling to join Daesh and other terrorist organizations and so that, should they do so, they are prosecuted as soon as possible; and calls on all parties to the conflict to respect universal human rights to facilitate the delivery of humanitarian aid and assistance through all possible channels. For all these reasons, I have voted in favor.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing. - The resolution that I voted this afternoon urges the international community to take urgent measures to counter the systematic massacre of religious minorities by the "Islamic State" group. The text reiterates the strong condemnation of ISIS / Daesh and its flagrant violations of human rights, deliberately targeting Christians, Yazidis, Turkmens, Shiites, Shabaks, Sabeans, Kaka'e and Sunnis who do not agree with their interpretation of Islam. These violations amount to "war crimes", "crimes against humanity" and "genocide", according to the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court (ICC). The resolution calls on the European Union to appoint a permanent special representative for freedom of religion and belief and urges all countries in the international community to prevent war crimes, crimes against humanity and genocide in their territories. . All EU Member States should update their legal and judicial systems to prevent their nationals and citizens traveling abroad from joining ISIS / Daesh and other terrorist organizations, and also ensure that, if they do, they are subject to criminal proceedings as soon as possible.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. - I gave my full support to this motion for a resolution that strongly condemns the self-proclaimed "Islamic State / Daexe", as well as the unprecedented abuses of human rights and the serious violations of international humanitarian law and against the Heritage of Humanity committed by this terrorist organization . It is urgent that all contracting parties to the UN Convention for the prevention and repression of the crime of genocide unite in the fight against these war crimes and against humanity, in full compliance with the legal obligations arising therefrom. The fight against these barbaric acts must be fought relentlessly and all countries of the international community must make their legal and jurisdictional systems, as well as their education systems, more effective, with the aim of helping to form more balanced citizens, fair and responsible. I believe that humanitarian aid organizations operating on the ground must cooperate fully and directly with churches, Christian communities and other religious minorities, offering a response that is in line with the needs of the general population. I also understand that the national and international judicial system must function firmly and without tibias, when faced with barbaric acts committed by the self-proclaimed Islamic State / Daexe.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this resolution which calls on the international community to take urgent measures in the face of the systematic massacre of religious and ethnic minorities by the "Islamic State" group in Iraq and Syria. It is essential to act without delay against these atrocities and to bring to justice those who are at the origin of such atrocities. I supported this text which qualifies the systematic persecutions and executions of Christians, Yazidis and other minorities as genocide, and calls for the United Nations Security Council to recognize them as such. This is the first time that the European Parliament has qualified ethnic massacres as genocide. This position is based on a UN report of March 2015 which had already underlined that the attacks perpetrated by the "Islamic State" group in Iraq against the Yazidi minority could constitute genocide. Finally, the resolution calls on the UN Security Council to seize the International Criminal Court about the crimes of the "Islamic State" group in Iraq and Syria.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution proposed by the EPP because it provides that all abuses and discrimination perpetrated by ISIS, including against Christians, be recognized by the European Parliament as genocide, at the same time inviting the United Nations Security Council to dosame to you.We must use every means to fight ISIS and give its victims the dignity and respect they deserve.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: written.- We abstain from voting on this Resolution considering that: 1) the call to accept the jurisdiction of the International Criminal Court must also be addressed to the United States, China, India and all States, and not be limited to Syria and Iraq;2) any authorized intervention must be of a civil and humanitarian nature and not a military one;3) The use of the concept of genocide with a spectrum much greater than that granted to it in the framework of the International Criminal Court (apart from the case of the Yazidis) is problematic.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: in writing.- I condemn the many and serious violations of international human rights law and international humanitarian law committed by all parties involved in the ongoing conflicts in Iraq and Syria.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: written. - We have abstained from this Resolution because the text appeals to the "Responsibility to Protect" (R2P), which is at the origin of the disastrous military interventions that have caused destabilization in the region. Those who supported R2P also supported the jihadist "rebels" who today attack religious minorities. We strongly condemn the killings of civilians, including religious, ethnic and minorities of any kind, but we are against the exploitation and use of certain religions by the EU. We have opposed the expansion of powers of the EU's foreign action by creating a high representative for Freedom of Religion and Belief, because we understand that her work would overlap with that of the High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy and It could be counterproductive if it reproduces the parliamentary reality, which prioritizes attention to certain confessions to the detriment of others, which can contribute to Islamophobia. For this reason we have abstained in this Resolution.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing.- Finally, a European institution has found the courage to define the atrocities of ISIS against religious minorities for what they are: a genocide.Persecuted Christians, destroyed churches, the impossibility of professing one's faith: this is the situation in the Middle East in the hands of the so-called Islamic State.I hope that after the positions of the Council of Europe, which recognized the genocide last week, and the European Parliament, the United Nations will define these crimes against humanity as "genocidal", further raising public awareness.I therefore voted in favor of the resolution.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ The persecution of Christians, Yazidis and any Muslim not supporting the so-called ‘Salafi Movement’ is not acceptable, and this terrorist group should be held accountable for these actions. I must also add that the oppression of LGBTI individuals is massively upsetting and the brutality that they’ve suffered should be reflected in this resolution.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: written.- I did not support this report, but this explanation of the vote arises as a critique of the current system of evaluating the work of MPs in the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities highlighted in Croatia, which does not reflect the actual quality

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing - The situation of religious minorities living in areas occupied by the Islamic State is constantly deteriorating. The UN, together with other international organizations, continues to report widespread and serious violations of international human rights and humanitarian law. In the territories of Syria and Iraq, the IRS is committing targeted killings, forced conversions or kidnappings on ethnic and religious minorities. Anyone who disagrees with the radical idea of ​​IS becomes an enemy of their ideology, which serves as a justification for their actions. I therefore agree with the call for the international community and EU Member States to push for the crimes of this terrorist organization to be recognized as genocide. There is no other way to call the actions of a group that disagrees with other than a radical interpretation of Islam. It is an attempt by the group to exterminate all religious minorities in the territories under their control. UN member states must also abide by their obligations under the Security Council resolution and ban all forms of IS assistance, from arms supplies, oil trade to financial assistance. If individual countries do not act, if they turn a blind eye to genocide, they will also be violating international law. The Gulf states have a significant responsibility, which must step up their efforts and confront the extremist ideology of the Gulf. Minorities living in their historical homelands in Syria and Iraq have an inalienable right to life.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: in writing. - I welcome the resolution adopted, which clearly condemns war crimes and crimes against humanity by the so-called Islamic State. I consider it important to call on the UN Security Council to label these crimes as genocide. I consider it a mistake that this has not yet happened when, in 2014, the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights said in his report that the so-called Islamic State had murdered up to five thousand Yazid men and held another five to seven thousand Yazid women in captivity. , among other things, as a sex slave. The efforts of the so-called Islamic State to "cleanse" its territory of people of other religions are clearly visible. ISIS persecutes not only the Yazidis, but also Christians, Shiites, Turkmen, including Sunnis, who interpret Islam differently than ISIS. That is why I support the call on the UN Security Council to refer the matter to the International Criminal Court. I consider point 14 to be absolutely essential, in which we call for humanitarian aid and, above all, for the creation of humanitarian corridors under a UN mandate that would protect UN peacekeepers. I agree that these corridors can be part of the solution to the current refugee crisis. For the UN, this issue should be one of the absolute priorities.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: in writing. - The data show that the targets of the so-called ISIL / Da'isha are still ethnic and religious groups in Iraq and Syria (Chaldeans, Syrians and Assyrians, File Kurds, Kakais, Sabeans, Shabaks, Shiite Arabs, Turkmen and Yazidis). These represent deliberate victims of serious abuses and violations of international human rights law and international humanitarian law. As the latter, according to UN experts, I can list war crimes, crimes against humanity and perhaps even genocide. These systematic and horrific acts against specific ethnic and religious groups include mass executions, ethnic cleansing, planned massacres, forced conversions to Islam, kidnappings, forced displacement, stoning and amputation, enforced disappearances and torture, destruction of religious and cultural heritage monuments. property. I agree that the many serious violations of international human rights law and international humanitarian law that have been missed by all parties involved in the current conflicts in Iraq and Syria need to be strongly condemned. At the same time, I find it necessary to recall that the humanitarian needs of the people of Iraq, Syria and Libya continue to go beyond the international response. I join the call for the warring parties in the region to immediately stop attacking the civilian population, release arbitrarily detained prisoners and respect the human rights of all, regardless of religion, ethical affiliation or political belief. In the light of the above, I support the motion for a resolution.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. - I voted today in favor of the European Parliament resolution on the systematic extermination of religious minorities by DAESH, because I believe it is urgent to step up efforts to prevent and suppress further and unacceptable acts of violence against religious minorities. The ideology of violent extremism carried forward by DAESH, through continuous attacks and violations of human rights against various minorities, such as Christians, Yazidis, Turkmen, Shiites and Sunnis who do not share their interpretation of Islam, as well as through its systematic destruction of cultural heritage, constitutes a terrible threat to international security and peace. For this reason, we believe it is necessary and desirable to introduce specific provisions in the laws of the Member States, on the one hand, to stop the financing of terrorist organizations and, on the other, to stem the phenomenon of foreign fighters, through measures to prevent their citizens to leave to join these organizations.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing - Minorities are the most vulnerable group in any conflict.Attacks on national minorities in Syria and Iraq are a manifestation of violence, especially against Christians.To deny Europe's Christian roots would be like denying European culture.It is necessary to condemn this mass murder, not only in words but also in deeds, and in this way to send a signal to Christian minorities that we have a responsibility for them in the form of a systemic solution to their protection.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: written. - The violent extremist ideology of ISIS, its terrorist acts, continuous severe systematic and widespread attacks on civilians, violations of human rights and international humanitarian law, including those committed on religious or ethnic grounds, destruction of cultural heritage and trade in cultural goods are global and unprecedented threat to international peace and security, as confirmed by UN Security Council Resolution 2249 (2015). Genocide, crimes against humanity and war crimes, no matter where and when they occur, must not go unpunished, and effective prosecution of these acts must be guaranteed by taking action at the national level, strengthening international cooperation and through the International Criminal Court and international criminal justice. . In accordance with international law, all individuals have the right to live according to their own conscience and to freely believe and change their religious and non-religious beliefs. It is therefore important to guarantee the necessary security conditions and opportunities for all those who have been forced to leave their homeland or have been forcibly displaced, to enable them to exercise their right to return to their homeland as soon as possible, to preserve their homes, land, property and churches. religious and cultural sites to have the opportunity for a dignified life and future.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written.- Every day we witness the persecution and killing of religious minorities throughout the area controlled by ISIS.The brutality of Islamists knows no bounds, and the victims are guilty only because they are different from the aggressors.Such treatment is absolutely unacceptable for the EU.Christians are persecuted from their homes and often stay in desert refugee camps where Islamists exclusively offer them death as a solution.We need to find solutions to the current situation, because the current situation is unsustainable.In addition to the extinction of Christian culture in the Middle East and the loss of intercultural cooperation, this is a terrifying humanitarian catastrophe.I support the adoption of this resolution in order to protect religious minorities throughout the area controlled by ISIS.It is not enough to just vote on the resolution, but additional steps need to be taken to protect religious minorities in these areas.The vote on the resolution is the first step in this extremely complex process.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the joint motion for a resolution on the systematic mass killings of religious minorities by ISIS.It is our duty to constantly warn when it comes to violent extremist ideology, acts of terrorism, constant severe, systematic and large-scale attacks on civilians, violations of human rights and international humanitarian law.No matter who implements them and in what part of the world they take place.I join the condemnation of the actions of ISIS, which can be defined as crimes against humanity, and the call for members of the UN Security Council to support the Security Council's recommendation to the International Criminal Court to investigate violations against Christians, Yazidis and other national minorities in Iraq and Syria.performs t.i.ISIS.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: in writing.- I supported today's resolution on the systematic mass extermination of religious minorities by the so-called Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, because its text makes it clear that terrorist organizations in Syria and Iraq are committing genocide against all religious minorities in living areas and especially Christians.The systematic effort to exterminate all minorities is complemented by murders and terrorism against Muslims who do not agree with these terrorists.In addition, the resolution makes it clear - and thus repeats only the content of UN resolutions - that no aid can be provided to those who commit genocide, not even financially, for example by participating in the oil trade.On the contrary, any possible assistance is needed to all those who are the target of the ISIS assassination in Iraq and Syria because of their religious beliefs or resistance to the spread of violence and terror.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE / NGL), in writing. - The tragic situation with the continuous killings and mass exterminations of religious minorities by ISIS is taking on uncontrollable proportions. That is why wish lists are not enough. We must speak honestly. Europe is not without responsibility for what is happening. With the tolerance of the EU, both France and Germany have been equipping the jihadists, and to this day the EU is becoming the tail of the US, contributing to the destabilization of the region. At the same time, while you know that Turkey is strengthening its military and supporting ISIS, you are whistling indifferently. Hypocrisy is enough. There is an urgent need to address immediately the causes that created and strengthen ISIS. To end foreign interventions and wars in the Arab world. And to actively support initiatives for the pacification of the region. It is equally important that we do not allow Muslims to be targeted for what is happening. Nor should we accept the legitimacy of repressive measures to restrict individual rights and freedoms. What is needed is peace, solidarity and respect for human rights.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: in writing.- Although the motion for a Resolution is generally moving in the right direction, we find it unacceptable that they are so hypocritically and insidiously trying to get through this funding of Turkey, which has been one of the main causes of the conflict from the outset.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the resolution because it sets out a clear resolution on behalf of the European Parliament for the protection of religious minorities, one of the main targets of ISIS's particularly brutal, often genocidal, acts of violence. I welcome the fact that the resolution also raises awareness that purely political, diplomatic means cannot put an end to the violent activities of this terrorist organization and points to the responsibility of the international community to intervene effectively by military means. I also think it is right that the EP also points to the responsibility of European governments, so that their legislation better restricts the movement of people who join ISIS from Europe and penalizes their actions. Aware that ISIS is a threat to other minority groups in society in addition to religious communities, I consider it important for the EP to take a stand in defense of these groups in the future, and I will support it if such a resolution is proposed.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: signed up. - The rise of the Islamic State in Syria and Iraq (ISIS) is one of the major challenges facing contemporary society. The violence and inhumanity of the methods used by the militants of this terrorist group have long exceeded all imaginable limits in a civilized world. Beyond the aspects aimed at international actions to counter this terrorist scourge, the unfortunate actions that ISIS militants are taking against minority groups that do not share their fundamentalist and extremist religious values ​​cannot be ignored. This category may include, in addition to Christian minorities, Shiite, Alawite, Sufi Islamic minorities, secular or non-Salafist Muslim populations, Yazidi minorities, women and sexual minorities. Those groups were brutally treated by ISIS militants, being the victims of their repression, through persecution, denial of fundamental rights, indirect attacks or even bodily injuries and homicides. In these circumstances, the European Union, as the defender of the civilized world, has a moral duty to criminalize these acts as crimes against humanity. ISIS and its members must be held accountable before a special international tribunal set up for this purpose for the atrocities committed against those groups. We, as representatives of European citizens living in free societies, have a duty to support this resolution.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing. - With this resolution, we strongly condemn the serious and multiple violations of international human rights law and international humanitarian law committed by all parties to the current conflicts in Iraq and Syria. In addition, we must condemn the massive and widespread atrocities committed by Daesh, including its deliberate attempt to attack religious and ethnic communities in the territories it controls. Finally, the European Parliament denounces with the greatest firmness the destruction of religious and cultural sites and symbols by Daesh, which are all attacks on the cultural heritage of all the populations of Syria and Iraq and of humanity in general; it calls on all States to intensify their criminal investigations and their judicial cooperation with a view to identifying all the groups involved in the illicit trafficking of cultural property and the damage or destruction of cultural heritage which belongs to humanity as a whole, in Syria, in Iraq, as well as in the Middle East and North Africa at large.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution urging the members of the United Nations Security Council to support a referral by the Security Council to the International Criminal Court (ICC) in order to investigate violations committed in Iraq and Syria by so-called ISIS/Daesh against Christians, Yezidis and religious and ethnic minorities. Daesh violations are clear crimes against humanity and war crimes. It is also important that the international community provide protection and aid, including military protection and aid in accordance with international law, to all those targeted.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing.- Daesh has transformed religious conflict into a central theme of its propaganda and his actions, it has used religion as a recruiting tool and as a pretext to claim lands rich in raw materials.For this reason, Parliament's vote on this joint motion is of fundamental importance, in fact it is a question of placing the international crimes committed against all religious minorities by this terrorist group at the center of the political debate.It is our duty to continue to promote preventive measures and further action to stop the incipient genocide in progress against Christians, Yazidis and other ethnic and religious minorities and communities.We also ask the United Nations to act decisively to prosecute the members of ISIS responsible for such heinous actions.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the resolution on the systematic and mass killings of religious minorities by ISIS.It is appropriate to strongly condemn the crimes committed and the attacks on religious and ethnic communities in the ISIS-controlled areas.Crimes against Christians with signs of ethnic cleansing are particularly to be condemned.The resolution also rightly condemns the destruction of religious sites and cultural property, which is tantamount to an attack on the cultural heritage of Syria and Iraq and of all humanity.Like the European Parliament, we must have an unequivocal position on this issue in order to send a clear signal against the acts of genocide.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written. - Despite the loss of territory in Syria and Iraq, the so-called Islamic State still controls a large part of the territory in those countries, as well as certain regions in other countries. It is a frightening realization that despite the great losses caused by numerous air strikes by states operating within the coalition against IS, the cruel campaign to suppress all religious minorities and the traces of their existence is not waning. This is supported by alarming information and warnings from the intelligence community that 2016 will unfortunately not be any calmer and that the attacks will continue, even with a stronger intensity. It is for this reason that more and more human rights experts are calling on the international community to characterize ISIL's campaign against minority groups as a war crime, a crime against humanity and genocide. I support the efforts of the UN Security Council to refer these cases to the International Criminal Court to prosecute and punish not only the perpetrators of these horrific crimes that the world does not remember, but also all those who in many ways supported the activities of various terrorist groups by financing and procuring weapons. . That is why I supported this resolution.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing.- I supported the motion for a resolution on the systematic mass killings of religious minorities by ISIS, as I believe that crimes against humanity and war crimes, wherever and whenever they occur, must not go unpunished and should not be part of our lives.I support the European Union's efforts to ensure the effective prosecution of such crimes, both by taking action at national level and by improving international cooperation.In this way, we will be able to restore a sense of security, peace and trust among the people of Europe.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: written.- We abstain from voting on this Resolution considering that: 1) the call to accept the jurisdiction of the International Criminal Court must also be addressed to the United States, China, India and all States, and not be limited to Syria and Iraq;2) any authorized intervention must be of a civil and humanitarian nature and not a military one;3) The use of the concept of genocide with a spectrum much greater than that granted to it in the framework of the International Criminal Court (apart from the case of the Yazidis) is problematic.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing.- On the night of 6 August 2014, more than 150,000 Christians fled the invasion of the so-called “ISIS / Daesh” into Mosul, Karakos and other villages on the Nineveh.All their property has been hijacked and they have since lived far from their place of residence, in precarious conditions, in northern Iraq.The so-called “ISIS / Daesh” captured all those who could not escape from Mosul and the Nineveh Plateau, and forced non-Muslim women and children into slavery, selling some while brutally murdering others.In the vote on this, I supported the position of the S&D Group.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: in writing.- Strongly condemning the widespread atrocities perpetrated by Da'esh, including the deliberate targeting of religious and ethnic communities in the areas occupied by the group;I call on the EU and the Member States to actively contribute and take practical and political measures, i.e.y.through the UN, to find solutions to these conflicts in order to reduce the suffering and persecution of millions of people of all religions and ethnic groups.

name: Inese VAIDERE
text: in writing. - Physical treatment of religious and ethnic minorities, Arabs and Sunnis, sexual violence against women and girls, trafficking in human beings, forced recruitment of children - these and others are atrocities incomprehensible to the human mind by the so-called "Islamic State" (Daesh). In the resolution, we support the position that, in accordance with the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court (ICC), all these horrific human rights violations are tantamount to crimes against humanity and war crimes, which the UN Security Council should recognize as genocide. Unfortunately, a terrorist group also receives support for its criminal activities from a number of UN member states, which is a violation of international law. We therefore call on these countries, which are directly and indirectly involved in the commission of crimes against humanity, to fulfill their legal obligations under international law and to put an end to this unacceptable behavior, which is causing enormous damage to Iraqi and Syrian society and seriously destabilizing neighboring countries and international peace and security. It is equally important for EU Member States to work actively to combat radicalization in their homes by improving their judicial and jurisdictional systems to prevent EU citizens from joining the Islamic State terrorist group.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because I find deplorable the human rights abuses perpetrated by ISIS/Daesh against Christians, Yazidis, Turkmen, Shi’ites, Shabak, Sabeans, Kaka’e and Sunnis who do not agree with their interpretation of Islam. These violations amount to “war crimes”, “crimes against humanity” and “genocide” according to the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court (ICC). With this resolution we urge the international community to take urgent action to counter the systematic mass murder of religious minorities by ISIS. We also call upon all EU member states to update their legal and jurisdictional systems in order to prevent their nationals and citizens travelling to join ISIS and other terrorist organisations and also ensure that, should they do so, they face criminal court proceedings as soon as possible.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: written.- We cannot look the other way while the Islamic State continues to perpetrate massacres against other individuals who do not process their religion.Christians and other religious and ethnic minorities in areas controlled by the Islamic State are being subjected to an unacceptable massacre.That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favor of a motion for resolution that only condemns an inadmissible fact on the part of the international community.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: written.- I voted for this resolution.I am fully convinced that everyone has the right to their fundamental freedoms and respect for human rights, regardless of religion or ethnicity.It is our duty to support those currently oppressed by the barbarians of IS.Whether in Europe or the Middle East, we are always stronger when we work together to fight such terrorist organizations.More than ever, the European Union must exert diplomatic pressure on the parties involved to find a solution.Ideally, this could happen during the negotiations between the Syrian government and the opposition in Geneva this month.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: in writing. - The resolution put to the vote of the European Parliament strongly condemns the massacres and violence committed by the group "Islamic State" (IS), which led in Syria and Iraq to one of the biggest humanitarian crises ever known, with displacement massive populations. But this resolution does not take into account the responsibilities of the international community in the current crisis in the Middle East and, moreover, supports unconditional military intervention as the only response. This resolution also obscures the responsibilities of the States which allow the financing of this terrorist organization, in particular through the trafficking of oil and cultural goods. On the contrary, at the GUE / NGL, we call for a political, diplomatic and peaceful settlement involving all the stakeholders, in particular the democratic forces, including the Kurds. We also urgently demand the establishment of a humanitarian corridor and demand that the financial and logistical sources that feed ISIS be dried up as quickly as possible. I therefore abstained.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing.- The violence and mass killings perpetrated by the so-called EIL / Daexe deserves our firmest rejection.However, the resolution blatantly conceals the responsibilities of the US and the EU on the path that led to the current situation.Those who were allies yesterday - ISIS - in the destabilization of Iraq and Syria today seem to become enemies.What is needed is solidarity and support for the Syrian and Iraqi peoples, victims of the barbaric action of these groups and the clear rejection that, under the pretext of their fight, interference, aggression and war processes developed by the strategic interests of theUSA with EU support.The end of the escalation of violence, which threatens to drag these peoples into an ever greater disaster, requires respect for their national sovereignty and independence, and not new warmongering adventures as this proposal seems to indicate in point 14.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: written.- The motion for a resolution extensively and unreservedly condemns the acts of IS.Proposals such as the establishment of protection zones are welcome, as is the call to leading Muslims to call the crimes of IS by their names.I am therefore voting in favor of this report.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: written.- Atrocities committed by the “Islamic State” (IS) and unimaginable human rights violations are an indisputable fact.Your condemnation and the endeavor to put an end to IS politically and militarily deserves any support, which is why all motions for resolution that were put to the vote had to be voted “yes”.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the project on the systematic mass murder of religious minorities by ISIS. As is well known, under international law everyone has the right to live according to their conscience and to freedom of religion, to change their religious beliefs. It is obvious that systematic and widespread attacks against the civilian population, violations of human rights and international humanitarian law, in particular those committed on religious or ethnic grounds, constitute a global and undoubtedly threat to the international order. I agree with the opinion that committing acts of murdering religious and ethnic minorities in consequence contributes to mass migration and internal displacement. For this reason, I also support the position of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees regarding the implementation of measures such as the humanitarian admission program, simplified family reunification procedures or more flexible visa regulations. However, for these actions to have a positive effect, it is necessary to develop and implement a cooperation plan of EU units with the participation of widely recognized ethnic and religious minority leaders.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ It is important for the international community to recognise the extent of the horrors committed by Daesh, and much more must be done in order to cut off Daesh’s funding. The EU and UN must take action in order to put pressure on Turkey, Saudi Arabia, and the Gulf states to cut off Daesh’s funds. However, the resolution does not address the plight of the hundreds of thousands of refugees who have escaped Daesh’s brutality. Thousands of vulnerable women, children, and men have made their way to Europe. 10 000 refugee children have disappeared, most likely abducted and trafficked, while moving across Europe. Many thousands more are in makeshift camps, such as those in Calais or Dunkirk, lacking basic services, surviving in inhumane conditions. Member States must do much more to alleviate the suffering of these refugees and take collective action, sharing responsibility instead of shying away from the problem.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: in writing.- By giving our affirmative vote, we join forces in the common struggle against obscurantism, bigotry and the violence perpetrated by terrorists.Christian populations as well as Sunni Muslims are persecuted and killed daily by the IK.The inhabitants of these areas need us, we must act immediately, putting an end to their daily torment.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: in writing.- I fully support this motion for a resolution because I find it completely unacceptable for mass killings of religious minorities to take place.The most vulnerable group in Syria and Iraq are Christians.It is unacceptable for Christians to be targeted and massively liquidated by the Islamic State, including women and children.I fully agree with the call for international organizations and state leaders to label such acts committed by ISIS as 'genocide', 'crimes against humanity' or 'war crimes'.We as politicians must clearly support the survival of these people and ensure their inalienable rights.Only with such support is it possible to end the suffering and mass displacement of Christians.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: in writing. - The criminal activities of the so-called The Islamic State undoubtedly bears the hallmarks of genocide. Even if not all legal definitions have been exhausted in this case, it is difficult to call anything else the systematic acts of violence, kidnappings, murders and executions against Christians in the areas of Syria and Iraq controlled by ISIS. This is a deliberate action by a brutal and ruthless terrorist organization like ISIS, aimed at the physical extermination of religious minorities in the area. This crime against humanity cannot remain silent and ignored by the international community. The complete isolation of ISIS and preventing the authorities of this criminal regime from receiving any support must be our overriding goal. By all possible means - political, economic and military - we must oppose the extermination of Christians who pay the highest price for our passivity and the geopolitical game of the regional powers. It is necessary to coordinate actions in order to prevent ISIS from recruiting new fighters and strictly punish those who have decided to join the ranks of this terrorist organization. We must not only enforce international law, including UN Security Council Resolution 2253 (2015), but also build a coalition ready to take further, real steps to eliminate this "political cancer". Peace in Syria seems extremely distant today, but without it it will not be possible to save the lives of thousands of Christians. I voted in favor of this text.

name: Milan ZVER
text: in writing.- Christian as well as other religious minorities are one of the most vulnerable groups in the war conflicts in Iraqi and Syrian society, systematically attacked by the terrorist organization ISIS / DAESH.Several reports by UN bodies, including the UN Secretary-General’s Special Adviser on Genocide Prevention and the UN Secretary-General’s Special Adviser on Responsibility to Protect and the Office of the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, stated that acts of t.i.Daisha / ISIS could mean war crimes, crimes against humanity and possibly even genocide.Such crimes against the civilian population, wherever and whenever they occur, must not go unpunished.I therefore support the European Parliament's Resolution calling for all necessary measures to be taken in accordance with international human rights law and refugee and humanitarian law to prevent and suppress these terrorist acts.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: This concludes the explanations of vote.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, dear Members of the European Parliament, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for putting on the agenda of this plenary session a debate on the role of public services in improving railway connectivity in the Danube and the Adriatic-Ionian region. . Earlier last week, I had the opportunity to attend the launch of the European Union Strategy for the Alpine Region, which took place in Brdo, Slovenia. This was the launch of the 4th macro-regional strategy and the enthusiastic response of the more than 500 participants certifies, once again, the need and importance of these macro-regional strategies. By getting involved in macro-regional strategies, European regions can work together to meet common challenges, thus contributing to territorial, economic and social cohesion. This cooperation is particularly relevant for improving the connectivity of regions, especially through the development of rail connections. Both the Danube Strategy and the Adriatic-Ionian Strategy have identified rail transport as one of their main priorities. Indeed, there are huge gaps between their regions in terms of public rail transport services, which undermine the common potential for economic development. For example, in what we call "old Member States", such as Italy, Germany and Austria, public services are largely satisfactory, although there is obviously room for improvement. In the new Member States, such as the Czech Republic, Hungary and Romania, the situation is unsatisfactory, but is improving, mainly due to the support provided by European funds. In contrast, in countries outside the European Union, public railway services are really inadequate and in dramatic need of reforms and investment. In this context, the European Commission considers that it is time to take vigorous measures to support public railway services in these regions. Actions should focus on the following: firstly, we certainly need closer and better cooperation between countries. There is no other way to succeed, at the micro-regional and macro-regional level. Secondly, we need the participating countries to work closely together to implement a series of railway reforms, such as the separation of infrastructure and operations, as well as the introduction of licenses and regulations. Third, we need investment in rehabilitation projects, removing bottlenecks and missing links in traffic management and capacity improvement systems. In this regard, I am pleased to say that the indicative value of the TEN-T network for the Western Balkans, which is currently in place, provides a useful framework for these investments. But, distinguished members of the European Parliament, we all know that only through cooperation, reforms and railway investment will we be able to overcome the current challenges. We must also work to improve project preparation, create and strengthen effective governance structures and align and simplify border crossing procedures. In particular, we need all parties involved to agree on a very clear principle: all public service contracts, rail transport, must be awarded on the basis of competitiveness. Public resources face severe constraints and we must therefore ensure that the available resources are used as efficiently as possible. Three years ago, the Commission presented a legislative proposal under the 4th Railway Package and we are confident that we, together with you as co-legislators, will reach an agreement on this proposal. As I mentioned, we have made great strides in elaboration of macro-regional strategies.It is now time to translate these principles into concrete actions and changes that meet the needs and expectations of both the private sector and citizens in these regions.This means, in concrete terms, better, more efficient public railway services.Thank you and I look forward to your contributions.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, macro-regions are a positive initiative, because they can bring coordination and bring cohesion between the various regions of those macro-regions. However, I believe that here we must be careful that the money is not distributed in the future to macro-regions because, then, cohesion policy, which, however, has some problems during this period, may have even bigger problems. I believe that coordination is needed at Commission level, at European level, so that the Member States in that macro-region can agree and direct the money from the Structural Funds towards coherent projects, which will take place in several countries. On the Danube and the Balkans: I think the Commission's initiative to expand the TEN-T network in the Balkans is very good. I believe that further attention needs to be paid, especially with regard to the railways, to the construction of corridors, ie to projects to build those corridors, especially to the Black Sea ports, Constanta and the ports of Greece. Here I think you can intervene, because you can coordinate national transport plans so that some corridors are completed. I would also ask you to follow carefully the completion of the railway package, because it is very important in this regard and also the return of the money I distributed to the EFSI back to the ESC, because there can be done railway projects.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: on behalf of the S & D group. - Mr President, Commissioner Corina Cretu, I am glad to have such an important debate today for the economic development of Romania, but also of Central and Eastern Europe. As you know, Romania and Austria were the first states to submit to the Council and subsequently asked the Commission to prepare a strategy for the Danube region by the end of 2010. The strategy of this macro-region consisting of fourteen Member States of the European Union aims to address the challenges common to these countries, namely the growing need for mobility, energy sources and energy efficiency in the region, water quality and socio-economic development. Unfortunately, the more common the set of challenges, the different and unequal this economic development in the macro-region. Thus, tools are needed to accentuate and increase social, economic, but especially territorial cohesion. This also includes the General Transport Master Plan of Romania, a master plan that is a prerequisite for European funding and a strategic tool in terms of major development objectives of the national transport system, as well as investment needs for projects and infrastructure investments. . This master plan was adopted by political consensus by the Romanian Government and subsequently approved by the European Commission, following negotiations. Railway infrastructure projects are prioritized in line with the objectives of Union transport policy to create a single European transport area. That is why, Commissioner, I am pleased to see that there is coherence between regional development policy and rail transport policy in the Danube macro-region. In the cohesion states, as in the case of Romania, this logic will contribute both to the socio-economic and territorial development, but also to the reduction of the existing gaps, as well as of the discrepancies that are still maintained, unfortunately, between the member states of the region.

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mister President! Thank you, Commissioner, for your explanation. Indeed, we have free mobility for people, goods and services as one of the fundamental freedoms in the EU. And with people, just as with goods, we naturally want to try to travel across Europe by rail. In most cases, however, this is not possible at all or not yet, and that is why we have to concentrate very strongly on this, especially with the macro-regions. Commissioner, you also said that rail links are a priority. And there is actually a lot going on. We cannot always connect all the islands in the same way - that would of course be great for those who are currently in the Adriatic region, but we cannot afford that. We just have to see where we actually have major deficits. And a macro-region also has the task of balancing out differences in its policy and ensuring that everyone has the same access. We have developed such a metro map for corridors across Europe that really connect everyone. And here I am only concentrating on three corridors that are in these regions. There is the Baltic-Adriatic corridor. We have a total of sixteen border crossings, nine of them by rail. Everywhere except Austria, ERTMS is missing, which is very important, and we have many bottlenecks on the railways, especially in Poland and Slovenia. The freight speed is sometimes so low that it is not possible to set up a freight operation there. The investment requirement for the railways alone would be 30 billion euros by 2030 - an enormous amount that we cannot afford! In the Orient and Eastern Mediterranean corridors, for example, the locomotive has to be changed six times if you want to travel from Athens to Hamburg. I know Hamburg is not the Adriatic or the Danube, but we still have to compensate for a lot of differences. And in the Rhine-Danube corridor, for example, we also have a lot of border crossings - eight by rail alone between Germany and the Czech Republic - where electrification and ERTMS are still missing in some cases. The rail network in Romania is in urgent need of modernization and connection. So there is a great deal to be done and it is good that we are trying to make improvements for the people there through the policies of the macro-regions.

name: Michael CRAMER
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner! A few months ago we had the climate conference in Paris. The EU was very committed to the climate goals. We have to do that! Transport is responsible for 25% of all emissions and is the only sector where they have increased since 1990, by 22%; in industry they have fallen by 38%. That is why we have to change mobility in order to achieve the climate goals. Mobility is a matter of general interest and therefore rural areas must also be recognized; they need to be connected. And please don't make Portugal's mistake again! In Portugal we shut down many rail networks ten or fifteen years ago - people should drive cars. Today they have no more money to drive their cars, the rail lines have been shut down, and mobility has been destroyed. We heard about the master plan and that is why we have requested this debate. 30 to 40% of the rail traffic in Romania is to be shut down. The government had decided that, and the Commission also agreed. If you do that, you can never reach the climate goals! Therefore you have to make it very clear: the railways must have priority. 60% of the structural funds go into the streets, only 20% into the railways. You have to change that and not follow the example of shutting down 30 to 40% of the railway lines! And of course the shorter distances also play a major role, because 90% of the passengers on the rail travel on distances of less than 50 kilometers. Don't just think of the big projects, not just TNT, but the connections. A network - that is the crucial thing that we have to enforce. And as far as the European rail network is concerned: this is a patchwork quilt with the gaps exactly where the borders are. So you need to create better incentives for Member States to re-establish the cross-border connections that were destroyed by the war and the post-war era. We can secure mobility and protect the climate, but not by shutting down 30 to 40% of the rail network in Romania. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: Question referred in accordance with the "blue card" procedure. - Mr Cramer, I remember having a discussion and a meeting in the European Parliament's Committee on Transport and Tourism in June. I remind you that, at that meeting, both representatives of the Romanian Government and representatives of the European Commission from DG MOVE and DG REGIO, together with me, made it very clear to you that this is not a cut with 30 -40% of the railway infrastructure in Romania but, on the contrary, it is about an optimization of that network. Even then, you did not answer my question. I told you that Romania has one of the largest railway transport networks in Europe and I also told you that countries like France and Germany have cut much more from the railway network in the last ten years than Romania has cut. My country and I have always been for rail transport and for a single, sustainable and sustainable European transport system, as it is based on infrastructure. But please do not come with misinformation in the European Parliament.

name: Michael CRAMER
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- I asked exactly how it is.I know that there is a great debate going on in Romania now as to whether or not the decision of the previous government will be recognized by parliament.This is also being discussed in the Commission.I also know that many rail lines in France and Germany have been shut down.That's what I fought against, and I don't care about the country.Rail has the future because it is environmentally friendly.And we can only stop climate change by rail.This is necessary so that our children and their children have a perspective of living on this planet.But if you now say "We want to optimize the network" and shut down 30 to 40% of the routes, for me that is not an optimization, but a destruction, and that must be stopped!

name: Nathan GILL
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, in the ever-lucid words of the Bismarcks of the 21st century – the European Union’s bureaucrats – ‘macro-regional policy is a vehicle for involving neighbouring countries, creating territorial synergies and reducing regional disparities’ – basically, globalisation and an ever-closer union. In the words of the Directorate-General for Internal Policies, ‘it is difficult to assess whether a macro-regions strategy has influenced the nature, or extent, of the existing initiatives’. As this is the case, why are we wasting British taxpayers’ money, and our time, doing this?

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I have listened very carefully to your speech, I represent the Czech Republic, which is in the Danube macro-region. I am personally convinced that, in future, future investments from European Union money should not only go to national projects, but also to support cross-border projects and cross-border cooperation. And especially in the area of ​​railway infrastructure, which we are debating here today, I feel that we have a great debt. The Iron Curtain has fallen, but the railway connection, for example between the Czech Republic and Germany, is still insufficient, it does not correspond to how today two neighboring friendly states could have interconnected railway infrastructure. I see the problem in the fact that if we want to invest more in this cross-border cooperation in the future and, for example, strengthen railway infrastructure, much more money will need to be allocated to such projects. Given that today, around EUR 222 million is earmarked for the Danube strategy, this is an amount that will not cover a single major railway infrastructure project. For example, we had an analysis of how much the modernization of the line Prague, Pilsen, Nuremberg, or Munich would cost, and that amount corresponds to the amount of EUR 1.4 billion, ie. more than five times higher than in the whole fund. So I think that in the future we should also address within the budget how much those cross-border projects should be more symbolic. It is supposed to be a place of transport and railways, for example, strengthening cycle paths, which are also in this project, I also welcome them, cycling is certainly important, but it probably does not, we all feel as important and strategic as the issue of railway infrastructure. So, the project is great, but more money needs to be released into this area.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: - Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank the Commissioner for presenting macro-regional cooperation, which is precisely designed to reduce the inequalities that occur across borders and between regions, which is one of the fundamental elements. Today we are dedicated to the specific sector of railways and public services. As the CEF rapporteur for the Connecting Europe Facility, I must admit that it was a miracle of solidarity between the East and the West to achieve that there were 10 billion euros for the CEF from the Cohesion Fund for a very complex ambition, and therefore Therefore, I am especially grateful for it. But here, in the CEF itself, there were two networks: the basic one, which was the nine multimodal corridors - that is, with everything, not just rail: road, inland waterway and whatever - and the global one. The global was the national plans. And so we put it. And I remember that, at that time, Romania had not presented its national plan - the previous Government - and the new Government - the Government of Mr. Ponta - had to present it in the last moments. And it was complex. Still, it was achieved. Therefore, I do not quite understand the concern or interest of some, when we know that there are absorption problems, that infrastructure is lacking and that high speed, that is, a railway, is not supported. But not even the European Parliament is helping to make it a railway of special interest to tourists. Furthermore, there are environmental conditions in Germany and Austria that prevent or hinder the Danube from being navigable. Faced with so many complex situations, I understand that the macro-region that Mrs. Crețu told us about is an extraordinary region for tourism. And therefore we have to accept that a part of the national plan has roads, and we also have to recognize that our fourth rail package, with public services, is not helping much to make the rail run better either. (She agreed to answer a question asked under the "blue card" procedure (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: David COBURN
text: blue-card question. – I would just like to say that in Britain we made tremendous mistakes back in the 1950s closing our railways – many of them small railways – because we thought cars were the future. I agree with you that trains are the future, but there is also an enormous problem in the UK: we want to spend an awful lot of money on HS2, which is a bullet train or whatever that goes from London up to Scotland. It is a good idea in many ways, but what we would rather have is a better railway system, rather than spending an absolute fortune on a railway system which does not help the average commuter. Also, the fares on this proposed line will probably be astronomical, and the only people who will be able to afford to travel on it will be superannuated businessmen and Members of this honourable House. Nobody else will be able to afford to go on it. I would much rather see money spent on regional railways than on taking business from one place to another and leaving everything in the middle ignored. Do you agree with me on that, Madam?

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: "blue card" response. - Well, look, as a Spaniard and with the success that the AVE has had in Spain - as a tourist country, but also for business - between Seville, Malaga, Madrid, Barcelona, ​​Toledo - because it also passes through Toledo -, etc., alone I can tell you that the Spanish experience has been the opposite, although it is true that it is a country with a demographic density very different from yours and with an orography that is also very different from yours. The Spanish experience has been enormously positive. We have even managed to take business away from the plane, from the Madrid-Barcelona air bridge. I understand their position, but I believe that the United Kingdom has the space and management capacity to have both: a train that leads directly to Scotland, which I think is good and, of course, not lose its surroundings. Surroundings; Another thing is the regional ones, some of them are not profitable enough, because people also take the car. I am very sorry, but it is so; I wish they didn't catch it so much.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Mr. President, I want to highlight three points or three problems. First, creating transport intermodality in this macro-region will require enormous resources. However, there is no alternative to connecting rail transport with that which comes by sea and that which comes by air. Another problem I see is the extreme slowness of the railways, both in Italy, on the Ancona-Bari route and all those routes in Croatia from Rijeka via Zagreb to Budapest, Zadar, Split to Zagreb or Ploce to Sarajevo or Bari, to Belgrade. Also, I want to point out a local problem that means nothing globally, but means a lot for Istria, where the Istrian branch of Croatian railways has a connection only with Slovenia and there should be resolved or build a railway tunnel through Učka or make an agreement with Slovenian railways. In the end, the introduction of the TNT network in the Balkans is something that is great and I congratulate you on that. You have support for such moves. (The speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the blue card (Rule 162 (8)))

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Question asked by raising a blue card.- Dear colleague Jakovčić, you mentioned the connection between Istria, that is, Croatia, and the Slovenian Railways.And, as we know, from 1902 to 1935 she was the so-called Poreč woman, Parenzana, who was extremely important.Do you think that there are still chances that we will actually revive this route and thus help both Slovenian and Croatian tourism?

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: the answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. - Thank you very much for this question. Of course, the Istrian branch of the Croatian railways, which is directly connected only with the Slovenian, can be resolved by building a railway tunnel through Učka. However, it is of course a long-term and very expensive solution. A quality solution would be a good agreement between Croatian and Slovenian railways. Personally, I have said on several occasions, I see no reason why, as during Yugoslavia, when Istria was also between Croatia and Slovenia, meaning in Croatia, or part of Slovenia, why it could be managed then. Slovenian railways operated at that time, I don't see any reason why an agreement should not be reached and that Slovenian railways would eventually manage until further notice, because today, if we do not agree on that, the entire railway branch will definitely fail. (The speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the blue card (Rule 162 (8)))

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.-  Colleague!You just mentioned that it is important to also connect the ports and the airports.Does that mean that there is a partial lack of railways there and that one should concentrate on it, or does that mean that above all else one has to build railways that are fast enough so that, for example, there is less flow?Colleague Cramer would like that if something like that were the answer.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: the answer to the question posed by raising the blue card.- Dear Sirs, if we want to strongly increase the intermodality of transport, then we must first of all solve the slowness of the railways.Because we have an arrival, for example by sea, to many northern Adriatic areas, especially in Croatian ports or in Bar in Montenegro.However, to take a man or some product from Bari to Belgrade or from Rijeka to Zagreb, so it's like Ćiro, a railway once in the former Yugoslavia.Well, that never arrives again.So we really need to do something to increase the speed of the railways at this point.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: - Mr. President, Distinguished Commissioner, Distinguished Colleagues, I am glad that you continue to support the macro-regional approach, especially today that we are talking about the Danube and Adriatic-Ionian macro-region and it is not just about connecting within the region, but also connecting the two macroregion. Because, specifically, for example, there are significant ports in the Adriatic Sea, significant capacities that could improve the transport of goods from the southern part of Europe to Central and Eastern Europe in contributing to the reduction of CO2 emissions. However, this network does not really exist on the map of the European Union. There are no such freight corridors for trains. So, what I am appealing to is that real and meaning new corridors for freight transport of trains are being drawn in these two macro-regions. Since from the current investments planned for 2014-2020 we do not really see where exactly this could be financed, to use funds from the Connecting Europe fund to build these freight corridors. Also, to reallocate funds that will enable the support of transport and environmental policy of the European Union in the period 2014-2020. because otherwise we will not reach the goals of 2030, neither in transport policy, nor in climate policy. What I would also emphasize as important is that, especially in countries that use cohesion funds, the absorption of the use of these cohesion funds for the development of railway infrastructure needs to be improved. Not only for the development of railway infrastructure, but also for the maintenance of especially cross-border infrastructure when it comes to regional connections, because it is very important that everything comes to life together. In Croatia, we currently have a good example of how such a development is currently being called into question due to public procurement.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we must ensure that these strategies produce concrete results. There is only one way to do this: to meet the needs of citizens. If we look at the current structure of the TEN-T networks, at the level of transport infrastructure the Adriatic-Ionian macro-region currently presents a hole that concretely translates into a lack of connectivity. I invite the Commissioner to travel along the Adriatic ridge by train to see with her eyes whether or not it is necessary to ensure that this connectivity deficit is closed as soon as possible. As will be recalled, on 28 October the Parliament made a clear statement, with the Jakovčić report on EUSAIR, on this need, asking to extend the TEN-T network to the entire Adriatic ridge, starting from Ancona, passing through Pescara, up to Bari and Brindisi. The Commission prefers to invest resources on the costly and controversial Turin-Lyon line and completely neglects the areas of Southern Europe, which are almost devoid of railway infrastructures and which instead would need more investments precisely to bridge the gap that exists the rest of Europe. Then show that there is really a real interest on the part of the European institutions for all regions, even those of the South. Show also that on your part there is the conviction that the regions of the South must not fail this important appointment with the future. Parliament has spoken and will monitor until the strategy meets its objectives. We therefore ask the Commission to play its part to the full.

name: Andor DELI
text: - Commissioner, Mr President! The Danube and Adriatic macro-regions are important mechanisms for gathering synergies in these regions. This is particularly important in the field of transport and, in particular, rail transport. In the area of ​​these macro-regions, extremely important TEN-T routes pass through, but the existing transport networks are fragmented and mostly concentrated in the territory of one country or region. It would be necessary to expand cross-border rail lines, better coordinate timetables and modernize equipment. The system of macro-regions can be an excellent help in this. However, it is also important to note that these macro-regions also include countries that are not yet full members of the EU. Thanks to the Vienna talks last summer, the TEN-T network has been extended beyond the EU to include candidate countries. In this way, a map of Europe covering the whole continent has finally been drawn. This could also improve the competitiveness of the Danube and Adriatic macro-regions and reduce their isolation from other parts of Europe. However, in order for the positive transport logistics and economic effects to be realized uniformly along the entire length of the transport corridors and for the so-called corridor effect to emerge, the financing mechanisms provided by the EU need to be reconsidered. Due to the different legal and financial status of the candidate countries, the synergistic effect of macro-regions cannot be fully realized and bottlenecks remain with all goodwill. I would therefore encourage the Commission to create the appropriate legal and financial framework for better involvement of the candidate countries in the review of the TEN-T corridors. We in the European People's Party want to help the Commission come up with solutions that are realistic, in line with the possibilities, while allowing for further improvements.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, Romania is a solid partner in the development of the European rail network and regulations, with its extensive railway network, its increased demand for mobility and its important potential, given its strategic role in the whole EU transport policy, mainly in south-eastern Europe. Without any doubt, the rail sector in Romania faces a number of challenges and requires prompt and thorough reform. I believe that Romania’s General Transport Master Plan makes a significant effort in the sense of allocating up to EUR 14 billion for the next year to rail infrastructure investments, mostly to the rehabilitation and upgrading of around 4 000 km of railway lines. The reduction of approximately 30% of the network that is stipulated in the Plan has been identified ever since 1990 by the EBRD and the World Bank, and now it represents only 2% of freight traffic and 8% of passenger traffic. Maintaining the whole existing rail network to EU standards would indeed be unaffordable, and the reduction will optimise efficiency and decrease operational costs. Also, this network has to be preserved because the future is railway transportation – and everybody mentioned this. We need to keep in mind that in the current situation of the Romanian rail network the efforts to maintain and upgrade it will absorb all necessary funds, despite the fact that Romania increased public funding for transport infrastructure for 2014-2020 to a yearly average of 2% from the previous 1.15%. Let me point out as well that Romania will not give up the rail infrastructure upgraded or rebuilt with EU cofinancing, emphasising once again the fact, that compared to the European average, the same number of passengers could, theoretically speaking, be transported by using a 20-30% smaller network. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Michael CRAMER
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- My question is, of course, whether the road network in Romania is in such excellent condition that the idea of closing a road would not occur.I am not aware that a street in Europe has ever been closed because there is not enough money for maintenance.So my specific question is: does this master plan contain 10 or 15% of the roads that will be closed, or are the roads taboo and only save on rail?

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card answer. – We have to respond to our dear colleague Mr Cramer: we are really waiting for European Union incentives to Member States like Romania to use the railway network more instead of the roads.

name: Jozo RADOŠ
