text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I welcome the inclusion of this item on the agenda because the railway is a very important, cheaper and better form of transport for the environment, and it has not been developed in Europe or in the whole European Union, and especially not in this area.to which we speak.Namely, there is almost no connection of the river network with the railway network.None of the airports in the Western Balkans has a railway station, and plans to build new traffic routes are more oriented towards road traffic than railway traffic at the moment.That is why I am glad that Commissioner Crețu mentioned the extension of the European TEN-T network to the Western Balkans.I expect that the consequence will be not only the connection of the Western Balkans with other parts of Europe, but also the strengthening of the quality of the railway network and the greater use of rail and river transport in total traffic in that part of Europe and throughout Europe.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - It's worth repeating what we're talking about. The Danube region practically covers 1/5 of the territory of the European Union today and in fact 1/5 of the population of the European Union lives in this area. Although this part used to be part of another great integration, not least when the railways developed at all in Europe, and 100-150 years ago, the railways themselves meant two concepts to the peoples living here: sustainability and modernity. . It's no different today. How history has fragmented this region, where it has scattered the integrated economy of its time, is obviously a matter for historians, but if we want to rebuild Europe, we need to pay special attention to it. I note here that, of course, out of the 14 countries in the region, only 9 are members of the European Union, and there are also two countries involved in the European Partnership, Ukraine and Moldova. My fellow Members will be surprised, but there are still sections of European gauge in Ukraine to this day, which, of course, are not widely used today, as there is wide gauge fashion, but it can be rebuilt. It can be rebuilt just like the whole region. As for the substance of the projects, I think it would be very, very important, even exemplary, to create intermodality, and in addition, even the environmental aspects, I think, deserve special attention, they need to be electrified.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, transportation is one of the key areas in both the European and Adriatic macro-regional strategies. For example, the recent Danube Transnational Programme, with a budget of EUR 222 million, should not only contribute to more effective water-management and flood-risk prevention policies, innovation or cross-border institutional capacity but also the creation of a modern regional railway system accessible to both numerous urban and rural dwellers, as well as flight transport.  The same applies to the Adriatic macro-region. With its growing seaports and traffic, investment is necessary to maximise the region’s economic potential. The European Structural and Investment Funds are just one of the possible sources. Moreover, in parallel to upgrading cross-border transportation capacity, not only telecommunications, postal services, law enforcement and other public services would improve, but there would also be benefits for people-to-people contact, which, aside from the pure economy, is the most important goal of all.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: - Mr Chairman!Today we are talking about the macro-regional strategy and the European TEN-T network of the Danube-Adriatic macroregion.I fully support the appeals of my colleagues to develop this railway infrastructure in this region as soon as possible.However, at the end of the debate, I would like to ask the Commissioner what priority the Commission will give to river transport within the European TEN-T network, in particular the Danube-Oder Elbe river route.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this is an extremely important topic, not for a conference, but for a debate from which to draw some conclusions. From my point of view, it is a pity that we put it on Thursday at such an hour. The transport development strategy, the European strategy, the Danube and Adriatic strategy that we are discussing today are extremely important and, Commissioner, you have made it very clear that we have countries, including the Czech Republic, Hungary, Romania, where transport quality is questionable. . You simply called it unsatisfactory. I agree. But, between the three points, which you presented that would be important for improving intermodality, you put the investments. My question is: can you convince Mr Juncker that we should also provide money from the Strategic Investment Fund for areas that have this deficiency, this backwardness in the quality of infrastructure? Because I don't believe in a single market, I don't believe in development. Transportation also means cost and pollution, cost for business people. Of course, I agree with Mr Cramer, because road transport not only pollutes, but we also have road accidents and loss of life. So, I think it is necessary to take the money to the areas that have this backwardness, for the development of railway infrastructure.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: - Mr President! If, instead of traveling here to Strasbourg to say this to the Commissioner, I traveled by train from my hometown of Sarajevo to the Commissioner's hometown, this journey of about 800 km would take 45 hours. I am infinitely grateful that the Commissioner has come here, it is much easier for both of us, even though the distance is almost 4 times as great. This is, of course, unacceptable; Lack of train and road connections has created enormous communication problems in the region. This shortage has hindered economic development, damaged jobs, reduced the movement of goods, services and people, damaged tourism, created problems with energy supply and exacerbated climate problems. That is why it is gratifying to welcome the Commission's efforts. Finally, you could say! Let us just hope that the efforts are made quickly and that the money eventually increases, that enlargement to the Balkans becomes more extensive and that follow-up takes place often enough, so that travel in the region no longer feels like an absurdity.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, dear Members of the European Parliament, thank you very much for your contribution. This lively debate once again reflects the importance and need for quality rail connections for the strategies of the Danube and the Adriatic-Ionian basin, as well as for the internal market. I would like to make a few clarifications. First of all, in relation to macro-regions, you know very well that they started on the condition that there are no new institutions, new legislation and additional money. So, in practice, these regions are putting all their resources together to meet common challenges that do not stop at state borders. The Commission has a coordinating role, but the programs and projects must come from the regions and Member States involved. Neither we, from Brussels, nor you, from here, from Strasbourg, can develop projects. Joint projects are very important. I am a strong supporter of these macro-regions, because, first of all, as you have pointed out, I am bringing together Member States of the European Union with states that are not members of the European Union and, for the time being, these are the only tools it brings together member countries and non-member countries of the European Union and responds to common challenges. For example, the Danube Strategy covers fourteen countries: nine Member States and five non-member states. As I said, the Commission does consider that the railway infrastructure in this region is inefficient and, in many cases, even lacking. I share your opinion. I was in Sarajevo. I have to go back to Vienna or Brussels so I can go to Sarajevo from Bucharest, but I still hope to come to Romania. Indeed, infrastructure is lacking, especially in terms of cross-border connectivity. Unfortunately, the national authorities do not always give priority to this and the action plan for the Danube region calls on the Member States - I also use this opportunity to renew this call - to strengthen transport infrastructure and extend public transport lines at the border. I think this is very important, especially in rural areas, given that the population in this region, in rural areas, is much higher than in other parts of the European Union. Regarding the question on river transport, which also refers to the Danube strategy: we discussed this topic at length in Ulm, where the annual conference on the Danube strategy took place. I think it is very important to emphasize that connectivity, in general, and the railway, as well as river transport are main priorities in the Danube strategy, but also in the Adriatic-Ionian. For example, I personally had a mediation role, to put together the transport ministers of Romania and Bulgaria. The worst navigability problems are in this area, due to the low level of the Danube at some times of the year and we tried to mediate, to bring the two ministers together, because it is enough that one meter does not it can sail between Romania and Bulgaria, and then the whole chain, from Germany to the Black Sea (practically all activities), is blocked. So, from this point of view, I hope that the two countries will take an important step to solve this airworthiness problem. As for the Adriatic-Ionian region, it covers eight states: four Member States and four non-member states of the European Union. I will be happy to launch this strategy in Dubrovnik in May. The railway services in this region are, of course, in a better condition than those in the Danube region. They can improve and become more competitive. There are rehabilitation projects within the Adriatic-Ionian macro-region, and the necessary efforts and investments it really needs to approach normal TEN-T standards. We must also take into account the fact that, unfortunately, statistics show that passenger traffic is declining, especially in terms of navigability on rivers. I would like to point out two more things. There are two key issues: on the one hand, we need everyone to be prepared to actively cooperate, as I said, across borders, establishing close links with neighboring countries and regions. On the other hand, we need strong political will to carry out the necessary reforms and thus facilitate the critical mass of investment that will allow public railway services to meet the needs of the population. Therefore, from our point of view, we now have all the tools in place and, of course, I would like to take this opportunity to encourage all stakeholders to use them optimally, to enhance the role of public railway services in these regions. The Commission wants to work with the European Parliament to make progress on these issues for the benefit of citizens, the business community and, implicitly, the European Union as a whole. I'm sorry the lady left. I was disturbed by this reference to the European Commission's indifference to southern Europe. I, personally, have been to Italy twice. We unlocked operational programs that were blocked, especially in Campania, Sicily, Calabria. When I took over as European Commissioner, all the analyzes showed that these operational programs could not be unblocked, and I succeeded. In Naples, together with Minister Delrio, we launched the new Bari-Naples railway line and we hope that, during our term, we will be able to inaugurate it. I was very happy that in this way Italy can be linked not only from north to south, but also horizontally, and I think that is a very important thing. I would not like to enter into this controversy related to Romania. I just want to say that the Commission does not choose the priorities and railway lines introduced in the national strategies, because the transport master plans represent the national strategies. Whether it is Romania or Italy, the European Commission provides support through our services, through ongoing consultations throughout the stages of developing master plans, but at the same time, of course, there is the right of governments to determine what these priorities are. My hope is that, during their implementation, national governments will have the necessary flexibility to meet the needs of their citizens, as needed.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The debate was closed.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: in writing. - The Adriatic-Danube macro-region has significant European transit routes, so the development of environmentally friendly transport routes is a priority, but care must be taken to ensure that this objective does not overshadow the priority aspects of nature conservation. The Danube, which also determines the hydrography of the region and - as a green corridor and wetland - its ecological conditions, is traditionally the most important waterway in the region. At the same time, the development of shipping poses a serious threat, as it threatens to eradicate the most valuable ecosystems: the elimination of bottlenecks, dams, dredging, navigational structures and the construction of defenses, according to the European Court of Auditors. lurking in habitats. In addition, as the implementation of the Danube Strategy and the development of the transport corridor are typically supported by the EU, there is a strong chance that the destruction of irreplaceable natural resources will inadvertently be financed by the EU itself. Experience to date has shown that the Natura 2000 network of sites, the Birds and Habitats Directives have proved to be an effective tool for conserving biodiversity to protect habitats. I consider it extremely important to harmonize European objectives, in this case to prevent development from taking place through the erosion of habitats. In the development of environmentally friendly shipping, ships must be adapted to the river and not the other way around: the Danube must remain as living water, it cannot become a canal.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written. - Macro-regional strategies for the Danube and Adriatic-Ionian regions can be considered as an instrument for European integration and stronger territorial cohesion based on voluntary cooperation between Member States and neighboring countries. New corridors are key to enable better connectivity and development of all regions. Each region should have an individual approach to railway infrastructure and its modernization, in accordance with its capabilities and EU support. Croatia is a unique case of a country located in the area of ​​two key macro-regions. So far, the Croatian government has not used these benefits intensively enough and has not invested in dilapidated infrastructure. Policy coordination, alignment of objectives and better use of EU funds will make it possible to reduce disparities between network infrastructure. Rail transport is the most cost-effective means of transporting people and goods, reducing costs for citizens in everyday transport and reducing CO2 emissions into the environment. Improving rail transport reduces socio-economic disparities between Member States. In addition to optimizing the capacity of existing infrastructure and creating new corridors, it is necessary to exchange good practices and strengthen cooperation with other macro-regions.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement: Introduction of compatible systems for the registration of pet animals across Member States (2016/2540(RSP))

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, let me begin by thanking Ms Sommer for raising the issue of the possible introduction, via a delegated act adopted by the Commission in the context of the proposal for a regulation on transmissible animal diseases, of compatible systems for the registration of dogs and cats to be accessible across the Member States. I wish to remind honourable Members that the proposed regulation on transmissible animal diseases, which should be formally adopted by the co—legislators in the coming weeks, provided a legal basis to establish detailed requirements for the identification and registration of animals of different species, including those for which specific requirements have not yet been established, such as dogs and cats. I must emphasise, however, that the need to establish specific requirements for the identification and registration of animals for which no such requirements currently exist must be considered on the basis of a prior risk assessment and impact assessment. In addition, I must stress that the impact assessment should, amongst other things, evaluate which measures are proportionate to address the identified animal health risk, determine the EU added value and estimate the expected financial and administrative impact in relation to the health risk. I hope that this clarification will allay any concerns raised by honourable Members, and that my colleague Commissioner Andriukaitis, who conveys his apologies for not being here, will be able to give you some more information.

name: Renate SOMMER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President! Commissioner, dear colleagues! 126 million dogs and cats are kept as pets in the European Union. You can choose from an infinite number of dogs and cats on the Internet, and pedigree puppies are offered at bargain prices at markets. These animals are illegally produced under unspeakable conditions. The parent animals are exposed to a true martyrdom - a ruthless, cruel exploitation of helpless creatures. Behind this is a mafia of illegal traders - we are dealing with organized crime! The illegal trade in dogs and cats is the third largest source of income after the organized drug and arms trade. The puppies are weaned far too early and are not vaccinated. Chip numbers and pet ID cards are forged. Many puppies are seriously ill, they suffer, and very many die after a short time. That is excruciating - also for the owner, by the way. Often they are communicable diseases. These puppies therefore represent a major threat to the health of other animals, but also to human health. The CALISTO study financed by the Commission also comes to this conclusion. Pets are carriers of more than 100 zoonoses and 70% of all new diseases in humans are due to animal diseases. In short, the problem of the illegal trade in dogs and cats goes well beyond the issue of animal welfare. It concerns public health, consumer protection and the fight against organized crime. Our legislation is not working properly. Not even after the revision of the pet travel scheme in 2013. It is far too easy to give animals a false identity. We asked the Commission to conduct a study on the welfare of commercially traded cats and dogs. Health risks should also be recorded. The possible establishment of EU-wide compatible systems for the registration of pets was discussed. Although the study has not yet been published - for whatever reason - the Commission presented the first results at a conference three months ago. In doing so, she confirmed that greater harmonization of the identification and registration systems of pets is necessary. Commissioner, I think it would be nice if you would listen! Because we urgently need these systems across the entire EU - time is of the essence. Some Member States already have such systems; harmonization is feasible and we have had something like that in other areas too - a technical question. There would finally be clarity about the actual age and vaccination status of animals, and the Commission can regulate this under the regulation on communicable animal diseases. It can present a delegated act that regulates this EU-wide identification and registration of dogs and cats. And it would also give the Member States, the regions and the cities the opportunity to hold irresponsible livestock owners accountable for simply throwing their animals on the street when they are tired of them. Because these animals suffer on the street or they cause unbelievable costs in animal shelters, and that can also be avoided. And this seems like the only way to stop the puppy mafia. I am always very much in favor of impact assessments, Commissioner, but I think that in this case the impact assessment is actually already done.

name: David MARTIN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, this is an issue which has prompted literally thousands of emails from the ‘Protect our Pets’ campaign. Our constituents are concerned about the growing illegal pet trade in Europe and they want us to take action. Thousands of animals – as the previous speaker has just said – have been traded illegally for profit each year, in spite of the existing European Pet Travel Scheme. This is costing millions of euros and the welfare of thousands of animals. They are bred purely to make money; they are born in inhumane circumstances on an industrial scale; they are poorly cared for and exposed to disease; there is no record of where they were born, or when they were born; no record of where they travelled through, or whether they have had the appropriate vaccinations. Any documents used are frequently falsified under the current pet scheme. Owners are unwittingly funding a disgusting industry, unaware of the level of care their pet may need. The Commission’s own investigation into dogs and cats concludes that lack of harmonisation in identification and registration systems across the Member States is a key area for attention, in order to end this illegal trade. To close the loopholes in the existing pet scheme, we need to ensure that pets have a person responsible for them at all times, whether that person be the owner, the breeder, or the shelter. This will enable us to keep track of origin, age, vaccinations and the animal’s welfare. The responsible person should then register these details with a competent overseer in the Member State. Should the pet then live in a different Member State, the competent authority there should be able to access its previous details. Today I would like to ask the Commission to bring forward regulations that will harmonise the national identification and registration systems and requirements for pets across the European Union.

name: Janusz WOJCIECHOWSKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Madam President! Mahatma Gandhi said that civilization's development and moral progress can be judged by the way it treats its animals. Today's debate shows that the protection of animals is at the heart of our European civilization, especially animals that are closest to humans, domesticated, and whose survival depends on humans. Dogs and cats have a special place in our European civilization and culture as animals whose relationship with humans results mainly not from their economic utility, but from their special attachment to humans and their special friendship with humans. Many of these animals live in our homes, but many are experiencing the drama of abandonment. We have the problem of homelessness of animals in Europe, especially dogs, which, unfortunately, often experience cruel treatment. Animals suffer, but so do people who witness this suffering mentally. Recently - I have to mention this also because of the presence of the Commissioner from Romania - we have a problem with the dramatic situation in Romania. Citizens of this country, people of good will, moved by the fate of animals, turn to me. In this country there is a problem of very brutal treatment of homeless dogs, which is the subject of many complaints from people who perceive this brutality not only as contrary to the principles of animal protection, but also contrary to the protection of human rights. I hope and appeal to the Romanian authorities - especially as chairman of the Animal Protection Intergroup of over 100 Members in the European Parliament - to urgently put an end to this brutality that does not conform to civilized European principles. The image of a beautiful country and brave Romanian nation loses much of it. Improving the fate of homeless animals is an important challenge for us, not only for animal welfare, but also for the well-being of people, because a sensitive person cannot feel happy when he sees the suffering of animals around him. Registration and identification is a way to increase the responsibility of owners and prevent abandonment of animals, it is a way to control the fate of these animals. There are many identification systems in the Member States, but they are not enough, so we should start thinking about an EU identification system. Ladies and gentlemen! Animal protection is a European value under Article 13 of the Treaty and we should keep this in mind. And when it comes to companion animals, such as dogs and cats, their protection should be a European task, with the possibility of using funds from the European Union budget for this purpose. Such funds should be envisaged, especially for humanitarian reduction of the population of homeless animals, for sterilization, adoption, shelter management, and for the identification system. We should think about this when working on the future budget of the Union.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: for the ALDE Group. - Madam President! I agree with what has been pointed out: that illegal trade in pets is a serious public health risk. It is not just about the spread of diseases such as rabies but also about antibiotic resistance. I also agree with those who say that illegal trade is a significant source of income for the mafia in Europe. That's also true, it's true. It is obvious that many Member States today have shortcomings in the control of their pets. Stricter rules for a database registration would reduce this problem, but all this must be done at Member State level. A European database would have no added value at all, it would cost more than it creates and it is very unclear who will create it? Who will update it? And how should it be done at all? Excuse me for saying that, but we are not even capable of registering all the refugees entering Europe. And now some want us to try to register all the cats and dogs that exist in Europe. It is impossible to do, simply impossible. It is this type of task that the EU should absolutely not do. The new EU Animal Health Act, for which I have taken over responsibility, will soon be finally adopted by the European Parliament. It allows the Commission to require countries to establish national databases for dogs and cats. So what you demand already exists. The new law also means more measures and registration requirements to get rid of the illegal trade that we have heard about and that was talked about here; the problem of stray dogs. Tools to solve the problem will soon be in place, as long as we have the strength to endure it for a while until it becomes effective. (The speaker agreed to answer 3 questions ("blue card") pursuant to Rule 162 (8).)

name: Renate SOMMER
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.-  Colleague!I do not understand why you think that 28 national systems in the European Union should be much cheaper than a single EU-wide system.Nor is it clear to me how you are going to ensure that an animal's origin, vaccination status and age can be traced when we have a separate system in each Member State.Because the mafia is about animals being moved across borders in the European Union.That's the problem!And that's why we need a uniform history across Europe.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: answer ("blue card").- Thank you very much for the question.The problem with this issue is that it is true that there are health measures that need to be taken, but they will not be implemented at European level.There will be no European Commission that will carry out those measures that you are talking about.They will be carried out on a national basis, and therefore we need national registers.I do not understand how a European database would improve the ability to carry out the necessary measures at national level.

name: Róża THUN UND HOHENSTEIN
text: question asked by picking up a blue card.- Mr.I am very surprised that in the 21st century, at the time of digitization, when we are constantly fighting for digital Europe and progress in this matter, you say that registering pets in one system is something beyond our capabilities.A little more faith - it is neither that complicated nor that difficult, and I fully agree with our colleague Mrs.an element that nobody mentioned, sentimental as well, because these animals are dying.And just the last element, why do you mix this organizational problem with the colossal, dramatic and political topic of refugees.Please, please don't do this.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: answer ("blue card").- Thank you very much for the question.All measures that need to be taken on this issue must be taken nationally.There is nothing that the EU will do other than what you want, namely to create a register.And that registry will be impossible to create because, excuse me for saying that, cats have a free sex life.How should you hunt parents?There is no way to get there.Simply because the measures that need to be taken, they need to be done at the national level.The health measures we need to introduce, those measures ... There must also be a registration opportunity to prevent the problems you are talking about, and all this must be done nationally.To turn it into a task for the EU to do is simply to create a bureaucracy that is not needed in this case.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: a question asked by raising a blue card.- Mr colleague, I understand your thinking about the national level, but that will not solve, as has already been said, cross-border trade.So wouldn't it be a solution for those national registries to be compatible and to work together?We have business registers in each country, we have other public registries that are interconnected across 28 countries, and those systems work together.That would not be so expensive if each national register was transit from a different country, etc. We do not have to have one central European register.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: answer ("blue card").- I agree that we do not need a central European register.That is exactly what I was trying to point out, and the measures you are calling for will be in the EU's new animal health law, which will be in place soon.That's exactly what we're talking about: registration is there.That law provides for the possibility of requiring countries to establish national databases for dogs and cats in order to prevent the illegal trade we are talking about.It will exist at the national level, and I do not understand why we should extend it to a level where it cannot be maintained.

name: Gabriele ZIMMER
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President! I would also like to turn to my colleague who just spoke again. I ask myself why the sex life of cats is difficult to register in Europe, but better nationally. I don't really understand that either. Overall, we need the national registers, which must be compatible, which must be networked with one another. That is the reason why we are also having the discussion today and what we would actually like to bring together. I would like to thank everyone who also put this topic on the agenda. I admit that just a few years ago, before the last European elections, I completely underestimated the dimensions of the pet trade here in Europe. In the course of the discussion that there has been that many people have expressed themselves moved about what happened to the street dogs in Romania and also to the street dog trade, especially from Romania, I already realized that we are here have to do more. At the time, I also committed myself to supporting every initiative that resulted in our joint European commitment to this. What I understand is that the national rules for pets are also very different in the Member States. Some are very strictly organized, others less so and in other Member States they are absent. So on the one hand it is necessary to make a recommendation to the member states to set up the databases according to common criteria and then of course to enable this networking. I fully agree, if we emphasize that this can also be an effective contribution to counteracting the health risks caused by stray animals, sick animals, and animals that have not been socialized. And I also agree with everyone who points out that there is also a particular risk that dogs or cats, their history, their socialization, their illnesses are not actually known to come into families and these families are then overwhelmed after a short time and then there is a risk that the animals will be abandoned or simply left to the animal shelter. I think we have a shared responsibility here. I heard the number that an estimated 700,000 puppies are being trafficked illegally. Many of us know people from our neighborhood, from our circle of acquaintances, who have bought dogs from which we do not know how they actually got them or where they came from, and who then have to see what happens next. In principle, 150,000 animals are said to have died as a result of this illegal trade. You said earlier, Mrs Crețu: we need to do an impact assessment. For me, however, the first question that we have to ask ourselves is: if there is the study that Mrs Sommer spoke of, which has not yet been published, but which the Commission has already reported on, and if there are specific statements there, what It means that if we do not carry out this registration, then that is a large part of what would actually have to be done in the context of an impact assessment. So I ask you: Take our wish from Parliament that we can find a European solution here together, that we do something here for animal welfare, but also to ensure that these mafia methods can finally be stopped.

name: Keith TAYLOR
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I have two questions for the Commissioner to consider. In October last year the UK RSPCA brought a successful legal action against a criminal gang which was smuggling puppies into Great Britain. The gang was making over GBP 35 000 a week selling sick and dying dogs while pretending to be bona fide traders. Whilst the gang was successfully prosecuted, this clearly is not an isolated case. Does the Commissioner agree that this highlights the degree to which this trade is criminal and represents cross-border organised crime, tax evasion and fraud?  Secondly, correctly identifying the age of a puppy or a kitten as meeting the legal requirement of 15 weeks is almost impossible at present. Unless there is a mandatory registration within the first few weeks of birth, does the Commissioner agree there will be continuing difficulty in establishing animals’ exact ages? Both of these examples, I believe, underline the clear need for the introduction of a harmonised national system for the identification and registration of pets in each Member State, so please support the resolution when we get a chance to vote on it at the second plenary in February.

name: Julia REID
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, I accept that many domestic animals need registration, especially when moving long distances, and that it makes sense for data systems to be compatible if they are to be tracked through international borders. However, I do not accept – and will never accept – that this justifies centralisation or a vast new bureaucracy. English is a wonderful language of vivid metaphor, and two phrases come to mind which perfectly describe what the EU does all the time. Firstly, using a sledgehammer to crack a nut. So often, massively over—engineered, highly technical solutions are produced to solve real problems, but ones which do not require monstrous bureaucratic apparatus backed by draconian laws and sentences, which are then enforced selectively – or perhaps not at all – in some Member States. Secondly, the thin end of the wedge, when the EU uses rational bureaucratic need to justify job creation and data recording to build what amounts to a major new edifice in the centralised EU governmental empire, with powers to match. Quite simply, the cats and dogs and goldfish and stick insects may need tracking but, if they do, it should be a role for national governments. They should not become an issue for Eurocrats, and that is what you will make them.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, millions of citizens are involved in pet farming throughout the European Union, and although we are addressing important security issues related to migration and war conflicts here in plenary, I am convinced that this issue, ie. conditions for the breeding of domestic animals across the European Union, has its place in the European Parliament and I thank my colleague Sommer for advocating the adoption of this topic for today's negotiations. The Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council of 2003 on the movement of pet animals specifies several requirements that each breeder must meet in order for his animal to be able to move across the European Union, ie. the animal must have a tattoo or be pinned, so it must be identified and must have a passport and a vaccination certificate. I believe that if the individual registration systems for pets in the various Member States were to be unified, it would help and make the current practice much more effective than if each Member State had its own system. It has already been mentioned here that these systems need to be compatible in order for this data to be interoperable. I am convinced that there is no need to build a new building and a new office, it is just a matter of interconnecting these systems. And for this connection to occur, there must be some standardization of the data that is delivered there. In this context, I would like to ask the Commission whether it therefore envisages widespread labeling and registration of domestic animals in the European Union or envisages the introduction of compatible systems that will only apply to the cross-border movement of animals, as is the case with the 2003 regulation.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, revision of the pet travel scheme has, regrettably, not made the system more effective, due to frequent abuses. The introduction of a compatible system for the registration of pet animals across Member States would make cross-border supervision of the animal trade, travel or pet vaccination much easier. As a result, these long-overdue changes, ideally combined with appropriate data exchange, would contribute to dealing with various disease outbreak threats, amongst other things. Many people have to leave behind, sell, cast out or even euthanise their pets simply due to being unable to take them along with them when going abroad, precisely due to pet registration system differences in our countries, and for no other reason. I have to say that the cause of mutual integration within the EU has contributed to the gradual alignment of an identity documentation system for its inhabitants – passports, IDs, diplomas and the like. The same should undoubtedly apply to our pet animals.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: - Madam President, Commissioner! Let me start with three short stories. First, the story of the little cat who ran away in the thick of Berlin's metropolitan areas and is searched for with notes on the street lamps. Second, the story of the faithful dog who was abandoned on a vacation trip at an Italian rest stop and found completely disturbed next to the motorway. Thirdly, the story of the little puppy who is illegally kidnapped from Romania and freed from a truck near Nuremberg just before dying of thirst. A cross-border, EU-wide registration system could help in all three stories, as I suggested over a year ago for precisely that reason. We are a European Parliament. It's our job to think globally. Then we can do it with the European dramas. Why don't we take the registration systems from 28 countries - where they exist -, compare them, take out the best parts and turn them into a functioning registration system that is completely European-neutral? Let's start with making this functioning system compatible across the EU, as is now the case in Austria. Let us orient ourselves on the database experience with farm animals, and let us agree on the framework within which we can establish European coordination while respecting subsidiarity. In short: let's do what we can to protect our pets as best as possible!

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: - We keep millions of animals in Europe, especially dogs and cats, but more than a thousand other often exotic animal species are sold as pets. That is very lucrative. Billions are made from the rogue animal trade. That also causes indescribable suffering. Pets are often bought on a whim and thrown away with the same ease. Every day in Europe many animals are neglected, abused, abused, dumped and killed. Pets are not toys! They are living beings with consciousness and feeling and they deserve our protection. You will be just a newborn puppy being dragged across Europe in the trunk of a car to be sold in Belgium. You will be a labrador roaming the streets of Romania, a land where animals are gruesomely persecuted and killed because every animal killed brings in money. You will be just a turtle and spend your whole life in a shoebox! Or you will be a galgo kept for hunting in Spain, used, tormented, tortured and if you are not fast enough, killed! Madam President, you will only be an animal in Europe. And you, the European Commission, can ensure that animals are helped. First of all, through mandatory identification and a European registration system for pets, for all pets. And linked to this a licensing system for breeders and sellers, with of course the associated animal welfare requirements. A second point, which is easy to enter, is a positive list for pets, as has been done in Belgium and the Netherlands, so that only animals can be kept that are also suitable for this purpose. And when will the Commission publish the promised study on the welfare of dogs and cats in the European pet trade? Still, would like a response. The sooner the Commission takes action, the sooner the miserable existence of many pets will come to an end. I also believe that European agricultural subsidies should be abolished.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: - Mr President, our humanity is measured by how we treat animals. As we have heard here on several occasions, the growing puppy factory and also the large-scale import of unsuitable species for pet use is aggravated animal abuse, and a very aggravated crime and money laundering practice. The existing solution is both administratively easy and cost-effective. Already today, most kennels and cat breeders' associations and other responsible companion animal registers have their own registers, which could be brought together into a European database based on an existing model, from which the animal's origin and pedigree can be traced, for example to prevent breeding. In this same context, it is also possible to determine which species are suitable for pet use through the so-called positive list of companion animals. The Commission has been dragging its feet on this for quite some time. In a number of informal contexts, most Commissioners have already promised this positive list and pet register over the last four years. I hope that, on the basis of this debate, we will have a clear reaction and also a clear promise from the Commission to create this register, because it is not a question of costs, it is not a question of over-regulation, it is simply a question of how we take responsibility for animals.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, I have to recognise that I am not a specialist on this subject. Because there were not many volunteers, I accepted to speak because my younger daughter is taking care of two cats and one dog, of course altogether with the whole family, and we love them very much. First of all I would to say to our colleagues, Ms Zimmer, Mr Gericke and Ms Hazekamp, that progress has been made recently in Romania. You should look at recent data regarding the protection of animals. At the same time, the response has to be a European Union one, a standardised EU system to protect pets. I support the introduction of a new passport model which stipulates that cats, dogs and ferrets can travel with their owners within the European Union if they have a passport that contains proof of their identity and their anti-rabies vaccination, all of which must comply with specific conditions. EU countries must provide the public with clear and easily-accessible information concerning the requirements applicable to the non—commercial movement of pets and the rules for compliance checks on such movement. I support the call for an EU—wide database for pet registration and I welcome the fact that the Commission has agreed to carry out a study on the welfare of dogs and cats involved in commercial practices.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, I am very pleased that we are discussing this topic here today, and I feel that it may make a lot more sense from the citizens' point of view and perhaps much more interested citizens than other topics that the European Parliament is discussing at a better time. Here, Commissioner, I wanted to appeal here to you, as the representative of the Commission, not to really underestimate this issue. I come from the Czech Republic, where there is an extremely strong public debate today about how to ban the so-called dog breeding, in which bitches are more or less forced to "produce" new and new puppies, and these puppies are then illegally sold in Western European countries. This means that ethical standards do not apply, laws do not apply, puppies are exported to Western Europe and therefore it is a problem of the whole European Union. It is not just a problem of the Czech Republic, but where cross-border trade is, moreover, illegal and unethical, there must, in my opinion, be intervened by the European Union. If you intervene, I am convinced that even for many Czechs who today view the European Union negatively or look at it as a body that is addressing their interests somewhere in Brussels, you will do something positive, you will do something for their animals. So I support us to enforce national registries, to keep those national registries interconnected and to clearly regulate and have clear rules for cross-border trade in dogs and cats. This is very important if we are to reduce this unethical, illegal behavior.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Madam President, for many people, one dog, one cat means everything.We often get a chance to read a series of touching stories about these little pets that have often made many, many people happy.That is why such people deserve and ask us to adopt appropriate regulations, to harmonize regulations at the level of the European Union, to create the compatibility of these regulations, because in that way we will show our humanity.What I want to further emphasize is the problem, in many countries, of animal shelters.We have to find ways to help such asylums because they are often in a subordinate position.That is why I call on you, as Commissioner in the European Commission, to consider how you can create both compatibility and standards when it comes to animal shelters.

name: Róża THUN UND HOHENSTEIN
text: - When we talk about domestic animals, dogs and cats, as you can see, ladies and gentlemen, it arouses great emotions almost everywhere - both in our Member States and here in this Chamber. Of course, I would like the subject that you mentioned so often: the suffering of animals and the unworthy conditions in which we keep them, to be extended to farm animals one day. We think about it much less often and it arouses less emotions and more interest in what money we earn from them. And, of course, the responsibility for how animals are registered lies with the Member States to punish crime, but we need a common system, as in many other areas, and we also need harmonization. And I would like to appeal to the Commissioner to use non-governmental organizations which in many of our countries have excellent insight into this subject, many good ideas that cooperate at the European level with each other and which for the European Commission would certainly be an excellent partner in solving this problem .

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there is a huge difference in the fate of our pets, between those who have a fortunate life in the heat of our homes and those who are seen as merely a commercial object to be sold with the greatest possible profit. Providing a European system that harmonizes the systems and standards envisaged for the identification and registration of dogs and cats, thus easily accessible from all Member States, could certainly be an excellent tool for combating illicit trade. In this way, a new form of cooperation between the States in the field of animal welfare could be established, thus allowing in the future to be able to improve and expand the legislation in this regard. Animal welfare is at the base, as we have said, there is the fight against illicit trafficking, as we have said, there are health issues to avoid the spread of diseases, but there is also the citizen's right to be informed and protected and to be able to find his friend dog or cat if he happens to lose him.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, it has been a very interesting debate and I would like to thank all Members for their contributions. Once again on behalf of the Commission I would like to thank Ms Renate Sommer for raising the issue of the possible introduction of compatible systems for registration of dogs and cats to be accessible across the Member States. Although it has been a long road leading to the recently-agreed Regulation on Transmissible Animal Diseases, I am certain this contains all the elements to further develop the delegated and implementing acts necessary to bring this legislation to life, and this includes the topic of registration of dogs and cats. However, it is important first to verify whether the development of such delegated acts would bring EU added value with regard to action by the Member States, and in particular to weigh the administrative burden on the Member States against the anticipated benefits of any envisaged measures. Anyhow I would like to inform you that the Commission intends to start the preparatory work for the adoption of these possible delegated acts, including expert consultations, when the proposed Regulation on Transmissible Animal Diseases is formally adopted by the co-legislators, most probably in the coming weeks. You know very well that this is not directly my portfolio, but I was very moved by the stories I heard here and you can be sure that I will ask Commissioner Andriukaitis who is in charge of this file and I will pass on all your words. I would just like to say that I am very much aware of the intense debate in the country I know best about the treatment of animals, including animals without owners. It is a problem and it is the responsibility of each Member State. Unfortunately, I think that under the Treaties there are not many things that the Commission can do regarding that, but anyhow I can assure you that the Commission is very much aware of the necessity of the controls. As I said at the beginning, the subject was very clear about the registration of pet animals across Member States, and I am sure that Commissioner Andriukaitis will come up with further details on how this could be done.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing. - This forthcoming text is part of the review of the rules for the travel program for pets (Regulation (EU) No 576/2013). This revision should clarify what constitutes a commercial movement, allow additional security features on pet passports, introduce a new minimum age for rabies vaccines and put in place new rules for those who travel with more than five pets. The Commission's commitment to carry out a study on the welfare of dogs and cats in commercial practices is a step in the right direction. The question will be whether we are going to introduce a delegated act concerning a dog and cat registration system compatible and accessible in all states. Even if this seems to go in the direction of animal welfare, I would remain vigilant on the harmonization of policies.This is why I would follow this file closely because the harmonization of standards would also allow a reduction in cruelties in animal farms. puppies and health risks for humans.

name: Emil RADEV
text: In written form. - There is currently no common European legislation defining a uniform system for the identification and registration of domestic animals such as dogs and cats, and each country determines the ways and means to do so. The individual national systems where they exist are also not linked, leading to a fragmented environment with incomplete or completely missing information on the status of the animals. In the presence of a common market for goods and services, free movement of people and labor mobility, the existence of a pan-European registration system is essential. It would save a lot of time and money, limit the bureaucracy of moving an animal to another country and last but not least - it would give owners much more certainty about the origin of their pets. Not to mention, of course, the benefits of disease control and the spread of infections among animals and humans, as well as the reduction of trafficking and abuse in the sale of dogs and cats. Having a unified identification and registration system would also encourage responsible animal husbandry, as disposing of them on the street will no longer be so easy and owners will be able to be quickly detected and sanctioned, which in turn will reduce the population of stray dogs and cats.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: I declare adjourned the session of the European Parliament.(The sitting was closed at 4.45 pm)
